TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 26 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 41 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Force, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Threatened Species
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worst extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Standard of Language: TV Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:
That your petitioners deplore the capricious use of swearing on television.
Furthermore your petitioners humbly submit:
That the time slot and the content of the advertisement for the program called "Chances", along with the program itself,, present a threat to parental authority in the home.

Your petitioners therefore call on the Government to demonstrate support for high moral standards in this country by immediately undertaking an inquiry into the standard of language prevailing in TV programs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Reynolds)—by leave—agreed to:

That the time for the presentation of the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies be extended to 25 June 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies on telephone message services.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the Committee's second and final report on telephone recorded message services. It is a follow-up report to the interim report I tabled on 12 December 1991. Since then the Committee has taken more evidence and, in particular, held hearings on 30 April and 6 May 1992 at which AOTC-Telecom and the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) were questioned on progress towards implementing the recommendations made by the Committee in its interim report.

PARA.TAB: The Committee was established on 21 June as a result of concerns expressed by a number of honourable senators about the absence from the Telecommunications Bill 1991, agreed to by the Senate on 17 June 1991, of any provision to regulate the content of telecommunications services. Furthermore, there was considerable disquiet in the community about the content of material carried on Telecom's 0055 service, particularly as to the suitability of the material being available in the family home where it could be accessed by children.

The Committee was pleased that AOTC, the Government and the telephone recorded message service industry generally had responded, mainly positively, to the recommendations of the December 1991 interim report. We anticipate that negotiations between AOTC and OFLC will soon result in a contract under which the Office of Film and Literature Classification will act as the monitoring and enforcement body for content and advertising standards for the telephone message service industry. This is the key element in the set of measures recommended in the December 1991 report. The new OFLC arbitration mechanism needs to be put in place to give the standards recommended by the Committee detailed meaning and effect when it comes to interpreting them in individual cases.

The Committee is also gratified by the positive response from the industry. The industry has taken action to remove from 0055 lines as from 12 May 1992 all so-called `adult' and other services provided by its members which did not meet the Committee's standards, which were the original standards of Telecom. The industry also responded promptly and positively to the issue that arose in recent weeks in regard to television advertising of children's competitions available on 0055 services. Cases have been alleged of children being lured by television advertisements into running up large telephone bills by engaging in 0055 competitions.

Fortunately, the industry, including the Australian Association of National Advertisers and other relevant organisations, took prompt action in response to community concern in drawing up advertising guidelines for such advertisements which were more stringent and more appropriate to children. The Committee anticipates that the action being taken by the industry on this issue, together with the Committee's own recommendations relating to disputed bills for telephone message services, will prevent abuses occurring in the advertising of 0055 children's competitions.

The recommendations in the report I am tabling today are intended to expedite the process of putting in place an appropriate regulatory framework for the telephone recorded message service industry. They cover:

SPEECH.PARA: codes of conduct for the message standards and the advertising standards for both the 0055 open access recorded message service and the 0051 closed access service;
a new arbitration mechanism consisting of the Office of Film and Literature Classification acting as the monitoring and enforcement body for content standards and advertising standards;
remedies for breaches of content standards;
AUSTEL's role in applying the Committee's recommendations to all telecommunications carriers;
consumer protection in the areas of:

PARA.TAB: providing basic information on recorded message services;
providing call barring facilities;
guaranteeing that the basic telephone service not be terminated because of disputes over recorded message service bills; and
establishing a system of independent mediation for disputes over recorded message service bills.

The Committee has reaffirmed the recommendations it made in its interim report, which called on Telecom to adopt a code of conduct which would completely eliminate the carriage of unacceptable sexual material on 0055 where it is accessible by minors. The industry would then be allowed to cater for this market only through its 0051 closed user access service, restricted to adults who must opt into the system using a personal identification number, but only for material of an equivalence no higher than the M film-video rating.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 gives effect to proposed changes in the areas of telephone concessions, Job Search Allowance and Newstart Allowance, social security agreements with other countries, debt recovery, the income and assets test, compensation payments and data-matching. The Bill also provides for a number of minor and technical amendments.

In the 1991 Budget the Government announced that from 1 July 1992 a new payment, known as telephone allowance, would replace the telephone rental concession voucher scheme. The new allowance will be more "user friendly" in that under the old concession scheme vouchers were sometimes misplaced or lost and pensioners were put to the inconvenience of obtaining replacements. It will also be much simpler to administer. The telephone allowance will be a payment of $51.80 per household each year. A lower rate of $25.90 per year will be paid where the person commenced to receive pension or benefit after 12 March 1992 and the person's partner is not getting a social security payment. It will be paid in quarterly instalments to pensioners who are permanently blind or who satisfy fringe benefit means tests and who are telephone subscribers. It will also be payable to certain social security beneficiaries aged 60 or over who are telephone subscribers and to certain other recipients of Commonwealth fringe benefits. The allowance will be indexed annually in line with CPI increases.

Last year the Government introduced a series of measures directed at young people under 18 years of age. One measure extended qualification for Job Search Allowance and Sickness Allowance to 15 year olds who meet the requirements for those allowances (apart from age), who are above the minimum school leaving age or have a formal exemption from attending school, who have an employment history and who are not living with or being supported by a parent. This Bill will provide that 15 year old Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance recipients who are in substitute care, often referred to as foster care, will also be paid the higher "independent" rate of allowance. This measure will align the rate of Job Search Allowance and Sickness Allowance for 15 year olds with the rate for 16 to 17 year olds in substitute care. It will further improve the overall level of income support to families who do not receive a substitute care allowance from a State or Territory authority and will encourage the substitute care of young people who may otherwise be at risk of homelessness.

The Bill will assist sole parents receiving Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance or Sickness Allowance whose only child is under 16 years and in employment. From the day of Royal Assent, the allowance will be paid at the higher maximum basic rate that is currently payable to a sole parent pensioner. This will ensure equitable treatment for pensioners and beneficiaries in similar circumstances. The allowee's child, despite being employed, will be taken to be dependent for the purposes of working out the allowee's maximum basic rate.

The Bill will remove an unintended restriction in the Social Security Act which prevents a recipient of Job Search Allowance (who is 18 or over) or Newstart Allowance who is incapacitated for work for a period which is expected to be longer than 6 weeks (in the case of Job Search Allowance) or 13 weeks (in the case of Newstart allowance) from being qualified for Sickness Allowance for 6 or 13 weeks. The Bill will enable the recipient to transfer to Sickness Allowance once the person is no longer qualified for Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance, subject to the recipient satisfying the usual qualification conditions for Sickness Allowance.

The Government will continue to target the provision of social security to those in need of assistance. To this end, the qualification conditions for Job Search Allowance and Newstart Allowance will be amended so that a person who is the subject of an assurance of support (assuree) will not be qualified for Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance if the Secretary is satisfied that the assuror is willing to provide the person with an adequate level of support and it is reasonable to expect the person to accept that support. As a consequence of this measure, an assuror who is willing and able to comply with his or her obligations under an assurance of support will not incur a debt to the Commonwealth. It is inappropriate for assurees who enter Australia on the understanding that they will be supported by an assuror to refuse (without good reason) to accept support which the assuror is willing and able to provide. Conversely, the interests of assurees will be protected by not requiring the assuree to accept such support in all cases, for example, where the assuree is subjected to abuse.

Austria is set to become the latest partner in the network of social security agreements between Australia and other foreign countries. The Bill will provide for implementation of the agreement with Austria once it has been signed.
The Bill contains a measure which will facilitate the Department's capacity and responsibility to recover social security debts.

The Act will be amended to provide that if a person owes to the Commonwealth an amount which is recoverable under the Act, the Secretary may recover the amount by making deductions from instalments of pension, benefit or allowance payable to another person. The consent of the latter person would be necessary. It will usually be the debtor's partner or relation who will agree to the deductions being made.
The Director of Public Prosecutions has commented critically on provisions in the Social Security Act which have created difficulties in prosecuting social security fraud.

This Bill will remove these obstacles by repealing the provisions that prevent a social security recipient from relying on the privilege against self-incrimination when requested under the Act to provide information. The provisions that limit the use of information obtained from social security recipients pursuant to the information gathering powers under the Act will also be repealed. From the day of Royal Assent, pensioners, beneficiaries and allowees will have the same right as other citizens not to provide information that may tend to incriminate them in an offence.
The Bill will make a number of changes to the rules for the ordinary income test and the assets test.

For some time now, people who are "asset rich but income poor" have sought to provide for themselves by accessing the equity in their principal home through a variety of sale/leaseback schemes. At present under the Act a person who enters into such a scheme is treated as a non-homeowner and is allowed the higher non-homeowner asset limit under the assets test for pensions, benefits and allowances. In some cases a social security recipient would be better off if he or she was treated as a homeowner (even though homeowners are subject to a lower asset limit) because any amount outstanding under the contract of sale would be disregarded under the assets test.

The Bill will align the treatment of sale/leaseback schemes with the treatment of retirement village residences and granny flat living arrangements. As a consequence, a person entering into a sale/leaseback agreement will be given the most advantageous result, whether as a homeowner or a non-homeowner.

The Mark Fitzpatrick Trust was established by the Government in 1989 to provide special financial assistance to people with medically acquired HIV infection and AIDS, their dependants and carers. In keeping with the Government's intention in setting up the Trust, the Bill will provide that payments made from the Trust will not be counted as ordinary income for the purposes of working out a person's rate of pension, benefit or allowance.

On 2 December 1991 my predecessor as Minister for Social Security announced a special measure to assist the restructure of unlisted property trusts in the wake of the downturn in sectors of the property market. The Bill will give effect to this by providing that if a social security recipient with an investment in an unlisted property trust realises that investment and is paid out with investments (units) in another trust, any capital growth at the date of realisation will not be counted as ordinary income. However, the units in the other trust will be taken to be a new investment and will be subject to ongoing assessment. Only those investments in unlisted property trusts made or acquired before 9 September 1988 will be affected by this measure. It will apply only to investments in trusts that are realised and paid out with units in other trusts before 23 July 1992.

The Bill will make two changes which will assist a person whose partner has died. It will enable certain wife pensioners and carer pensioners who care for their partners to be transferred automatically to sole parent pension after the deaths of their partners without having to lodge a claim for that pension. This will prevent unnecessary intrusion into the person's grief and ensure that there is no break in continuity in the provision of income support where it is apparent that the person would be qualified for sole parent pension after the 14 week bereavement payment period.

Generally, a claimant for Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance or Sickness Allowance must serve a waiting period before receiving payment. The Bill will provide that a person whose partner has died and was receiving Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance or Sickness Allowance (at a rate which included an additional amount for a partner) will not have to serve the waiting period if he or she lodges a claim for one of the allowances within 4 weeks after his or her partner's death.

The Bill will make a number of minor changes in the area of compensation recovery, such as stipulating that a payment of arrears of periodic compensation is not a lump sum compensation payment and protecting insurers and compensation payers from legal action where they are prevented from releasing moneys after being served with a notice under the Act.

Finally, a number of amendments will be made to the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 (the Data-Matching Act) and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These amendments relate to the matching of personal information and the use of tax file numbers. Most importantly the Bill makes explicit that data-matching results can be used to increase the assistance a person receives from the Commonwealth. Up to now the legislative emphasis in that program has been on use of results to reduce assistance. Implementation of the Data-Matching Act has also demonstrated the need for minor amendments. As well, the Bill will give effect to recommendations made in a report tabled in Parliament in December 1990 by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled "The Proposed Tax File Number Provisions and Data-Matching Program".
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY (FAMILY PAYMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill 1992 gives effect to the Government's commitment to integrate family payments for children. The integration of family allowance supplement and additional pension and benefit will result in a program of nearly two billion dollars which will assist about 800,000 families or nearly one and a half million children.

SPEECH.PARA: As well, family allowance and family allowance supplement will be amalgamated into a single payment with entitlement calculated under a two-step income and assets test.

Under current arrangements, family allowance is payable to a one-child family with a combined income of $64,167 per annum and full rate family allowance supplement is payable where combined income is $20,700 or less. Both are subject to an assets test based on net market value; $359,250 for family allowance supplement and $600,000 for family allowance with special provisions available for families with high net assets in hardship.
The total number of families assisted under the whole family payment program will be in the vicinity of 1.9 million, or nearly 4 million children.

The new payment will be payable at two levels: a basic rate equivalent to the current family allowance and a higher rate, called "additional family payment" in the Bill, equivalent to the current rates of family allowance supplement and additional pension and benefit, as well as rent assistance and guardian allowance if payable. The new payment and arrangements will commence from 1 January next year.

At present, paydays for family payments and payments for children in the pensions and benefits systems fall on different days in a fortnight. To ensure that the transition to the new family payment paydays does not result in loss, everyone who might otherwise miss out on payment for some days in the cross-over period, or as a result of the cross-over, will receive a one-off payment.

The new family payment is a major reform which derives from the Social Security Review. It will reduce poverty traps, improve work incentives for low income families, increase the take-up rate of the family payment for low income families with children and help families to budget better. I will deal with each of those improvements in turn.

Poverty traps occur where recipients of income support perceive that they have little financial incentive for increasing income from earnings. In a period when unemployment is higher than we would all like, it is critically important to do everything we can to encourage work force participation.

Currently, pensioners and beneficiaries may compare their financial situation while receiving social security with employment at a relatively low wage or salary and, because they are unaware of their likely qualification for family allowance supplement to top up their earnings, think that they will be no better off if they take work.

The measures in this Bill will make the choices between Government assistance and work much clearer and will signal to pensioners and beneficiaries that assistance for their families will, in all likelihood, continue if they take a job with a low to moderate wage.

When a person leaves income support he or she, if income support was received for 12 months or more, will automatically be sent a family payment claim form and will be given six weeks within which to claim the payment. Shorter term recipients will also be told how to get extra payments. This will give people every opportunity to test themselves for eligibility for the additional family payment. If they lodge their claim within the 6 weeks, full arrears of additional family payment will be made back to the time they ceased their pension, benefit or allowance.

One major effect of these reforms is that the new family payment will direct a greater proportion of the family's social security support to the person responsible for the day to day care of children, usually the mother. For example, in a family with 2 children under 13 where the father receives job search allowance, under the new family payment arrangements the mother will receive $163 a fortnight instead of the $41.40 she currently receives.

Family allowance supplement payments are now directed to the mother in most cases, as are the payments of additional pension for children of pensioner couples. The changes in this Bill will apply the same principle to child-related payments for families receiving job search allowance or other income support payments. Directing payments for children to the primary care giver is consistent with the Government's Social Justice Strategy and the National Agenda for Women.

The family payment will be paid on what are currently family allowance paydays. These fortnightly paydays fall on the alternative Thursday to pension paydays. Spreading pensioner's payments more evenly through a fortnight will assist family budgeting.

To give another example, a sole parent pensioner with 2 children under 13 currently receives $461.60 each fortnight on the Thursday pension payday and $41.40 in family allowance in the following week giving total assistance of $503 per fortnight.

Under the new payment structure, after 1 January 1993, a sole parent in the same situation will receive $311.30 in the pension week and $191.70 in the following family payment week, again, with a total of $503 per fortnight.
Rent assistance will also be included in the family payment for those families with children, eligible for additional family payment, who pay private rent.
I must stress that total financial support provided to the family from social security will not be reduced under the changes to payment arrangements.

At present sole parents who receive family allowance supplement do not receive guardian allowance, whereas sole parent pensioners do. Under the new family payment this anomaly will be addressed and all sole parents who qualify for additional family payment will receive the guardian allowance. At the moment, guardian allowance is $746.20 a year (or $28.70 a fortnight). Paying guardian allowance to eligible working sole parents will deal with a potential poverty trap for this group.

Maintenance income is currently taken into account in determining the rate of pension or benefit. Under the new arrangements, maintenance payments will only be taken into account in determining the rate of the additional family payment. If the level of maintenance is such that no additional family payment is payable, the excess maintenance will not then be counted to reduce pension or benefit entitlements nor the basic family payment.

Family allowance supplement recipients are currently not subject to the maintenance income test. However, from 1 January 1993 all persons qualified for additional family payment will have maintenance taken into account.

Although this means that some recipients will receive a lower rate of additional family payment, it will result in a more consistent treatment of people in receipt of maintenance. As I mentioned earlier, guardian allowance will be paid to all sole parent additional family payment recipients, and the additional $746.20 a year will largely offset the impact of the maintenance income test for a substantial group.

As part of the package included in this Bill it has been decided to continue the family payment until a student leaves secondary school or until the end of the year in which he or she turns 18, whichever is the earlier.

This measure encourages families to allow their children to complete education and overcomes an existing anomaly whereby some families receive family allowance for children aged under 18 throughout year 12 while others with children who turn 18 at some time during the year cease eligibility at that time. As at present, students aged 16 years or more will not attract the payment if they are eligible for AUSTUDY.

To improve take up of the new family payment, tax file number data-matching will be used to detect clients who may be eligible for, but are not receiving, additional family payments. FAS is currently assisting over 200,000 families, and it is estimated that a substantial number of additional families will be identified as having an entitlement to an additional family payment. I remind senators that such payments are free of income tax.

The increase in the FAS threshold from April 1992 together with the introduction of the new single two-step program is estimated to lead to an additional 90,000 families receiving additional family payments.

The changes being introduced in this Bill require major changes to the ADP systems used by the Department of Social Security. Such major reforms are feasible only because the Social Security computer system is as advanced as any in the world. The changes will also require extensive training of staff and publicity and information material for Australian families.

I mentioned the assets test earlier. Senators will recall that, from the beginning of 1992, this Government introduced a hardship test as part of each assets test applicable to family allowance and family allowance supplement.

In the prevailing economic circumstances, especially the rural downturn, there are concerns about the welfare of children in families with assets above the family allowance supplement assets test threshold, but where those assets are returning very low incomes. Senators will be pleased that the new family payment system preserves the hardship tests for both the basic and additional family payments to protect the families concerned.

The Bill I am presenting to the Senate today is not the end of improvements to this Government's policies to provide assistance for families. It is the end of a rationalisation process that has taken a great deal of work to formulate and put into practice. Our commitment to Australian families is undiminished and this Bill is another clear signal to the families of Australia that their interests will be both protected and, where possible, enhanced by this Government. Above all this Bill brings about a level of consistency in the administration of family payments hitherto absent from the system. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes amendments to Veterans' Affairs and associated legislation. It gives effect to a number of important changes to benefits for veterans' and their dependants. The Bill also contains a number of minor policy measures as well as some necessary drafting and technical changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Among the most important measures contained in this Bill are:
the extension of benefits to members of the Australian Defence Forces serving in Cambodia;
the replacement of the existing voucher system for telephone rental concessions with an annual telephone allowance; and
changes to the assessment rules for unlisted property trust investments.
This last amendment arises from similar changes to Social Security legislation.

The extension of benefits in respect of service in Cambodia follows the Government's decision of 9 October 1991 to deploy Australian Defence Force personnel for service in Cambodia as part of the United Nations peacekeeping efforts.

The Bill will designate Cambodia as an operational area from 20 October 1991. This is the date, confirmed by the Department of Defence, on which Australian Defence Force personnel were deployed for service in the area. It will remain an "operational area" until the United Nations ceasefire takes effect, and related demobilisation and cantonment measures are in place. After that time, service in Cambodia will be designated as "peacekeeping service".

Both periods of service provide entitlement to compensation in respect of incapacity or death based on the more generous standard of proof. The Bill will also extend eligibility for service pension for the period Cambodia is designated an "operational area".

A further amendment to the legislation will be necessary to close off the period of operational service in Cambodia. Administrative arrangements will also need to be made to provide eligibility for benefits in respect of peacekeeping service in the area. These changes will take place after the United Nations ceasefire.

In case there are any concerns, in the light of reports that the Department of Defence may call on some Army Reservists to serve in Cambodia, I specifically make the point that this bill ensures they will be entitled to the same benefits as those available to full time members of the Regular Defence Forces.

In line with the Government's announcement in the 1991 Budget, this Bill will provide for the existing telephone rental voucher system to be replaced with a telephone allowance. This change will be effective from 1 July 1992.

The Bill will also provide for the payment of a special telephone allowance for World War I veterans and mariners. This allowance will equal the annual telephone rental charge for a single telephone service, paid in four instalments.

Changes to the rules for assessing income in respect of certain investments in unlisted property trusts are also proposed in this Bill. The proposed amendments give effect to the Government's decision of 25 November 1991. A more generous income assessment will apply as a part of the restructuring of the unlisted property trust investment industry. These amendments also reflect similar changes made to the Social Security Act earlier in these sittings.
Other amendments proposed by this Bill reflect either:
minor changes and improvements in benefits available to Veterans and their dependants; or
streamlining of administrative provisions to provide for a more efficient and effective delivery of benefits for veterans.

The Bill proposes a number of amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act and the Defence Service Homes Act which fit within this category. In relation to Defence Service Homes, the Bill will provide that certain persons, who revoked their entitlement to benefits under the Defence Service Homes Act in favour of benefits under the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act, will be able to withdraw their revocation and regain entitlement under the Defence Service Homes Act.
Other proposed changes to the Defence Service Homes Act are:

provision for all financial transactions in relation to the Defence Service Homes Insurance activities under the Act, or in respect of insurance as an agent for an insurer, to be conducted under the Defence Service Homes Insurance Trust Account;

provision to enable the Commonwealth and Westpac to agree to waive the first mortgage requirement on advances, in certain circumstances. This will enable persons to take advantage of State housing assistance;

provision for certain persons who were discharged on medical grounds, or who die, prior to completing the minimum six year period of service. This change will ensure that such persons, or their dependants, can establish their full entitlements under the Act; and

clarification of the "portability" provisions. This change follows my announcement on 22 August last year that two or more persons, both of whom are eligible for assistance under the Defence Service Homes Act, may "pool" their entitlements on the same property.

One other significant change is the proposed amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements and Seamen's War Pensions And Allowances Acts to allow for the automatic grant of war widows or widowers pension and payment of funeral benefits in certain circumstances. This change will streamline current administrative arrangements and result in improved service delivery.

Changes of an administrative nature are also proposed in respect of the dismissal of applications to the Veterans' Review Board. The changes are designed to clarify current provisions for dismissal of an application for review where the matter has not been finalised within two years.

The remaining measures in the Bill relate to changes which flow from amendments to the Social Security Act. This will ensure consistency in the application and administration of the income and assets tests.
Finally, the Bill contains a range of minor technical and drafting amendments.

All the measures contained in this Bill have minimal financial impact with the exception of the provisions relating to the telephone allowance. The estimated program costs for telephone allowance are $12.060m in 1992-93, $11.307m in 1993-94 and $11.401m in 1994-95.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: DAIRY PRODUCE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill and the accompanying levy Bill, will set the framework for the Commonwealth's dairy marketing arrangements until the year 2000 and will have a substantial influence on the future direction of the Australian dairy industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to set the rate of assistance for manufactured dairy exports each year up until 30 June 2000, to provide for the termination of Commonwealth underwriting for dairy exports from 30 June 1992 and to provide more flexibility in the way promotion and other industry funds can be expended.

Mr President, the Australian dairy industry is one of our great traditional primary industries. Over the years it has experienced good times and there have been bad times. The past few years in particular have been difficult, especially for the export sector, but as always the industry has shown great resilience and is adjusting well to meet the new marketing challenges. The package of measures that I will outline today will better equip the industry to handle those challenges. It is the Government's response to the Industry Commission's September 1991 Report on the Australian Dairy Industry.

The details of the announcements go to both assistance and market development. It is proposed that there be a moratorium for a further 12 months on any reduction in market support. This is particularly to assist the situation in Victoria and Tasmania, where farmers have been hard hit. There will be a phase-down in market support to the year 2000 in equal instalments, taking the market support equivalent protection from 22 per cent above export parity to 10 per cent above export parity. I should point out that this 10 per cent above export parity is the equivalent of and is consistent with the tariff target of 5 per cent for manufacturing industry. Importantly, it is a figure that has been achieved with the agreement of the industry. It is not a figure that was advocated by the IC, which the Opposition was locked into. Underwriting has been abolished, but the cheese tariff quota remains. The `comfort clause' has been abolished and there will be a further review and reorientation of structures to give this industry a more effective market development orientation.

First, let us have a closer look at the dairy industry. There are just under 15,000 registered dairy farms in Australia producing about 6,400 million litres of milk per annum worth about $1.7 billion. The industry is labour-intensive, directly employing some 50,000 people and indirectly employing a further 50,000.

Victoria is the key dairy State producing about 60 per cent of national milk output. The wholesale value of processed dairy foods is around $4.5 billion—manufacturers and processors add nearly $3 billion of extra value. Around 30 per cent of milk production is exported as dairy products worth around $700m. East Asia accounts for 67 per cent of Australia's dairy exports. Japan is the largest market, closely followed by the Philippines. Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand sales opportunities are increasing as a result of continuing income growth in South East Asia.

In 1986, my colleague the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon John Kerin, introduced what became known in the industry as the `Kerin Plan'. The aim was to wean the industry from its reliance on Government assistance and to make it more commercially based and more responsive to market opportunities. There would be few in the industry who would disagree that the `Kerin Plan' has been a great success. The industry is now neither backward nor stagnant. It is adopting state of the art technology and adjustment has been taking place on a continuing basis. Farmers have, for example, been leaving the industry at a rate of 3 per cent per year. Nevertheless, national production has tended to increase slightly. There has been continuous amalgamation of and investment in manufacturing facilities and a shift in emphasis from commodities to the marketing of profitable value added products. Nominal assistance to the export sector has reduced from around 45 per cent in 1986 to the current 22 per cent.

The `Kerin Plan' assistance terminates on 30 June this year and the challenge has been to develop a new set of arrangements that would be consistent with the Government's broader industry objectives, maintained the momentum created under the current arrangements and yet recognised that the industry is currently feeling the effects of low world prices.

Mr President, the package I will now detail will achieve all of these objectives. It is the outcome of productive consultations with the industry's leadership and it has a large measure of support within the industry. In its development the Government sought a strategy that capitalises on the technical and marketing achievements resulting from the six years of the Kerin Plan and provides the framework that will enable a more productive, internationally competitive and export focused sector to develop. The process of interaction with industry has enabled the laying of a sound foundation for the industry's position up to and beyond the turn of the century.

Let me say that the important thing about this outcome is that it reflects the active consultation with the industry. That is the important difference between our approach and the Opposition's in terms of addressing industry development.

Praise should be given to the industry which negotiated this package of reforms. The Australian Dairy Industry Council represents both producers as well as processors and therefore is an important body because it involves more than just the grower end of the market. It had to negotiate this in difficult circumstances. Not only did the Council have an IC report which it could not live with—members of the coalition could because they were committed to introducing it—but also it had to cope with the disciplines associated with our position in the GATT and a constituency that was arguing for the retention of the status quo. But against that background, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy challenged it to produce a forward looking strategy that would secure the industry and make it grow. The Council responded in positive negotiations.
Assistance Program

Assistance to the export sector will remain at the 1991-92 level of 22 per cent of average export prices throughout 1992-93. This is in recognition of the difficult circumstances currently facing many dairy farmers and will provide some time for the industry to re-group. Thereafter, the rate of assistance will be reduced in equal annual steps to 10 per cent in 1999-2000. This 10 per cent market support rate is consistent with the 5 per cent tariff target for manufacturing industry because of the manner in which dairy market support applies and reasonably reflects the Government's industry objectives as announced in recent policy statements. The new arrangements will `sunset' on 30 June 2000. The industry's leadership accepts that the dairy industry should expect no further legislative support beyond the year 2000 and that it will be treated the same as other industries at that time.

In keeping with current Government policy, Government underwriting of dairy export returns will terminate on 30 June 1992. Underwriting has been of limited assistance to the dairy industry as it was not triggered until 1990-91 when SMP and casein received $22m in support.

The cheese tariff quota will be renewed from 1 July 1992. My colleague, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, will be introducing shortly the necessary alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 by way of a Customs Tariff Proposal.

The new arrangements will have no direct impact on the State market milk schemes. These are a State responsibility and continue to provide the major portion of the measured assistance to the dairy industry. Most States have in place, or are planning, significant deregulation post the farm gate. This is a commendable objective which may lead to significant changes. The Government welcomes the current moves for a more uniform national approach to UHT milk pricing. The possible inclusion of enhanced farm gate pricing regulation (the so called section 38 type provisions) will remain a controversial issue and my only comment on this aspect is that States may find it prudent not to be locked into any new farm gate pricing regulation which does not offer scope for flexibility to deal with changing market conditions. Developments in State market milk arrangements will be kept under review in the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand.

As an added discipline on the States, the Government has decided to terminate the so called `comfort clause' from 30 June 1992. This provision has provided a connection between the Commonwealth arrangements and the State schemes. This enabled any State to seek suspension of the all milk levy and so discourage inter-State milk trade.
Market Development Program

The `Kerin Plan' was aimed primarily at raising the farm gate return for manufacturing milk. It also involved the removal of the long-standing practice of equalising domestic and export product returns. The changes exposed dairy manufacturers more directly to market forces. Consequently, a more efficient manufacturing sector has evolved through technology transfer and infrastructure rationalisation. Nevertheless, dairy manufacturers are still some way from achieving their potential in both a well developed marketing ethos and operating practices. The Government has therefore decided to add a second element to the new marketing arrangements to encourage further development in these areas.

The impetus for change will come from a redirection of the operation of the Australian Dairy Corporation and to a lesser extent, the Dairy Research and Development Corporation to further enhance the industry's export marketing and market development, particularly for profitable higher value products. The Government will be working closely with the Australian Dairy Industry Council and with the Corporations in the coming months to put in place specific activity that will assist dairy manufacturers in the general area of market development. This Bill makes provision for more flexibility in the use of industry promotion funds and the Dairy Industry Fund in market development activity to provide additional funds to support and reinforce the industry's marketing efforts.
Australian Dairy Industry Council

The Council has a legislated role under the current arrangements in respect of a range of policy issues. This is an unusual status for an industry based body and is different from the current representational model based on statutory `industry councils'. Nevertheless, the Council has operated responsibly in its administration of the `Kerin Plan' and the Government has decided to continue that role in relation to the new arrangements. On the other hand, the Council is industry based and cannot avoid an `agri-political' role. This Bill provides for Ministerial scrutiny of the funding of the Council to ensure that funds available for its policy role are not used for other purposes. This process will ensure the contribution of the Council to industry policy development remains under review.

Mr President, the package I have just detailed will provide an industry arrangement that is transparent, predictable and progressive. It highlights the benefits of consulting with industry and it underscores that this outcome for the industry could not have been achieved by the coalition, because it is locked into `Fightback' which proposes the elimination of tariffs and the adoption of the IC report. There is no flexibility in the Opposition's position at all, and that is why the National Party, in particular, has found itself in such great difficulties within its own constituency. On the other hand this Government has taken a reasonable approach given the industry's current situation and the desirability of further assistance reductions. It will take the industry to the end of the decade and leave it in good shape to face the future thereafter.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986 to complete the measures that will set the framework for the Commonwealth's dairy marketing arrangements that I have outlined in the Second Reading Speech on the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill.
This Bill extends to 30 June 2000, the imposition of the market support levy which provides funds for the market support payments on manufactured dairy exports.

The Bill also repeals section 6 of the Principal Act which is known in the industry as the `comfort clause'. The provision allows for any State to seek suspension of the market support levy through the processes of the Australian Agricultural Council (now known as the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand). Its effect has been to enable any State to discourage interstate trade in market milk. The Government accepts the industry's view that this levy suspension provision has outlived its usefulness.

Finally, the Bill increases the maximum rate of levy collected for dairy promotion from 5.5c to 8.0c per kg butterfat to allow for increased promotion activity by the Australian Dairy Corporation. The Government will be working closely with industry to put in place activity that will assist dairy manufacturers in the general area of market development.

The increase in the maximum rate of levy is supported by the Australian Dairy Industry Council. The actual operative rate of levy, which is currently 4.65c per kg butterfat is prescribed by Regulation. Recommendations of the Council are required to be taken into account in prescribing any new rate of levy.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
This Bill makes amendments to a number of Acts within the Health, Housing and Community Services Portfolio.

Part 2 of this Bill makes a number of amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986. The amendments to Part II of this Act are part of a new strategy to assist Commonwealth funded organisations improve the standard of service they provide for people with a disability. The primary focus of the amendments is on providing people with the services which best meet their needs and aspirations, and to ensure that the quality of these services is subject to safeguards.

The Disability Services Act came into operation in 1987. It provided all the then funded services (called prescribed services) with five years to meet the higher standards of service embodied in the objects (which are contained in section 3 of the Act), and principles and objectives (made under section 5 of the Act, and Gazetted on 9 June 1987). This five year period ends on 30 June 1992.

Although significant achievements have been made, it has become clear that for many services this five year period was not long enough to deal with the complexity of the changes required. Therefore, the Bill provides for ongoing funding to prescribed services so that they can complete the necessary changes enabling them to further the objects of the Act, and the Gazetted principles and objectives.

To be assured of ongoing funding, services will have to meet prescribed minimum standards. The minimum standards were introduced administratively in February 1991 and all services are expected to meet these standards by 30 June 1992. Ultimately, all funded organisations will be required to become eligible for funding under section 10 of the Act, by providing a service at a standard consistent with the objects of the Act, and the Gazetted principles and objectives.

However, to give recognition and assistance to those organisations who are continually and substantially improving their services, but who have not reached the standard for eligibility for funding under section 10, the Bill establishes an intermediate level of service standard and attainment. To reflect their progress and transition on the path to higher service standards, these services will be called transitional services.

The Bill provides for the Minister to determine clear and objective standards, which services will be expected to meet. Where a service fails to meet the applicable standards the Minister will be able to take actions under the terms and conditions contained in the funding agreement; however, this action will be subject to a review by a Disability Standards Review Panel. The amendments provide that the performance of funded services against the applicable standards is assessed at least once every 5 years.

The Department is currently consulting with a wide cross section of the community about setting appropriate standards, the processes for monitoring service performance, and the operation of the review panels.

The Bill also contains provisions relating to the transfer of services under the Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement signed by all Heads of Government on 30 July 1991. The Agreement marks a turning point in the provision of more efficient, and better, services for people with a disability in Australia, by rationalising the responsibilities of each level of government, and by ensuring co-ordinated service delivery. The Bill contains provisions to allow State and Territory Government employment services which are transferring to the Commonwealth, but which are not yet furthering the objects of the Act, or the Gazetted principles and objectives, to be funded as prescribed services under section 13.

The Bill removes the restriction on funding of for-profit organisations. This will allow the Minister to fund, on a case-by-case basis, services which are provided by other than non-profit organisations; for example, some attendant care services for which there is currently no option but to fund outside the Act.
The Bill also provides for some other minor and technical amendments to Part II of the Act.

The amendments to the objects of the Disability Services Act clarify that the Disability Services Program and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service are assistance programs that operate within budget constraints.

With respect to the amendments to Part III of the Disability Services Act the amendments clarify that the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) does not have liability for payments under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) for pensioners and beneficiaries whose rehabilitation programs involve tertiary training. As is the case for other Australian students, it is appropriate that students with disabilities should meet these costs when their income exceeds the HECS liability threshold.

Other minor amendments to Part III of the Act would achieve an increase in the operational flexibility of the CRS by: providing legislative support for the reasonable termination of CRS programs; deleting and/or replacing outdated references to goods, services and Social Security allowances; clarifying eligibility for free services; and allowing administrative arrangements to be put in place with other Commonwealth entities.

Part 3 of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983. The First Home Owners Act was amended in 1990, as part of the Government's data-matching program, to insert a provision requiring current and new beneficiaries under the Act to provide their Tax File Number (TFN) data within 60 days of its request. Failure to comply results in termination of all future monthly payments of assistance, an unintended and unduly harsh penalty.

Recipients of assistance under other Government programs covered by the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, who respond late, can resume their entitlement simply upon reapplication after furnishing the requisite TFN data, with the penalty only of those benefit payments lost in the interim. However, the option of a fresh application is not available to First Home beneficiaries.

The new subsection 17C to be inserted in the First Home Owners Act will allow monthly payments of First Home Owners assistance to be resumed once the applicant supplies the required TFN data, with the penalty only of those payments lost by failure to provide it within the specified period.
The amendments in Part 4 of this Bill relate to the provisions of the Health Insurance Act 1973 concerning pathology services and the initiation of excessive diagnostic imaging services.

The amendments affecting diagnostic imaging services, are designed to give the Minister the authority to refer an ordering practitioner, including a medical or a dental practitioner, a chiropractor, a physiotherapist or a podiatrist, to a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry, if the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that such a practitioner has initiated excessive diagnostic imaging services. Under the existing provisions of the Health Insurance Act a Medical Services Committees of Inquiry can deal with practitioners who render excessive professional services, but does not enable excessive ordering to be considered.

The current legislation enables the Minister to refer medical practitioners who initiate excessive pathology services to Committees of Inquiry under section 23DM of the Health Insurance Act. The amending legislation before the Senate provides for similar provisions to apply to the initiation of excessive diagnostic imaging services.

As a result of previous amendments to the Health Insurance Act, from May 1991 and March 1992 chiropractors, physiotherapists and podiatrists have been able to refer patients for certain diagnostic imaging services.

The amending legislation proposes, therefore, that the definition of "practitioner", in relation to diagnostic imaging services, be amended to include chiropractors, physiotherapists and podiatrists, so that these practitioners may also be subject to examination, on referral by the Minister, by a Committee of Inquiry for the initiation of excessive diagnostic imaging services.

This legislation also provides that certain procedures are to be followed before the Minister may refer a practitioner to a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry. Such procedures parallel similar provisions already existing in the Health Insurance Act in relation to pathology services.

Similarly, Committees of Inquiry will follow the same procedures for the hearing and reporting of cases in relation to the initiation of excessive diagnostic imaging services as they do for other cases brought before such Committees.

Part 5 of the Bill contains amendments to the Hearing Services Act 1991. In response to a Report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services undertook to amend the Hearing Services Act during this Sittings by omitting paragraph 66(5)(c). The amendment will have the effect of limiting the protection of section 66 to the name National Acoustic Laboratories, the acronym "NAL" and the NAL logo. In addition, subsection 56(5) is to be omitted from the Hearing Services Act, as it is no longer a requirement that the Treasurer tables in the Parliament Commonwealth guarantees of borrowings by the Authority.

Part 6 of the Bill extends the Safety Net arrangements under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, contained in Part VII of the National Health Act 1953, to include medication supplied through out-patient departments of State public hospitals and Repatriation hospitals.

The expenditure by patients on such medication will be able to be recorded by the hospital authority and count towards the threshold for the issue of concession and entitlement cards. The holders of these cards obtain their pharmaceutical benefits for $2.60, or free of charge, respectively.
The hospital authorities will be able to issue the cards to patients.

By agreement with the various State governments, these arrangements are to be retrospective to 1 January 1992. Procedures were put into place for the recording of supplies of out-patient medication from 1 January 1992, and upon passage of this Bill the concession and entitlement cards will be issued to persons who have qualified for them and refunds made where appropriate.

The passage of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991 created the position of Senior Deputy President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. A consequential amendment, in Part 6 of this Bill, provides that the Chairperson of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal must be either a Senior Deputy President or Deputy President of the Commission.

Part 6 of the Bill also provides that in cases of amalgamation of pharmacies, only the pharmacist or pharmacists whose pharmacy or pharmacies will close under the amalgamation agreement, may apply for, and thus receive, the grant of financial assistance.

Part 7 of this Bill contains several measures aimed at improving the administration of nursing homes under the Aged and Community Care program. The Government has achieved a considerable amount of reform in nursing homes over the last six years, and the measures proposed here build on this achievement. The measures improve both the rigour of the management of nursing homes and the outcomes for the frail, aged residents of nursing homes.

The first measure relates to pre-admission leave. One immediate benefit to nursing home residents of this Bill will be the introduction of pre-admission leave. Nursing home residents already are able to leave the nursing home for up to 28 days a year without any reduction of nursing home benefits paid to the nursing home. In the case of residents having to go to hospital, there is no limit to the number of days leave during which benefits will still be paid.
This entitlement to 28 days non-hospital leave is now being extended to allow for up to two days of leave to be taken before the resident actually enters the nursing home.

Both the nursing home industry and the public have expressed concern about the existing arrangements, where an elderly person often receives short notice of a permanent vacancy in a nursing home. The person is often expected to take up the place the same day, or risk losing the place.

Under the existing legislation, no Commonwealth benefit is payable until a person occupies a place in a nursing home. The understandable desire of nursing home proprietors to maximise their occupancy can lead to considerable pressure being placed on the aged person to enter a nursing home as soon as possible.

The amendments to the Act will allow new nursing home residents to use up to two days of their existing 28 day entitlement for non-hospital leave, immediately prior to their entering the home. This two day period will enable them to organise their affairs, and prepare for the change of living arrangements, without fear of losing their place in the nursing home. It will also assist people in country areas who may have to travel some distance to the nursing home.

The introduction of pre-admission leave is not meant to be an automatic condition proprietors require of all residents but will be an option available to those who need it. A limit of two days will ensure new residents retain a generous social leave entitlement for the remainder of the financial year to assist them to adjust to long term care.
The second measure relates to the disclosure of information to prospective purchasers of nursing homes.

The nursing home funding system is, in part, a cost reimbursement system. Commonwealth benefits are advanced to proprietors each month and, following the end of each financial year, that advanced benefit is acquitted against the proprietor's actual expenditure on nursing and personal care. Where a proprietor has spent less on nursing and personal care than has been advanced, the balance is recovered. This is frequently the case.

What this means is that it is possible for a proprietor to underspend benefit and sell his or her nursing home before the overpayment can be identified, let alone recovered. Once the home is sold, the Department is able to quantify the overpayment. However, the current legislation makes the new proprietor liable for recovery of the previous proprietor's overadvance.

This process is well established and known in the industry, and is usually accounted for in contracts for sale of nursing homes. However, the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act 1953 prevent the disclosure by the Department of information relating to a nursing home to a prospective purchaser. While prospective purchasers may appreciate the possibility of a recovery subsequent to sale, without specific information as to current and impending recoveries, they may be unable to adequately make provision in the contract of sale. They may, as a consequence, be significantly disadvantaged by underestimating the amount of the recovery.
This may place some strain on the home's financing, making it harder for the new proprietor to provide quality care to the residents.

The Bill contains amendments to assist in protecting the incoming proprietor and ensuring continued quality care for residents by allowing the Department to provide the prospective purchaser with the information he or she needs to make an informed decision about a sale.

The rights of existing proprietors are also considered, as the Department will be required to wait 7 days before disclosing information, during which time the proprietor may make a submission on the matter for consideration. In situations where there is an urgent need to act to protect the interests of a prospective purchaser, however, the Department will be able to act immediately.
The elimination of this risk in the purchase of a nursing home will promote confidence in the transaction, stability in financing and continued quality of care for residents.
The third measure in this Part of the Bill relates to the keeping of certain records by former proprietors of nursing homes.

A further consequence of proprietors being able to sell their homes before an overpayment can be quantified is that, if the Department is unable to gain access to the proprietor's accounting records, it will be very difficult to quantify the overpayment accurately. While nursing home proprietors are subject to a number of statutory responsibilities in relation to the keeping of records, those responsibilities presently cease once the proprietor has sold his or her home.

The amendment in relation to this matter will help to protect taxpayers' money by introducing a requirement for former proprietors to continue to maintain their records for 12 months after they have sold their business. The amendment also enables the Department to approve a specific location for the keeping of the records, and provides appropriate penalties for former proprietors who fail to maintain their records accordingly.
The fourth measure introduces amendments in relation to receivers, liquidators, etc. who are appointed to run a nursing home.

The Bill amends the secrecy provision contained in the National Health Act 1953 to clarify the Department's ability to divulge key information to persons appointed to manage a proprietor's approved nursing home. Historically, there have been practical problems about how the secrecy provision should be administered where, for example, a receiver or a liquidator is appointed to conduct a proprietor's nursing home business. This has limited the Department's ability to deal effectively and co-operatively with such appointees, thus making it difficult for the Department to act in the interests of the nursing home residents.
The final measure in Part 7 of the Bill relates to transfers of nursing home bed approvals under section 39B of the Act.

The Bill contains a measure to protect residents, where approved beds are to be transferred from one home to another. Approval-in-principle for such a transfer will be subject to a condition that the proprietor of the home yielding the beds continues to comply with nursing home conditions of approval. This is to further protect the welfare and safety of the residents in that home which will close or be reduced in size.

The amendments will also provide for the formulation of principles to be referred to in making decisions to grant or refuse approvals-in-principle for transfers. These principles will address such matters as fraud or the provision of false or misleading information, failure to meet gazetted nursing home standards, and problems with any other statutory requirements. The effect will be that, where a person does not have a satisfactory record in the provision of aged care, that person will not be able to expand his or her interests in the industry by buying and transferring nursing home beds. This is a further example of the Government's commitment to ensuring quality care for the frail aged.

Part 8 of the Bill introduces amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. These amendments clarify the definition of `therapeutic devices' for the purposes of that Act and implement, in the time suggested, further recommendations made by Professor Peter Baume for improving Australia's regulatory regime for therapeutic goods. These recommendations are contained in Professor Baume's "Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia", tabled in Parliament in July 1991, and adopted for implementation as a package by the Government.

The amendment to the definition of `therapeutic device' in the Act will strengthen the regulation of therapeutic goods used to replace or modify the human anatomy for cosmetic purposes, such as breast implants. The amendment will also serve to permit greater scrutiny by the Therapeutic Goods Administration of therapeutic goods used to influence conception, including goods used in the IVF program. These changes also serve to bring the definition of `therapeutic devices' closer to that being used by the countries of the European Community, from which a significant proportion of therapeutic devices are imported into Australia. The new definition will accommodate emerging technologies being developed in the fields of immunology, genetic engineering and computer software.

The remaining amendments largely give effect to the recommendations contained in Professor Baume's Report. During the last Sittings, amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act were introduced to enable deadlines to be set for completing evaluations of certain therapeutic drugs. The Bill inserts a provision, as recommended by Professor Baume, to enable applicants to treat a failure by the Therapeutic Goods Administration to meet the stipulated deadline as a decision to refuse marketing approval for the applicant's drug, for the purposes of precipitating a direct appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill also contains new reporting requirements designed to ensure that, for the protection of consumers and the public, any adverse safety data relating to certain drugs that have been approved for marketing, or that are the subject of an application for such an approval, will be reported by the relevant sponsors or applicants where they become aware of such information.

In order to attract suitable candidates to assume the challenging responsibility for initiating recommended changes and improvements to the regulatory regime for therapeutic goods in Australia, Professor Baume recommended, in Chapter 12 of his Report, that the position of both National Manager and Director of Drug Evaluation in the Therapeutic Goods Administration be filled on a contract basis. To enable such officers to exercise relevant powers under the Therapeutic Goods Act and Regulations, the Bill introduces amendments that will allow regulations to be made to permit the Secretary and the Minister to delegate their powers and functions to officers who have not been appointed to the Therapeutic Goods Administration as public servants.

Finally, the Bill facilitates Professor Baume's recommendation that the deliberations of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee and its subcommittees be more widely disseminated. It permits the making of regulations authorising the release of therapeutic goods information to the public.
I now turn to the amendments to the Health Insurance Act relating to the repeal of the Medicare Co-payment arrangements, contained primarily in Schedule 2 of the Bill.

These amendments will operate retrospectively from 1 March 1992. Provision has been made, however, for the preservation of the effect of the benefit reduction, co-payment and "additional fee" for those prescribed services rendered during the period 1 December 1991 to 29 February 1992. Provision has also been made for the preservation of transitional arrangements for the medicare safety-net as it is affected by the change for individuals from a financial to a calendar year.

The Health Insurance Act is amended so as to remove the enabling provisions for the Health Insurance Regulations to prescribe services which would have a reduced level of medicare benefits, and where these services are bulk billed and provided to non-cardholders, a co-payment and an additional fee. The Health Insurance Regulations have already been amended so that no services have been prescribed under these provisions since 1 March 1992.

Specifically, the Bill withdraws the provisions which enabled a reduction to the benefit for out-of-hospital general practitioner attendance items by $3.50 and eliminates the further reduction that was to apply to medicare benefits for prescribed services in the following year.

It also withdraws the provisions which permit medical practitioners to charge up to a $2.50 co-payment for those prescribed services which are bulk-billed and provided to non-cardholders, and the payment of the $1.00 additional fee to the doctor in respect of these services.

From 1 January 1992, registered families have been counting their out of pocket medical expenses or "gap" payments towards a safety-net threshold of $246.00 per annum. A "gap" payment is the difference between the lower of the Schedule fee or whatever the doctor charges, and the medicare benefit. The extension of the medicare safety net arrangements to families remains unchanged by these amendments to the Health Insurance Act.

However, the Bill removes the provisions relating to the safety-net concession card and the need for a declaration form. These are not necessary as there is no longer a co-payment for bulk billed services and therefore families and individuals do not have to provide evidence to their general practitioner that they have reached the threshold in order to be exempt from the co-payment. The safety net status of an individual or a family need only be known by that person or family and the Health Insurance Commission.

The withdrawal of these provisions does not affect the overall intent of the 1991 Budget announcement relative to general practice. This Government is committed to working with the medical profession to achieve structural changes in general practice, which are aimed at achieving better quality care at better value for money. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services will be making more specific announcements on these measures in the coming months.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
