SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, which is now before the Chamber, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Many of the amendments have already been introduced as customs tariff proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule One is operative from the first day of July 1990 and subtracts the customs duty component from the New Zealand rate of duty for tobacco products of chapter 24. The amendment is made in the context of Australia's obligations under the 1988 closer economic relations protocol.
Schedules Two, Three and Four contain amendments to concessional items in Schedule 4 of the principal Act.

Schedule Two, which will operate from the first day of January 1991, amends item 41a. This will allow motor vehicle component manufacturers to directly use import credits which they earn under the motor vehicle export facilitation scheme.

Schedule Three will have effect from the twelfth day of March 1991. Item 56 will allow certain capital equipment which is technologically more advanced, more efficient or more productive than equipment available from Australian manufacture to be imported duty free.

Schedule Four will take effect from the first day of October 1991. The provisions of Item 31 have been expanded to allow all aircraft parts, materials and test equipment for use in the manufacture, repair and maintenance of aircraft to be imported duty free. The only exceptions are goods which are used for servicing aircraft. This affirms the Government's objective to develop and maintain the international competitiveness of Australia's aerospace manufacturing and aviation industries.
The sunset clause has been removed from Item 36b which allows certain chemicals to be imported duty free for specific end-uses.

Item 57 has been created to allow certain chemicals and textile fabric to be imported duty free when used in the chemicals, plastics, and book binding and allied industries. This action will also assist the international competitiveness of these industries.
Item 58 has been inserted to allow general purpose components and materials for use in the manufacture or repair of invalid carriages to be imported duty free.

Schedule Five is operative from the first day of January 1992. Schedule 1 of the principal Act has been amended to give effect to changes in the concessional tariff treatment accorded goods from Yugoslavia and its republics under the Australian system of tariff preferences.

Changes to Schedule 3 of the principal Act involve the treatment of motor vehicles. The definitions of off-road and passenger motor vehicles in additional notes 4 and 5 to chapter 87 have been amended. The upper weight limit for light commercial vehicles has been raised from 2.72 Tonnes to 3.5 Tonnes.
Item 40g is inserted in Schedule 4 to cover those textile orthopaedic goods excluded from heading 9021 by sub-note 1(b) to that chapter. This item will retain a free rate of duty for these goods.
Schedule Six operates from the first day of March 1992. These amendments:
.Contain further changes to the tariff treatment of goods from Yugoslavia and its republics;

.Are made in the context of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and insert new quota tender and tender extension duty rates for tcf goods from the first of March 1992 to the twenty-eighth of February 1993. This follows the determination of rates under the 1992 tender quota scheme;
.Increase the footwear priceline for seven subheadings in chapter 64 and one sub-item in Schedule 5;
.Reword item 40g in Schedule 4 to allow only those textile orthopaedic goods which are excluded from chapter 90 by sub-note 1(b) to that chapter to be imported duty free; and
.Alter Item 57 in schedule 4 by expanding the range of raw materials and intermediate goods available as duty free inputs for the chemicals, plastics, and book binding and allied industries.

Schedule Seven will commence on the first day of April 1992 and clarifies the intent of note 4(e) to chapter 87 by ensuring that clearance levels for off-road vehicles applies to front and rear axles as well as to the suspension.

Schedule Eight will operate from the first day of July 1992. The duty on cold-rolled, and clad, plated or coated flat-rolled steel products of tariff headings 7209, 7210, 7211 and 7212 will be reduced from ten per cent to five per cent. This represents, for the specified products, an acceleration of the phasing down of general tariffs announced in the 1991 industry statement.
The tariff rates for goods from Hong Kong, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan Province will be maintained at five per cent in line with measures announced in the industry statement.

As previously announced, in relation to high volume imports of used or secondhand passenger motor vehicles, the Government has decided to impose a duty of $12 000 per vehicle in addition to the duty already in place. This action will protect the Australian motor vehicle industry from low cost imports of secondhand vehicles particularly from Japan.
A new Item 59 in Schedule 4 of the principal Act will ensure that the existing provisions for personal or low volume importations of used or secondhand vehicles will remain unchanged.
A new tariff structure is provided for short pack bicycles.

Schedule Nine will have effect fourteen days after this Bill receives royal assent. It inserts new additional notes to Section 16 and to chapter 84, to clarify the intent of the customs co-operation council in relation to the classification of certain goods.
Also contained in the Bill are a number of minor technical and administrative changes.
Summaries of the amendments contained in this Bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable Senators.
I commend the Bill.
CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (TARIFF CONCESSIONS AND ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing a series of amendments to the Customs Act 1901, the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988, and the Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987 to:

SPEECH.PARA: 1)repeal Part XVA of the Customs Act 1901 and substitute a new Part XVA of the Customs Act 1901 to give legislative effect to the Government's response to the Industry Commission's report on the Tariff Concessions System (Report No. 9 of 8 March 1991), announced by the Government on 24 September 1991; and

2)amend Part XVB of the Customs Act 1901 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 to give legislative effect to the Government's review of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing system, announced by the Government on 5 December 1991.

PARA.TAB: I will now briefly outline the proposed changes:

SPEECH.PARA: 1)Tariff Concessions

PARA.TAB: The present Commercial Tariff Concession System allows duty free entry of imports where there are no goods serving similar functions made by Australian industry in the normal course of business. The objective of the system is to ensure that industry is not taxed by the Tariff where it is serving no protective function. By lowering input costs, the concession system is an important element in the Government's program to improve the international competitiveness of Australian industry.
Once a Commercial Tariff Concession Order is in place, any importer can use it to import goods described in that order duty free.

The present Commercial Tariff Concession System was introduced in 1983, following an IAC report in 1982. The March 1991 Industry Commission inquiry and report to which this Bill is addressed has been prompted by a growing dissatisfaction with the operation of the current system, particularly with the time taken to obtain a concession order, and the lack of transparency in the decision making process leading to the grant or refusal of such an order.

The amendments proposed in this Bill reflect the Government's decision to accept most of the Industry Commission's recommendations for changes to the Commercial Tariff Concession System. They will make concessional entry more readily available without affecting the assistance given to industry and improve the openness, clarity and consistency of the tariff concession system.

In particular, Clause 10 of the Bill introduces a new Tariff Concession System by repealing the old Part XVA of the Customs Act and substituting a new Part XVA. The four principal elements of the new system are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: .the first introduces new definitions for the current core criteria for the granting of a tariff concession order to replace the old "goods serving similar functions" test, which incorporated the economic concept of "cross-elasticity of demand", which has proven difficult to interpret and administer,

.the second introduces strict time limits both on the processing of applications or revocations by the bureaucracy, and on the submission of information by affected parties. This will streamline the consideration of applications for tariff concession orders or revocations of such orders, and help make the process more transparent,

.the third introduces limited and definitive grounds for the revocation of tariff concession orders, to improve accountability and address concerns amongst users of tariff concessions about possible arbitrary revocations,
.the fourth introduces a right to merits review of all decisions made in the new Part XVA, first through an internal review mechanism, and then via the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: With respect to this final principal reform, it is noted that the current Concession System allows persons aggrieved by a decision under Part XVA to obtain judicial review of that decision under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. This is both costly and time consuming, and importantly, limited to errors of law.

The proposed new two tiered process of Internal Review/AAT Review is a merits review process which will allow for review of a decision on the facts, together with a substitution of decisions in appropriate cases.
Other more technical amendments relevant to the new Tariff Concession System contained in the Bill are explained in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: 2)Anti-Dumping

PARA.TAB: The proposed anti-dumping amendments in this Bill follow the Government's review of Australia's anti-dumping policy and administrative arrangements in late 1991.

Dumping and subsidisation are not supported internationally if they cause, or threaten to cause, material injury to an industry producing like goods in the importing country. The internationally agreed remedy is the imposition of a dumping or countervailing duty sufficient to remove the injury to the local industry.

The Government has consistently maintained that effective anti-dumping and countervailing measures are necessary to protect Australian industry from injury caused by these unfair trading practices. However, in taking anti-dumping and countervailing actions there is need to strike a balance. A balance between providing local producers with effective relief, and ensuring that relief does not unjustifiably impede trade or increase costs to Australian consumers.

Anti-dumping decisions therefore require judgments to be made involving a blend of economic and commercial considerations. Over the last two years the Government has particularly focused on the time taken to process applications for anti-dumping and countervailing action. The Government looked exhaustively at the options for reducing the time between a request for anti-dumping relief and the time when such relief can first be made available.

In the 1991 March Industry Statement the Government proposed and the Parliament subsequently passed legislation which greatly reduced the processing time for applications. Clause 13 of this Bill will further shorten the total time allowed to reach a preliminary finding to a maximum of one hundred and twenty five days, or for complex cases, a maximum of 145 days.

This compares more than favourably to the times taken by other countries in the processing of requests for anti-dumping relief. Australia now has one of the fastest anti-dumping systems. The USA for instance, takes between 160 and 210 days; Canada between 141 to 186 days, and the European Community around 270 days.
I incorporate into Hansard a comparative table of these time limits, for the information of honourable members.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATA BASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 2861]

PARA.TAB: To keep processing time for anti-dumping relief to a minimum, the Government also considers it appropriate that the applicant for that relief provide sufficient information to enable a prima facie case to be established. The technical requirements of applications have therefore been tightened by clauses 12 and 13 of the Bill.

However, I draw to Honourable Members attention that the Business Liaison Unit or Shopfront of Customs has been expanded to continue its important role in assisting Australian industry to complete the form for anti-dumping applications.

The Government has also recognised industry's dissatisfaction about the relatively short period, that is 3 years, that anti-dumping and countervailing measures are in place. In recognition of this and also to remain consistent with amendments proposed to the GATT in the Uruguay Round, Clause 17 of the Bill provides for anti-dumping and countervailing measures to be extended to five years. In addition to this extension, Clause 7 then provides for a review to be undertaken by the Anti-Dumping Authority as to whether measures should continue after the five year expiry date for measures or undertakings, following a request for such a review by an interested party. The Authority will call for submissions no later than eight months before this expiry date so as to allow sufficient time for a comprehensive inquiry to be made by the Authority—and a decision to be made by the Minister—before the end of the five year period.

Measures will be retained where the Minister is satisfied that they are required—but they may not necessarily be of the same type or magnitude. For example, if earlier measures were in the form of an undertaking, they might, depending on the circumstances, be replaced by anti-dumping duties. Similarly, earlier measures based on prices in the country of export may need to be revised to reflect prices which are more current.

This reform is considered by the Government to be preferable to requiring an Australian industry to re-apply for anti-dumping or countervailing relief, with the possibility of a gap occurring in the important relief which might be available.

Finally, with regard to the substantive anti-dumping amendments contained in this Bill, the Government is proposing in Clause 8 the extension of the life of the Anti-Dumping Authority for a further 8 years to August 2001. During the course of its review, the Government considered claims of duplication of work by the Customs Service and the ADA, but it is satisfied the current division of responsibilities between these two bodies should be retained, to ensure the comprehensive and impartial review of anti-dumping measures that is currently provided by the Authority.

In proposing the substantive anti-dumping amendments which I have briefly detailed, together with the several technical amendments to the anti-dumping system which are explained in detail in Clauses 11 to 16 of the Explanatory Memorandum, the Government does recognise the important part which imports play in our economy and reiterates that it will not see the anti-dumping system used as de facto industry protection. However, the Government believes Australian industry will welcome the changes which this Bill proposes to make to the anti-dumping system.

The message is clear. The Government will not allow material injury to local industry from dumped or subsidised goods. The Government has backed up that commitment with an anti-dumping system that is one of the fastest in the world, which recognises the need for applications to substantiate a case, and which provides appropriate assistance to all parties and is fair in its judgements.

SPEECH.PARA: Financial Impact Statement

PARA.TAB: The financial impact of the measures contained in this Bill relating to anti-dumping and tariff concessions involve new staffing costs to process the various applications for measures within the stricter time constraints, to expand the Business Liaison Unit within the Australian Customs Service to assist with dumping applications, and to meet the new merits review reform in the tariff concessions area. In addition, new notice requirements in provisions of the Bill relating to the tariff concessions reforms will involve increased printing costs. The estimated total increased costs are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: i)anti-dumping;

PARA.TAB: $848,000 for financial year 1992-93,

SPEECH.PARA: ii)tariff concessions;

PARA.TAB: $300,000 for financial year 1992-93.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 as a consequence of the proposed anti-dumping amendments which I have detailed in the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill deals with the proposed clarification of the law relating to the application of anti-dumping measures in cases where both dumping and subsidy is causing injury, and is related to Clause 18 of that other Bill.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its Explanatory Memorandum.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the circumstances surrounding the positive drug test on Mr Alex Watson, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: By agreement, Mr President, I understand, my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne and I have both bound ourselves to 10 minutes, so it might be of assistance if we start the clock. I am very pleased to see this report tabled in this place today. I think it makes a nice sequel to the drugs in sport inquiry. Before I make some comments about the report, I would like to take the opportunity to thank my colleagues and to thank the staff, including the Secretary, Mr Grundy, for his assistance with this report. I would also like to thank those many staff who have been listed in the report as assisting us, particularly Dr Anne-Gabrielle Thompson, Derek Drinkwater, Angela Misic, Laurie Swift, Kathy Casey and others.

PARA.TAB: The report has taken some time. Indeed, the Committee report was circulated to members of the Committee in late February but there has been a delay until now to get the finalised report and the accompanying minority report. We wanted the tabling of this report to match when Alec Watson was back in the country and that has meant that we are now seeing this report finally tabled in May. I am appreciative of that now being the event.

This inquiry was a modest inquiry. Before we took this reference, Alex Watson said that he had nothing further to say to what he had said in the drugs in sport inquiry, and in all sorts of places subsequent to that. However, when the terms of reference were taken by the ERA Committee, Mr Watson was pleased to contribute; he provided a submission and he appeared before the Committee. It was an inquiry that was focused in its aim. It was also limited in the number of people who were interested in putting submissions; it was a very specific inquiry about a specific matter. We received four submissions and we had about five witnesses come before us in the hearings that we held.

The Committee wanted to make clear that this was not a continuation of the drugs in sport inquiry and that it was not a rehearing of the Alex Watson appeal. Both of those were important points of consideration and I think they qualified how the Committee tackled its report. As I understand it, the essential difference between the Committee's report and the minority report is the amount of detail that the minority report goes to: in no way did it detract from the Committee report, nor indeed did the Committee report detract from the minority report; there was just a different weighting of how these issues should be addressed.

There is one significant difference in our recommendations. The Committee's report found, as was beyond dispute, that Alex Watson—as he had said many a time before and has always acknowledged—was above the prescribed limit for caffeine when he was tested for drugs in the Olympic Games in Seoul. He has never disputed that and that is still not a matter of dispute. In dispute were the points at issue for Mr Watson—the Committee spells them out on page three of the report—and he was particularly pleased to be able to put them to the Committee. He said that, if he had gone above the level—and yes, he had gone above the level—he had to have done so unintentionally because the only caffeine he could have taken was what was in beverages that he had consumed during the course of a day's performance in Seoul: coffee and Coca-Cola. So he wanted it to be known that he had unintentionally exceeded the limit.

Secondly, he felt that the IOC, the International Olympic Committee, in making the judgment about him—or about anybody, for that matter, who had exceeded the prescribed limit—presumed illegal behaviour, that a person could not have possibly gone above the level without having done something besides drinking coffee or Coca-Cola, that it could not have been inadvertent to have exceeded that limit.

Thirdly, he was concerned that the Australian Olympic Federation, as it was then, had imposed a very inappropriate penalty at the time of Seoul, that it was harsh and peremptory, and that there were no appeal provisions for him. Finally, he was concerned that, in the course of all of this, his reputation and good name were seriously damaged.

The Committee was concerned to hear from the AOC, the Australian Olympic Committee, as well as from Mr Watson, and we also took evidence from Professor Burkett about the information we could find out from expert witnesses about caffeine.

I have to say in summary, particularly given the time constraints today, that the jury is out on caffeine. While the jury is out on caffeine, this Committee comes down with these recommendations, very strongly: if we cannot be clear with any reliability about how caffeine is absorbed into the body or how it is circulated or how it is excreted, if we cannot be sure that we can set an absolute, scientific, valid level that is appropriate for everybody, then we must, until that is the case, proscribe it. My colleague in his minority report concludes differently, and he will no doubt speak to that.

The Committee judges that the penalty given to Mr Watson for a first offence, that is, the life ban put on by the Australian Olympic Federation at the time, was an excessive penalty. Indeed, it is not hard to agree with that because the AOF itself, subsequently the AOC—I shall call it the AOC from here on—concluded that the penalty of a life ban should be reduced to a two-year penalty to be served concurrent with the ban put on by his own pentathlon organisation, to run from the time of his disqualification from the Olympic Games. As everybody knows, Alex Watson has now completed that two-year ban and is currently preparing to represent Australia at these Games.

The Committee felt that that penalty was excessive, and we recommend that in the future penalties for drug offenders should match as much as possible the now recognised—or somewhat accepted—standard of three months for an inadvertent use, two years for a first time penalty, and life for subsequent offences. Mr Watson was not given that kind of benefit. Subsequently, on appeal he was, and we feel that that decision by the AOC on appeal corrected the excessive penalty put on at the time of the Olympic Games.

It is also clear, from questioning and from reading the evidence, that the Australian Olympic Committee at the time in Seoul was clearly very distressed itself by the shock of this happening. Alex Watson's positive drug test was the first for any Olympic athlete from Australia. I think it was not only a shock to Australia and, as we know, to Alex Watson that this should be recorded; but also it was a very big shock to the Australian Olympic team officials. It is without doubt that they were caught on the hop and overreacted in the way they managed the situation in Seoul.

It is for that reason that the Committee report has been at pains to recommend that, in the future, that not be allowed to happen again, that proper procedures be put in place to ensure that, in particular, the rights of the athlete are protected and provided for. Another athlete at Seoul at the same time was assisted by an advocate in his dealings with a positive drug test. That is now going to be the situation for the Australian team. It was not, until this event, and I think we should take heart from some of those protocols being in place. I believe it is important that natural justice prevail in this area as much as anywhere else.

I said we were concerned not to continue the drugs in sport inquiry. What has happened in this country is that, because of law and legal behaviour, considerable penalties and considerable loss, particularly of good name and of income, have occurred as people have been tested positive for drug use. Those consequences are very stern, but it is not an area that has a long history of using judicial process. That is something we should look at in the future, to continue to provide not only natural justice but proper justice. I think that the past might have been a learning curve for people involved with drugs in sport.

This brief report concludes the matter of the Alex Watson inquiry. It continues this Government's commitment and this Parliament's commitment—a united commitment—to oppose drugs in sport as being unfair and of no example or model in this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Crowley observes, the minority report is of some length. It is over 100 pages. I have to say, with respect, that that is a modest contribution to the level of detail that ought to have been committed to this report. Let me say from the outset that ultimately there are some significant differences between the findings of the minority report and those of the majority report because in some respects the majority report chose not to make findings. The essential finding made in the minority report is that Watson did breach the allowable IOC urine caffeine concentration levels. The minority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The IOC Medical Commission was of the belief that Mr Watson did not obtain his urine caffeine concentration levels in the manner he claimed.
We found:
There is no evidence that Mr Watson reached these levels other than by the manner he claims.
Scientific evidence demonstrates that a urine caffeine concentration level of 12 mcgs/ml can be obtained by the normal consumption of coffee.
Scientific evidence demonstrates that Mr Watson could have obtained his urine caffeine concentration level of 14.45 mcgs/ml by the consumption of coffee.
Scientific evidence indicates Mr Watson could have reached his urine caffeine concentration level of 14.45 mcgs/ml by consuming the amount of caffeine he claimed.

In my view, Alex Watson has been treated in the most appalling way by the AOC and the IOC. The AOC has redeemed its sins by subsequently accepting an appeal from Alex Watson and reducing his life penalty to two years. In some ways, the AOC expunges its sin by making the following observation. I quote Mr Gosper:
The Board determined that Alex Watson's evidence throughout has been consistent and that it could see no evidence of consumption of caffeine other than by his drinking of coffee.
In other words, the AOC found that Alex Watson did not reach his level by the ingestion of caffeine tablets or suppositories; he obtained it by the consumption of coffee.

PARA.TAB: That contrasts sharply with the IOC's findings and the grounds for which it deemed him to have tested positive to a dope test, expelled him from the Twenty-fourth Olympiad, expelled him from the Olympic village, placed him on an aircraft at 5 o'clock in the morning, and sent him home in disgrace to Australia. The IOC concluded that the drug test taken by Mr Alex Watson was positive, given the high level of caffeine, which could not have been due to drinking coffee, even in considerable amounts. This conclusion of the IOC Medical Commission was accepted by the Australian Olympic Federation and the UIPMB—the International Union of Modern Pentathlon and Biathlon.

The IOC Medical Commission consequently recommended to the IOC Executive Board that Mr Alex Watson be disqualified from the Seoul Olympic Games. The IOC Executive Board accepted the recommendation of the IOC Medical Commission. The finding of the IOC was that he had been deemed positive not because he had reached the level of 14.45 but because he could not have reached that level, in the view of the IOC Medical Commission, by the normal consumption of coffee. That has been found by the AOC to have been wrong. It has been found by the minority report, accepting all the available expert evidence of world renowned reputation, that Alex Watson reached his level in the manner he claimed. So Alex Watson was expelled from the Games improperly and by a miscarriage of justice.

Following that, and notwithstanding the most vigorous campaign to clear his name, the IOC has not been prepared to entertain an appeal. Perhaps the greatest sin of the IOC in its cavalier disregard for the rights of Alex Watson and all the athletes is that it does not have an appeal mechanism available. While the IOC preaches fairness, equity, justice and the spirit of goodwill for all athletes of the world, it does not itself have an appeal mechanism which allows athletes whose reputations are destroyed across the world to have a forum in which to claim their innocence.

It took our Committee, inquiring for the first time into the basis of the grounds for his expulsion from those Games, to learn that, in fact, Alex Watson had not cheated; that Alex Watson had consumed coffee in the normal way; that Alex Watson had every reason to believe that his consumption of coffee would not take him over the prescribed limit. As Dr Sando, the AOC doctor, said, `If I had known Alex Watson was going to drink 14 cups of coffee over 12 hours, I myself would not have counselled him that he was likely to breach the prescribed limit'. Yet subsequently, when Watson breached the prescribed limit by the normal consumption of coffee—I say `normal' in the sense that he consumed coffee and did not use a suppository or take tablets—the AOC promptly found him guilty and banned him for life from competing. The IOC expelled him from the Games and kicked him out of the village.

I regret that I have but 10 minutes this morning to talk on this issue, but I accepted the 10 minutes because, if I had not, the report would not have been tabled. It has taken from 1988 to 1992 for it to be learnt that Alex Watson did not cheat and that the grounds upon which he was expelled from the Games were false. Our findings are buttressed by Dr Birkett, Head of the Department of Clinical Pharmacology at Flinders University and recognised as a leading world authority, whose views are supported by people such as Professor Richard Day, Dr K. Donald and a significant number of other authorities. In fact, Professor Beckett, who is a member of the IOC Medical Commission, supports the proposition that is put by us.

In conclusion, I believe that the conduct of the IOC is absolutely reprehensible. I refer those who have an interest in this matter to the 12 letters I wrote to the IOC demanding that it provide the basis and the grounds for the conduct. On each occasion the IOC denied us a response. It was only in the last 24 hours that we received correspondence from it which sets out very clearly that Watson was expelled from the Games because the IOC did not believe he consumed coffee in the manner he claimed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

—When we met yesterday I was pointing out the outrageous fact that I had learned that the ALP, which is spending some $80m, I understand, to build its new building—I wonder where it is getting its money—is to have as its major tenant the Australian National Audit Office. Perhaps that is where it is getting some of its money. I find it absolutely unacceptable to have an organ of the Parliament, the hugely important National Audit Office, as a tenant of this new building. The Auditor-General is a man who must be independent and who must be seen to be independent. He must be seen to be under no pressure at all. He must be seen not to be in a position where he could be said to be influenced. That certainly is not the case should he be in the Australian National Audit Office.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan spoke to me when we broke for luncheon yesterday and asked me whether I had finished with this matter. I asked that he table in the Senate all contracts, correspondence, lease agreements or whatever, disclosing the price and conditions of negotiations, which went between the Australian National Audit Office, DAS and the Australian Labor Party. Senator McMullan tried to tell me that it was all DAS's negotiation. We all know that DAS is the organ that does the work, but the client in this case is the Australian National Audit Office, and of course it is the client who gives instructions. Therefore, the relevant people to answer these questions are the officers who actually negotiated those contracts or those leases, whatever they are. So I would ask at this stage whether Senator McMullan has been able to get that documentation, whether he is going to table it for us now, and whether or not he has present the actual officers who negotiated that arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated yesterday, I have referred the question of tabling those documents to the Minister. He will be giving me a reply and somebody will advise the Senate on his behalf—probably me.We have senior officers here capable of answering questions about office accommodation. It might help if I put on the record some small amount of background that I have sought with regard to this matter.

PARA.TAB: During 1991 a number of Commonwealth departments and authorities, including the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian National Audit Office and the Industry Commission expressed a desire to occupy accommodation in and around the Parliamentary Triangle. In response to this interest, the Australian Property Group sought expressions from building owners and developers interested in providing between 3000 and 8000 square metres of office accommodation in the Barton-Parkes-Forrest precinct, in order to ascertain what proposals were under consideration and whether they met the Commonwealth's requirements.

Advertisements calling for expressions were to be placed twice weekly in the Australian, the Canberra Times and the Australian Financial Review for a two-week period between 27 October and 14 November, and in the Australian Property News issue of l November 1990. Expressions were received from 14 parties, including the Lend Lease Corporation acting on behalf of the ALP, and from Mr Tony Eggleton of the Liberal Party of Australia.

In 1989, the owners of the Silverton Centre in Civic closed the building because of major structural problems, and it remains closed. This necessitated the temporary relocation of the Australian National Audit Office to Medibank House in Woden. Medibank House is of a low standard and does not meet the longer term needs of ANAO. Indeed, report No.296 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the reform of the Australian National Audit Office recommended that the ANAO plan for a new building within the Parliamentary Triangle or on State Circle adjacent to the new Parliament House. ANAO has a requirement for approximately 6000 square metres of quality accommodation, and the ALP proposal represents the only option large enough to comply with ANAO's requirements. It should be noted that the Liberal Party did not turn up at an appointment to discuss its proposal and has not since made contact.

The proposed building in Barton offers 6000 square metres of office space and 128 basement and 25 on-site car parking spaces. The building will be completed by the end of 1992 or early 1993 and will be constructed in accordance with the Commonwealth office accommodation standards. The lease term will be for 15 years, with an option to renew for a further period of five years.

The other information in this document I have is a matter of detail. It is not secret but it is a little dated, and events have overtaken those subsequent pieces of information. That is the background information I can provide, which perhaps gives some sort of context for how this decision came to be made by the Australian Property Group and the Audit Office in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. Senator McMullan has told us everything except the relevant figure—the price, the rental to be paid.

—I have the figure; I was not absolutely sure that it was the correct up-to-date figure so I did not want to quote it. I just want to get the terms right. The base net rental rate as at 1 January 1991 was $280 per square metre, which compares with the Barton area average of $320 to $325 per square metre. PARA.TAB: Before I do that, I want to ask a couple of other questions relating to this document. I do not know whether anybody has done the computations. It does not matter. We will do them during the break after I have deferred discussion. I note for the record that the Australian Labor Party is going to receive 6,000 times $280 every year for 15 years with a five-year option. That makes a joke out of the disclosure legislation.

We had the ads ban legislation being decided while we had Senator Richardson, a director of the Labor Party owned station, sitting on the board. We have evidence of Senator Richardson intervening in the granting of new licences with regard to the Lismore area. We have evidence that the Labor Party has influence in other radio stations. We know that with the ad bans legislation we are not allowed to put paid advertising onto the airwaves, either radio or television, and we are dependent for the interpretation of our message on employees of Labor owned stations. Is it not amazing that they are going to have what is seen as an improper advantage?

There is a distinction to be drawn between the Australian National Audit Office and other Government departments. One can argue a case for ordinary Government departments choosing accommodation that is suitable to them, but we are going to have the keeper of propriety over the expenditure of money housed in a building owned and operated by the Australian Labor Party. Does the Minister appreciate that the Australian National Audit Office could face some problem of a conflict of interest when it is a tenant of a political party which may be in government, or in opposition for that matter, and it is in a situation where it is beholden to its landlord for the terms and conditions of its rental?

PARA.TAB: I see that Senator Cooney is in the chamber. I am sure that Senator Cooney would agree with me that, on the face of it, there does seem to be a conflict of interest. It seems to me, as Senator Bishop has mentioned—I ask Senator Cooney to think about this—that the problem with the National Audit Office is that, as it is the keeper of the nation's purse, it must be seen to be utterly and totally pure in relation to all of its activities and that it should not be in a situation where it is in some way or other beholden—it must always be beholden to its landlord in some way—to a political party, as its landlord. In this case the political party happens to be the Labor Party. I put it to the Parliamentary Secretary that if the political party were the Liberal Party, he would see that there was some problem in relation to a conflict of interest. That seems to me to be the case. If the Parliamentary Secretary does not agree with me, could he explain to me why he does not agree with me?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not regard one's tenancy of a building as creating any question of conflict of interest. My understanding is that the Auditor-General does not, either. I think that is a matter which the honourable senator should consider. Of course, the Auditor-General is aware of, and has been involved in, these discussions and, to my understanding, has indicated that he sees no problem. That is an important factor for the honourable senator to realise.

PARA.TAB: I have been a manager of buildings over a long period, as the representative of the landlord. I can see no circumstance in which that would have given the opportunity to exercise leverage over the tenant. I cannot see how, in the contractual situation between tenants and landlords of the scale we are talking about—I am not talking about individual citizens renting a house, when sometimes the contracts are not so even—any real or perceived conflict of interest is likely to arise. More importantly, I guess, I am advised that that is also the Auditor-General's view.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister says that that is the Auditor-General's view. I accept the Minister's word and I accept the Auditor-General's view, but what I would ask the Minister to ascertain is whether it was the Auditor-General who set out to negotiate the rental of these premises from this particular landlord at this particular location, or whether it was something that the Government arranged for the Auditor-General and is the Auditor-General, in effect, saying, `I will accept the situation. I am sufficiently strong to be able to stand up to my landlord and I will not be overborne by the landlord'. That is the first part of the question: was it the Auditor-General's actions or was it the Government's actions?

PARA.TAB: Secondly, notwithstanding the Auditor-General's personal view, does Senator McMullan not see that there are problems? Does he not see that there may be future political problems? If the Auditor-General comes down with a report in relation to some Government activity when the Labor Party is in government but the report does not seem to us in opposition to be as strongly worded as it should be, we will be tempted to think that in some way or other the office of the Auditor-General is not being carried out, for some reason which we do not understand. All I am asking the honourable senator is whether, from his point of view, he does not see that there is a conflict of interest?

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Parliamentary Secretary answers that, perhaps he could say whether he thinks that the real issue is not whether a particular party occupies a building but whether the lease is made as a fair commercial lease. That sets out the entitlements of both the landlord and the tenant. Is it within his contemplation, in these days when a tenant can be in a very strong position in setting out a lease, that that might be to the advantage of the tenant rather than the landlord? Does he think that a lease establishes the rules between the landlord and tenant? As has been pointed out, for someone as powerful as the Government, the lease is often made in favour of the tenant. Once the lease has been established, that is really the end of the matter. It is hard to see how a landlord can influence a tenant once the lease is made. Maybe once the lease came up for renewal there could be some influence; other than that, it would seem to be—
—Well, you've answered your own question, then.

—But this is the question I am asking—whether he thinks these are all matters to be considered and whether some of the leases that the Government wants to put out these days are fairly oppressive of the landlord rather than the tenant. He might want to look at some of the leases that governments put out these days to see what I mean. It makes many a solicitor who is acting for the landlord think long and hard and work late into the night to get some sort of reasonable deal from the Government these days. I wonder whether the Parliamentary Secretary has thought about those sorts of things.

—I respond to Senator Lewis's points first. With regard to the question of whose initiative this matter was, if that is not clear from the documents which have already been sought I will seek extra information because I think it is a relevant question. I expect it to be disclosed in the documents Senator Bishop has sought. If it is not, I will make sure that some further information is provided that establishes that point.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the overlapping points between Senator Lewis and Senator Cooney, I can only reiterate that which I said in response to the first question: it is not my experience as a representative of a building owner, both in Perth and in the ACT, with both public and private tenants, that this put the landlord in a commercial property development in such a powerful position in relation to tenants that one could exercise influence over them.

Certainly, in my experience, the landlord was rather more enthusiastic than the tenant about the renewal of the lease, and rather more concerned about the commercial consequences of the renewal, for obvious reasons. The interest payments go on. The renewal is, therefore, fundamental to the financial viability of the commercial developer. I do not see the problems, real or perceived. I do not know anything about this lease but, assuming it is a standard government lease, it will have all those protections, as such leases have always done in the past. There is no reason to indicate that it will be other than a standard government property lease whereby the rights of the Commonwealth, as tenant, are very adequately and appropriately protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary will understand that if, at some stage or other during the Australian National Audit Office's occupation of premises owned by the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party in some way or other feel unhappy about some aspect of an Auditor-General's report, the Liberal and National parties may feel that there is some sort of closeness that ought not to exist between the Labor Party, on the one hand, and the National Audit Office, on the other hand.

PARA.TAB: I say to the Auditor-General, through the Parliamentary Secretary, that the Auditor-General ought to rethink what he is doing because of that smell which undoubtedly will arise. Whether there is any reason for it, whether the lease is as pure as the driven snow, and whether the negotiations are at arm's length and all the rest of it, at some stage or other the Liberal and National Parties will be feeling that they are unhappy with some aspect of the Auditor's report, and their temptation will be to suspect that something is happening that ought not to be happening. I just ask the Secretary to appreciate that that will be our position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just ask the honourable senator, while he is thinking about that, to think about this proposition. There is much merit, as there always is, in what Senator Lewis says; and he is saying that the proximity between the Australian National Audit Office and the party headquarters is a problem. Does he think that, in those circumstances, it might be a good idea that officers of government be separated from any organisation, whether it be a political party, or the National Farmers Federation, or anybody else? Does he think it might be a good idea if those buildings were, say, a mile from those headquarters? Perhaps the people who work in the Australian National Audit Office should not buy their sandwiches where other people do, as well? Does he think it might be a good idea that they do not go to the same parties together? Does the Parliamentary Secretary think that would be a way out of this problem?

—Those were two excellent contributions which need no enhancement from me. I understand that Senator Lewis is essentially putting his views on the record after our response. I respect the views. I do not share them, but I respect them; and I thank Senator Cooney for his generous assistance.

—There is a big difference between the positions of a lessor and of a lessee, as Senator McMullan said, when lease renewals come up. Clearly, the tenant is in a strong position then and the lessor is sweating on the fact that he will renew the lease. But that is not an issue that comes to pass with a 15-year lease. Such leases are becoming the norm, rather than the exception, in the major capital cities of Australia. Only a few years ago five-year leases were about the longest term lease one would get. They have become the norm because of the massive incentives that landlords have had to pay. That is not the case in the Canberra office market, which is a very unusual market dominated by government.

PARA.TAB: A tenant paying, as the Parliamentary Secretary has said, a rent—a gross rental, from what I can understand—of $1.68m a year for an area of 6,000 square metres is what any property developer anywhere in Australia would consider to be an extremely plumb tenant, a fantastic deal to get hold of. What we have to look at is that that lease is for 15 years, which even in terms of the Perth office market or the Sydney office market—where we have massive oversupplies—is an extremely long lease. There are often good reasons for that. But a 15-year lease really is just gold for a developer or a property investor; it is just like solid gold. Having a government tenant on a 15-year lease is like winning lotto.

In that scenario, where there is a 15-year lease, the rent reviews become very important and that is where the relationship between the lessor and the lessee becomes important. I think it is important that the Senate be informed as to how often there are rent reviews. I would like this recorded for the benefit of the Senate and for the benefit of the people of Australia. It is the taxpayer who is giving this gift to the ALP. I would also like to know the terms of those rent reviews, whether they are based on the market or whether they are linked to a CPI. Also, is there some sort of cap on those rent reviews? How will they be negotiated and how will they be determined? I think it is an important matter because the lessor with a 15-year lease has the lessee over a barrel.

I think the important political point, the important policy point and the important point of principle is that not only should these sorts of deals be fair and equitable, they must also be seen to be fair and equitable. I think that most people would be horrified to know that the Australian taxpayer will be a captive tenant of the Australian Labor Party for the next 15 years, plus there is a five-year renewal. It does not matter how well worded the lease is or to what extent the whole deal seems to be at arm's length, the concept of a political party, a major Australian political party, being the landlord of a captive government tenant will stink a little.

In Western Australia massive construction is being undertaken by the Superannuation Board, flowing from deals that were negotiated through the heady days of the 1980s—deals that I do not need to go into now because they are well publicised and well understood. Those buildings are basically being paid for, and underwritten, by the taxpayer of Western Australia and they are attracting major government tenants at a time when there are a number of vacancies in buildings constructed by the private sector.

So, again, the taxpayer is having to bail out the Labor Government in Western Australia because it has entered into silly commercial decisions. In some contexts, the situation in Western Australia can be compared favourably with what is happening here in Canberra with this deal. At least there it was a quasi-government agency, the State Government Insurance Office or the State Government Superannuation Board, ostensibly leasing a commercial building, the Government would argue, at arm's length, to some of the major tenants there. Here the Australian Labor Party is the developer and the owner of the building and the Australian National Audit Office or, in other words, the Australian taxpayer is paying this $1.68m starting rental. That is obviously to be reviewed fairly regularly for the next 15 years.

I think it is the sort of deal that the Australian taxpayer should be rightly concerned about; it is the sort of deal that should not go on. I think the ALP is being stupid for doing it because I think it is inviting a political reaction. In terms of principle, political parties should not lease office space to government departments. I think that is the principle we should stick by. I share Senator Bishop's view that, if the Liberal Party has done it in the past it is wrong; if the Democrats do it, it is wrong; if the Labor Party does it, it is wrong. It is as simple as that. It is a bad principle: it is bad philosophy and bad policy. The Australian Labor Party has made a mistake, and it is a mistake that the Australian people should frown upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were some questions within Senator Campbell's contribution but I think some of those questions are in the purview of the Department of Administrative Services. I will ask Senator McMullan to respond when he wishes to do so.
—I am happy to wait or to respond to Senator Campbell's points now, whichever Senator Short would prefer.

—I support very strongly Senator Campbell's comments. I think the points he has raised are extremely important, and I guess we will find the answers to some of them when we get these lease documents. I presume we are getting them.
—I have asked the Minister.

—With due respect to Senator McMullan, I think it is not a matter of asking the Minister, it is a matter of the Committee requiring that documentation before it will be prepared to approve the appropriations for this Department. We are not in the Minister's hands on that, I am afraid. We are saying—and Senator Bishop has already said this—that we will defer approval of these appropriations until such time as all this information, which is highly relevant, is available.

PARA.TAB: In that context, I want to support very strongly the points Senator Campbell made. They are extremely pertinent. I want to add another question; I am not certain whether it has been asked or not. I want to know whether the National Audit Office did seek, of its own volition, to move to the Parliamentary Triangle or whether it was suggested to it by someone else—perhaps by the Department of Finance or someone else. Do we have an answer to that question?

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been raised in some detail, and I have assured Senator Lewis that if there are any documents available relating to that I will make them available. My advice is that the Audit Office initiated the request; and, as the honourable senator would know, it was supported in that by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which also said that it should be in the Parliamentary Triangle. I think it is quite correct; but irrespective of whether it is correct or not, that was the view it expressed.

PARA.TAB: I come back to some of the points raised by Senator Campbell. He picked up the fact that I had referred only to the renewal situation. I raised that only because it had been explicitly raised with me. It is certainly not the only point in the relationship. I responded to a specific query with regard to the circumstances that arose at renewal. There are, as I am aware, a large number of other points in the relationship. I am also aware that the Commonwealth has a very powerful position as tenant in the ACT and negotiates very favourable rents for itself.

This principle that political parties should not be landlords is a very new one. For the last 25 years at least political parties, starting with the National Party, have been landlords for the Commonwealth in Canberra. I cannot give the exact date, but it certainly goes back before 1972. I think there probably were some eyebrows raised when it was first done for McEwen House. I am not aware of that but, given that that was the first time, there probably were some queries. The Hansard would indicate that; I do not know. I have to say that there has never been any indication that anything untoward has occurred, nor would I have expected there to be.

Whatever political differences I might have had with the National Party from time to time, it would never have occurred to me that they would use improperly their position as landlord of whichever government bodies have been within their building from time to time. It has certainly never been indicated in all those 25 years or so that anybody has raised the slightest concern that that should be the case. It has never arisen with regard to the Labor Party; and the Liberal Party—quite reasonably, from my point of view—has also expressed an interest in supplying such office accommodation to the Government. I do not make that point to embarrass the Liberal Party, because I think that they are perfectly entitled to do that.

What the Australian public is entitled to know is that these are legitimate commercial operations. Within Canberra, as the honourable senator would know, there are a large number of national organisations, of which political parties are a very small proportion, which develop properties in Canberra as part of the development of the national capital and which lease space in those buildings, not always to government but predominantly to government because it is the largest tenant in the ACT. That has been the case for more than 20 years. It remains the case, and in all that time there has been no concern expressed.

There are two separate issues here. One is whether political parties should be landlords to the Commonwealth. The history of that is fairly clear and I do not regard it as even a matter of controversy, let alone difficulty. The second question is whether there is something peculiar and special in the relationship between the Audit Office and the political party. That is Senator Lewis's point, and Senator Bishop has also referred to it. I think that is an argument quite separate and distinct from the primary one that Senator Campbell was referring to. I have expressed my views about it, and I am confident that the independence and integrity of the Audit Office will not be in any way undermined, nor would this Auditor-General or any subsequent one allow it to be.

I just wanted to distinguish the two issues. Senator Short and Senator Campbell were referring to the second, Senator Lewis and Senator Bishop to the first. We need to keep them separate, although they are both properly before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make my point quite clear. I make a distinction between the Australian National Audit Office and any other government department. The case Senator Campbell put is a very sustainable case, but this is even worse. It is the Australian National Audit Office, which holds a very special position in the scheme of governance as we have it. It is the linchpin between accountability for the expenditure of government funds and accountability of those funds to the Parliament. The Auditor-General has to be, like Caesar's wife, above suspicion, and to have him as a tenant of the landlord of the Australian Labor Party is unsuitable.

PARA.TAB: I was making the point a little earlier on, and I am going to make it strongly again, that the Australian Labor Party has shown itself not to be a fit and proper landlord for a body such as the Australian National Audit Office. It has shown that senior Ministers are involved in sleazy deals. We could have the likes of a Symons being the broker. We have seen what underhanded methods the Labor Party will stoop to in order to gain a political advantage.

The Australian National Audit Office must be above any of that sleaze, and it cannot be in the same premises as the Australian Labor Party: a little drinky-poos after work, little words being exchanged. I am not in any way impugning the high integrity of the Australian National Audit Office people; they hold their jobs with rigour and they do them well. But I have heard around the traps, as others have, that the Government is not happy with the Auditor-General. He is a bit too harsh on it. It would like a tamer one. What better way than to put the Audit Office in the home ground?

I make the point strongly: there is a distinction between the Australian National Audit Office and any other government department, but the idea that that Office could be under the auspices, in terms of landlord and tenant, of the Australian Labor Party, with its record of sleaze and corruption, is just not on.

Let us go to very specific questions about the lease. First, has the lease been signed? Second, what is the average length of a lease between a government department and any other landlord? Third, why was the area of Barton-Parkes-Griffith-Forrest chosen?

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?
—By DAS.
—In that advertisement?

—In that advertisement. Fourth, what are the comparative rentals to be paid between the area advertised, Barton-Parkes-Griffith-Forrest, and other commercial buildings in all areas of Canberra? I think all of us who come from large cities understand that nowhere is very far away in this town. Fifteen minutes is not a long way. Fifth, what dispute provisions are proposed for the lease, if it has not been signed, or are contained in the lease, if it has been signed? Sixth, what provision is built in for increase in annual rent?

PARA.TAB: I have worked out that the Labor Party is going to benefit from this cosy little deal to the tune of $1.68m per year—not allowing for any increments. If that is taken over 15 years, it comes to about $18m—taxpayers' money to the Australian Labor Party. Then we add in the increases in rental over that period—and what have we got? A pipeline to the Mint. I wonder how the Labor Party can say that it wants full disclosure when it has got little deals like this one going. Will that turn up in its files? I bet it will not. I would like those very specific questions asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me return in a moment to the last point that was raised, about the amount of money, et cetera. First, let me go to the specific questions, most of which are matters for the Department of Administrative Services. I am advised that an agreement for lease, or a document to that effect, has been signed; those are the words I have—
—Say that again.
—I am advised that an agreement for a lease has been signed.
—That means your lease has not been signed.

—I am trying to be very careful in my wording; I am giving the honourable senator only the information that has been given to me. The documentation that is being presented will make, I think, the significance of it more clear. But I can convey to the honourable senator only the information that is conveyed to me. Those matters are primarily, of course, as I understand it, matters for DAS or—
—Has the lease been signed?

—I am just trying to be careful in the words. That concept of an agreement for a lease is not a concept with which I am familiar, and the extent to which that means one is committed to the lease is not clear to me from that piece of information.
—I will ask you in a few minutes about how that can be broken, but it is not the lease itself.

—I just have to say that the relationship between the two documents is not clear. It would be irresponsible of me to say unequivocally yes or no because the information I have is not sufficiently clear to make—
—Well, make it clear; ask him.
—How does the honourable senator think I got the information? That is the information he gave me.

—Wait a minute. The situation is that that is the information available to me. The other five matters are clearly matters in the contract. Some of them are not; three of them are matters for Department of Administrative Services—about average length, choice of particular areas and comparative rentals. I am sure that, if the honourable senator were to ask, at the appropriate time, the Department of Administrative Services could provide that information.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop emphasised that nowhere is far from anywhere in Canberra, and compared to Sydney and Melbourne it is certainly true. If the thrust of that was that there should be more emphasis on decentralisation of Commonwealth office accommodation in Canberra out of the CBD and the Parkes areas into the town centres, I support that; and I have supported it on several occasions, both publicly and in discussions with any department which might come across my path.

In regard to the National Audit Office, we have got a specific request from the Parliament—from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts—that it should be in the Parliamentary Triangle. I think it is in a somewhat different position from many of those others who, in my view, should not be in the Parliamentary Triangle; and I have expressed that view to them. Some of them already are. It is probably sensible that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet should be, but for the Industries Commission, the Australian Taxation Office and the others I do not think it is anywhere near so significant. I share some of the implied concern that Senator Bishop raises, but I do not think it relates to the Audit Office. It has a special relationship to the Parliament and the Parliament has asked that that be reflected in its geographic location. So it is only appropriate that that should take place.

The answer to the question with regard to dispute provisions and rent review provisions will be, I assume, in the rental documents which I am seeking from the Minister. Senator Short remarked that it is not for me to say that I am seeking them. To that I will just say, as I said to Senator Bishop, that I cannot give guarantees. It is not within my power to give them. It is no good my saying yes, I will present them. They are not my documents. I am seeking them. I have asked the Minister to provide them. It is no good my saying yes, I will do X, because I cannot guarantee to do it. I am trying to do that and I am telling the Senate that which it is in my power to do. I cannot do other.

Notwithstanding the fairly shonky arithmetic that came out from Senator Bishop, it is nevertheless a lot of money we are talking about. Anybody who heard or read the outline that has been given might think that this was a net benefit of some very large amount going to the Australian Labor Party. Yet anybody who has the slightest knowledge of the commercial situation in Australia, now or at any time, would realise that that is a gross figure against which a very large amount of costs have to be borne. I have been involved as landlord on behalf of a property owner for many, many years. In several of those circumstances but not all, the tenants were government tenants. Some of them were private sector or trade union and interest groups, other professional bodies, et cetera. There is a vast difference between a large cash flow of rental income and a large profit. In many of the instances the buildings were in their early years. I think that most buildings in their early years, because of repayment requirements on borrowings and start-up costs, make a loss. If that were not the case, the situation for many of our business people who invested significantly in commercial property and those financial institutions which supported them would be vastly different from that which we find ourselves in today.
With regard to the disclosure provisions, Senator Bishop's suspicions are entirely ill-founded. There is no property owned by the Australian Labor Party. It is owned by a company—

TALK.START.PARA: —You own 2KY. You own 2HD.
—Nationally. What happens in New South Wales I am not sure.
—And I'll bet you're grateful you don't!
—Let me make the situation clear, because it actually answers your question about this building. I do know something about the legal situation concerning—
—What about Sussex Street?
—Thank you for your assistance. I do know something about the national secretariat of the Labor Party and the way its commercial operations work.
—I'll bet you do.

—Yes, I do. There is a company called John Curtin House Pty Ltd, which owns the building. If it were to make a donation to the Labor Party it would be a disclosable donation under the Act. So if any money—
—And if somebody else has made a donation to it, is it disclosable?
—Yes.
—Who is the shareholder for John Curtin House?

—The Labor Party owns it. I am simply saying it is not income that can flow into the election account but can be in any way hidden. Any money that flows through John Curtin House to the election account is disclosable. Senator Bishop raised a point about this being a mechanism for avoiding disclosure. Quite clearly it is not. Money has been transferred from John Curtin House Pty Ltd to the Labor Party and it has been disclosed.

—And there is that nice little warehousing deal you can do with the trade union movement. But that is another issue. I want to concentrate on, firstly, the Labor Party as a suitable tenant; secondly, the Australian National Audit Office being in a separate category; and, thirdly, the amount of cash that is going to be milked from the taxpayer to the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: I want to go particularly to this agreement to lease that has been entered into. I understand from your answer that an agreement to lease has in fact been signed. I want to know what terms and conditions are yet to be fulfilled under the agreement to lease, and I want to know what the penalty is if the lease does not go ahead and we find more suitable premises for the Australian National Audit Office.

The Auditor-General is seen to be doing a first-class job. The number of complaints you hear about him from the Government of the day probably means he is doing his job exceedingly well. I hear that the Labor Party does not like the Auditor-General and does not like the Audit Office. I trust that the Labor Party is, nonetheless, going to reappoint the Auditor-General when his term comes up. If it were not to do that, of course, lots of questions might flow from that aside from this question we are examining now. Those two particular points I want to know: what terms and conditions are yet to be fulfilled and what penalty is to be paid if the lease does not proceed?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some advice, through these officers, from Australian Property Group, with regard to some of these matters, but it does not go to all of them. Some may also be a little useful with regard to previous questions. I will try to look at that which may relate to other matters that have been raised.

PARA.TAB: To reinforce a point I was making earlier, the Commonwealth representative with regard to the lease is the State Manager of Australian Property Group in the ACT. The agreement to lease was signed by the principal legal officer of the Attorney-General's Department. I have advice that goes to one of Senator Bishop's questions, but it does not answer the second, about which I do not have any information at this stage. So long as the building complies with the conditions, the actual lease will be completed and signed. There is, subject to that, a legal obligation to sign the lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —That doesn't tell us a damned thing.
—It tells us one piece of information, but it does not say anything about what happens if one breaks the lease, and I do not have any information on that.
—It is this agreement. I want to know what the penalty is if you break the agreement.

—I understand that, but what happens if we breach that legal obligation of the Commonwealth is not clear to me from any document I have. It is not a matter in the hands of the Audit Office, of course; it is the Australian Property Group and the Attorney-General's Department that would know that. I do not know the answer.

—With respect, it will not do to simply push it from pillar to post, from this department to that department, so that whoever we have here with us can say, `I do not know. They know. They are not going to be called' and so on. That just will not do either.

PARA.TAB: There was one point I wanted to deal with before my colleague, Senator Short, puts a question. I am going to foreshadow now that I will move that we defer questioning on this issue until I get the answer to those six questions, and leave the matter until such time as we receive a copy of that agreement for lease and the proposed lease, so that we may see exactly where we stand. I think the question of the average lease entered into is a most important question.

I want to go to the point you raised earlier about trying to blame it all on the Public Accounts Committee. Here is the Public Accounts Committee's report No. 296: a big, thick, hefty report. The main recommendations of this report were to reinforce the fact that the Auditor-General is completely and utterly independent. We said, firstly, that we wanted him to become a statutory authority; secondly, that we wanted an audit committee of the Parliament to oversee his terms and conditions and the appropriations he gets every year; and, thirdly, that we needed new audit legislation.

We have been asking for these things now for something like three years; and still we have not seen the legislation, still we have no commitment on the parliamentary audit committee, and still we have no commitment on the question of whether or not the Auditor-General becomes a statutory authority so that he has more independence and is seen to be above other departments.

Somewhere in here there might be a word about the desirability of having the Audit Office in the Parliamentary Triangle in a new building because its accommodation in the previous building was thought not to be satisfactory. But we sure as hell did not say that it ought to become the tenant of the sleazy ALP. We did not say that the Australian Labor Party ought to be in a position to be the landlord of the Australian National Audit Office; and to try to say that the whole justification for this rental is based on a recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is to mislead this Parliament in a way which is simply not acceptable. But I should not be surprised: the Labor Party is very good at it; it has had lots of practice recently.

TALK.START.PARA: —You throw that allegation around with such gay abandon.

—Really? I am going to find this specific recommendation in here and put it into context. In the meantime, I know my colleague Senator Short has a question to ask, and then I am going to move that we defer until we get the information.

—I am not going to allow all that to go without being responded to, Mr Chairman. I do apologise for taking up the time of the Committee because most of what Senator Bishop said was right off the subject we are discussing. But to pretend that I said that the principal reason for this being done is that it was a recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is, I think, tantamount to misleading the Senate. I certainly did not say anything of the sort.
—It is in this bit of paper here.

—Of course it is in the bit of paper; that is what I quoted. I did not write it; I read it and I tabled it. To say that I am misleading the Senate when I table somebody else's document is the most preposterous proposition in the history of the Parliament in the twentieth century. It is absurd.
—You have gone on to say you did it because it was the Public Accounts Committee's recommendation.

—I did not say anything of the sort, but it is nevertheless true, as I am advised, that there is such a recommendation. As I said to Senator Short, and I thought it was a valid point, a lot of people want to be in the Parliamentary Triangle. I disagree with most of them being here, and have said so and will continue to do so. But the Audit Office has a special relationship with the Parliament which, as I am advised, was reflected in the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. If that is the case it seems reasonable, but we would probably have made the same decision, that it is a body that should be in the triangle, were it not a recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, because it seems like a good idea.I think we should be kicking a lot of people out of the triangle—but not the Audit Office.

PARA.TAB: Could I just say that nobody is pretending that that is the only reason. If the Joint Committee made that recommendation, which I am advised it did in that report, it seems like a sensible recommendation because there is a good case for it being there, as there is a good case for some other government instrumentalities being in the triangle. But there are too many people who want to be in the Civic area or the Barton-Parkes area for the commercial good sense of the Commonwealth. I oppose many of them, but not this one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Bishop formally moves that this matter be deferred until the required material is available, a move which of course I totally support, I just want to ask a couple of questions of Senator McMullan, both in his capacity as handling this and also bearing in mind his position as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and therefore being directly associated with one of the two key departments with responsibility for the proper management of the finances of the Commonwealth, namely, the Treasury and the Department of Finance.

PARA.TAB: I preface the question I am going to ask by pointing out that, as well as handling the Bills before the Committee today, Senator McMullan is also the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and therefore has a direct interest in one of the two departments, the other one being the Department of Finance, that have the greatest responsibility for the protection and management of the public purse. The Department of Finance really is the custodian of the public purse, along with the Audit Office. They each play a unique role and have a unique importance, therefore, in the proper management of government, especially financial administration. I link the Treasury in with that as well.

What I want to know from Senator McMullan is whether the Department of Finance or the Minister for Finance was consulted in relation to the proposed move by the Audit Office into this new Labor Party owned building. If they were not consulted, why not? If they were consulted, does this move have their concurrence?
