TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Finance was involved in the usual way, which is that there is a requirement for budgetary consideration of any extra rental cost incurred. This would be for any instrumentality, not just for one within the Department of Finance. Before it could agree to enter into such a contract, it would have to have the approval of the Department of Finance to commit the Commonwealth to spending the money. So, to that extent, in the normal way, the Department of Finance would have been aware of the arrangement overall, but the question of who owned the building was not a factor that the Department of Finance would have been involved with. That is a matter fundamentally for the Australian Property Group, which negotiates leases on behalf of the Commonwealth. To the best of my knowledge, the Minister for Finance was not informed, and in the normal course of events he would not be, with regard to such matters as the entering into of rental agreements and the negotiation of such commercial contracts. As I am advised, it is not a matter usually drawn to the attention of the Minister and it was not on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: As to the proposal to defer consideration of this matter, I do not know what the Parliament's decision about that will be, and that will be a binding decision with which we will all have to abide. I just want to take this opportunity to say how strongly I disagree with any such proposal. We have advised the Opposition, all the other parties and independent senators that the Commonwealth needs the Appropriation Bills passed today, and it will be an extremely serious matter if, with regard to this, a decision is made by the Senate that might in some way obstruct the capacity of the Senate to pass this Appropriation Bill today and therefore lead to problems in the provision of the necessary financial resources to different arms of the Government to maintain their operations.

I ask honourable senators opposite to think about the significance of what they are proposing. There is no question of my seeking by that to back away from my intention to provide all the documents that I have undertaken to provide and to press the Minister for Finance to provide those others which are not in my power to provide but which I wish him to provide. I am seeking to avoid that, but I make the point firmly that it is a serious matter that honourable senators opposite are proposing and I think we need to keep the nature of the issue and the nature of the response in some sense of proportion. I put on the record the Government's very serious concern about a proposal for such an adjournment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond to a couple of those points. I find it extraordinary that the Minister for Finance, the prime elected representative custodian of the public purse, has not been involved, consulted or asked to express a view on what is so obviously a highly sensitive and contentious issue. I just put it on the record that I find that extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator McMullan to obtain views from the Minister for Finance and his Department on the propriety of the Audit Office occupying premises owned by the Labor Party or, as we have said, by any other party. It has no direct responsibility for the Audit Office, but a great involvement; it is part of the same camp, the most important financial custodian camp in the nation. It is incumbent on the Government to let the Senate have the views of the Minister for Finance and his Department on that matter. I am amazed that no such view has apparently been sought or expressed at this stage.

Senator Bishop will no doubt wish to comment on this as well, but I refer to the Minister's remarks about the seriousness of the matter that the Opposition, through Senator Bishop, is proposing. The Opposition is proposing to defer further consideration of this until the necessary documents are provided to enable the Senate to take an eyes-open view on these matters. It is very serious to propose that this Senate should pass Appropriation Bills on important and sensitive issues, issues that go right to the propriety of government, without the Senate being provided with the necessary information to be able to take a fully considered judgment. That is where the seriousness of the matter really lies. Senator McMullan is trying to shoehorn appropriations through the Senate—and through the Parliament—including matters about which there are, at this stage, the gravest questions of propriety going to the whole core of decency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which appropriation in here refers to it? Tell me one.

—The honourable senator knows what we are talking about. We are talking about the Audit Office; we are talking about a contract; we are talking about a deal between the Labor Party—the Government—and a major, fundamentally important agency, the custodian of the public purse. The honourable senator knows as well as I do that that is a very serious matter indeed.

PARA.TAB: Let me just comment on the honourable senator's other point, about why it is serious from his point of view that this matter not be deferred. It has been said that it is fundamentally important that the appropriations are passed today. My advice from the Department of Finance is that that is not correct. There is no awareness—this is subject to confirmation—on the Department's part that major difficulties would be experienced if these Bills were not passed until early next week. So before that claim is made, I think it should be checked out and the Senate advised of the basis for the honourable senator's assertion. Otherwise, one will just automatically get—rightly—the impression that honourable senators opposite are trying, as I say, to shoehorn this thing through. They are blackmailing the Senate into having to pass legislation today, which I understand is not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just so we understand: at page 20 of the program performance statements there is a request for an additional appropriation of nearly $10m for running costs. Until we see the documentation, we do not know when it was signed, what fee was paid, and what running costs have been paid out of this additional appropriation. There are a whole lot of things that need to be answered.

PARA.TAB: Just so we understand what we are really talking about, I have drawn attention to the fact that I consider the ALP to be specifically unsuitable as a landlord for the Australian National Audit Office. I have said that there is adequate evidence on the record as to why that is so. However, I also made the point right at the beginning that I do not care which political party it is; the Australian National Audit Office ought not to be a tenant of any political party. The Australian National Audit Office has to be above suspicion, like Caesar's wife, Calpurnia. It is not above suspicion to have the Australian National Audit Office in the building owned, operated and, I presume, occupied by the Australian Labor Party or any other political party.

I said that I drew a particular distinction between the Australian National Audit Office and any other organ or department of government. There is an arguable case that the rule should apply across the board, but today we are not discussing any other agency or organ of government: we are discussing very specifically the Australian National Audit Office. I said that I was going to take a look at the report of the Public Accounts Committee entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. The last recommendation in that report is recommendation 78, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office plan for a new building—
I stress: a new building—
either within the Parliamentary Triangle or on State Circle adjacent to the new Parliament House, and that the building be called Audit House.

The Public Accounts Committee did not recommend that the Australian National Audit Office become a tenant, whether of the Australian Labor Party or anybody else. It said that the Australian National Audit Office should be granted its own building, to be called Audit House, to draw attention to the fact that the Auditor-General is just what our report says he is—the ally of the people and the Parliament. It is through the Auditor-General, to the Parliament, to the people, that the accountability for the expenditure of taxpayers' money is made available. This arrangement between the Labor Party and the Australian National Audit Office, through whoever has done the negotiations, is simply not acceptable.

PARA.TAB: I am going to move that we defer this matter until we have received an answer to the six questions I asked Senator McMullan but, more particularly, until we sight at least this so-called agreement to lease and see what conditions remain to be fulfilled and what penalty would be incurred if that agreement were broken. I think the Committee is entitled to sight that because the Committee ought to make a decision as to whether or not this agreement to lease should be broken and any penalty paid. This matter is of great importance. This is an agreement covering 15 years, with an option for a further five years, with a refurbishment of the building at the end of 10 years; and then there will be an agreement to exercise the option.

These are very serious issues. Yes, in the course of this debate colourful phrases have perhaps been used. But I would have thought that, at the end of the day, those people on the other side, those people who agree that the question of the integrity of Parliament is the most important question here, would agree that it is not possible for the Australian National Audit Office to be a tenant of the Australian Labor Party. Bear in mind that the Public Accounts Committee referred to `a building of its own called Audit House'. This briefing paper, which I suppose is what Senator McMullan tabled and which is called Provision of Office Accommodation for the Australian National Audit Office, Barton, simply does not meet, either in spirit or in word, the recommendation of the Public Accounts Committee. I move:

That further discussion on this item be deferred until such time as that information is laid before the Senate and the Senate has the opportunity of sighting it, scrutinising it and making a decision about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. I seek your guidance. I would like to indicate to the Senate that I and a number of other senators are members of the National Executive of the Australian Labor Party, and either directors of John Curtin House Pty Ltd or prospective directors. We would like to indicate to the Senate our involvement in this matter to that extent. I seek your guidance, through this point of order, as to how it would be appropriate that I do that, before the Senate votes on the motion that Senate Bishop has moved.
—Senator Faulkner, you can declare an interest—and you have declared an interest—but you are able to vote in any division that we might have.
—I indicate to you that I do that on my own behalf, and of course there are a number of other senators who find themselves in a similar situation.

—On the point of order: could you tell me if there is a precedent on this matter? Clearly the Australian Labor Party does have a vested interest in this matter. Do we have a precedent that says that members of the Labor Party are entitled to vote on something from which they are going to derive a benefit?

—I do not think that Senator Faulkner is going to derive a benefit. In fact, he might derive something less than a benefit by having to spend some time on it. I do not have a precedent in front of me, but I would rule that if Senator Faulkner has declared an interest that would be recorded in the Journals of the Senate.
—On the point of order: I may not have indicated clearly what I intended, so let me spell it out. I indicate an interest, but not a pecuniary interest in this matter.

—Could I speak to the point of order as well, Mr Chairman? In the brief period I have been in the Senate, there have been ample precedents. A number of senators, particularly those with farming interests, quite properly have developed a practice of disclosing an interest when matters come up that affect their farming establishments. The most recent example—and I hasten to say I am not criticising him, he did absolutely the right thing—was Senator Panizza speaking on a motion recently with regard to a crop which he apparently grows on his farm. He quite properly declared his interest and quite properly voted. I do not want anything I say to be seen as a criticism of Senator Panizza—he was pursuing the proprieties, as Senator Faulkner is—but there is ample precedent in that regard.
—Yes, Senator McMullan, thank you very much. You have prompted my memory and I can remember the incident quite well—and other similar incidents.

—On the point of order, Mr Chairman: of course, I abide by your ruling on this, but I cannot let go the comment that there was no pecuniary interest involved in this. There is a pecuniary interest involved in this matter, either directly or indirectly, by every member of the Labor Party. What we are talking about is a deal which is going to bring the Labor Party $20m plus over the next 15 years; and in some financial sense, in some way that will benefit every member of the Labor Party. So, with great respect—and, as I say, I accept your ruling—I think it is a fact that there is a pecuniary interest, directly or indirectly, for every member of the Labor Party.
—Senator Bishop, do you have a copy of the motion?
—Yes.
—It would be helpful to the Chair.

—I have moved that we defer discussion on this item until such time as the answers to the questions that I asked of Senator McMullan and the documentation, including the agreement for lease, are tabled before this Senate; and that we defer discussion on this item until that is received.
—I will seek some further advice. I think I know the answer, but I will be careful.I am advised that a motion such as that is put without debate, so I will put the motion.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I do not want to debate the motion; I want to speak on the question of pecuniary interest.
—On the declaration of interest, yes.

—The reason I have a problem, as does my colleague Senator Short, with Senator Faulkner's assertion that there is no pecuniary interest to each and every one of the members of the Labor Party is this: the Labor Party, like the Liberal Party, is an unincorporated body. If people want to sue the Australian Labor Party, for instance, they have to sue every member of it. So there is no corporate entity, as it were.
—John Curtin House Pty Ltd.

—Senator McMullan tells me—I do not know; I have not seen the title—that John Curtin House Pty Ltd is the owner of the premises and the building. I wonder how that fits with the terms and conditions of the allocation of property, which I understand is given free for such development. I would be interested to know the terms and conditions upon which the lot of land opposite the National Press Club was given to the Australian Labor Party—how much it cost, what the rental is and so on. On my information, the Labor Party is spending $80m developing that site. I want to know where that money comes from.
—This is supposed to be a point of order.

—On the point of order, this is pecuniary interest matter; otherwise individual senators could be called upon to finance it. If this $20m from the Australian National Audit Office is not forthcoming over that period of years, where will it get the rest of the money from? There is a very definite pecuniary interest and advantage to every honourable senator on the other side, because that is the way that some money will be used to fund their campaign, for which they will individually receive their salaries.

PARA.TAB: So there is a very specific pecuniary interest to every member of the Labor Party. I would say that that is different from the isolated case Senator McMullan cited of a farmer who grew a particular crop and received payment under legislation for that. His future as a member of this Senate would not depend on his being paid for his crop, or whatever the benefit was. In the case of the Australian Labor Party, each and every member and senator who is up for election will benefit from the money paid out of Commonwealth coffers to an organ of the Australian Labor Party.

I would say to you, Mr Chairman, that there is a very distinct difference between the two items, and I really cannot say that you could depend on that precedent. I say to you again that I think it is improper for the Government to vote on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am ruling that if an honourable senator declares an interest, that will be recorded in the Journals of the Senate. I am also ruling that that honourable senator has the right to participate in any vote, whether it be a vote on the voices or a vote by division. That is the ruling I am giving.
—On that ruling, Mr Chairman, Senator Faulkner has disclosed an interest. Is he purporting to do so on behalf of each and every member of the Labor Party in the Senate?
—I believe not.
—Even if he is—

—I am speaking on behalf of a number of my Government colleagues who are not here. There are not many Opposition or Government senators here. There are a number of my Government colleagues in a similar position to myself.

—Through you, Mr Chairman, I say to Senator Faulkner that it is not just a number of his Government colleagues but all of his Government colleagues. He has expressed his personal interest in this. I would have thought—with respect and in accordance with your ruling, Mr Chairman—that each and every Labor senator should do precisely the same.
—I am not on the National Executive.

—The question of whether Senator Coates is on the National Executive or not is irrelevant. The fact that he is a member of the Labor Party is the only criterion as to whether he has a pecuniary interest. He has a pecuniary interest in this matter, for the reasons that I and Senator Bishop have spelt out; and the question of the distinction between National Executive membership and Labor Party membership is absolutely irrelevant.
—I have made a ruling. The ruling is that honourable senators may vote either on the voices or division, as the case may be.

—I am sorry. I will have to put the point of view again, Mr Chairman. I accept the ruling but I do think it is proper that every member of the Labor Party should be asked to put on the record that he or she has a pecuniary interest because—
—It is not a pecuniary interest. Senator Faulkner did not mention a financial interest; he mentioned an interest.

—Even if it is `an interest', because of the nature of the structure of political parties, if he has an interest, so do all his colleagues have an interest. Mr Chairman, you cannot make the distinction. It is not a board of directors situation: it is, as I have explained to you, that political parties are unincorporated bodies. Every member of the political party is in exactly the same position. If Senator Faulkner has admitted he has an interest, as you have accepted, so does every other member of the Labor Party in this chamber have an interest.
—It is a very important reflection on a number of my colleagues. I would like the opportunity to say something about it, Mr Chairman, although your ruling is absolutely correct—
—It is purely voluntary for a senator to declare an interest. There is no obligation on senators, except perhaps a moral obligation if they feel that the interest is so strong.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McMullan

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to quote the relevant sentence in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: There is no Standing Order of the Senate under which a Senator can challenge a vote on the ground of pecuniary interest.

So let us get that precedent fairly clear before we go to the point of the absurdity of the proposition that a contract between John Curtin House Pty Ltd and the Australian Government involves a pecuniary interest for members of the Labor Party, beyond that of any other company which donates to a political party. The only way in which any benefit would flow, however indirectly—even in the House of Commons they say it must be an interest not shared in common with other citizens—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you not all citizens?

—That is what I am saying. I will read it later. I will not try to explain it to Senator Bishop; it is too hard for her. The situation is that the only way a member of the Labor Party, a candidate for election or whatever—other than directors who have an interest, though not a pecuniary interest, because they are not paid as such—could be said to have a pecuniary interest would be if John Curtin House Pty Ltd sought to donate to the Labor Party for the election campaign, as it does from time to time and which it discloses; as do many other companies which donate to both parties.
—It is owned by the Labor Party. The asset is the Labor Party's.
—That is really not the point.
—Order! The Chair is in the situation of having to put this motion without debate, so I am going to do so.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bishop's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the estimates for the Department of Finance. Program 5, specific payments and receipts activities, was deferred earlier, so I will move to program 5.

—The deferral of this item yesterday related to the asset sales task force, and I thank Senator McMullan for making available members of the task force in response to my request yesterday. I have several questions that I want to ask, but I will wait until he can listen to them.
—I am sorry, Senator Short. It was just a procedural matter in the chamber. Could you say that again and I will respond?
—I was just actually thanking the honourable senator for making available members of the task force as requested yesterday and saying that I have several questions.
—We won't have to divide on that! I agree with you.
—When we considered the asset sales task force in the Estimates Committee on 3 April, it was said that there had been no asset sales made this financial year to date. Is that still the situation?
—Yes.
—What was the Budget estimate for asset sales receipts for 1991-92?

—I do not have that figure immediately to hand, Senator Short, but there is no disagreement. There was a presumption in the Budget Papers that there would be revenue from asset sales that has not been achieved. In terms of the point of principal, there is no argument. I do not have the particular figure in front of me, nor is it in the documentation, which I thought would tell me what it was. But it is on the public record, as the honourable senator would know.

—I think the honourable senator will find that it is something of the order of $625m. Does the Parliamentary Secretary anticipate any revenue on asset sales being received between now and 30 June? In other words, will there be any revenue from asset sales in 1991-92?
—I do not anticipate the conclusion of any sales in that period.
—So there will be a shortfall in the Budget?
—Senator Short, I think it might be best to leave it there. It being 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody knows that the Liberal and National parties' Fightback package has created considerable excitement in the Australian community. It is certainly a collation of policies and initiatives that will ensure that at the next election the Australian community will be able adequately and properly to assess both the failures of the present Labor Government and the initiatives and proposals being put forward by Dr Hewson on behalf of the Liberal and National parties.

PARA.TAB: The Fightback package is of particular importance to people living in northern Australia. I am very pleased to note that the Northern Territory Government undertook a special program of analysing in detail the Fightback package and commissioned—I understand, with the support of the Labor Party Opposition in the Northern Territory Parliament—a major review of the Fightback initiatives. In the Northern Territory Parliament last week, the Northern Territory Treasurer, the Hon. Barry Coulter, made a major statement and tabled a number of important documents which properly analysed the Fightback proposals. I take the opportunity to seek leave to table those documents in the Senate.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, those documents are the tabling statement by the Northern Territory Treasurer, the Hon. Barry Coulter, dated Thursday, 21 May 1992, and a media release of the same date. The documents specifically referred to are, firstly, a document entitled Tax Reform: What's in it for the Territory? This is a broad assessment of the case for indirect tax reform, including the introduction of a goods and services tax and its general implications for the Northern Territory. This very considerable 72-page assessment has been conducted by Professor John Freebairn, Chairman of the Department of Economics at Monash University.

PARA.TAB: The second document is entitled The Impact of a Goods and Services Tax on the Northern Territory: Administrative and Practical Aspects. This report has been prepared by Michael Evans, a partner of the tax consulting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick of Adelaide, South Australia. Again this is a comprehensive 63-page document with a number of appendices. It certainly commands attention.

The third document is one prepared by the Northern Territory Treasurer and is a report entitled Report on the Impact on the Territory of the Fightback! Proposals. Again, this is a 45-page document which covers many aspects. I would certainly commend this document for very close scrutiny by anyone who is following the Fightback and goods and services tax debate. The fact is that a major initiative is now on the table. The table of contents from the assessment by Professor Freebairn reads as follows:
Focus;
The Present Indirect Taxes in the Northern Territory;
Present Indirect Taxes and Tax Design Principles;
The Black Economy: How big is it? Can it be taxed?
The Impact of Indirect Tax System Reform.
Broader Effects of a Tax Reform/Spending Reduction Package;
A Goods and Services Tax and Business Costs;
Impact of Tax Reform on the Northern Territory Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there are some concluding remarks.

PARA.TAB: The second document I referred to is probably the one that will affect many people and many small businesses with a lot of its detail. This is the one that looks comprehensively at the administrative and practical aspects of a goods and services tax. The table of contents for that document states:
The GST—How Does it operate?
Design Aspects that Impact on Compliance Costs
Practical Issues for N.T. Government

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a series of appendices that relate to many services that impact on government, business and families.The report by the Northern Territory Treasury underpins the major debate for Northern Australia. In its table of contents these are the chapter headings:

PARA.TAB: Fightback!—Main Elements;
Macroeconomic Effects of Fightback!
Why is the Territory Different?
Implications of Tax Changes for N.T. Industry
Implication for Northern Territory Households
Inter-Governmental Financial Relations

SPEECH.PARA: Then there is a list of tables. This study relates to how the Fightback proposals will impact on remote, regional and in particular northern Australia, and I would certainly commend it to all honourable senators and any other interested persons. It is a document that openly gives advice, makes criticisms, and comes down in very strong support of the Fightback document. I know that this will be debated in the Northern Territory Parliament, and I hope that members and senators in this place and in the Northern Territory Parliament will give it the assessment it deserves because of the initiatives it contains.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: World Environment Day: Land Management Leaflet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I gave notice of a motion concerning what I regard as a very negligent breach of ministerial responsibility. Every school in Australia has been sent, at taxpayers' expense, a kit on World Environment Day. I believe that it involves some 50,000 kits, and they were sent to 12,000 schools right around Australia. The intention was that they be used to celebrate World Environment Day on 5 June and that teachers use the material in the kits to stimulate discussion and increase students' knowledge of environmental issues.

PARA.TAB: I have not yet had time to read all the papers but I have read some, which is more than I can say for the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Ros Kelly. Mrs Kelly was forced to admit, after the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, and the shadow Minister for sustainable development and the environment, Mr Fred Chaney, brought it to her attention, that something she had endorsed she had not even bothered to read. That is an indictment of any Minister in this Parliament, and especially in the Government at the moment, where so many Ministers are forgetting to read anything about some of the little memos that are going around the place.

Other senators might have seen Mrs Kelly featured on television a few nights ago. It highlighted her success, her toughness and her rising stature. She is billed as one of the Labor Party's stars—I suggest a falling star. It is a pity Mrs Kelly does not spend a little more time on her portfolio and a little less time on her personal image and her ambitions.

Mrs Kelly endorsed this kit and accepted an invitation to launch it today without even having read it. Mrs Kelly's excuse is that it is not her fault, it is her Department's fault. Is this the latest Labor Party excuse line? We have heard Senator Richardson admitting that he did not know what his staff had received. We have had Senator Evans tell us he does not know what his Department or senior advisers are up to. Now it is Mrs Kelly's turn. She does not say `Mea culpa'; she says, `Blame it on the Department'. No doubt she will also in time take the Evans option and blame one or other of her staff.

On reading the ministerial list, I noticed that Mrs Kelly has no fewer than 14 people on her ministerial staff. Included in that list are seven advisers, two consultants and one departmental liaison officer. Yet despite all those people, despite the fact that this kit could not have been written and produced overnight, despite the fact that Mrs Kelly had personally endorsed the kit and had accepted an invitation to launch it, she admits on the morning of the launch that she has not read it.

Where does ministerial competence and responsibility start and where does it finish? Just what was it that she did endorse but did not read? Let me turn first to the page about biodiversity. This leaflet suggests:

The earth's biodiversity is under threat—mainly from land clearing for agriculture, such as intensive, single crop agriculture. In developing countries, this generally means producing cash crops for western consumers as a way of paying off debts.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no mention in these papers of what the cities do to the species range or of the pollution caused by cities and their residents' cars, gardens and indiscriminate use of water. We are told that it is all the fault of the farmers. I am trying to stand up for the farmers in this place because the Government has spent the last eight or nine years kicking them in the guts, and I do not think that is fair for the farmers of this country.

PARA.TAB: Let me move on to the leaflet on land management. Here we are told:

The earth's fertile land is disappearing at an alarming rate as forests are cut down and cash crops and modern farming methods destroy the soil. . . Until about 50 years ago, most farms were `mixed'. The average farmer produced small amounts of many different crops—perhaps growing wheat, barley, potatoes and other vegetables, and running cows, pigs, ducks and hens.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that the diagram here shows a typical English farm. It does not show a typical Australian farm. The leaflet goes on:

PARA.TAB: Farming practices today are very different. Farmers are often specialists—growing enormous amounts of just one or two types of crop. Artificial fertilisers and herbicides are used to produce the biggest crop possible—

SPEECH.PARA: I hope we do try to grow the biggest crop possible, to help with our balance of payments situation—

PARA.TAB: At first glance, this style of farming seems like a huge step forward. . . But the environmental costs of these farming practices are high, and loss of fertility, soil erosion and land degradation have occurred in many places.

SPEECH.PARA: She suggests that the diagram I have just mentioned be used to discuss farming practices in class. She tells the students that that is what is done. On that little diagram it says:

PARA.TAB: Constant use of fertiliser reduces the soil's health and structure, while increasing acidity.
Natural habitat destroyed to grow more food. Natural enemies of pests die out.
Fields without trees cause water table and salinity increases.
Animals are often kept packed into pens—they can hardly move.
Eroded fields.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is not trying to indoctrinate a new generation, I do not know what it is. We have been told that the Minister did not see this and did not even know about it. But someone in the Department must have, and should have brought it to her knowledge. They should have known that it was inaccurate, divisive, and bound to give a whole generation of children an anti-farmer bias.

PARA.TAB: Where is the departmental responsibility? Is it the intention of that Department, and indeed of the whole of the Australian Labor Party, to give farmers a kick everywhere and anywhere they can? Giving a $20 billion industry a kick, I believe, is treasonable. It is an attack on agriculture generally. I do not think that anyone in the community should take much more notice of the Minister because of the way she has behaved in this regard.

This is not the first time this sort of propaganda about farmers has been circulated, and the chances are that it will happen again, but I believe it is about time it stopped. The Minister's apologies and the duckshoving on radio this morning are not good enough. I think every kit ought to be withdrawn from the schools immediately and replaced with more accurate information.

It is all very well to say, `I have made a mistake'. That is a little like making somebody pregnant and then saying, `Well, I have made a mistake. We will change it all again'. But you cannot change it all again. The Minister's suggestion that a letter be sent to each school advising that she will not endorse it will not be worth a tinker's cuss to the people out in the community. The Minister needs to be reprimanded. She also needs to be reminded that with the perks of office come a lot of responsibility. As she is the Minister, the buck stops completely with Mrs Kelly.

I know that Senator Crane is going to say a lot more on this. He will obviously give the Western Australian perspective to it. But I believe that it is an indictment of the Government, and it is an indictment of the Minister that she has put out this blatantly incorrect propaganda, which she has now admitted is incorrect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the same subject as Senator Brownhill. I too this morning gave notice of a motion on this subject.
—You cannot discuss it, under the Standing Orders.
—I am not discussing it, I am discussing the pamphlet.
—Go for it.

—Thank you. This is indeed a tragic occasion not just for farmers but for the Australian community. It is particularly damaging for the political processes that have been developed in this country over the past 10 or 15 years in tackling the problems that have occurred—and nobody will deny that—in understanding what happens in terms of the farming process. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, put out a pamphlet which is nothing less than blatant left wing communist propaganda. Senator Coates can laugh; I hope he has seen it.

PARA.TAB: Even in this little thing about land management there are the words `down on the farm'. There is a very succinct message in that. The propaganda written on that is a total misrepresentation of the situation that exists in Australia today. It should also be rejected by the Government because it flies in the face of the Government's own Landcare program; it flies in the face of its support of the national soil conservation program; it flies in the face of the things that the various State governments have done on soil conservation since 1982. After a series of meetings, the States made amendments to various soil conservation Acts. I was heavily involved in that because it was in Western Australia that the first soil conservation Act was changed to allow certain things to happen in terms of land management and land care and the development of different skills.

In terms of managing our land, managing salinity, managing wind erosion, managing minimum tillage and a host of other new ways of operating in the farm sector, things have changed dramatically. This flies in the face of the previous Prime Minister's launching of his own landcare program, but I shall come to that in a moment.

I come back to the propaganda that has been put before us today in terms of the environment. It suggests that schools hold a special assembly on World Environment Day and invite an environmentalist or an Aboriginal elder to be the speaker. What is wrong with inviting the head of the division of resource management in the State? What is wrong with inviting some of the farmers who have carried out conservation programs and changed their farming practices? What is wrong with inviting some of the officers of the forestry departments who have been involved in on-farm plantations? What is wrong with involving some of the scientists from the agriculture departments who have been developing methods for controlling water run-off, salinity, wind erosion and a number of other things? They are people who actually know what is happening on the ground, people who will give a balanced position on these things.

In the Minister's announcement today she admitted that she had not seen the material. That seems to be a habit of Ministers of this Government in recent times. They have not seen the material, or they sign letters when they do not know what is in them, or they sign references for people when they really have no idea who those people are or what they are about.

The Minister says that she will not now launch the pamphlet. Why can the Minister not also announce that she is going to withdraw that pamphlet from every school in Australia to which it has been sent and replace it with a balanced and fair presentation? Why would a Minister want to corrupt the minds of young people who are objective, who are now in training and who wish, when they are through that process, to have jobs and become useful contributors to society? One might ask why the Minister wished to lead those young people down the garden path and give them a totally false impression.

Let us look at some of the things that have happened in land management on the farm and deal, first of all, with one of the comments made in this pamphlet that has been sent out as part of the package. It says that nutrients leach into the water table and rivers, causing algae growth. No mention is made of the fact that CSBP in Western Australia has developed a fertiliser which fixes into the soil and prevents such things from happening. No mention is made of the fact that last year in Western Australia alone farmers on water charge areas planted some 20 million trees to stop some of the movement into the streams. No mention is made of the fact that those trees will make an enormous contribution to correcting the problems that have developed because of wind erosion. No mention is made of the fact that in the year prior to that some 12 million trees were planted and many thousands of kilometres of contour banks, drainage lines and interceptor banks were put in.

There is no balance whatsoever. It just gets stuck into the poor old farmers, the graziers, or the cockies, as they are commonly known, who are living through some of the most difficult economic circumstances that this country has ever seen. Yesterday, a farmer from 50 miles north of Canberra rang me and said, `Can you get one message into that Parliament of Australia while you are there? I want this message into the Parliament. Will you tell them that, while the rest of Australia might be in recession, the farmers of this land are in serious depression?'. He is a woolgrower and a wheat grower, and he started outlining some points to back up what he was saying.

Let us look at some of the constructive things that have been done—the sorts of messages that should be got out to the schools of this country to show what is really going on in rural Australia as far as land care and soil conservation programs are concerned, not the rubbish we have had presented to our school children. Back in 1982 there were approximately 25 Landcare groups in total in Australia. There are now over 1,000. Let us deal with Western Australia in isolation, because that is my State. We now find that 70 per cent of all Western Australian land users are involved in the 109 land conservation districts. That is not just farmers; that includes land users, it includes mining companies, it includes other groups who are involved in land use and management of some of the public estate.

Those 109 land conservation districts cover 75 per cent of the agricultural lands. The latest information I have is that that has grown to 90 per cent of agricultural lands. We find that 80 per cent of the pastoral lands of Western Australia are covered. As I understand it, that was the situation when this report was brought down. It is just a pity that Mrs Kelly did not take the time to read it, because it is very instructive and it would give her a much more accurate position of what the situation is in Australia at the current time. I understand that in Western Australia now about 85 per cent of pastoral areas are covered. That has all happened in the past 10 years.

One would think that a Minister in the position which Mrs Kelly holds would in fact look at the facts before allowing the Department to send out this propaganda. Of course, she tries to do a Pontius Pilate and wipe her hands of the whole thing and blame her Department. I guess in due course it will come down to blaming somebody in her Department, as Senator Brownhill suggested. However, that does not excuse her position; it does not excuse the fact that she has not got control of her Department, if they can put out this type of nonsense and rubbish.

In the time I have remaining to me, I would like to look through some of the other facts, in terms of what has occurred in the various States. If we look at the national soil conservation projects, we will see that there are 23 of them around Australia. The twenty-third project is being run and supported by the Central Australian Aboriginal communities land management education program. In New South Wales there are 92 programs currently running; in Victoria there are 86; in Queensland there are 93; in South Australia there are 55; in Western Australia there are 80; in Tasmania there are 28; in the Northern Territory there are 25; and the Australian Capital Territory also has a number. What is wrong with Mrs Kelly pointing out some of the things that are going on? What is wrong with her showing what is happening with the individual farmers?

The biggest problem we have with the national soil conservation program at this time and with the land-care program, is not with the willingness of the farmers to carry it out, but with the economic policies of this current Government. It has virtually sent the farm sector down the drain. It has done that purely and simply by a misuse of monetary policy over the last five or six years. We have seen, through the use of interest rates, the whole farming sector ground into the dirt. During that period—the same period that I spoke about when these districts were developed—we have seen the take in fuel excise go from 6.8c a litre to 26c a litre, something that we are addressing in Fightback. We have seen the wholesale sales tax regime—which has had a very big impact on the farm sector, the very people Mrs Kelly seeks to denigrate here—increase from over $3 billion to in excess of $9 billion, peaking at $11.8 billion.

Mrs Kelly would be well advised, if she wants to communicate with Australian schoolchildren, to do it in a factual, fair and balanced way—not by denigrating the very people who provide much of the wealth of this country and who have addressed the particular problems that she misrepresents. One has to ask has she never heard—in terms of the well-being of the Australian community —that when the farm sector is doing well most of the rest of Australia is doing well. Will she ever realise that there are particular aspects of land management that have to be addressed in this nation of ours? We need to have a thriving, successful and prosperous farming industry and we will then have the dollars and cents to do what has to be done. The problems will then be addressed. There is no need to send out this propaganda, this rubbish. It is, I repeat, left wing communistic nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to put on the record my strong approval and pleasure at yesterday's Sydney District Court decision in which a four-person jury found an employer guilty of negligence for failing to provide their employee with a smoke free work environment. It awarded her $85,000 in compensation.

PARA.TAB: Now this is a historic verdict. The employee, Ms Liesel Scholem, was employed as a psychologist by the New South Wales Department of Health. Notwithstanding that the Department had, on paper, a smoke free workplace for part of the time in which Ms Scholem worked for them, she suffered from passive smoke inhalation. At times, up to eight of her nine work colleagues smoked cigarettes in her presence. The jury found that her emphysema—a most distressing disease—and chronic asthma were contributed to by this passive inhalation over many years.

I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to the energy, persistence and help that Dr Arthur Chesterfield Evans gave to Ms Scholem in the passage of this case over many years before it reached court. It is evident that, given Ms Scholem's chronic ill health, she has received an immense amount of support from many sympathisers and supporters over the years, chief among them being Dr Chesterfield Evans. It is the Non-Smokers Movement of Australia, of which Arthur is the president, that can also share in this victory.

Honourable senators may remember the historic decision of Mr Justice Morling in the Federal Court in February 1991 in which he held that passive smoking was a contributing factor to the development of a range of diseases of non-smokers, including asthma. These two decisions are of immense importance for the health and well-being of our community, and especially of our work force and our children.

In regard to the work force implications of these decisions, I wish to point out that clearly employers have a duty of care to their employees to make available smoke free work premises. Fortunately, the Commonwealth Public Service is largely smoke free. Fortunately, the vast majority of Commonwealth

SPEECH.PARA: employees are not subjected to passive smoking. Unfortunately, many of our State governments and their departments are not so enlightened. Worse still, many private enterprise employers either refuse to acknowledge the importance of this issue, or lack the will to implement sensible workplace policies.

PARA.TAB: I think it is true to say that the Liesel Scholem case is the tip of an unfortunate iceberg. There are many cases of passive smoking victims in a range of occupations and social contexts. Consider, for example, the following: bar attendants, waiters, flight stewards, prison officers, nurses, cleaners, security guards, teachers, shop assistants and bus and tram conductors in some jurisdictions. In all of these occupations and others there is, or until very recently has been, some very real threat of permanent health damage being done to non-smokers through passive smoking. Our workplaces are long overdue for reform in this important matter. Employers, unions and the work force all need to sit down and implement sensible workplace policies. Even speaking of this place, I would say that once they have done that they then have to work out ways of having them implemented.

Of course, this has big implications for the hospitality industry among many others. The vast majority of the population—even the vast majority of smokers—when polled, have consistently said that they want smoke free dining in restaurants. So I call on restaurant owners and managers, and the unions in the hospitality industry to implement smoke free dining as a matter of urgency. How many Liesel Scholems are there in the hospitality industry alone? How long is it before a restaurant owner or manager is sued for negligence? How long will it be before a union is sued for failing to look after the interests of its members in regard to this particular occupational hazard?

Finally, I turn to the matter of children and passive smoking. I am pleased this is one of the main thrusts in the `Quit' week activities in some Australian States, some of which I will be participating in in my home State of Victoria this weekend. One of the great tragedies of smoking is that children are usually the passive victims, the silent victims. Passive smoking greatly increases the risk of unborn children having a greater than expected incidence of a whole range of childhood illnesses and diseases including leukemia, brain disorders and learning difficulties. These problems are now well-known to medical practitioners. The message is simple. Women who are pregnant should not smoke. There are also many older children who are passive victims suffering from a higher than expected incidence of asthma and other respiratory diseases as a result of smokers in their own household in particular.

The Scholem decision means that what has long been accepted by the medical and the caring professions is now established in law. For the sake of our work force and our children, this Parliament has a duty to legislate to minimise the glamour and attractiveness of smoking. It is not glamorous and it is not attractive: it is advertising's ultimate con job. Our work force, our children, our whole community suffer as a result.

I applaud the Government's announcement that it will finally legislate to further limit tobacco advertising and, in particular and especially, its association with sport and cultural events. The Democrats will keep the Government to this recent promise, just as my own private member's Bill banning print advertising, which achieved all-party support in this Parliament at the end of 1989, saw the end of print advertising from the beginning of 1991. Just as that Democrat action pushed the issue further after 13 years of inaction, we will ensure that remaining advertising, sponsorship and promotion of this harmful product—expensive in terms of Australia's public health and of the health of individuals—stops.
The tragedy is that this action is coming 15 years too late for Liesel and for hundreds of others who have suffered and still suffer. Liesel is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It has taken away my health, and no verdict can ever restore that no matter what happens.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
(1)That the discussion of matters of public interest be not further proceeded with this day;
(2)That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of Government Business, order of the day No. 2 (Asian Development Fund Bill 1992);
(3)That this order have effect until 2.00 p.m. this day.
Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Asian Development Fund Bill. However, there are some comments I wish to make. The first relates to the share of Australia's global aid budget that is allocated to international financial institutions, the so-called IFIs. The Government has made commitments to the World Bank that have substantially increased the share of the aid budget going to international financial institutions. The second reading speech of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) states that on current projections of draw-down on Australian commitments, the share of the aid budget going to IFIs will rise to 18 per cent in 1994-95 compared with 8 per cent in the mid-1980s and 12 per cent in 1991-92. Thus we have been witnessing a steady rise in the percentage of the aid vote going to such institutions.

PARA.TAB: We think the figure that has been reached to date is too high. The Government has never sought to justify the increase in the allocation to IFIs, although there are several factors that have obviously influenced the series of decisions that have led to this situation. The first is that the steady series of cuts in the aid program was never anticipated. The economy was always expected to do better and there was therefore no recognition that the commitments to international financial institutions that have been made, which have to be made well in advance, would fundamentally change the balance of the Australian global aid budget.

Secondly, there is the power and influence of the Treasury in this matter. Under the Government's practices, and I think the previous Australian Government's practices, the position of alternate executive director of the World Bank is provided to a member of the Australian Treasury. That tends to have some effect on the fact that multilateral aid seems to be the last to be cut.

That is not just my assessment, but I refer to the independent review of Australian multilateral aid as carried out by the Canadian North-South Institute, which attributed the continuation of high levels of support to IDA to `Australia's firm commitment to IDA and the power of the Treasury Department, IDA's senior champion within the bureaucracy'. That is at page 25 of that report.

Thirdly, the Government and Treasury alike were no doubt unwilling to admit that the Australian economy would grind to a halt and thereby shrink the aid program when the IDA-9 pledge was made in 1990. The balance between the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, the ADB, in Australian contributions also has never been adequately explained. World Bank payments call for much larger contributions from Australia, but Australia's share of the ADB funds are larger —6.5 per cent in ADF-6 compared with 1.99 per cent in IDA-9.

The North-South Institute study describes Australia's contribution to the World Bank as `somewhat passive, formula driven, and a response to notions of good international citizenship', compared with the ADB involvement, which `has more passion since it addresses political, strategic and economic imperatives close to home'. It says that Australia is a player in Asia and much more a spectator on the world stage.

Australia has been critical of the ADB's management, to the point of seriously considering a 10 per cent decrease in the expected share of ADF-5 in 1987-89. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade supported this position, calling for higher standards of accountability and disclosure. In response to criticism from donor countries, the ADB established a panel of experts, which led to the introduction of improvements in reporting.

Australia's contributions to the International Fund for Agricultural Development, IFAD, should also be considered. For reasons that appear to be little more than ministerial whim, Australia announced in 1987 that it would not participate in the third replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development. Following strong representations from Australian and international agencies and consultant communities and again a recommendation from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, this decision was reversed, but it shows clearly the need for a proper articulation of the criteria by which Australian contributions to IFIs are determined.

The Government needs to explain in more detail the decrease in Australia's share of ADF-6. Does it relate solely to questions of Australia's difficult economic and budgetary situation or is there an element of criticism of the ADB? The drop in Australia's share is 23.5 per cent, which is far more substantial than the threatened cut of 10 per cent in ADF-5. Is a similar cut presently being negotiated in Australia's share of IDA-10? Does the Government accept the assessment of the North-South Institute review that Australia is a player in Asia but more a spectator in world affairs? If so, will IDA-10 be cut more substantially than the Asian Development Fund procurement 6? If not, is the Prime Minister's talk of Australia's future in Asia no more than empty rhetoric?

I also want to touch upon benefits which might flow to Australia from assistance to IFIs. Because the ADF and the IDA are restricted to low-income countries, Australia's contributions to these funds, by definition, contribute to the reduction of poverty. Given the concentration of the bilateral aid program on middle-income countries, the IFI contributions can be presented as providing a balance in the overall Australian program. However, it must be asked whether these contributions are effective in reducing poverty. The overall record of poor countries in reducing poverty as a result of contributions from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank is not encouraging. It is the better-off developing countries that seem to be doing better, both in achieving economic growth and in increasing equity. Indonesia, for example, has reduced poverty from more than 60 per cent of the population in 1970 to less than 20 per cent at present.

We need to ask ourselves whether our aid dollar might not be more effective in reducing poverty, as far as the bilateral program is concerned, by concentrating on the developing countries. Perhaps we can more directly assist those in greatest need, the poorest countries, by making a greater proportion of our contribution through small-scale NGO projects, which might be better targeted to those most in need. Certainly, when we are looking at loans that are made through the World Bank or the Asian Development Bank, there must be clear agreement on policy frameworks necessary for effective implementation of projects and programs.

I want to mention also the trade benefits that can flow from the program to Australia and how we could do better. The Asian Development Bank and the World Bank procurement programs provide opportunities for Australian suppliers of goods and services. The second reading speech refers to the ADB as a significant source of procurement for Australian business, but expresses the hope that Australia can increase its share of ADB business. In reality, however, Australia's record in IFI procurement is disappointing. On a cumulative basis, Australia has obtained 95c for every $1 provided to the ADB-ADF and $1.08 for each $1 provided to the World Bank-IDA group.

When contributions are being considered, Australia's contributions are always presented as percentage shares of total contributions. Data on procurement, however, is always presented as dollars earned or dollars contributed. The fact that dollars contributed are leveraged with borrowed dollars is overlooked. The ADB and the World Bank have far more funds to lend than those contributed. I suggest respectfully that the Minister could in future present to the Senate data on our shares for procurement, and also say whether they are comparable to our shares of contribution.

By comparison with other donors, the independent review by the Canadian-based North South Institute concludes that Australia's procurement record is `disappointing'. Australia's low share of procurement partly reflects the lack of international competitiveness. We cannot realistically expect to have a share of procurement comparable to that of Japan or other competitive exporters of manufactures unless we significantly increase our competitiveness.

Nevertheless, there are areas where we can hope to improve the promotion of our exports. The second reading speech reference to an interdepartmental task force working on the problem suggests that the Government is conscious that it has not been doing enough. But one has to be an optimist to believe that an interdepartmental committee will find ways around the fundamental problem of lack of international competitiveness.

Before concluding I want to mention certain policy issues relating to the Asian Development Bank. Australia is the second largest donor to that bank and therefore has a significant role to play in ADB policy development. The second reading speech of the Minister refers to several areas where Australia has played an active role, but such expressions are in the most general of terms. We need to extend policy input beyond such broad, general issues. We need to ensure that Australia maintains a tough stance on issues of effectiveness. Any temptation to grant loans simply to achieve disbursement targets should be strongly resisted. Each project and program loan proposal should be scrutinised carefully and proposals that are not likely to be effective should be ruthlessly rejected.

Let me conclude with a few comments on coalition policy. The Coalition supports the Australian contribution to the IFIs but believes that Australia's contribution should reflect Australia's economic reality. As I said at the outset, we believe that the proportion of the overall aid budget that is appropriated to IFIs has become too high. The maintenance of Australia's level of contribution to the World Bank in these difficult economic circumstances, and following substantial cuts in the overall aid program, is not justifiable. Australia's peripheral role in the World Bank means that a drop in the level of contribution would not have major adverse consequences.

On the other hand, given our larger role in the Asian Development Bank, our location within the region and the claimed successes of the Government in influencing ADB policy development, a case can be made for at least maintaining our existing level of commitment or only reducing it slightly. However, any cut in the level of the Australian ADF 6 share—23 per cent—should be matched by a cut of at least the same proportion as the World Bank's fund. The next contribution, which I understand is currently under negotiation, will be through IDA 10. Anything less would be totally inconsistent with recent Government rhetoric about the importance of Asia to Australia. With those few comments I confirm that which I said at the outset: the Opposition will support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chamber has been well served by the speech that was just made by Senator Hill. It is a speech which needs to be studied by the Government and responded to. I am also one who believes that far too great a percentage of our aid budget is going to the international financial institutions. As does Senator Hill, I consider it important to ensure that the aid gets directly to the people in very poor countries. One of the best ways of doing this is through NGOs, and through people who are on the ground there, including social groups, community organisations, churches and so on.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, as we all know, much aid money does find its way into the pockets of governing cliques. A great deal of aid money is used to buy government cliques to empower themselves governmentally over the people that the aid is supposed to help. This has been an ongoing discussion in the aid area for many years. I do not need to relate to the Senate the various views that have been expressed over the years on that particular question. On another issue, where a large proportion—18 per cent or thereabouts—of aid money is going to the international financial institutions, do the representatives of the taxpayer, who is footing the bill, have effective policy control over where that money is spent? The Asian Development Bank, World Bank and other institutions are very large bureaucracies and a lot of the money is eaten up by administrative expenses. Of course it is necessary to have an effective administration, but I share Senator Hill's view that the percentage at present is far too high.

Where you have large bureaucracies such as the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, it appears that they are able to develop policies which really tend to be political policies. I am concerned about these organisations' diversion of amounts of aid money from directly attacking the problems of poverty into areas such as population control policies. As a parliament and as a member country of the Asian Development Bank, we deserve a far more objective report on health, population and development in Asia and the Pacific than we were dealt by the Asian Development Bank in 1991.That document simply accepts as a given the assertion that population growth is a crucial negative factor in development. That is not a given at all. There is no real academic consensus on that particular issue. Yet the other view that has been put forward by, amongst others, Julian Simon, and so on, academics of world renown, is not even given a mention here.

It is the same thing as we had yesterday. Over the last couple of years, in addressing AIDAB at Estimates committee hearings, one was trying to find out certain features of the population control program in China. AIDAB then commissioned a report which gave only one side of that area. When I asked for a more balanced and objective report to be provided it was not done; in fact, it was refused. So I sent the AIDAB report to a China expert in America, an absolutely world renowned expert, a former research analyst with the Bureau of the Census' China desk in Washington—Dr John S. Aird. Yesterday I was able to table in this place a document from Dr Aird in response to the AIDAB document. That was a 72-page document, with 186 footnotes, which completely demolished the AIDAB document upon which the Government's policies are based.

It is important that we have an open-minded approach to this, not a closed-minded approach. It is unfair to blame the fertility of poor women in developing countries. These have been made the scapegoat for a range of problems from environmental damage to famine, the causes of which are war and political instability and man's inhumanity to man. These are the sorts of things that we ought to be considering. The report makes the point that where growing standards of living occur, the fertility rate tends to decline. That is not an absolute and general rule but it is overwhelmingly the experience. But what I am asking for really is a more scholarly approach to this question and not an acceptance of the `givens' which are promoted by other international bureaucracies which have a vested interest in the area. I refer to UNFPA and IPPF.

I simply stand here and appeal to the Government that such an approach be taken, so that policies are determined on the basis of the truth which has been discerned after scholarly efforts have been made, and genuine attempts by politicians and bureaucrats have been made to obtain the truth, having sought it with an open mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to respond in any detail to the points made here. I might fax Senator Hill's speech across to Senator Evans to see if he wants to respond to any of the points to date. I think Senator Harradine was reinforcing points he made yesterday.
—Evans or Kerin?

—I am sorry; I only ever think in terms of the premier chamber, Senator. Yes, I meant Mr Kerin. I think Senator Harradine has been reinforcing some points he made yesterday and has used this as an opportunity to transmit those views. I do not think he wants a detailed response from me today—and if he does, he will be disappointed. So I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. On 22 November last year, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was made aware of the Sibraa letter to Washington which included the assertion, now known to be false, that the President of the Marshall Islands had asked the Australian Government to help Mr Symons in relation to his, that is, Symons's, business. Did the Department bring to the Minister's attention this serious error? Did the Minister or his Department bring to the attention of Senator Sibraa the error contained in his letter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is based on a false premise. We have had a long debate and discussion about what the Sibraa letter intended to say and what it did say and the gap in the language accordingly. Senator Sibraa has made it perfectly clear that the only information before him and his staff member, Mr Peppinck, at the time that the letter was written was the physical presence of Mr Symons before him claiming to be exercising some delegated authority, holding himself out to be representing the Marshall Islands Government, and he, Mr Symons, asking for Australian Government assistance, through Senator Sibraa to the Washington Embassy, to pursue the particular matter.

PARA.TAB: In debating Senator Sibraa's statement a couple of days ago, we discussed at considerable length—and I certainly said at considerable length then, and I do not need to repeat it at that length—what is the proper interpretation of Senator Sibraa's letter. I quote the relevant sentence of the letter:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . President Kabua has sought the assistance of the Australian Government in expediting discussions in Washington with key US Government officials. . .

What he was obviously intending to say was, `President Kabua has, through Mr Symons, sought the assistance of the Australian Government'. There was no belief at any stage—and Senator Sibraa has made this perfectly clear—that there had been any separate request. Certainly, as I understand it, he had not been told that there had been any separate request directly on a government to government basis. This was simply an infelicitous and incomplete recording of the particular circumstance that Senator Sibraa found himself confronting.

PARA.TAB: Of course, I was not made aware of this letter at the time of the letter being faxed back from the Embassy in Washington to Canberra, nor at the time that Canberra followed it up by sending it to our Ambassador in Pohnpei to see what he could find out about it. Nobody seemed to attribute any particular significance to the phrase in question, so far as I have been advised, nor so far as appears from the documents, no doubt because everyone was reading this as a straightforward and simple letter of introduction which was self-contained and which was not, in fact, containing a reference to some prior and separate communication from the Marshall Islands to the Australian Government because, of course, it is the case that there was never any such separate communication.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister yesterday gave us a lecture on the English language. I would have thought that what was included in the letter was unambiguous, that is, `President Kabua has sought the assistance of the Australian Government in expediting discussions in Washington with key US Government officials' in relation to the business affairs of Mr Symons. I ask the Minister: is his interpretation of that, as he has put to the Senate today, the interpretation that was made by his Department at the time and is that the reason that he is saying the Department did not bring it to his attention?

—I can only assume that that was the interpretation given to it by my Department at the time, because if my Department had taken a different interpretation of it, no doubt there would be a flurry of documentation—
—A literal interpretation.

—A literal interpretation and not read it in the total context, no doubt there would be a flurry of documentation asking, `What on earth is this communication from the Marshall Islands Government about?'.

PARA.TAB: The point is that, no doubt as a result of personal communication that occurred between Mr Lamb and Mr Symons, or whatever the background was, nobody thought it necessary to go off on that particular goose chase. I am making that assumption. I do not know what the answer is. I assume that, if the Department had believed for a moment that there had been such a communication, they would have followed it up. They certainly did not bring it to my attention or to the attention of my office. Obviously, the matter was perceived at the time as a simple, straightforward letter of introduction which led to a contact being made in Washington with Mr Lamb, who followed it up by giving straightforward and simple advice to Mr Symons—which was very good advice—to the effect that there was nothing the Australian Government could do for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to media reports that Roger Gyles, QC, has brought down his report on productivity in the construction industry? Has he received this report and what action does he intend to take in response to this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the report by Roger Gyles, QC, into the building and construction industry in New South Wales. It is the Government's intention to respond fully to his findings.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I believe the Minister is still a member of the BWIU and he should tell the Senate that his answer may have some conflict of interest.
—There is no point of order and I would not be aware of what union the Minister is a member of.

—Mr President, in regard to that point of order, this morning in the chamber we had a very strong discussion about people declaring their interests and, indeed, Senator Faulkner declared an interest he had in a matter before the Chair. If Senator Cook is in fact a member of the BWIU and he is about to comment on the propriety of a report brought down concerning that trade union, as Senator Walters has said, he ought to declare that interest here and now.
—What is the standing order?
—This morning we did cite Odgers on the issue.
—I do not think there is a point of order. I believe a ruling was made from the Chair this morning and I am attempting to check on that at the moment.

—I will return to my answer to the question put to me by Senator Burns. He has asked an intelligent question—unlike the interjections and points of order which have been taken—and is entitled to, and will get, an intelligent reply. I welcome the Gyles report into the building and construction industry in New South Wales and the Government will respond fully and properly after we have had a chance to receive and digest the 5,000-plus pages of that report.

PARA.TAB: Three weeks ago I wrote to the Minister for Industrial Relations in New South Wales, with a copy of my letter to the Premier of New South Wales, saying in anticipation of the Gyles report that I would stand ready to include in the Federal Government's building industry reform strategy any suggestions or recommendations that came forward from that report which were constructive and useful; and that remains the case. For the record, I have not received a reply from either the Minister for Industrial Relations or the Premier in New South Wales, nor have I received an overture from either of those people, despite their public announcements in the media over the last two days. No formal approach has been made by that Government to me or this Government for talks or discussions arising out of what they style as matters of high concern.

The first thing I did when I became Minister for Industrial Relations in 1990—as I recall, I was sworn in on the last day in March—was to take action to implement a reform strategy for the building and construction industry in Australia. The record is that, at the MOLAC meeting in Queenstown, New Zealand, in April, I placed this matter on the agenda for the Ministers for labour of the various States of the Commonwealth meeting with the Federal Government. From that point on, I have rigorously pursued a program to reform this industry, because it is an industry in dire need of reform.

The program came to its culmination in October of last year when the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, announced the reform strategy of the Federal Government for the building and construction industry in Australia—a reform strategy which all the State governments in this Commonwealth, except the State Government of New South Wales and the State Government of Tasmania, have signed their commitment to. I might also say that it is a reform strategy that all the major players in the industry—all of the major employer organisations, unions, industry associations and support associations of the professions—have committed themselves to as well. This is a substantial reform strategy which is addressing the problems in the industry and achieving success.

There have been 22-odd reports into problems about the building and construction industry in Australia. It seemed to us as a Federal government that there was no need for yet a further inquiry which would have the effect of simply supporting the inquiry industry rather than doing something about the building industry. There was a need to act on the body of information that was publicly available and achieve change and reform. So our approach has been not to conduct an inquiry to add yet another unimplemented report to the shelves of libraries to gather dust but actually to do something about resolving the problem. We have been doing that. As I say, it is beginning to show results and it is important.
