On the face of what I now know of the findings of the Gyles royal commission, the only new thing that seems to me to have come out which was not on the public record before is the outrageous and disgusting revelations—and I congratulate Gyles for the way in which he carried out this public duty—of the collusive tendering practices that have been going on, supported by some industry associations, it is alleged, among major tenderers for building contracts in this country. I am not sure how widespread it is, but Gyles has revealed a massive rort which has cost taxpayers and clients of this industry around Australia billions of dollars. In that context it is passing strange that, on the announcement of the findings of this commission, all the Premier of New South Wales could refer to in his two-page formal press release was attacks upon a building union, with not one mention of the problems of collusive tendering and the massive rorts and costs to this community that that has revealed.

Let me make this clear: if there are matters of illegal conduct in the building industry in New South Wales, they should be prosecuted in a court of law. One does not need a royal commission to do it. But if the royal commission has served its duty—which I believe it has—those involved should be prosecuted and dealt with under the due process of the law. If there is a case for the deregistration of a union, the New South Wales Government should take that case to the Industrial Court in New South Wales and let the proper authority, the Industrial Court, make the judgment. It does not need to have the Commonwealth holding its hand in doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, this is becoming a very long answer.
—It is, Mr President; that is true. I apologise to you, sir, for that, but I have been delayed by a number of mindless points of order.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that there are some who believed that the Gyles royal commission into the New South Wales building industry started out as an election gimmick for the Greiner Government and who believe that it is now ending up as a `keep the Premier in office' gimmick. The issues of this industry are too serious, deep-seated and fundamental to be treated in such a superficial political way. They require a considered approach. We have that approach. It is working. I ask the New South Wales Government now to join the majority of State governments and the Commonwealth of Australia in supporting our reform strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I draw your attention to the length of the answer, on which you have commented, and, more importantly, to the fact that the Minister failed to respond to the allegations of conflict of interest. I invite you to consider the fact that on the Notice Paper there is already a motion in relation to the registration and declaration of senators' interests which would require Senator Cook to disclose his membership of any organisation. I ask you, in the spirit of cooperation and the bona fides of the Government, whether Senator Cook should be required at this stage to indicate his interest.

—On the point of order: all Ministers in this Government are required to fill out those details. They are made publicly available. Senator Alston reads them, so he knows that. It is not in terms of Senator Cook's role as a senator but as a Minister that he answers those questions. Therefore, whatever pecuniary interests he has or whatever organisations he is a member of are usually on those forms. I might add that the one weakness in that form, as it applies to the House of Representatives or to Ministers, is in regard to whether every organisation is listed. People on both sides sometimes omit those, not out of any sense of impropriety; it is just that they do not list every organisation they are in. The question is whether it is on the ministerial one, not whether there is notice of some motion.
—I agree with what the Minister has just said—
—On the point of order, Mr President.
—Order, Senator Cook! Is this another point of order?
—It is in response to what Senator Ray has said. It is on the point of order.

—Order! Something that is on the Notice Paper has not been passed and therefore has not come into law. I am informed that this morning a ruling was made that senators are not obliged to declare an interest and it is a matter for individual senators. That is the current position.

—On the point of order: I have made a declaration of my interests and have lodged it in the appropriate way. I understand that it is available. The question that was asked of me by Senator Burns was a straightforward question and it got a comprehensive and straightforward reply. In that reply I said—and I repeat—that if anything illegal has happened, people should be prosecuted. If this union has misbehaved itself and there is a case for its deregistration, the case should be made before the proper authority. There is no question here of my acting in any way other than as a responsible Minister. I resent the implication and the inherent smear involved in it.
—On the same point of order, Mr President—
—Order! I have ruled on this point of order. Senator Bishop, do you wish to speak to the same point of order?
—Yes, to the same point of order.
—Are you a member of the New South Wales Law Institute?
—Of course I am. It is the Law Society of New South Wales, if the Minister wants to know.
—You are a member, are you? We wouldn't know that because you will not pass the form in.

—It is on every curriculum vitae. For the record, the ruling that was made this morning by Senator Colston related to the fact that Senator Faulkner had made a disclosure of interest. Argument then took place about whether or not the rest of the Australian Labor Party ought to make a similar disclosure. The ruling that he made was not a general ruling as to the voluntary nature of disclosure. In fact, the ruling he made related to a different point.

PARA.TAB: In discussion and in subsequent points of order, there was discussion about whether or not it was voluntary or involuntary. But, if you check the record, I do not think you will find that the actual ruling related to the point of whether it should be voluntary or involuntary. The point that was discussed was whether or not the interest was a pecuniary interest. Indeed, one could argue whether or not the Minister has a pecuniary interest which ought to be disclosed as distinct from just an ordinary interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have given a ruling. I state again that there is no rule that honourable senators have to declare an interest.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Poland, led by the Marshal of the Sejm, Professor Chrzanowski. I welcome Professor Chrzanowski and the delegation to the Senate. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Professor Chrzanowski to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. As the Minister will be aware, there was press coverage of the Marshall Islands affairs in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 April 1992. The Minister will also be aware that the matter was reported in the Marshall Islands Journal of 10 April, including the Attorney-General's statement that it was feared, because of Mr Symons's influential friends in the Australian Government, that he would leave the Marshall Islands and never return. The matter was then raised in the Victorian Parliament on 16 April. Further publicity continued from 29 April when Senator Richardson's involvement was reported. I ask the Minister: is it not the usual practice for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to provide briefings to the Minister in relation to such reports? Was the Minister provided with the usual briefings in relation to each of those reports? Or is it the case, yet again, that the Department and the Minister's office failed to bring them to the Minister's attention?

—Honourable senators will recall that I was out of the country from 5 April to 12 April; so I would not have seen the Sydney Morning Herald clipping unless it appeared—as it probably did; I do not recollect—in the clipping service that would normally have been sent to me. I did see, subsequently, the Marshall Islands newspaper clipping. As I recall, that was part of the fax that was sent across to me, to my office, on 21 April which I referred to in answer to a question yesterday. There were two things. There was a fax, and that happened to be the press clipping in question—I think it was probably the one that contained that reference, I cannot recall. There was also an accompanying cable dealing, as I said yesterday, directly with consular matters. There were other odd references to this accompanying the events of 29 April. I have acknowledged previously that, certainly in the context of 29 April, I looked at some of this material.

PARA.TAB: I have no recollection of any other briefing coming across from the Department. Scuttlebutt circulates all the time about all sorts of people. I believed that I knew the true circumstances of the alleged influence of the Australian politician because I had had the discussion in question with Senator Richardson on 3 April. As a result of that, obviously, I believed that the context in which Senator Richardson might well have raised his head in the Marshall Islands press was that of the conversation I had with him; namely, ringing on behalf of his cousin's spouse to put the case for assistance—or the exercise of a discretion—so far as the release of the passport was concerned.

I am acutely well aware of the way in which actions of this kind can lead to rumours circulating; obviously, they did in this case—that was what was reported by the Ambassador on 6 April. To the extent that I was aware of this through press clips, none of this came as any news to me. As such, it was not a matter on which I have any particular recollection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister if he will now check the Department's records to see whether in fact a brief was provided to him in relation to any of the public reports that I have mentioned with the exception, of course, that he has mentioned that 11 days later he received some note of the report in the Marshall Islands Journal, but particularly in relation to the others.

—I checked yesterday the departmental documentation on this and said that so far as that documentation is concerned the only record of any communication between the Department and the Minister's office were the two documents noted on 21 April as having been sent over to my office, the content of which I have just described.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and relates to public opinion on the Australian Defence Force. I refer the Minister to a news poll, with which I believe he is familiar, which was published in the Australian on 22 May. It concluded that two out of every three Australians think the ADF is inadequate to defend Australia's national interests. Can the Minister offer an observation on that survey? Is there an alternative evaluation?

—Everyone in the chamber knows that one gets the answer according to the question asked and the way it is phrased. I was somewhat puzzled by that opinion poll as the Defence Force public relations area, I think twice a year, polls people generally on their attitude. The last one of those shows that four out of five Australians thought we were well placed to defend Australia. I suspect that our own polling is a little high and that the Australian polling is a little low and, therefore, the real result is somewhere in the middle.

PARA.TAB: I was also very puzzled to see a press release come out saying that the Opposition, having looked at this particular poll, favours an increase in defence expenditure. It took some time to track down who the Opposition spokesman was; I was quite puzzled. As it turns out, it was the shadow Minister, Mr Downer, who put out that press release. I was a bit puzzled by this because when one looks at the Fightback policy one will see that spending on the Defence portfolio is to be cut by 2 per cent in real terms in the second year of operation. This seemed rather strange to me. Of course, I might have been able to resolve the conflict between Opposition defence policy on the one hand and Fightback on the other if indeed there were an Opposition defence policy.

My colleagues will, of course, remember that the Liberal Party, in an opportunistic way, in the middle of the Gulf conflict set up a committee of review to report on defence policy and provide an alternative within four months. Some 17 months later, of course, we have seen nothing. We do know that the committee met six times last year. As a result of an interchange between two of us in this chamber, we established that the committee had met only six times. I am looking forward to its report simply to see how Mr Downer tries to resolve this question. I know not everyone in his own party room agrees with it: it is probably one of the most contentiously debated aspects of Fightback within the coalition. To cut back defence spending by 2 per cent under the current circumstances is quite amazing. The coalition then goes on to argue that it will have a $300m enhancement of the combat section.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?

—Senator Newman asks the supplementary. I am sorry, Senator Loosley, she got in before you. There will be $200m off in year two. Members of the Opposition should go and read their documents—$200m off in year two. That is fractionally above 2 per cent on the current Budget. They should go and do their sums and come back and dispute it if they like.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition goes on to say that it will have another $300m injection and that it will achieve that through redundancies on the civilian side of the Department of Defence. To add up, that has to be on top of a program put in place by us to reduce civilians by 15 per cent over eight or nine years along the redundancy line. The really interesting thing in Fightback is that two departments are exempted for supplementation for redundancy—the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Defence. So to try to achieve the $300m injection it will have to let thousands of staff go and pay redundancy for them.

There will be no gain in the first year, no gain in the second year, and gain will be highly dubious in the third year. In the fourth year out I concede that some money starts to be saved and the coalition might be able to have its $300m injection—down the track, four years later, having ripped $200m off in the second year continuously out into the out years of the Budget. Yet Mr Downer says we should increase defence expenditure. All I can say is that that is monumental opportunism by him and monumental hypocrisy. He obviously has not read the Fightback documents that included these sorts of cuts in the defence expenditure. So I will be very interested to see how the Opposition tries to resolve its new defence policy against that background.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Minister acknowledge that Senator Richardson's approach to the President of the Marshall Islands on behalf of Gregory Symons has aroused considerable concern as to its propriety, and very little support? In hindsight, does the Minister still believe that he gave the correct advice to Senator Richardson on that matter, given that Senator Richardson's attempt to present himself as acting in a private capacity was neither credible nor realistic? Is it appropriate for members and/or Ministers, other than the Minister for Foreign Affairs, to intercede on behalf of Australian citizens before the courts in foreign countries? Finally, in future, does the Minister intend to give clearances to parliamentarians and/or Ministers to intervene in overseas legal proceedings?

—The questions raised by Senator Coulter involve rather delicate matters of judgment, not only as to what one should do but also as to how what one does in all propriety and honesty might be perceived, and the implications that flow from that. I was really very conscious of that. It was a matter of responding very quickly to a request that was made to me by Senator Richardson in what he described, from the outset, as being a private legal matter involving a relative by marriage who was in trouble.

PARA.TAB: You will recall, Mr President, from when I gave the full details of our conversation, that Senator Richardson had been asked specifically in a phone call by the defence lawyer to make a representation himself directly to the President of the Marshall Islands. Senator Richardson was wanting to assist the person in question, obviously, but was a little troubled by the protocol dimensions of this. That is the way Senator Richardson put it me: `What is the Foreign Affairs protocol of making such an approach?'.

I was anxious to help him as best we could, and we had quite a substantial conversation about the way in which the matter could be handled. The result was that I said to him, `You must make this phone call in your capacity as a private citizen and not in any way hold yourself out to be representing the Australian Government'. Of course, he had the status of a Minister and he could not change that status. But all of us on this front bench have that status. We can and we do change our roles. When I talk, for example, to the headmaster of my daughter's school, I am not doing so as Foreign Minister; I am doing so as a father, although I remain Foreign Minister. The point is a reasonable one to make in the situation: provided one makes it clear in the conversation in question that the basis on which you are making a representation is not the basis of the status that you may have, but your particular role as someone who is trying to help. That was the first point, and it was a very important point.

The second matter was that I put very squarely to Senator Richardson—not that he needed to be persuaded on this—that his representation must confine itself to the particular question of the executive discretion involved as to whether or not the gentleman's passport would be taken away or returned to him, in the context of the kind of prosecutorial decision that would have to be made as to whether to seek the removal of the passport or not. It was obvious that anything that could be construed as an attempt to interfere in any way with the determination of guilt or innocence on the substantive matter in question would be wholly inappropriate. It was on the basis of everything that Senator Richardson has said on the public record that I believe the call took place.

The particular question of speaking to the President of a country as distinct from the prosecuting attorney, the head of the law department, another Minister, another senior official or something of this kind, is obviously one that also raised itself in the course of this discussion. As I have said previously, it is a somewhat unusual situation, obviously, to be calling the President of another country. That is again something that was troubling Senator Richardson. But he had been asked specifically by the defence lawyer to call the President, so obviously the defence was not concerned about this being counterproductive or being seen to be improper in Marshall Island's terms.

There is also the reality. As I said to Senator Richardson, I have been to the Marshall Islands, I know the scale and the kind of place it is. Small Pacific islands operate in accordance with different sorts of practical conventions as to the way in which business and government operate, than elsewhere. Very often it is the case that the senior executive official, or elected official in this case, is really the only person to deal with if you are trying to get something done quickly or some executive discretion exercised, as was the case here.

There was an element of urgency about it. Senator Richardson understood that the matter was going to be addressed in court later that morning. In fact, as he said in his report, he made an attempt to call later that morning, 3 April. So it was not a situation that gave me a lot of opportunity for reflection and thinking about, even though, in the event, Senator Richardson was unable to make his call and get through until 6 April. Opinions can differ about these things. As I began by saying, it is a delicate matter of judgment. I believe that the advice I gave—that it was okay, provided these various constraints were observed—was appropriate advice.

As to the other part of the question about the circumstances in which it is ever appropriate for governments or government Ministers to make representations in court matters involving Australian citizens, this is an issue that has arisen from time to time. It is squarely on our plate at the moment in the context of the Australian citizen, McAuliffe, in Malaysia. The principle that we have adopted as a government is that we do not in any way seek to participate in the process before the matter is finally heard and determined by the court process. But when it comes to the matter of the exercise of executive clemency, it is appropriate on occasion for some representation to be made. Such representation has now been made in the McAuliffe case by the Prime Minister and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not aware that Senator Evans's daughter is at a foreign school or, indeed, is under arrest in a foreign country. It seems to me that the decision to withhold the passport was, according to the Minister's reply just given, a legal decision. Consequently, the Minister concerned—former Minister Richardson—was intervening in a legal decision. The question again is, should we? It seems to me from the latter part of the Minister's reply that he would have to agree that it is not appropriate for other Ministers to intercede in something which goes to a legal matter which is before the courts in a foreign country; it is not at that stage an executive matter.

—Well, it is a matter of the proper legal characterisation of it. The decision made by the prosecution to prosecute is essentially an executive decision. A decision made by a prosecution to seek a particular result from the court, so far as the passport withholding is concerned, is an executive decision made by the prosecution as the executive arm of government. It is not as if one is seeking to ring up the judge and say, `Can you please make your judicial decision in a way that gives assistance to or acknowledges the rights of my relative to prepare his defence?'. If one had rung the judicial officer directly, obviously, whether one is acting in an official capacity, a private capacity or anything else, very real questions of impropriety would arise.

PARA.TAB: But there is a twilight zone when one is talking about executive discretion and executive decisions of this kind and that was something that I thought was a relevant distinction. I am not casting any aspersions on Senator Coulter's judgment on these matters. All I can say is, I think it is a matter about which reasonable people can differ. I took a different view then and I do not resile from that now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In the preparation of the One Nation statement, senior Ministers consulted widely with business and community groups. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government plans a program of community consultation as it draws up the Budget over the next few months?

—The process of Budget consultation has already begun. The EPAC secretariat has asked for the views of 25 community and business organisations. That will be followed up by others concerned with the preparation of the Budget.

PARA.TAB: When the One Nation statement was being prepared, there was an extensive process of community consultation which concerned a number of people, like Senator Short and Dr Hewson, who took it upon themselves to make fools of themselves by ringing businessmen around the country and telling them that they should not consult with the Government. That is a very sad fact, which Senator Short does not deny. He publicly made a fool of himself by embarking on that process. The process of community consultation on this occasion will not be aborted by any efforts by Senator Short or anybody else to interfere with it, particularly in terms of business consultation. I must say that that process played a very important part in the preparation of One Nation.

However, the Opposition has abandoned any pretence of consultation on the same lines. The Opposition is to have an American style convention to which business people will be invited—a sort of Charles Manson family at play to which all sorts of business people will be invited to see a spectacular collection of Opposition spokesmen. Of course, the Government, in the process of drafting the Budget, will consult with business, community groups and the States. The consultation process ensures that the Government has a view of groups in the community. It will be a process of working sessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —A consumption tax perhaps?

—Let us deal with that issue. In the process which the Opposition envisages, let us make it quite clear that the Liberal Party is planning to charge business for access to senior Opposition figures in order to pay for the Fightback package prepared by consultants for the Opposition. Those opposite talk about the sovereignty of Parliament and political parties, but the Fightback package prepared by consultants has to be paid for. It is in that context that charges will be levied.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to two things. The first point is that the matters to which Senator Button is now referring have nothing whatsoever to do with his portfolio. Secondly, I draw your attention, Mr President, to standing order 73(4), which states without qualification that in answering a question a senator shall not debate it. Senator Button clearly is debating the matter. In accordance with the standing order, Mr President, I ask you to draw him to order.

—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Button was asked a question about whether the Government would consult. He was contrasting the Government's position with that of the Opposition. However, Senator Button's answer is becoming a debate because of constant interjections and his replying to them. Maybe it would be better if we had fewer injections.

—Mr President, there is no debate about Senator Short ringing up businessmen trying to talk them out of taking part in a process of consultation with the Government. There is no debate about that at all. That is why he gets up to take the point of order—because he made a fool of himself over this issue. The business community, in terms of the Opposition's convention, will pay $750 to meet a shadow Minister. That is a lucky dip if ever there was one. What will people who dip into the barrel get?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. There is no way in which that response can relate to public administration under this Government. I ask you to bring Senator Button to order and sit him down.
—Order! I said before that I thought the Minister's answer was beginning to be debated. I ask for fewer interjections from both sides.

—Of course, the question is whether business people will get in the lucky dip somebody who is charming, somebody who is thick or somebody they have never heard of. That is the exciting element about this proposal of a convention. Business people may get somebody they have never heard of. This is a very important question about political style. We will embark, as we always do, on a genuine process of political consultation in the period leading up to the Budget. We will not be charging $750 a head. We will not be charging $1,000 for somebody who has a bit more style. We will not be doing that. That is an important question of political style to which my attention was brought by the effort of Senator Short on the last occasion the Government embarked on the process of political consultation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw his attention to the article in the Australian of 28 April in which it was reported that Senator Richardson had been heavying the President of the Marshall Islands to have the serious forgery charges against Mr Symons dropped. As this flatly contradicted what Senator Richardson had told the Minister he was going to pursue with the President, which was merely to seek the return of Mr Symons's passport, what steps did the Minister take to have this matter investigated? Has the Minister checked whether the only call by Senator Richardson to the President or other Cabinet Minister in the Marshall Islands was the call to President Kabua of 6 April regarding return of the passport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The allegation that first came to light in those terms in the Australian press on 28 April was, of course, responded to that day by a very detailed statement by Senator Richardson, who made it very clear in the statement he put out on that day that there had been only one phone call; that it was of the character that has been described. I will read it again. The relevant part of this particular statement by Senator Richardson on that day reads as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: After checking with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, to ensure that I was not acting improperly, I rang Mr Amata Kabua, the President of the Marshall Islands on 6 April.
The conversation lasted less than five minutes.

In introducing myself, I made it clear that I was not ringing in my official ministerial capacity, but on the basis that I knew the individual concerned and wanted to clarify what the possibilities might be.
I pointed out that I was not familiar with their judicial system and understood that Mr Symons' passport had been confiscated.

I said it would seem reasonable for him to be allowed to prepare his case, which in this instance would require him to gain access to documents held in Australia. Therefore, I asked that he be permitted to return to Australia after supplying whatever assurances or bail which might be required by the Marshall Islands.
Mr Kabua gave me no undertakings other than to say he'd look into the matter.

That was the statement made by Senator Richardson that day. I cannot remember whether he consulted with me before he put this statement out or not. But there was some discussion of it and the next day, of course, in Parliament, we were asked questions about it and that was when I gave a very detailed answer as to the basis of my conversation with and advice to Senator Richardson.

PARA.TAB: At every stage along the way Senator Richardson has publicly and privately stated and made it clear that there was only one phone call to any official. That was to President Kabua. I have absolutely no reason to doubt Senator Richardson's word, Senator Richardson's integrity, in this respect and, certainly, I have no other information whatsoever which would lead me to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: firstly, what is the Australian Government's response to the peace plan put forward by Jose Ramos Horta on behalf of the Fretilin leader, Xanana Gusmao, which indicates that East Timorese opposition groups are prepared to engage in unconditional talks with Indonesia under United Nations auspices? Secondly, does the Minister accept that this plan represents a reasonable proposal for implementing a long term strategy of reconciliation in East Timor? Thirdly, is the Government aware that the Catholic, Anglican and Uniting churches in Australia have all given their unequivocal backing to this proposal?

—I have already said publicly that the Horta proposal is one that I find interesting but it is not one on which the Government proposes to take any action. I have said that for two reasons: first, it is by no means clear that the proposal enjoys the support of the East Timorese community either in East Timor or here—or at least the across-the-board support. There are a lot of different streams and currents of opinion. For example, I understand—although I did not hear it directly myself—that on The World Today radio program of 21 May the Australia-based East Timorese activist Alfredo Ferreira was reported as saying that he doubted whether there would be widespread support for the idea of ceasing to resist Indonesian rule, and Mr Horta's views are his own and do not necessarily represent those of other East Timorese.

PARA.TAB: So there is a question mark at the outset as to its representative status but that does not go to its quality. As to that—this is the second point—to the extent that that proposal of Mr Horta's leaves open the question of sovereignty over East Timor, it simply is inconsistent with the position that the Australian Government has adopted since 1979 when de jure recognition was extended by the then coalition government, and that recognition has been maintained, as Senator Bourne would know, by successive Labor governments.

Ultimately, the Horta proposal is one for the Indonesian Government to respond to and if the Indonesian Government is minded to go down that particular path, then so be it. We will certainly follow the process with some fascination. What I can say positively about the Horta proposal is that if it does have the effect of contributing to an atmosphere of longer term reconciliation, if it does have the effect of contributing to a longer term reconciliation process in East Timor, to that extent we would, of course, welcome it. We have been stressing the need for such a process of longer term reconciliation ever since the Dili killings, quite apart from all the shorter term reactive measures that we have been arguing for. That process should include improved social and economic development and certainly greater recognition of East Timor's distinctive cultural identity.

We have also said to the Indonesian authorities—and I have made the point personally a number of times—that reconciliation might be very much assisted by giving the local people of East Timor a significantly greater say in the running of their affairs. Whether one calls that autonomy or by some other name is less important than the practical reality of it. We have also made it clear that the security forces in East Timor, for as long as they remain there—and we hope that will not be very long—certainly need to be more sensitive to the needs and aspirations of the East Timorese people. So to the extent that that is an element in the Horta proposal, we certainly support that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that there is no documentation in relation to the contact between Dr Garnaut and the Prime Minister, or between the Prime Minister, the Prime Minister's office and the Minister's Department?

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to continued media comments about the superior performance of overseas ports compared with Australia's waterfront. Is the criticism justified and, if so, can the Minister advise when our ports will start to show improvement from the current reform process?

—Despite my unstinting efforts to publicise the very significant improvements in the Australian waterfront, the myth still persists that Australia is lagging behind its trading partners. The reason I make that point is that yesterday I did notice some media comment that I have been quiet about this performance improvement and, of course, the Opposition in here has complained loudly and consistently that I have been too loud about it. Perhaps that particular section of the Fourth Estate can correct its own perceptions by translating this piece of good news from out of here into the real world.

PARA.TAB: The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, WIRA, has today released its latest set of performance figures for Australian ports and those figures contain a very good news story for Australia. I have previously advised that stevedores have reported significant productivity improvements as a result of the major restructuring of our stevedoring industry. All major ports have now moved to enterprise employment, and in fact the only block of regional ports left to go is in Western Australia. These regional ports are also introducing new labour arrangements, which will be completed by the end of October.

The total waterfront work force has now been cut by 42 per cent, from 8,900 to 5,100 employees, and it will be more than halved by the end of the reform program. The new stevedoring industry award has been restructured. That single award now replaces some 20 separate stevedoring awards and agreements and numerous pay categories have all been converted into a single skills based classification structure.

The improvement in the performance of Australian ports resulting from these changes is now confirmed by the release today of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority's latest performance indicators—for the March quarter this year. This report shows that the average—I stress average—crane loading rates at Australian container terminals is now around 18 to 19 containers per hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does that compare with the rest of the world?

—If the honourable senator waits, I will tell him. This compares with average container rates of around 12 an hour in 1989 when the reforms commenced and an average of 15 per hour in the last WIRA report. In specific trades the current performance rates in our ports are equal to or more efficient than overseas ports with which Australia trades, including Hong Kong, Auckland, Osaka and Tilbury. While figures vary between container terminals and different trades, the latest performance indicator reports demonstrate the improving trend of Australian ports.

PARA.TAB: The encouraging thing about these figures is that the figures themselves are good news. They are substantially improved performance indicators for Australian ports, but the important thing about these average container rates of 18 to 19 an hour is that the last WIRA report indicated an average container rate of 15 an hour. So in fact this performance is now progressively improving. At a meeting I had this morning with the major stevedoring executives in Australia, they stressed—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps some Opposition senators should have been at this meeting this morning. In spite of the unions committing themselves to improving this already good performance by matching international best performance, some trenchant criticism was given to me this morning by stevedores themselves. They are sick and tired of politicians in particular continuing to knock the improving performance on the Australian waterfront. This is a matter of serious concern to them in their business. In terms of Australia's overseas image, it is about time that people—whilst pointing out what still needs to be done—gave some public and ungrudging acknowledgment of the significant improvements in the performance of Australian ports. These are the first such improvements in 50 years. I point out that these performance indicators—which show almost a doubling in the performance of Australian ports—are being accomplished with half the original work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Spindler asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I have a detailed answer to Senator Spindler's question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING
SENATE QUESTION
(QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE)
Senator Spindler asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, without notice, on 27 May 1992.

With reference to my Question on Notice No. 1721 on March 30 in which I asked the Minister "how much finance has the Commonwealth contributed to the (NSW) Master Builders' Association Apprenticeship Scheme'.

1.Does he agree that his answer which refers to administrative costs and states that "the NSW Master Builders' Association Group Training Scheme has never been funded by the Commonwealth" is seriously deficient by not mentioning Commonwealth funding to the NSW Master Builders' Association under other headings;

2.Would the Minister explain why he provided a seriously, and apparently intentionally, misleading answer by mentioning the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-Time Training (CRAFT) in general terms and yet omitting to disclose that under CRAFT the MBA received a total of $2,197,739 during the years between 1988/89 and 1991/92;

3.Is the Minister's answer that no audit reports were requested by the Commonwealth still correct, and if in fact no audit reports were requested, why not, since we now know that the Minister's earlier answer was incorrect and that the Commonwealth in fact did contribute funds to the NSW MBA Group Training Scheme.
Senator Cook—The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

1.No. My answer to Question 1721 identified correctly that the NSW Master Builders' Association Group Apprenticeship Scheme has never been funded by the Commonwealth under the Commonwealth/State and Territory Policy on Financial Assistance to Group Schemes, and that group schemes are eligible for and receive employer incentives under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-Time Training (CRAFT) and the Australian Traineeship System (ATS) at current rates.

2.For the reasons identified above the answer provided was not, nor was it intended to be, misleading. My answer to Question 1721 stated correctly that, "group schemes, as with other common law employers of indentured apprentices and trainees are eligible for and receive employer incentives under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-Time Training (CRAFT) and the Australian Traineeship System (ATS) at current rates. This includes rebates of training costs, available under CRAFT, for group training schemes approved to provide off-the-job training courses".
The NSW Master Builders' Association Group Apprenticeship Scheme, as an employer of apprentices, has qualified for the following employer subsidies under the CRAFT scheme since 1988/89:

3.Yes. Since the Commonwealth has not provided any contributions to the establishment costs or administration of the NSW Master Builders' Association Group Apprenticeship Scheme, it has not called for audit reports. The principal sources of Commonwealth subsidy for apprenticeship group training schemes are twofold:

PARA.TAB: i)firstly, a subsidy, provided under the Commonwealth/State and Territory Policy on Financial Assistance to Group Schemes, as a contribution towards the administrative costs of schemes. Schemes which are recipients of this subsidy are required to be established as separately incorporated bodies administered by independent Boards of Directors, and are subject to strict audit and accountability requirements.

The NSW Master Builders' Association Group Apprenticeship Scheme, has never sought nor received any Commonwealth subsidy towards its administration costs under the joint Commonwealth/State and Territory policy of Financial Assistance to Group Schemes.

ii)Secondly, group schemes are eligible to apply for financial assistance under general support programs. All employers of apprentices, including group schemes, who qualify for a Commonwealth Rebate for Full-Time Training (CRAFT) are entitled to a grant for financial assistance for each person employed who is registered or indentured by a State Training Authority. These are incentive payments to employers to encourage them to employ apprentices. The monies paid are not tied or otherwise required to be expended for any particular purposes.

Payment by the Commonwealth of CRAFT incentives to employers is conditional upon verification that individual apprentice training arrangements or indentures are formally registered with the relevant State or Territory Training Authority.

—Senator O'Chee asked me a question without notice on Tuesday this week about the public documents relating Mr Gregory Symons's composition under part X of the Bankruptcy Act held on the public file at the registry of the Federal Court in Sydney. I have a fairly long answer but, given the time that Senator O'Chee spent regaling the chamber on this matter, I should perhaps express it rather than seek to incorporate it.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee alleged that certain important public documents were missing from the file and implied that those documents had been deliberately removed so as to prevent them from being publicly disclosed. He repeated those allegations in the Senate again yesterday. It is now time to put this matter to rest.

Apparently what occurred is that on Tuesday morning of this week a search clerk from a firm of solicitors went to the counter of the Sydney registry of the Federal Court on Senator O'Chee's behalf to search the file regarding Mr Gregory Symons. That file was produced and the search clerk asked the counter officer to find three documents: the statement of affairs; what he called the `deed of arrangement'; and what was termed a `certificate of release'. The statement of affairs was located, but the other two documents sought were not there. This is not surprising.

Three kinds of arrangements can be entered into under part X of the Bankruptcy Act: a deed of arrangement; a deed of assignment; and a composition. Mr Symons entered into a composition. Therefore, no deed of arrangement would or could have been on the file. Neither was there, nor could there have been, a document on the file entitled `certificate of release'. There is no document by that name relevant to a composition under part X of the Bankruptcy Act.

Two of the three documents sought by Senator O'Chee—or at least by the clerk; I presume, acting on his specific instructions—from the file, were not present because they did not and could not exist. It is true that the counter officer, in accordance with normal practice, removed from the file what is called the correspondence folder before providing it to the search clerk. It is the practice of the Sydney registry of the Federal Court to maintain all correspondence in a separate manila folder within the file—that is, letters addressed to the registry, letters from the registry, internal file notes and the like. These are not public documents filed pursuant to the Bankruptcy Act and rules and are, therefore, not normally provided for public search.

However, as with all files which are the subject of continual inspection by members of the public, public documents can sometimes be misplaced in this correspondence folder. I understand that in this case the statement of affairs had been misplaced in the correspondence folder but that after inspection by the counter officer, that document was placed in the file and then made available for inspection by Senator O'Chee's representative. I should add that at no time did the counter officer say that any documents were confidential. Indeed, I understand that Senator O'Chee is welcome to inspect the correspondence folder at any time but that he will find it contains no documents of substantive significance. Many people have examined the public file often, paying the prescribed fee.

Accordingly, the vital point is that the public file relating to Mr Gregory Symons was fully intact and contained all public documents when it was provided to Senator O'Chee's representative. It may be that Senator O'Chee's representative was confused by the entirely separate facts that, firstly, two of the documents sought by Senator O'Chee were not present because they do not exist; and, secondly, the fact that in accordance with normal practice, the correspondence folder was removed from the public file for inspection. Senator O'Chee, of course, leapt inevitably to the wrong conclusion.

On the basis of this thorough and comprehensive investigation, Senator O'Chee then rushed into the Senate and asked a question without notice in which he alleged that important public documents were missing from the file—which they were not—and implied that they had been deliberately removed as part of some cover-up. On the basis of confusion or misdirection on the part of the clerk engaged on his behalf, Senator O'Chee made a very serious allegation. What he was, in effect, alleging was that an officer or officers of the Federal Court of Australia had, presumably at the Government's behest for some political purpose, deliberately removed public documents from a public court file and concealed them from public search. It is disgraceful that Senator O'Chee would make such allegations on such a flimsy basis.

It gets worse. Naturally, inquiries were put in train as a result of Senator O'Chee's question without notice. As a result of those inquiries, I advised Senator O'Chee that evening that the public Federal Court file on Mr Symons was intact and contained all appropriate documents and that no documents were missing. I provided him with copies of the major documents from the file, including the section 188 authority; the statement of affairs, which I understand he already had a copy of; the statement by the debtor proposing a composition; the report by the controlling trustee; the minutes of the meeting of creditors and related documents; a special resolution of that meeting; the controlling trustee's certificate that a special resolution for the acceptance of a composition had been passed to the meeting of creditors; and, finally, the certificate by the trustee that the terms of the composition had been carried out.

Copies of all these documents were provided to Senator O'Chee on Tuesday evening with advice that while these constituted the primary documents of significance, the whole of the file could be accessed during normal business hours at the Federal Court registry in Sydney. I emphasise that it was made abundantly clear to Senator O'Chee that at no stage had there been any public documents missing from the Federal Court file.

I also understand that Senator O'Chee personally had telephone conversations during Tuesday afternoon with relevant officers of the court registry, including the Sydney registrar, Mr Gilroy, who assured him that documents from the public files were not withheld as confidential. At that point one might have expected that Senator O'Chee would have come into the Senate and expressed his apology for the allegations he had made, particularly to the officers of the Federal Court of Australia whom he had implicitly maligned so seriously. Not only did that not occur, but almost incredibly Senator O'Chee stood up yesterday and repeated allegations which he could not fail to know by then were completely untrue and without foundation.

Senator O'Chee attempted in his speech yesterday to make much of the fact that I said in my press release on Tuesday evening that his representative had looked at the wrong file and that this was not correct. The Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, who relayed this information to me as a result of his telephone inquiries of the Federal Court, has since advised me that this should have read `was looking for the wrong documents', as he had misinterpreted what he had been told on the subject.

This does not detract from the main thrust of my press release or the advice I gave to Senator O'Chee; though to the extent that it may reflect on the competence of the search clerk to look at the correct file I naturally apologise. What he apparently did was to ask for the wrong documents.

Finally, so as to ensure that there can be no possible misunderstanding, I repeat that the public Federal Court file concerning the composition under part X of the Bankruptcy Act entered into by Mr Gregory Bernard Symons is and was at all times entirely intact and available for public search during business hours. No public documents are, or ever have been, missing from it.
