SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to questions without notice asked by Senator Alston on 26 May and 28 May 1991 relating to Senator Graham Richardson.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of concern on 26 May and, indeed, today was the nature and extent of the involvement of Senator Richardson in a very large-scale commercial project. On its face, it is one that should give rise to a great deal of concern in that an experienced member of parliament—he having been in Parliament by that time for some four years—deliberately chose to bypass the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Dr Garnaut, as the Australian Ambassador to China at the time.

PARA.TAB: The answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) discloses the duration of the visit, being 5 to 7 March. It tells me quite gratuitously that no assistance was provided by Austrade. However, I did not seek that information. I sought details as to the nature and extent of Senator Richardson's visit; whether he received any payment, remuneration or recompense for his services; and details of the level of concern.

It is quite clear that it would be very unusual for an ambassador to feel the need to contact a Prime Minister about the activities of a backbencher in a foreign country. One can only assume that Dr Garnaut was very concerned indeed. I would be very surprised if his concern merely extended to an apparent breach of protocol. It is much more likely that what exercised Dr Garnaut's mind was that Senator Richardson may well have had a commercial interest in the activities that he was pursuing. Senator Evans's answer seems to confirm that Senator Richardson was indeed acting as an intermediary—he has not denied that element of the proposition—and one can therefore understand that Dr Garnaut would have been particularly concerned to know the nature and extent of Senator Richardson's activities.

It is therefore of the utmost importance that Senator Evans should provide the Senate with more detailed information as to whether Senator Richardson received any payment, remuneration or recompense for his services. There would clearly be a matter not just of impropriety but conflict of interest for a member of parliament to receive any money, any form of recompense or consideration for involvement in a commercial project.

It is a matter which ought to have been disclosed, if not at the time, certainly to this chamber and certainly by way of explanation to the Prime Minister. We do not know what the Prime Minister said. Senator Evans seems to be assiduous in avoiding providing even the merest details.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is this a matter for me now?

—Senator Evans has chosen to provide scant details of a matter on which he acknowledges there was concern on the part of Dr Garnaut. He has investigated the matter to the point that Dr Garnaut has recently had a discussion with his Department. Senator Evans is clearly aware of some of the details, but he chooses to not make all of them available. The gravamen of the concern is that Senator Richardson may well have been involved in a commercial project, he may well have received some recompense, Dr Garnaut may well have been outraged at that fact; yet we have not been told anything of the detail of that.

PARA.TAB: I cannot for a moment imagine that Dr Garnaut felt compelled to ring the Prime Minister simply because of a breach of protocol. It must have gone well beyond that. If the Minister does not regard it as a matter of the utmost seriousness, I cannot understand where he ever draws the line. I therefore invite the Minister to table all relevant documents to ensure that the Senate is made fully aware of Senator Richardson's activities, concern over which can only be heightened, I might say, by the second part of my question today.

It is quite clear that Senator Richardson has made a habit of visiting this part of the world on a very regular basis. Given that we have now had it confirmed today that he was in fact acting as an intermediary—I think the Minister's words were `seeking to assist Multiplex and Kumagai Gumi'—we ought to know the basis on which he did that, the circumstances that led him to do what he did and whether there was any quid pro quo. These are matters which go very much to the heart of not just propriety on the part of the Minister's Department but also matters that obviously concerned the Ambassador and which were relayed to the Prime Minister.

We ought to know what the Prime Minister's response was. Did the Prime Minister merely say, `Do not do it again, Richo' or `You are Richo so I will not even hit you with a feather' or did he say, `Do it again and you will get the chop. If anyone else did it in similar circumstances I would cut him off at the knees'? We ought to know these things. We ought to know just what response this Government makes if there is evidence of a member of Parliament, clearly someone who was close to the highest echelons of government and who was on the verge of becoming a Minister, choosing to involve himself in what would be a very unusual level of activity for a member of Parliament. I ask the Minister to provide full and frank details accordingly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given full and frank details about the nature of the records and the material that is held on departmental files about this particular matter. It is exactly as I have described it. There is no documentary material whatsoever, I am advised, on departmental files, on my office files, relating to any possible exchange between Dr Garnaut and the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, on this matter in 1987.

PARA.TAB: It really is a pretty extraordinary thing I am being asked to further investigate. It is a conversation between an ambassador who is no longer an ambassador and a Prime Minister who is no longer a Prime Minister about a person who is no longer a Minister and who was not at the time a Minister, in a situation where obviously the basic nature of the concern by the Ambassador, as I have already intimated, was essentially a concern simply at not being advised of the presence of Senator Richardson in the country in relation to a major commercial project in which the Government obviously had an interest.

On the basis of my knowledge of the situation, everything else that Senator Alston has said has been totally fanciful. He is simply trying to create a sort of scenario which is utterly without foundation so far as I am aware. When I say that I am not in a position to prove a negative at this stage but it really is quite extraordinary and really quite outrageous that Senator Alston can construct some particular view of what might have been involved, what the nature of the concern might have been, and just sit in this chamber and use it to slur the character of Senator Richardson. I do not think it has been an edifying little contribution from Senator Alston, but then he would not want to break his duck in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I want to raise with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) concerning this matter. One is his statement that he has given full and frank answers on this matter. Might I point out that he has given neither full nor frank answers. Many matters are outstanding, including information he has agreed to table. There is the information he agreed to seek for me during the process of the Committee of the Whole debate on the Appropriation Bills yesterday morning concerning the records of Suva, Hong Kong and the Taiwanese gentleman who was sought by Multiplex to have brought into Australia. That remains outstanding, as does the document for Senator Teague. There are also the documents which the Minister claims he somehow cannot table because they are `consular'.

PARA.TAB: I have been troubled by this word and what the Minister means by it when he says it. I took a look at the Macquarie Dictionary and the Macquarie Dictionary describes a consul as `an agent appointed by an independent state to reside in a foreign state and to discharge certain administrative duties'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not an English-speaking unit now.

—I would have thought that if the Minister is claiming something to be consular and that it somehow has some sort of imprimatur, then we are entitled to know what on earth he is talking about. The dictionary simply describes `consular' as the task; the Oxford English Dictionary goes somewhat further. But I can see no reason why documents pertaining to the consul—which is what I take `consular' to mean—or his activities should not be tabled here in the Parliament, and indeed they must be.

PARA.TAB: As I said to the Minister before, the reason that he gives, which is that those documents contain references to a court case in a foreign country, has no effect under sub judice rules. It is in the public interest that he makes all that documentation available to the Senate. I can only say, as we said yesterday, that the Minister's answers have been neither full nor frank and that it is simply not believable that all these matters and activities were taking place in the Minister's private office and Department and nobody told him.
We have had another example of a forgetful Minister today. Minister Ros Kelly put out a kit on the environment but today refused to endorse it, even though she signed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Surely Senator Bishop, who is speaking to a motion to take note of the Foreign Minister's answer, is now drawing an extremely long bow by starting to speak to the Senate on a matter relating to Minister Kelly in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—I ask Senator Bishop to relate her points to the motion at hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am relating it to the comments concerning Senator Evans's answer because I am describing the sort of culture in which the Government operates. I said yesterday that his defence was an amnesia-led defence. I am waiting for the moment when Senator Evans tells us that it was all the fault of his officers. As I said yesterday, Senator Evans advised that Mr Kupa, his adviser, swore his statutory declaration. As I pointed out yesterday, if I had been in his shoes I would have sworn it also.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, the next step in this saga is going to be, `It was not any fault,' said the Minister. `It was all the fault of my advisers because they didn't tell me'—just like Ros Kelly's advisers did not tell her that this was a rotten kit going out to schools. If Senator Evans at the end of the day is going to continue to say that he was not advised and that he simply runs his office where he is not informed by his staff as to what is going on, then he ought to stand aside for incompetency as well as for misleading Parliament.

To put the final word to it, we require the full and frank tabling and disclosure of all the documents that have been referred to, both in question and in answer, without this curious defence that they are consular documents, which simply means that they are documents relating to the consul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the same motion and to add emphasis to the fact that we have now been waiting for a couple of days for Senator Evans to table the schedule of cables and other matters which relate to this matter. Senator Evans promised that. That has not been tabled. In relation to a question yesterday, Senator Evans promised to table a communication from his Department to his office on 21 April. That has not yet been tabled. In the same answer that he gave, he made an absolutely astonishing statement, on reflection, when one reads through it, particularly as this is the Minister who has not received full briefings from his Department on this matter, despite the fact that it has been in the news for quite a long period.

PARA.TAB: I wish to draw the Minister's attention to a particular statement he made yesterday, which appears in Hansard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that during that period there were one, two or more cables sent from Pohnpei addressing particular consular matters and things of that kind which did come to me in the context of other cables. I have no particular recollection of it.
Again, the same problem: no memory of matters—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Nick Greiner's memory.

—I know that Senator Faulkner is sensitive about this, but I think that if Senator Evans wanted somebody to defend him he certainly would not be asking Senator Faulkner. The question I put to the Minister for Foreign Affairs—
—He is indefensible; that is the problem with him.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, would you mind speaking to Senator Faulkner and asking him to keep quiet for a brief moment?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—I think both sides have transgressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am standing on my feet and I have the call. I am entitled to speak, am I not?
—Yes, all right.
—Well, would you mind asking him to keep quiet?
—I ask for the interjections to be quieter and less frequent.

—Ask him to keep quiet. That is a very simple instruction. I ask the Minister whether, with regard to the material regarding the communications that his Department has received—which, hopefully, he will detail at some stage in the near future—he could list all the cables which his office has received on this matter and table those cables.

PARA.TAB: As was pointed out by Senator Hill today, it is inconceivable that with all the press reports that occurred during the period from 3 April to 7 May there were no briefings from the Department on these matters—no briefings at all, apparently. That is quite astonishing. Apparently there were no cables that can be tabled which show that the Department was carrying out a proper monitoring of these activities. We are waiting for the schedule of documents which Senator Evans promised. We are waiting for him to table the communications which his Department sent to his office on 21 April. We want him to table, in particular, all the cables relating to this and associated matters which he referred to in his answer yesterday.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Burns on 28 May 1992 relating to productivity in the construction industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer to the question today by Senator Cook to Senator Burns was notable for two things: firstly, when Senator Cook was challenged on a point of order to declare whether or not he had a conflict of interest regarding the question before him and whether or not he was a member of the BWIU, he declined to do so; and, secondly, in the macho-ness of his answer, he failed to spell out what the Federal Government's response would be to the Gyles report.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the second matter first. I note that in his answer today Senator Cook spelt out that members of the MBA, or people involved in the building industry, should be prosecuted for the wrongs that they have done. I do not have an argument with that. He then went on to spell out the fact that the New South Wales Government should take action against the BWIU if it wanted to proceed with the deregistration proceedings against the BWIU. In the Gyles report there is a recommendation for the deregistration of the federal BWIU.

The question I pose to the Government and to Senator Cook is: why did he not address that particular aspect? It is all very well to come into the chamber, thump the table and say that everybody else should take action to end the corruption that has been pointed to in the report, but not spell out what the Government's position is. The Government has a very clear responsibility in terms of the Gyles report and it will be interesting to hear in due course what that action will be. I suspect from the dorothy dix question asked by Senator Burns today that the Minister has already given notice that the Federal Government intends to do nothing.

I think what happened here today was absolutely deplorable. The Minister could have spelt out quite clearly to this chamber the fact that he is still a member of the BWIU. He could also have spelt out quite clearly in his answer, when challenged to do so, the fact that he has been an official of the BWIU. We will explore certain aspects of that at a later time.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I said that I would speak only briefly so as to clear up the matter of the Minister's membership of the BWIU. I seek leave to table the returns of the Minister's private interests which he signed on 11 November 1991 and 28 June 1990—bearing in mind that he became Minister for Industrial Relations on 4 April 1990. It is stated quite clearly that the Minister is a member of the BWIU. As such, I believe he had a duty during Question Time today to declare that interest.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a reprehensible and disgusting effort by Senator Winston Crane to smear me. The words `reprehensible' and `disgusting' are used in this context deliberately and after some consideration and analysis. The position is this: the organisations to which I belong are declared by me. The Government makes that information available to the community. There is no doubt, nor has there ever been any doubt, with which organisations I am associated and of which organisations I am a member.
—We have got it here.

—That is right. Senators have got it here by courtesy of the fact that I make it available. There is no evidence of what organisation Senator Winston Crane is a member. The reason there is no evidence is that he does not do as I do. He does not swear a declaration of interests and make it available to the community. He, like the rest of honourable senators opposite, conceals his interest.
—That is a lie.

—Senator Crane conceals his interest. Until such time as Senator Crane does as I do and makes available on the public record all of his interests for public scrutiny, he is concealing his interests from public scrutiny.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is Senator Cook suggesting that Senator Crane is a member of the Master Builders Association? If so, he ought to say so. Senator Cook complains about smearing. In fact, he is a principal exponent of smearing; he is demonstrating it in the chamber right now.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order and, of course, there never was a point of order. It is typical of the Opposition and of Senator O'Chee to do this sort of thing. My point is that my interests are on the public record and are disclosed; the interests of Opposition senators are not. There is a word that describes that—it is `hypocrisy'.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Crane raised this point to indicate a possible source of conflict of interest. It was in that context that he was asked during Question Time to disclose whether he was still a member of the BWIU. He was commenting on a matter relating to that union. There is a clear, distinct conflict of interest between his ministerial responsibilities and his membership of a trade union which is under attack and under suspicion.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Quite right, Madam Acting Deputy President—again there is no point of order. This was an effort to disrupt my point. My interests are disclosed; the honourable senator's are not. There is a word that describes the way in which this matter has been raised—that word is `hypocrisy'.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to what has been said here. It was said that I was asked to disclose my interests. I was not. I was asked a question going to my ministerial responsibilities by Senator Burns. He asked me a question about the Gyles Royal Commission's report into the New South Wales building and construction industry. I replied that I welcomed the report and the findings. I said that, upon being sworn in as Minister by the Governor-General, one of my first acts—and the public record on this matter is available—in April 1990 was to raise the question of building industry and building construction reform in this country with the State Ministers for labour at the conference in Queenstown, New Zealand in which the State and the Commonwealth Ministers for labour met and discussed issues of importance. That was my first ministerial act.

I did that for this reason: for a long time I had been concerned about the state of the building industry in this country. It is also a fact that, as a Minister, I took action and in 1990 put down legislation in this chamber, which was carried, to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation for another period of time, given its reprehensible behaviour and the actions and intimations of criminality on its behalf.

It cannot be said by anybody that I have not acted responsibly. When I did that, my action was acclaimed by the industry, the Master Builders Association, the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the State governments concerned and the ACTU. As a consequence of taking that action, I did not think, and I do not think, that to simply move against an organisation constitutes cleaning up the industry because it does not.

There is no single party in this industry that can claim to have behaved itself impeccably—all have some taint or another. The nature of this industry—which operates on the basis of the lowest tender being successful, and employment lasting as long as the job takes to build—might be euphemistically described as tough and difficult, and it is an industry in which many of the participants seek to cut corners. It may be euphemistically described in those terms. To just pick on one element of the industry and deal with that is not to say that the complete picture of problems has been solved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody has said that.

—That is why I, not the Opposition, took the actions that I did in talking with the State governments and the major industry organisations on the employer side, the union side and among the professions that work in this industry to achieve, as was announced by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in October 1991, an in-principle agreement by all of the major players.

PARA.TAB: Who are the major players? All of the unions that operate in this industry, the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors that operates on behalf of all of the national building companies, the Master Builders Association which operates on behalf of major building companies—medium and small—and all of the professions, including the State governments of Queensland, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia.

The only governments that have not signed on to reform this industry are the governments in Tasmania and New South Wales. We have a commitment to a set of reform goals in this industry which will bring substantial savings to the Australian community, straighten out this industry once and for all, increase its efficiency, position it to sell its product as a construction industry overseas in the burgeoning construction belt of the ASEAN economies and deliver a high quality product at a low price, on time, to the Australian community. They are the goals of the in-principle agreement which all of the parties have signed.

Do those opposite want me to declare my interest? I declare my interest, which is to succeed at delivering those goals for Australia—and that is a responsible interest of the Government. That means that a lot of the problems of this industry have to be cleaned up. The problems of this industry are not exclusively industrial relations problems—although there are some of those, no doubt.

The Gyles Royal Commission has brought forward new information. I congratulate the Royal Commissioner, Roger Gyles QC, for adducing this information from his inquiry. The most significant finding and new information that came out of the evidence that Gyles adduced is that leading building companies in this country—supported by their industry organisations, which have taken a cut—have been involved in collusive tendering practices that have ripped off governments and clients of this industry for, to quote Gyles, `billions of dollars'. That invites a consideration that maybe there are matters here of criminality.

What reduces this debate to a political farce, rather than a debate about serious national matters of how that money is to be recovered, is when the Premier of New South Wales, without notice to the Commonwealth, holds a press conference on the release of this report and does not mention at all in his press conference the fact that there has been this collusive tendering—not one word of it. What the Premier does mention is that the Building Workers Industrial Union has to be deregistered. That reduces this significant national issue to the level of playing politics, and that is what I think is an abomination and a disgrace.

If people are to be serious about reforming this industry and achieving the changes made in the in-principle agreement, which I have developed with the cooperation of the main players, then one takes an objective view of what are the problems, and fashions a sensible and intelligent strategy about how one solves them rather than simply playing politics about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's what you do all the time; you're the expert.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I observed the proceedings before, when Senator Kemp was complaining about interjections and noise. Why do you not uphold his point of order now, when he is hypocritical and two-faced? He whinges like a jib when he is making his contribution and now he interjects. I do not object to the interjection, but someone should draw public attention to his weak pleading to the Chair.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me bring my remarks to a conclusion, based on the facts that I have put forward. This Government, during my tenure in this post as Minister for Industrial Relations, acted immediately to clean up this industry and to gain the cooperation of the majority of the States and of the major industry participants, their organisations and the professions that support it in a set of principles that will achieve that. Do those opposite want me to declare my interest? That is my interest. That is the national interest and that is the interest of this industry, as it is of the economy and of all consumers of building and construction, be they home purchasers, investors in multi-storey construction or developers and proponents of major projects in this country. That is my interest and that is the record.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will find that record and that interest acclaimed, dare I say it, by all of the players who say to me constantly, `Thank God you did it, because it required the Government to take a strong stand to enforce a discipline upon this industry. We were unable to reform it from within. We are glad the Government set these parameters, which means that we can now focus on those objectives'.

The Gyles Royal Commission has served a great public duty in exposing collusive tendering practices which have cost, I think in this case the Commonwealth, millions of dollars. That is something we will obviously deal with. The New South Wales Government, as I stand here—despite the release of its findings earlier this week—has not yet deigned to contact the Commonwealth Government and ask, in any formal way, for its cooperation in dealing with the findings of the Royal Commission.

If a government is serious, it observes the normal courtesies and contacts the government from which it wants cooperation and seeks that. The New South Wales Government thus far has not done so. I can give the chamber this assurance: if it does, it will get cooperation from the Commonwealth because we were already in the field of reform before it got there. If there are other valuable elements of this Royal Commission, we will take them and fold them into our strategy because that will help us achieve the goal that we have set for ourselves. So that is the important answer. Let me come back to this question that I did not declare my interest. I declared my interest—here it is—on a public document.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had to go and get it.
—No, it has always been available. It is a public document—up front, out in the open, nothing to hide.
—Why didn't you bring it into the chamber?

—Senator Newman is interjecting; she has not declared her interest. Senator Crane is interjecting; he has not declared his interest. Senator Bishop is interjecting; she has not declared her interest. What are the interests of those opposite in this? No-one knows, because they will not declare them. I say to those opposite: do not come in here and try to smear me and the way this Government has fronted up to and dealt with these problems. That is low politics. If those opposite want to play low politics, fine, they can play low politics if they wish. But if they do, they should not expect that anyone in this industry will regard them as anything other than low politicians. They should not expect that anyone in this industry will regard them as serious about the fundamental questions here at stake for the reform of this industry.

PARA.TAB: If there are any other speakers in this debate, I would expect, in order to avoid the tag of hypocrisy being appended to their names, that they would stand first and declare their interests, because their interests at this point remain secret. I expect anyone who wishes to speak in this debate to stand and declare their interest. There are some who have said to me that the Royal Commission in New South Wales was started as an electoral stunt by the Greiner Government to try to win the last election, to kick the anti-union can and to stir up all these allegations, and that what we are now seeing is a stunt by the Premier of New South Wales to save his hide.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't work; Bronwyn is organising against him now.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I cannot let the sort of nonsense that Senator Faulkner goes on with be on the record.
—Is there only one Bronwyn in New South Wales?
—There is only one Bronwyn in this Parliament here. I ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—I do not consider that Senator Faulkner used any unparliamentary language.

TALK.START.PARA: —He made an improper suggestion as to action I was taking. I wish him to withdraw.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise to support Senator Bishop. That remark was offensive. It insinuated that Senator Bishop was overthrowing Nick Greiner and, as such, it does not represent anything to do with truth. It is a misrepresentation of her position. In her words and my words, it is an absolute lie. I ask that you rule that it be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I find Senator Faulkner's remark highly offensive, highly distasteful and untrue and I ask that he be asked to withdraw that remark immediately.
—Senator Bishop, there are many such statements made in this place every day.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The offensiveness of the remark is often in the eye of the beholder. Quite clearly, Senator Bishop resented the remark and found it offensive for Senator Faulkner to say that she had withdrawn her support of Nick Greiner. In those circumstances, we could at least call upon Senator Faulkner either to stick by his remark or to withdraw it, rather than you making a ruling at this stage, Madam Acting Deputy President. I would suggest that course of action.

—On that point of order, given Senator Bishop's invitation and the invitation of Senator Ray, I am now convinced that Senator Bishop is behind Nick Greiner all the way. I am not quite sure where he is going, but I am sure she is with him to the second last ditch and I do withdraw my comment.

—That is not good enough. I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I want those remarks withdrawn unconditionally. I find the effrontery of the remarks that preceded the withdrawal quite unsatisfactory and in no way satisfactory.
—You don't support him them?

—The point is that the man has told an untruth in this Parliament, which is not unfamiliar in this place from Senator Faulkner. I ask him to withdraw his remarks unconditionally, because his remarks were totally untrue and offensive and I do not need him to give a preamble which is equally offensive.

—On the point of order: a remark is either withdrawn or it is not. Senator Faulkner used the withdrawing of his remark to make another cheap shot at Senator Bishop. He should be asked to withdraw unconditionally.

—I withdraw the remarks I made and Senator Bishop has hurt my feelings. I am a very sensitive senator and I ask her to withdraw the comments she made about my telling this Parliament untruths on a regular basis.
—For a new age, sensitive man, I withdraw them.
—All I can say is: thank God. If politicians ever wonder why the public hold them in low esteem, we have just had an example of the reason.

PARA.TAB: I was saying that, irrespective of what is the superficial play-out of the political game, this Government will nonetheless treat the findings of the Roger Gyles QC Royal Commission seriously. It will respond comprehensively and fully in a short while, after it has considered and digested his report.

If there is a belief on behalf of the New South Wales Government that there has been illegality in the conduct of individuals or organisations in this industry, we say: `Do not wait for our reply to your findings'; we say that the New South Wales Government should take legal action immediately. If the New South Wales Government believes that the BWIU—and I am a member of the Western Australian branch—in New South Wales has misconducted itself, I say to the New South Wales Government, `Take action for its deregistration in the Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales and do it forthwith. Put your evidence before the judge and let the court make a determination. Do not wait for us'.

I draw attention to the recommendations in the findings of the Royal Commission that the Federal BWIU has conducted itself in such a way that it has supported award restructuring and the progressive development of the industry. I also draw attention to the remark in the findings that there seems to be two organisations.

I conclude by saying that nothing will prevent us from rigorously pursuing our reform objectives. If Senator Winston Crane thinks that I treat the oath of office as a Minister of the Crown in this Government in less than a fully serious and proper manner, and that I am somehow influenced by a membership of the Western Australian branch of the BWIU, he should say so. If he is game enough to say that, he should say it outside this building. Otherwise he will simply be a coward who is not able to justify allegations of smear on his behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is wholly improper for Senator Cook or any other senator to accuse another member of this chamber of being a coward. It has previously been ruled that that is unparliamentary and I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to invite him to withdraw it.

—I did not say that. I said that, if Senator Crane is prepared to make the allegation, which he has not yet made, that I have been influenced in my dealings with this industry by membership of a trade union, then he should say it outside this building. He may not be prepared to say it. If he is not, we will draw our own conclusions about what his intent in raising this matter might be.

—I did not intend to speak on this matter, but, having heard the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook)—who is an apologist for the BWIU—I thought I would speak fairly briefly. The Minister has obviously had enough because he is leaving the place. This Minister, who is also known as the Minister for BWIU and the Minister assisting the ACTU, is bringing legislation into this place which is to the benefit of the Building Workers Industrial Union and has the audacity to get up here and say that Senator Winston Crane is somehow maligning him if he goes outside this chamber and says, `Guess what? The Minister for Industrial Relations is a member of the BWIU and was a senior official'.
—That's pretty defamatory.
—That is what he says is defamatory. This person in industrial relations is trying to convince us—
—This is just a disruption of business.

—Senator Tate has no sense. I am amazed to hear such a remark coming from Senator Tate, of all people. From other people such a remark would not surprise me. There is sense of propriety here. Here we have Minister Bolkus getting all het up about the disclosure of financial donations to political parties and candidates—quite rightly and with our support—and saying that this is some sort of corruption, yet there is a Minister in the Government, who was a senior official of the BWIU before he came in here and is a continuing member of the BWIU—
—So what?
—Senator Ray says, `So what?' Government members have lost all sense of decency.
—Show us where the conflict is in his public actions.

—The conflict is that he is member of the BWIU and he is handling a matter which relates to the BWIU—it could be the Gyles Royal Commission in New South Wales. He is bringing in legislation that will force subcontractors to join the BWIU, his own union. If he had any sense of decency, he would dissociate himself from the Commission and from any legislation which favours his own union.
—How do you know it favours it? Where is your conflict of interest?

—Senator Ray, this is a thing that is concerning everyone in this country. Every small business operator in this country is concerned because they will be coerced. This the same union. The Minister stands up here and says, `If there is evidence of some sort of illegality'. Everyone would know, particularly Senator Cook because he was a senior official—
—When?

—Before he came into this place. He has come in here and said, `If this illegality has gone on', but everyone knows what has happened in the building industry and it is going on today. There are little subcontractors in my own State—
—You did not have the guts to do over the BLF. We had to do it.

—It favoured the BWIU, did it not? You got rid of the BLF. There are small contractors even today in my State. The Labor Government falls over and plays dead any time a militant union wants to do anything. For instance, only two weeks ago I was talking with a concrete mixer who was doing some work at the weekend in the Fortitude Valley in Brisbane. He said that a couple of heavies came along and asked, `Where is your TA?'. He asked, `What is a TA?'. They said, `You're black, mate. Where is your membership of the BLF?'. He was then told that unless he joined up by Monday he would be black.

PARA.TAB: Recently, on a major construction site, a unionist turned up and said, `This is a construction site. It doesn't matter who works here, they have to join'. That is what is going on. In the end, the unions are not at all interested in individual names. They say, `Give us the money and we'll go away'. They are not even bothering to check names. That is the sort of stuff that is going on. It is not ideological; it is crooked. It is Mafia stuff.

When Senator Cook says, `If anything illegal has been going on, let's take them to court', I would challenge anyone in society to be brave enough to take these people to court. That person would not survive. The unions still have memories of companies such as Mainline. After it went into liquidation, the union said, `It couldn't have happened to a better lot of Bs', forgetting the fact that it had destroyed hundreds of jobs.

The Minister for Industrial Relations took two hours to come out and say that he was a member of the BWIU, even though it is on his document. This is the person looking after the industrial relations of this country. We may as well have Dracula looking after the blood bank.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations,

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook, says that he takes his oath of office very seriously and that he is a good Minister. Yet this is the Minister who has told us untruths about Robe River, besmirched John Panizza and refused to apologise to them both. This is the man who, as Senator Parer said, took two hours to admit that he was a member of the BWIU.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook spoke at great length about the fact that he had declared his interest on a document. He asked honourable senators on this side of the chamber to sign the same document. What a nonsense! The document he has signed is one which he is required to sign because he is a Minister. The day I or anyone on this side of the chamber becomes a Minister, we will sign a similar document. In that document he is required to disclose whether he belongs to an organisation which may bring him into a position of conflict of interest. Clearly, the BWIU meets that category.

Senator Cook has disclosed it in that document, but then sought not to speak about it. I presume that he particularly did not want to tell the nation that he had been a former office-holder of the BWIU and that he still remained a member during Question Time because it is televised. He did not want to tell the Australian people that as a member of the BWIU, he is fostering and sponsoring legislation into this Parliament which will force independent contractors, against their will, to become members of—that is, pay money to—the organisation of which he was previously an official and remains a member.

We had a big discussion this morning about what constitutes a pecuniary interest. One matter that came before us this morning was the fact that the Australian Labor Party is constructing a new building—said to be worth at least $80m—and has managed to secure for itself the Australian National Audit Office as a tenant. We are told that it is a lease that will run for 15 years, with a five-year option, and indeed, that would mean that the Australian Labor Party will get $20m of taxpayers' money by way of the Australian National Audit Office paying rent.

We also had a discussion as to whether members of the Australian Labor Party therefore had a pecuniary interest in that lease because they will all benefit from that money by way of supporting their campaigns. If a Minister is to sign a document and disclose that he is a member of that union and that it is the source of possible future conflict, it is most important that he admit to it when he stands to answer a question on an inquiry into the building industry where the commissioner has said that the BWIU should be deregistered.

Senator Cook stood up to try to defend his union and to damn other interests. It was very interesting that named in that inquiry on the employer side was someone that we have come to know very well in its association with Mr Symons and Senator Richardson—that is, Multiplex. It is a well-known player in Western Australia. It was represented at the famous lunch where money was sought for a donation to the Australian Labor Party.

To say that it is all a rather incestuous affair would be putting it mildly. The Australian Labor Party, Multiplex and BWIU are now erecting a building of which we do not know the source of the funds. We do not even know who is building it, for that matter. One could almost say that the ALP is now securing a pipeline to the Mint with a guaranteed income of over $20m courtesy of the taxpayer. That is why my colleague Senator Crane sought leave to take note of the Minister's answer.

Senator Cook signed that document as a Minister of the Crown. If he takes his oath of office seriously, when responding to what was a dorothy dix question during Question Time, the Minister ought to have disclosed the fact that he was a former office-bearer of the BWIU and a continuing member of the BWIU. He propounds trade union policy very often in the guise of ministerial responsibility. Senator Crane was quite right to take note of that answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to make a few comments in closing this debate. First, this debate need never have happened if Senator Cook had just said in answering the question, when he had the opportunity to do so, `I am a member of the BWIU'; that is all he had to say. The fact that he did not do that then but then took some two hours before he came back into this chamber and said it, makes one feel rather suspicious about the reasons why, when he was on television and people were watching, he would not say it then.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Cook said that I had concealed my membership, I presume, of various organisations. I refute that totally. It is a misrepresentation of the facts. I have not concealed my representation of various organisations. In fact, I highlight in particular that when the wool debate was on last year, I declared that I had an interest in it as a woolgrower and as a member of a grower organisation. It is absolute nonsense. I imagine that many other honourable members and senators of this Parliament have done similar things. Certainly in this case, when I did have an interest in a particular matter, I made it quite clear on the public record.

My next point concerns why the Gyles report is so important when considering the two points that I raised in my opening comments. The first point was that there was no statement in terms of the dorothy dix question as to what either the Federal Government or Senator Cook, as Minister for Industrial Relations, would do about the Gyles report. However, there was a lot of advice to the building industry and the New South Wales Government as to what they should do about it.

When Senator Cook came back in here, he said that the Government would treat the report seriously and that it would make some comment in the very near future. It is worth noting in terms of this debate and where the various interests lie, particularly in New South Wales, that, while we refer to the State branch of the BWIU, it must be recognised that most people involved in the building industry in New South Wales on the employee side are members of the Federal BWIU.

The apologist—he came in here and walked out from the debate—for the Secretary of the ACTU and the BWIU referred to me as a coward. He challenged me to make certain comments outside this chamber which, if I were to make them, would be to my detriment. What on earth was he conjuring up in his mind about what I was going to say? He was trying to provoke me into saying something. He has employed typical union tactics—to which this country has been subjected for many years, particularly in the building industry—of intimidating people into doing things. I inform the Minister that I will not be intimidated into doing any of these particular things. If I want to say something, they will be my words out of my mouth; they will not be put in my mouth by the Minister.

The final reason why this issue is very important is that the subcontractors legislation will come before this Parliament next week. This legislation is fundamentally about the Troubleshooters case, which emanated from the case between the BWIU and Troubleshooters. That is what it is about. The linkage into declarations of interests and the position where people stand on that legislation is crucial.

This episode would not have happened if the Minister had said in Question Time today the simple words, `I am a member of the BWIU'. He chose not to do so. He came in here fuming and jumping, with wrath coming out of his nostrils, purely and simply because he did not want the people of Australia to see him on television stating that he was a member of the BWIU.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of an answer given by Senator Ray in Question Time earlier today.
—Is leave granted?
—I indicate that leave is granted on the basis, as indicated across the chamber, that this may only last five minutes.
—Leave is granted.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Loosley on 28 May 1992 regarding the opinion polls on Australia's defence capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: In a dorothy dixer in Question Time today the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) chose to talk about a press release put out by a colleague, Mr Downer, on 21 May. The Minister left the very clear impression in the mind of the listener that Mr Downer was calling for an increase in defence spending. The Minister has indicated that he did not say that Mr Downer was calling for that, but he canvassed the press reports reporting Mr Downer's press release. As I represent Mr Downer in this place, it is important that I make it very clear exactly what Mr Downer was saying in his press release of 21 May.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer called on the Government to increase spending on the combat capability of Australia's Defence Force. He referred in his press release to the publication of an opinion poll which had been put out that day showing that Australians lacked confidence in our defence capability. They rightly have reason to be concerned about our defence capability because for nearly a decade the Government has been whittling away the combat capability of the Australian Defence Force. I say that very advisedly.

When Labor has made savings in defence, they have been made continually in the combat area. We have had the recent example of two out of our six regular infantry battalions being abolished. A couple of our major ships are tied up rather than the money being spent on taking them to sea. Year after year we have had continual reductions in the flying time for our Air Force. We have had reductions in the steaming time for our Navy. We have had exercises cancelled left, right and centre for our Army and the other services. We have also had a continual whittling away of the training days for the Army reserves. What has happened to the ability of the Army reserves to do the job they are called on to do is a matter for a speech all on its own. Whether we are talking about the regular forces or the reservists, this Government has always taken it out of the hide of the combat forces. We are in very real trouble when we have 6,768 days of unpaid service undertaken by Australia's reservists. That is what happened last financial year. It is continuing.

The Opposition wants to make sure that the cuts that have to be made, because of the mismanagement of Australia's economy and because of the inability to currently spend more on defence, are made out of the tail. How can we justify in any way having 24,000 to 25,000 public servants servicing a defence force of under 68,000? The mind boggles. Yet successive Ministers for defence have refused to take the necessary action. If ever there was a case of Yes, Minister it was when Minister Beazley received a joint parliamentary committee report. He got snowed quite clearly by his bureaucrats and was prepared to be snowed. He took no action on the recommendations of the Cross Committee back in 1986 or 1987.

This problem has continued. Every time we argue this case we hear the Minister of the day argue, as Minister Ray did today, that there have been cuts in the civilian component. There have not been substantial cuts. The Williamstown dockyard, for example, has been sold off to private enterprise so that those employees have gone off the Commonwealth payroll. Australian Defence Industries and AeroSpace Technologies of Australia have been established as corporations. Those employees have also gone off the Commonwealth payroll. Yet we are left with about 25,000 public servants to support a force of under 68,000. We believe that savings have to be made in that area.

We have only to look at the fact that $100m has been spent over a number of years on a totally unsuccessful mine countermeasures procurement program for the inshore minehunter. Even though the Government recognised that that was a tremendous and terrible waste of people's money, it allocated another $13m in the 1991-92 Budget. It is unbelievable that more money could have been thrown after bad when the Government had already finally admitted publicly that that project was a total and utter failure.

Until such time as we get a government that can make this economy prosper again, that can get things up and going again, we will not be able to spend more money on defence. Mr Downer was not suggesting that. We are spending about three times on social security what we are spending on the defence of the nation because nearly one million people are unemployed. That is why we cannot properly defend this country; that is why the combat capability has been run down. This Government has failed to grasp the nettle and to make the hard decisions which will mean getting rid of this heavy tail. The Government needs to reallocate resources within the Defence budget and make sure that Australia's defence capacity is enhanced. Currently, it is going in a totally wrong direction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: For the information of Honourable Senators, I present the Government's response to the Report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, which was tabled on 23 August 1990.
I seek leave to make a statement on the Report.

The use of chemicals in, the control of pests and diseases in plant and animal production, public hygiene and domestic use, is an important issue which is attracting increasing public attention both in Australia and overseas. This is clearly evident from submissions given to the Senate Select Committee.

The Government has noted that many of the submissions presented to the Senate Select Committee questioned farm chemical use and practice from a community health and environmental impact viewpoint. Nevertheless, the overall tenor of the Senate Select Committee's Report indicated that, in general, the controls over agricultural and veterinary chemicals are indeed sound, although there are community concerns and deficiencies in some areas which the report clearly identifies and which cannot be ignored. Farm chemical use has in the past been and continues to be carefully addressed by the Government.

Before outlining the Government's response to the Report, I note that, the Senate Select Committee identified major deficiencies in the current clearance and registration arrangements including: inadequate resources at federal level, duplication between the States, lack of a minor use program, and no substantial program to systematically review existing chemicals.

The Government has moved swiftly to overcome these areas of concern. With the strong support of the Australian Agricultural Council, the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and individual State Governments, the Commonwealth Government has decided to establish a national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals and at the same time provide for: a minor use program, a program of reviewing existing chemicals, and an upgrade of existing resources. The Government will provide an additional $6.2 million for these programs in 1992/93, with funding in future years to be determined following the review of the National Registration Scheme in 1993. Initially cost recovery will be 50 per cent of the scheme's user-attributable costs rising to 100 per cent over four years.
It is presently planned to have a national registration system in place by July 1992 and the minor use and review of existing chemical programs to commence in January 1993.

To facilitate the implementation of the National Registration Scheme in a timely and efficient way, the Government established an eight member implementation team which is responsible to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. This Council is comprised of representatives from: the Commonwealth, the States, the Northern Territory, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, and Worksafe Australia. A consumer representative now also attends meetings of the Council.

The Government considered it important to firstly improve the basic regulatory process concerning the assessment and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and to rationalise Commonwealth/State responsibilities in the area, before attempting to address issues of wider concern to Government and the general community. While establishing the National Registration Scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals has delayed responding to other recommendations, these recommendations can now be considered on the firm basis of the National Registration Scheme being established and with a clear vision of the future roles of the Commonwealth and States, not only in respect to registration matters but in other areas associated with the overall management of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

In addition to addressing the state of clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia, which is being responded to in a comprehensive way, the Senate Select Committee made significant recommendations in respect to: alternative approaches to current chemical use practices, the integration of farm chemical use and alternative pest control methods, chemical container disposal, and aerial spraying.
Overall the Committee's Report provides a blueprint for the management of farm chemicals in agricultural production for the next decade.

In its examination of the Report's recommendations the Government is mindful of the importance of agricultural production to the Australian economy. During 1989/90 Australia's agricultural industries contributed 4 per cent of our Gross Domestic Product, provided 26 per cent of our much needed export income, and ensured domestic consumers had access to a variety of low cost, wholesome agricultural produce.

Farm chemicals play a vital role in Australian agricultural industries. It has been said that the contribution of the use of farm chemicals, over the last forty years, ranks with those of farm mechanisation and the development of new varieties of plants and breeds of livestock, in increasing production and lowering the cost of agricultural produce.

Research reveals the substantial gains in production from the use of farm chemicals. Benefits accrue directly to primary producers through increased yields and greater reliability of production. Consumers gain through lower prices, better quality of produce and reliability of supply. The use of chemicals needs, however, to be in accordance with sound use practices.

Excessive or inappropriate use of chemicals may adversely impact upon the environment and lead to excessive residue levels in agricultural commodities, resulting in a loss of consumer confidence in the regulatory system and the possible loss of valuable agricultural export markets.

The growing concerns of consumers and environmentalists suggest that if the substantial benefits deriving from the use of farm chemicals are to continue, the problems that do exist must be resolved to ensure continued public health and environmental protection and that the confidence of consumers, both domestic and international, in Australia's regulatory system is not only maintained but enhanced.

The Senate Select Committee direct 25 of its 45 recommendations to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council for further action and, where appropriate, implementation. The Government has every confidence in the Council's ability, as the prime body in Australia for the management of chemical issues, to address these recommendations in a timely and comprehensive manner.

I must stress, however, that it is important to recognise that the resources available to meet the many tasks recommended by the Senate Select Committee are not infinite. While health, environmental, occupational safety and trade standards will not be allowed to decline in any way, some of the Committee's recommendations may be progressed at a pace that is commensurate with the economic restraint we need to exercise in these times.
THE GOVERNMENT'S STRATEGY FOR THE NEXT DECADE
The Government's strategy for handling the sensitive and highly complex farm chemical issue for the next decade consists of five major thrusts:
(i)ensuring community confidence in the regulatory system;
(ii)improving the administrative efficiency of the clearance and registration processes and their integration with programs monitoring the use of chemicals;
(iii)developing a comprehensive approach to international and domestic aspects of farm chemicals;
(iv)enhancing education and training in regard to chemical use; and
(v)promoting alternative and integrated approaches to the use of chemicals in agriculture.
ENSURING CONSUMER CONFIDENCE
To continue to hold consumer confidence, the regulatory system must not only be open, but be seen to be open, accessible, accountable and comprehensive.

It is of concern to the Government that submissions to the Senate Select Committee identified a range of issues which, if left unresolved, have the potential to undermine public confidence in the regulatory system.

Issues identified include: the need for consumer input into the deliberations of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council; inclusion of wider interests in the consultative process including farmers, manufacturers, unions, veterinarians and environmentalists; the lack of information on the regulatory process and on the significance of farm chemical residues in food; and the need for short summaries of toxicological assessments to be made available to the public.
As the Government sees no challenge more important than maintaining consumer confidence, it has already moved to:
.have a senior officer of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs attend meetings of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council;

.request the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council to give priority to the publication and wide distribution of publications setting out details of the regulatory process and those agencies involved in it, and other information on farm chemicals;
.request Council to report on the feasibility of making available to the public short summaries of toxicological assessments; and
.review existing chemicals through the National Registration Scheme to ensure health, safety and environmental standards are maintained at the highest level.
IMPROVING THE ADMINISTRATIVE EFFICIENCY OF THE CLEARANCE AND REGISTRATION PROCESSES AND THEIR INTEGRATION WITH PROGRAMS MONITORING THE USE OF CHEMICALS

Several submissions to the Senate Select Committee noted that a system involving agricultural and veterinary chemical registration in each State and the Northern Territory was inefficient and confusing due to varying regulatory regimes. Other submissions criticised delays and administrative inefficiencies in the clearance process.

The National Registration Scheme, which is consistent with the Government's microeconomic reform program, will eliminate duplication and improve the efficiency of service delivery by Commonwealth agencies. The States and Territories have embraced the objectives of the National Registration Scheme and significant progress in achieving this goal has already been made.

Both the Departments of Primary Industries and Energy, and Health, Housing and Community Services, have had management consultants independently review their respective procedures in the evaluation and clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The resulting reports recommended changes to improve administrative efficiency. Such changes would have beneficial resource implications. The Government is determined to ensure that improvements in the registration process continue to be implemented through an efficient and effective administrative framework. With this in mind, the Government has requested that a report on organisational form, along with proposals for funding mechanisms and charging policies associated with the National Registration Scheme, be brought forward to Cabinet in 1992.

The National Registration Scheme will enhance the existing close liaison between areas of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy involved with agricultural and veterinary chemical issues. In particular, National Residue Survey administrators will have access to relevant information from a single authority on all products registered in Australia.
DEVELOPING A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO INTERNATIONAL AND DOMESTIC ASPECTS OF FARM CHEMICALS

Australia has a detailed procedure for the evaluation and clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals before they are registered for use. The community, I feel, can have confidence in the present regulatory system and that, as in the past, any deficiencies will be responded to.

The Government is totally committed to the National Residue Survey. The National Residue Survey has provided extensive information on the residue status of Australian food commodities since the early 1960's. A recommendation calling for the expansion of the Survey to more widely include food for domestic consumption, is being considered by the Standing Committee on Agricultural's Co-ordinating Committee on Agricultural Chemicals.

This follows the Government's expansion of the Survey in 1987 in response to Australia's problems with organochlorine residues in meat for the United States market. Extensive measures continue to be taken to minimise farm chemical residues not only in export meat, but in other food commodities as well. An emphasis on the careful and cautious use of farm chemicals is essential to ensure the acceptability of Australian agricultural commodities in both domestic and highly competitive overseas markets.

May I remind the Honourable Senators of a conclusion of the Australian Science and Technology Council Report titled, Health, Politics, Trade: Controlling Chemical Residues in Agricultural Products of March 1989, `that chemical residues are not an undue health hazard to consumers of Australian agricultural produce'.

The results of the National Residue Survey and other residue monitoring programs, such as the Market Basket Survey, are widely distributed internationally, thereby highlighting to our trading partners that we can ably demonstrate the safety of our agricultural exports and food commodities.

Chemical residues are not confined to food, they can also contaminate the environment. In the case of fisheries products, the boundary between environmental and food residues becomes rather indistinct. Such contamination is particularly characteristic of the persistent organochlorine insecticides, which have now been essentially withdrawn from agriculture. While modern pesticides generally have lower environmental impact because they are less persistent in the environment, there is still a need to understand how chemicals impact on wildlife and ecosystems, and to obtain data on levels of agricultural chemical residues in the environment.

An area of particular concern to Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory regulatory authorities is the growing need for approved chemicals on minor crop and animal uses. The Government has decided to establish a national minor use program. In general, minor use situations occur where a farm chemical is used in a situation which is an extension of the crops permitted on the label but where the level of use does not provide the incentive for chemical manufacturers to seek approval. Such instances are often particularly important to developing horticultural industries. The absence of approved chemicals for use in minor crops does of course hinder development and expansion of new minor crop industries, many of which have significant export potential. It is hoped that the timely availability of chemical products and residue standards for minor crops will help to promote those industries.

The Government is aware of how quickly international and domestic circumstances surrounding the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals can alter. The Committee's recommendation that a section be established within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, to monitor overseas developments in the many facets of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, and to formulate strategic responses to emerging issues, will be considered.
ENHANCING EDUCATION AND TRAINING IN REGARD TO CHEMICAL USE

Increasing community concerns about potential environmental and health hazards associated with chemicals used on farms, in the home and in industrial situations, challenge the continuing use of such chemicals.

These concerns are being addressed. In particular consumers will have available a greater range of information on farm chemicals, including information on how the regulatory system operates in Australia and how toxicological assessments are undertaken. Much of this material is under development.

The occupational hazards associated with the use of farm chemicals has been and continues to be addressed by Worksafe Australia and the National Health and Medical Research Council. Data on the effect of occupational exposure to farm chemicals is also being compiled and may be used by regulatory authorities to further strengthen control measures.

The Government is pleased to announce that the development of national standards for the training and licensing of pest control operators, recommended by the Senate Select Committee, is currently being undertaken. The Government has also supported the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association's Accreditation Scheme. This Scheme involves the training of farm chemical retailers in the proper storage, handling and disposal of farm chemicals. This training will facilitate a flow of information in respect of farm chemicals from the manufacturers, through the retailers, to the end-user, who has a responsibility to be acutely aware of the hazards which may result from improper chemical use. Such hazards extend not only to end-users in an occupational sense, but also to their families, consumers and the environment.
PROMOTING ALTERNATIVE AND INTEGRATED APPROACHES TO THE USE OF CHEMICALS IN AGRICULTURE

The final report of the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Group on Agriculture, while not detracting from the importance of farm chemicals, addresses in part alternative and integrated approaches to the use of chemicals in agriculture.

The Working Group has addressed Integrated Pest Management as one strategy which through carefully controlled co-ordinated management combines, for example, the use of plant breeding for pest resistance, and biological control through preservation of natural enemies of pests, with minimum inputs of chemicals. Integrated Pest Management is already widely practiced in some agricultural industries and is being developed in other areas, especially in the citrus industry and in the control of mites on pome fruits. Apart from Integrated Pest Management strategies, Rural Industry Research and Development Corporations dealing with products such as: cotton, rice, grapes, apples and pears, have long term research plans which support research to reduce the use of chemicals.

Biotechnology also offers the scope to reduce the use of chemicals. One aspect is the rapid development of agricultural commodities that are less susceptible to pest attack by identifying and exploiting particular resistant genes. In animal production, the development of several vaccines by the CSIRO, will also reduce the use of man-made chemicals for control of external and internal parasites.

There are now biological control methods involving the introduction of other organisms to control particular pests or diseases. Paterson's curse, for instance, is now widely controlled by a particular type of moth. Several other agents for the control of Paterson's curse are under study and are expected to be released soon. Another example is the control of blackberry by the release of European blackberry rust, which is expected to have a major impact.

The Government recognises these strategies as part of an integrated approach to pest management. As elaborated in our detailed responses, the Government has given priority to the development of integrated pest management programs and research into biological control methods. Significant Government funding in these areas has already been provided. This priority will continue.

Also the Government has provided support to the emerging organic farming sector. Assistance includes the establishment of the Organic Produce Advisory Committee to develop national standards and to provide advice on organically grown food. The Advisory Committee has already prepared national standards and farm certification procedures.

In July 1990, a major study of domestic and international prospects for marketing organically grown food was released by the Government. This was in response to the increased interest shown by both domestic and international consumers to organically grown food.
CONCLUSION

Many of the Senate Select Committee's recommendations have been incorporated in the Government's strategy for farm chemicals for the next decade. It is a strategy based on concern for: community health, environmental impact, occupational safety, and trade issues. It recognises the important role played by farm chemicals in one of Australia's most important economic sectors.

I seek leave to have the Senate Select Committee's recommendations and the Government's response incorporated in Hansard. Also, I have taken the opportunity in developing the Governments response to address the recommendations of the Australian Science and Technology Council Report titled, Health, Politics, Trade: Controlling Chemical Residues in Agricultural Products, of March 1989, which are closely related to the Senate Select Committee's recommendations.
SPECIFIC CONCERNS WITH THE AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS ACT 1988
Membership of the Council
RECOMMENDATION 1

The Committee RECOMMENDS that section 23 of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 be amended to include on the membership of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council one member nominated by the Commonwealth Minister for Consumer Affairs to represent consumer interests.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government will fully address membership of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) during consideration of the National Registration Scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

The Government has in the meanwhile already arranged for a senior officer of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to represent consumer interests on the AAVCC. Consumer representation will add an additional dimension to the AAVCC's consideration of consumer and social issues relating to farm chemical use.
Consultative Arrangements—Recommendations 2, 3, 4 and 5, joint response
RECOMMENDATION 2
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 be amended to establish an Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee.
RECOMMENDATION 3

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee include members from groups representing farmers; manufacturers, distributors and transporters; workers; veterinarians; consumers; environmentalists; other user groups; and government agencies.

The Committee recommends that the composition of the consultative body should provide balanced representation of interest groups and individuals and should include a reasonable representation of women.
RECOMMENDATION 4
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council provide secretariat support to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee.
RECOMMENDATION 5

The Committee RECOMMENDS that section 9 of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 be amended to enable the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council to refer matters relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation that the views of the wider community need to be made available to the AAVCC.

The establishment of a National Registration Scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals was agreed at the August 1991 Australian Agricultural Council/Standing Committee on Agriculture (AAC/SCA) meeting.

In deciding on the administrative arrangements for the National Registration Scheme, Government will consider a range of options for advisory mechanisms including the establishment of an Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee to advise on issues of broad community concern.
Delays and Lack of Resources
RECOMMENDATION 6
Recommendation 6 concerning a review of resources is included with recommendation 25.
RECOMMENDATION 7

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council in consultation with industry representatives, review the quality of applications for clearance, relevant guidelines and handling procedures for applications in order to implement a policy of according priority to complete applications.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
An independent review has been undertaken of the agricultural and veterinary chemical evaluation system which included an examination of application handling procedures.

Preliminary screening of all applications has been introduced to ensure that only applications, which are of an acceptable standard, are forwarded to the committees for consideration. The AAVCC and industry have also discussed ways to further improve the quality of submissions. This has helped to eliminate sub-standard submissions thereby allowing complete submissions to be progressed more quickly.
RECOMMENDATION 8
