The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Community Services and Health, in consultation with the National Health and Medical Research Council, examine measures to co-ordinate more effectively the work of relevant National Health and Medical Research Council committees and to increase the frequency of meetings.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

In response to the changed requirements under the National Registration Scheme a review has been undertaken of the work of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Committees and changed procedures are now before the NHMRC for adoption.
A number of measures have already been implemented to increase the efficiency of the NHMRC committee support structure including:
.the preliminary screening of all applications, to ensure that only complete applications are forwarded to the committees for consideration; and
.the introduction of a priority system related to the clearance of chemicals, (including those for which commercial trials are proceeding).

The scope for increasing the number of NHMRC Committee meetings is limited by the commitments of existing committee members, and the shortage of skilled persons with appropriate professional expertise.
Imported Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals
RECOMMENDATION 9

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council, in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, examine controls relating to the private importation by users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in order to ascertain whether the Customs Act 1901, the Therapeutic Goods Act 1966 and relevant State legislation need to be amended to strengthen control procedures.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

In the context of establishing the National Registration Scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals, a process to standardise the varying State and Territory control over use requirements will be examined. The extent to which private importation is occurring and associated implications will be addressed as part of that process.
Export of Chemical Products—Recommendations 10 and 11, joint response
RECOMMENDATION 10

The Committee RECOMMENDS that sub-section 35(2) of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 be amended to require the compulsory provision of relevant information to an overseas body having similar functions to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council or where no such body exists, to the Government of an importing country.
RECOMMENDATION 11

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council monitor developments on Prior Informed Consent under the Food and Agricultural Organisation's Code of Conduct on the Distribution and Use of Pesticides. The Committee also recommends that the Council advise the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy of any amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 required to reflect Australia's international commitments in this regard.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

As Australia accepts the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) Code of Conduct on the Distribution and Use of Pesticides and has indicated acceptance of Prior Informed Consent under the provisions of the Code it is unnecessary to amend the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 to provide for the compulsory provision of information to governments of countries to which Australia exports pesticides.

This Code requires Australia to provide advice to the FAO on pesticides which have been banned or severely restricted, thus facilitating countries being advised in an internationally co-ordinated manner. The situations under the Code where advice is required have also been clearly defined, thus minimising the need for discretion.
The AAVCC's Chemicals Co-ordinator has been nominated as the Designated National Authority for Prior Informed Consent under the FAO Code.

The Government acknowledges the need for international cooperation in the exchange of information on agricultural and veterinary chemicals. To this end the AAVCC is pursuing with foreign Governments the issue of exchange of information relevant to the assessment and regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Such exchanges will strengthen the controls exercised over chemicals and help to avoid duplication of effort.
CONCERNS ABOUT CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE REGULATORY SYSTEM
Availability of Information—Recommendations 12 and 13, joint response
RECOMMENDATION 12

The Committee RECOMMENDS that an account of the regulatory process, setting out the roles of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council, its specialist and advisory committees, Commonwealth Government Departments and agencies and State and Territory governments, should be made publicly available.
RECOMMENDATION 13

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the brochure entitled "Chemical Residues in Food—Questions and Answers" be circulated widely in the community and that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council disseminate and publish other information relevant to the regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The AAVCC has already published a document titled, Regulatory Control of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals—Questions and Answers, for distribution to the public. Other documents are at a draft stage and will be published in the near future.
The brochure, Chemical Residues in Food—Questions and Answers, has been widely circulated by the Chemical Residues Section of the Bureau of Rural Resources.

Other information including information regarding inter- and intra-Departmental responsibilities and the relationships between: the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Branch; Bureau of Rural Resources, including the National Residue Survey; the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; and the Market Basket Survey; as well as the regulatory responsibilities of each State/Territory will be published by various Commonwealth Departments.
RECOMMENDATION 14

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council make publicly available short summaries of toxicological assessments. The Committee also recommends that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council examine the feasibility of other options presented to the inquiry in order to provide the Australian public with necessary information on the safety, health and environmental aspects of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

AAVCC is acting to meet the need for more information on agricultural and veterinary chemicals to be made available to the Australian public. AAVCC has discussed the format and content of toxicological summaries. The matter is being progressed out-of-session and will be further considered by AAVCC which will also examine the extent of industry and/or government involvement in the preparation and distribution of the summaries.

The preparation of toxicological summaries is a complex issue because a balance needs to be reached between information subject to the confidentiality provisions of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, while ensuring that the summaries are informative to the public.

AAVCC will also examine the feasibility of other information being made available so as to provide the Australian public with the necessary information on the safety, health and environmental aspects of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
Monitoring of Chemical Residues
RECOMMENDATION 15
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the National Health and Medical Research Council reconsider its decision to conduct the Market Basket Survey every two years rather than annually.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
The Government believes that the Market Basket Survey should be conducted on a biennial basis.

The Market Basket Survey was reintroduced on a new and expanded biennial basis in 1990. The Government believes that there should be an opportunity for the effectiveness of the new arrangements to be demonstrated.

There are distinct advantages in undertaking the Market Basket Survey biennially rather than annually. It gives an opportunity for a greater range of food/chemical combinations to be assessed and thus provide a more thorough examination of dietary intake. Furthermore, it allows the analytical findings of the previous survey to be taken into account, whereas, the results from an annual survey may not be available when the next survey commences.
It is notable that a number of other countries undertake Market Basket Surveys at intervals of more than one year.
RECOMMENDATION 16

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the National Residue Survey be expanded to include imported foods and a broader range of domestic agricultural produce, including organic produce. The Committee also recommends that the Bureau of Rural Resources investigate alternative sampling procedures to facilitate traceback systems similar to those for meat and wheat.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
An import monitoring program administered by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service commenced in July 1990. This program focuses on products considered to present significant risk.
In addition, the Bureau of Rural Resources is developing an integrated National Residue Survey which would meet Australia's export, domestic and import residue monitoring needs.
RECOMMENDATION 17

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy review the funding arrangements for an expanded National Residue Survey and, in consultation with the chemical industry, examine the feasibility of a monitoring levy on the chemical industry.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

A review of funding options for a range of agricultural and veterinary chemical programs including the National Residue Survey and clearance of new agricultural and veterinary chemicals was considered by the Standing Committee on Agriculture in February 1991.
The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is now evaluating the feasibility of the various options of cost recovery for the National Residue Survey.
Labels
RECOMMENDATION 18

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council, in consultation with representatives of rural and chemical industries, users and consumers, examine ways of improving the labelling of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. This examination should include the use of pictograms, packaging and design and practical occupational and domestic safeguards.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

An AAVCC Working Party on Labelling is investigating these issues. The Working Party includes representatives from: the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association, the National Farmers' Federation, and Worksafe Australia.

Priority has been given to the labelling of home garden products as it is in this area that considerable consumer concern has been expressed. Revised guidelines for the labelling of home garden and domestic products are soon to be published.

Information is being sought on the best way to apply label design principles to produce improvement in user understanding of label instructions by changes to label format, use of pictograms etc. Persons will be consulted who are experienced in communication and familiar with the laws relating to: labelling, packaging, weights, and measures requirements.

There will also be consultation with Dangerous Goods Enforcement bodies. This will ensure that labelling requirements, under the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, are consistent with those laid down in The Australian Code for the Transport of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail.

Concerns about public understanding of hazards of chemicals used in the home environment, have led the National Health and Medical Research Council to give priority to the development of a national plan for the domestic use of chemicals and poisons, with the objective of reducing the incidence of poisoning. A national survey has been undertaken in order to establish a baseline of data on: public awareness, and attitude to and behaviour to chemicals in the home, including compliance with safety directions and warning statements on current labelling and packaging of scheduled chemicals.
Data on Accidental Poisoning
RECOMMENDATION 19
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Community Services and Health examine the feasibility of a comprehensive system of reporting of accidental exposure to agricultural chemicals.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The NHMRC at its 100th Session in November 1990 agreed that the most appropriate mechanism for establishing a database on poisoning by domestic chemicals, including agricultural chemicals, was the inclusion of poisoning data in the Injury Surveillance Information System being developed by the National Injury Surveillance Unit. It was agreed that the Australian Institute of Health be requested to consider the establishment of a poisoning data collection process within this system as a priority initiative.

Worksafe Australia is collecting statistics on work injuries and diseases on farms under its Farm Safety Initiative—Farmsafe. This is part of a national strategy designed to improve the occupational health and safety of people working on farms and is jointly directed by Worksafe Australia and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

Under the strategy farm safety action groups (community based organisations) will collect data on occupational injuries from casualty units of regional hospitals. A national database on selected hospitals will also be developed and held by the National Injury Surveillance Centre to which Worksafe Australia will have access.

It is intended that Worksafe Australia and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services will jointly keep under review development in these reporting arrangements in the domestic and occupational health areas.
Minor Use of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals
RECOMMENDATION 20
Recommendation 20 concerning minor use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals is included with recommendation 25.
International Considerations
RECOMMENDATION 21

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy consider further the establishment of a section within the Department to monitor international developments on agricultural and veterinary chemicals issues and to give advice which will enable government and industry groups to formulate strategic responses before trade problems emerge.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Australian Science and Technology Council Report titled Health, Politics, Trade: Controlling Chemical Residues in Agricultural Products, of March 1989, established that chemical residues impair the marketing of Australian agricultural produce. Residue problems and rapidly changing requirements of our trading partners means that it is essential to monitor developments on agricultural and veterinary chemical issues. The protection of Australian trade necessitates a first hand knowledge of the chemical concerns of our trading partners. The need to augment the existing level of resources devoted to this will be carefully monitored.
NHMRC Methodology
RECOMMENDATION 22

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the National Health and Medical Research Council monitor closely relevant international research and any developments in regulatory responses to the special diets of children.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The NHMRC contributes to and receives information from the Codex Alimentarius Commission concerning special diets. This ensures that NHMRC remains informed about internationally recognised research and overseas regulatory developments in relation to the diets of special groups, including children and ethnic communities.

The Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals Committee of NHMRC recognises the need for consideration of intakes in diets of subgroups, such as ethnic or child diets. The Committee will take this into account in its deliberations, where pertinent.
RECOMMENDATION 23

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the National Health and Medical Research Council fund research into allergies and hypersensitivities arising from exposure to chemicals, including agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The appropriate organisations to address this recommendation are Worksafe Australia in respect of occupational health research and NHMRC concerning public health research into the effects of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
The Government will refer this matter to NHMRC's recently established National Research Centre for Environmental Toxicology for consideration.

Worksafe Australia is funding research into the toxicology of chemicals used in the workplace. This includes extramural research into: allergies and hypersensitivity covering the prognosis of contact dermatitis, epoxy resin allergies, epoxy resin dermatitis, and the causes of dermatitis in painters and fitters.
Furthermore Worksafe Australia has an intramural, laboratory based, toxicology research program investigating the effects of occupational exposure to chemicals.
Review of Registered Chemicals
RECOMMENDATION 24
Recommendation 24 concerning a review of registered chemicals is included with recommendation 25.
NATIONAL APPROACH TO THE REGULATION OF AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS—RECOMMENDATIONS 25, 20, 24 AND 6 JOINT RESPONSE
RECOMMENDATION 25
The Committee RECOMMENDS that:
(i)before the cessation of the operations of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988; and

(ii)in consultation with State and Territory Governments, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy assess the efficiency and effectiveness of administration and co-ordination systems under the Act and consider the establishment of a national system of clearance and registration for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
Minor Use of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals
RECOMMENDATION 20

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council examine the regulatory approach to the minor use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and develop a national minor use program.
Review of Registered Chemicals
RECOMMENDATION 24

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Minister for Community Services and Health examine what role the National Health and Medical Research Council should play in the review of registered agricultural and veterinary chemicals and ensure that adequate resources are available for the systematic review of these chemicals.
Delays and Lack of Resources
RECOMMENDATION 6

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Ministers for Primary Industries and Energy and Community Services and Health review resources, including personnel, to ensure that the evaluation of agricultural and veterinary products is carried out expeditiously.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government agreed, on 2 August 1991, to establish the National Registration Scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The establishment of a national system for the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals encapsulates extensive consultation with the Australian Agricultural Council, the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and individual States. When implemented a national registration scheme will replace the eight State and Territory Registration bodies, thereby creating a single point of contact for industry, government agencies and overseas governments. A single authority will provide for greater efficiency and allow the implementation of uniform requirements across Australia.

In introducing the National Registration Scheme, the Government has taken the opportunity to implement a national approach to the approval of chemicals for minor crop and animal uses. Also the introduction of a more formal and intensive program for the review of existing agricultural and veterinary chemicals which are of concern for health or environmental reasons will be subject to review under the new arrangements. Resources for the existing clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, have been increased following independent consultants' reports. Resources for Worksafe Australia and DASET have also been increased in-line with their involvement in the clearance process. The result will be improved efficiency and effectiveness of the clearance process. The total cost of implementing the National Registration Scheme is estimated to be $5.5 million in 1991/92 and $9.9 million in 1992/93. Funding in future years will be determined following a review to be undertaken in 1993. Initially cost recovery will be 50% of the scheme's user-attributable costs rising to 100% over four years.

It is the Government's intention to have a national system for registering agricultural and veterinary chemicals in place by July 1992. The approval of chemicals for minor uses and review of existing agricultural and veterinary chemicals is planned to commence in January 1993.
PATENTS AND PROPRIETARY RIGHTS TO REGISTRATION DATA
Patents
RECOMMENDATION 26

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce consider establishing a scheme, similar to that applying to human pharmaceuticals, to enable the patent term of agricultural and veterinary chemical products to be extended.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government examined the case for extending the patent period for agricultural and veterinary chemicals during passage of the Patent Amendment Act 1989. It concluded that there was no substantive reason to change the patent period for this class of chemicals.
In considering this recommendation there does not appear to be any significant reason to warrant changing the earlier decision.
Proprietary Rights to Registration Data
RECOMMENDATION 27

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy should not accept the proposal of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association for recognition of proprietary rights to registration data presented to the inquiry. Nevertheless, the Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy continue discussions with the farm chemical industry and rural organisations in order to identify alternative proposals that would resolve conflicting views on proprietary rights to registration data.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is continuing discussions with the farm chemical industry and rural organisations, concerning proprietary rights to registration data. In particular the discussions have focused on proprietary rights to additional scientific data generated at the request of the proposed national registration body.

It is anticipated that this approach to proprietary rights will facilitate the production of data for out of patent products which are included in the review of existing agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The full implications of the introduction of proprietary rights to registration data will be considered as part of the implementation of the national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
EFFICACY OF AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS
RECOMMENDATION 28

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council, in consultation with industry and rural groups, examine maximum use provisions and the implications of using other than label rates. This examination should include consideration of a national permit system to document variations of label rates thus providing a database to allow existing label rates to be amended.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The AAVCC will examine maximum use provisions with a view to providing information upon which decisions on a lower rate than that stipulated on the label can be made. This initiative is consistent with the objectives of sustainable agriculture.

Whether rates different from label rates are of benefit depends on factors such as impact on resistance and need for follow-up applications. The benefits of different rates needs to be determined by trials and/or scientific studies.

A national permit system is unlikely to be useful either in determining the extent of variations from label rates or in determining whether changes in label rate are desirable. This is because of the infinite number of possible rates below the maximum rates and the various conditions under which products are used.
EFFICACY OF NON-CHEMICAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS
RECOMMENDATIONS 29, 32 AND 33 JOINT RESPONSE
RECOMMENDATION 29

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Commonwealth Government, through its various research and funding agencies, extend research and development of organic farming methods and sustainable agricultural systems.
INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT
RECOMMENDATION 32

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy ensure that high priority is given to the development of integrated pest management programs by Commonwealth agencies undertaking and funding research in this area.
BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AND BIOTECHNOLOGY
RECOMMENDATION 33
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Commonwealth Government, through its funding and research agencies, give priority to research and development of biological control strategies.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government has established sustainability as a fundamental goal for all of the Research and Development Corporations founded under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. Furthermore, it recognises the need to foster research on pest management systems that reduce dependence on pesticides by integrating the use of biological, chemical, cultural and physical control methods within sustainable production systems.

Funding has already been provided in regard to integrated pest management, which features among the objectives of most Research and Development Corporations. About 12% of total Rural Industry Research Fund expenditure of $14.2m in 1988/89 was directed to research on non-chemical methods, the ranking of these issues depending on the importance of pest control to the industry concerned.

The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is supporting 32 integrated pest management projects involving expenditure of $705,202 and 8 biological control projects involving expenditure of $170,446.

In addition, research on pest management is being undertaken by CSIRO, State Departments and universities. In 1988/89, CSIRO spent $11.4m on research into the control of insect pests; work on biological and physical control processes accounting for 77% of that expenditure. The Government's statement of May 1989, provided an extra $5m to CSIRO for research on ways of reducing dependence on pesticides in the control of insect infestation of crops and livestock.

The CSIRO received $3.6m to support a strategic approach to the control of parasitic infections of livestock through the development of sustainable and integrated control systems using chemotherapy, vaccines, genetic selection of resistant animals and grazing management.

The Australian Research Council is funding a range of research projects including the use of recombinant DNA, or other molecular techniques, to enhance knowledge relevant to conservation, exploitation and management of biological resources.
EFFICACY OF NON-CHEMICAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (continued)
RECOMMENDATION 30

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with State and Territory Governments and organic farming associations, develop a uniform system of standards and guidelines for the production and marketing of organic produce.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has already initiated the development of national standards and certification procedures for organic produce.
In February 1990 an Organic Produce Advisory Committee was established comprising representatives of:
.the three national organic farming groups, namely: the Biological Farmers of Australia, the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture Australia and the Bio-dynamic Agricultural Association;
.three State/Territory representatives of the Standing Committee on Agriculture;
.the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations; and
.the National Farmers' Federation.

The Organic Produce Advisory Committee's terms of reference include the development of national standards and also the provision of policy advice to the Government and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on organic produce, and to provide a mechanism through which the Department can facilitate trade in organic produce.
The national standards and farm certification procedures are intended to prevent deception and fraud in the market place where organic produce is commanding price premia.
RECOMMENDATION 31

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy assess the overseas market prospects for organic produce and, in consultation with organic farming associations, investigate mechanisms to provide export assistance for organic produce.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
In July 1990 a major study of domestic and international prospects for organic foods was released. Funding was provided through the Australian Special Rural Research Council.

The study recommended that a special organic industry research and development program be established by the newly established Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation in conjunction with State/Territory Government's agencies and producer organisations. The Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation superseded the Australian Special Rural Research Council on 1 July 1990.

Also in 1989 Austrade provided funding to the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture Australia under the Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program. A major purpose of this was the development of export markets.
RECOMMENDATION 32
Recommendation 32 concerning integrated pest management is included with recommendation 29.
RECOMMENDATION 33
Recommendation 33 concerning development of biological control strategies is included with recommendation 29.
ECONOMIC IMPACT OF AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS
RECOMMENDATION 34

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics undertake a quantitative assessment of the economic impact of the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals on Australia, including an analysis of indirect costs.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has advised that quantifying the costs and benefits associated with the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia would provide valuable information. As indicated to the Senate Select Committee inquiry, the information needed to carry out such an assessment is currently not available. Until such data are available, introducing such a project would be premature.

However the feasibility of collecting data on the type, characteristics, volume and usage of agricultural and veterinary chemicals will be examined. These data would facilitate an assessment of the net economic value of the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
SOCIAL IMPACT OF AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS
RECOMMENDATION 35

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Department of Community Services and Health examine measures to fund surveys on the occupational health of farmers and other users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Worksafe Australia) already collects data on the occupational health of farmers and other users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals as part of the Farmsafe initiative.

Appropriate bodies for co-ordinating occupational health surveys are the National Farmsafe Secretariat and State Farmsafe Committees. The National Secretariat will be meeting with Worksafe Australia on a biannual basis to discuss issues of concern in regard to occupational health and safety and the rural industry.
RECOMMENDATION 36
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the National Health and Medical Research Council fund research on the possible long term effects of exposure to agricultural and veterinary chemicals upon human health.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
The Government will refer this matter to the NHMRC's recently established National Research Centre for Environmental Toxicology for consideration.
In view of the nature of the research it is desirable to co-ordinate the research with international organisations.
ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT OF AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS
RECOMMENDATION 37

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Commonwealth Government examine ways in which funding may be made available for further research into minimum tillage and herbicide residues and ensure that such research proceeds.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government recognises this area of research as important and will draw the recommendation to the attention of its research and funding agencies including statutory Research and Development Corporations.
There is a substantial amount of research into minimum tillage and herbicide residues which has either been completed or is currently being undertaken.

To facilitate the maximum utilisation of agricultural reference material the Bureau of Rural Resources has established a data base of Australian Rural Research in Progress. Further the CSIRO has established a data base of Australian Bibliography of Agriculture.

The Government has already established the National Soil Conservation Program which is supported by the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985. The Act provides for the payment of financial assistance for soil conservation projects and the establishment of the National Soil Conservation Fund and the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. Major studies undertaken include a Study of Conservation Farming Practices and Environmental Effects of Herbicides Used in Conservation Cropping Systems.
RECOMMENDATION 38

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Commonwealth Government examine ways in which funding may be made available for regular, nationally co-ordinated surveys to monitor the environmental impact of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and ensure that such surveys proceed.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government recognises that environmental surveys are essential if the environmental impact of the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals is to be defined and understood. The surveys would need to encompass monitoring of agricultural and veterinary chemical residues in air, soil, sediment, water (inland, including groundwater, and marine) and biota, including investigation of incidents of wildlife mortality.

Sound monitoring data from environmental surveys are essential to underpin recent initiatives, such as the policies covering layout and design of new cotton farms in relation to their proximity to sensitive wildlife habitats which were proposed in the Australian Cotton Foundation's environmental audit.
Resources for undertaking environmental surveys will be considered further in the next budget context.
SPECIFIC SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS
Aerial Spraying
RECOMMENDATION 39

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council consider every aspect of the social and environmental impact of aerial spraying. The Council, in consultation with the Civil Aviation Authority, representatives of the aerial agricultural industry and other interested parties, should develop a uniform, national approach to the regulation of aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals. The Committee further recommends that, if its recommendation in relation to aerial spraying is not implemented fully, calls for the banning or phasing out of aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals should be supported.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government agrees that there is a need to develop a uniform national approach to the regulation of aerial application of agricultural chemicals and notes a number of initiatives with that objective.

The SCA has already established a working party to undertake an extensive review of Commonwealth and State/Territory legislation relating to the aerial application of agricultural chemicals particularly in respect to the problem of chemical spray drift. The AAVCC will be asked to cooperate with this working party and examine the social, environmental and economic impact of aerial application together with the feasibility of a national registration and accreditation centre for aerial applicators.

The Civil Aviation Authority is reviewing the legislation governing various aviation activities including aerial agriculture. The Authority is working closely with the Aerial Agricultural Association on the review of requirements governing aerial spraying. The requirements are expected to be available for circulation to industry in 1992.

These requirements will continue to include programmes which emphasise the education and training of pilots in the knowledge, handling, application and environmental aspects of agricultural chemicals before engaging in their aerial application.
The Government will request research bodies, as appropriate, to review research needs regarding the aerial application of agricultural chemicals.
Disposal of Chemical Containers—recommendations 40 and 41, joint response
RECOMMENDATION 40

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural Council refer the issue of the safe disposal of chemical containers to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council develop strategies for the safe and effective disposal of chemical containers.
RECOMMENDATION 41

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council liaise closely with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association Task Force which is also addressing the issue of the safe and responsible disposal of chemical containers.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
A Working Group on Farm Chemical Container Management has been established in Victoria and includes representatives from the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association.
The AAC, AAVCC and the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council have endorsed the Working Group developing a national strategy for farm chemical container management.
The Working Group has released for comment a draft report addressing a strategic approach to container management.

The AAVCC will liaise with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association Task Force. It is recognised that the disposal of containers is a high priority for the Government, the agrichemicals industry and users.

DASET, through the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, has drafted standard disposal statements for containers and their residues for consideration by the Agricultural Chemicals Advisory Committee. Following agreement from all interested parties, including industry, it is intended that the statements be included in the AAVCC document Requirements for the Clearance of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products.
Organochlorine Pesticides
RECOMMENDATION 42
The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Commonwealth Government accord funding priority to research into chemical and non-chemical alternatives to organochlorine pesticides and termiticides.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The development of alternatives to organochlorine termiticides was dealt with recently by the Co-ordinating Committee on Agricultural Chemicals which concluded that, at present, no suitable alternatives exist, particularly for continued protection of existing buildings.
The CSIRO has programs under way to examine alternative termite control strategies involving chemical, biological and physical methods.

Three methods with potential which are being developed jointly with industry are: reticulation systems that are placed on a bed of porous or crushed rock underneath a building slab, stainless steel mesh underlays that are placed under a building slab, and beds of crushed granite placed under slabs to provide a physical barrier to termites. A five year efficacy test period is required before any of these methods could be recommended for general use.

The Government recognises this area of research as important and will draw the recommendation to the attention of its research and funding agencies including statutory Research and Development Corporations.
RECOMMENDATION 43

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the National Health and Medical Research Council conduct a full review of the persistent organochlorine compounds used in Australia in order to reassess whether their continued use is justified on public health grounds.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

A review of organochlorine termiticides by a NHMRC Working Party has been conducted. The draft report of this Working Party was released in January 1992 for public comment and it is expected that the final report will be considered by NHMRC later in 1992.
Pest Control
RECOMMENDATION 44

The Committee RECOMMENDS that, as a matter of priority, the National Health and Medical Research Council, in conjunction with Worksafe Australia, develop national standards for the training and licensing of pest control operators.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

Worksafe Australia, in conjunction with the NHMRC is developing national standards for the training and licensing of pest control operators. A schedule which sets out the minimum criteria for training and certification of pest control operators is being developed by a working party reporting to both agencies. This schedule will form the basis for a National Occupation Health and Safety Commission national code of practice on training of pest control operators. The code will provide a basis for uniform licensing of pest control operators by each State and Territory.
Education, Training, Safety and Responsible Use
RECOMMENDATION 45

The Committee RECOMMENDS that Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, all those associated with the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry, rural organisations and users of chemicals recognise education and training as the essential component of programs to improve occupational health and safety and to promote responsible and judicious use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
The Government sees education and training as the key to responsible and judicious use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
The education and training of users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals could be expected to improve occupational health and safety and lead to more professional handling practices.

The rural industry, through the National Farmers' Federation and the Rural Industry Training Council of Australia, has recognised education and training as a priority and has received a grant of $70,000 from Worksafe Australia to develop a national accreditation system for chemical users on farms. The needs of non-English speaking users of chemicals will also be addressed in education and training programs.

Worksafe Australia has instigated a number of programs to improve occupational health and safety. These include developing an occupational health and safety resource manual for Farm Safety Action Groups. The resource manual will provide information and preventive strategies for the wide range of hazards found on farms.

It has also been recognised that rural women have a significant role to play in the safe and responsible use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. This is reflected in the material in the resource manual and also in the provision of an Occupational Health and Safety grant for the development of education and training material on occupational health and safety issues for rural women.
Chemical resellers have been identified by Worksafe Australia for chemical education and training so they can inform their clients of the hazards associated with using chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, I wish to make some comments on the Government's response to the Committee's report. As honourable senators will recall, the Select Committee was established to inquire into and report on three broad areas relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals. These were: the adequacy of Commonwealth legislative and administrative arrangements, the efficacy of pest management systems and the economic, social and environmental impact of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The inquiry received 256 submissions and generated nearly 6,000 pages of evidence. The Committee's unanimous report, which was tabled in July 1990, made 45 recommendations and reached 18 major conclusions on a range of issues and concerns relevant to its terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that the Government's response recognises the valuable work done by this Committee. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee's report provides a blueprint for the management of farm chemicals in agricultural production for the next decade.

Time will not permit me to address all of the matters raised in the Government response. However, there are five responses to recommendations which I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: First, the Government has accepted the Committee's recommendation concerning the need for a national system of clearance and registration. In August 1991, it agreed to establish a national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals. This scheme replaces the eight State and Territory registration bodies and creates a single point of contact for industry, government agencies and overseas governments.

As recognised by the Select Committee in its report, a single authority will eliminate unnecessary duplication of laws and procedures, reduce associated costs, provide for greater efficiency and result in a uniform approach to regulation. The national registration scheme will also include three programs identified by the Select Committee. These are a minor use program, a program of reviewing existing chemicals and an upgrading of existing resources. I note that the Government will provide an additional $6.2m for these programs in 1992-93.

Secondly, the Select Committee recognised that the regulatory system for agricultural and veterinary chemicals must be open, accessible and accountable and must be seen to be so. During the Committee's inquiry this system was described as a `closed shop' and as `secretive'. In its response, the Government recognises that the perceptions noted by the Select Committee have the potential to undermine public confidence in the regulatory system. Accordingly, the Government has responded positively to the Committee's recommendations.

In particular, the Government has arranged for a senior officer of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to represent consumer interests on the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. The Government has requested that the Council report on the feasibility of making available to the public short summaries of toxicological assessments. The Government has accepted the Committee's recommendation that the views of the wider community need to be heard in the regulatory system. I note that the Government is considering a range of options for advisory mechanisms, including the establishment of an agricultural and veterinary chemicals consultative committee.

Thirdly, the Government has endorsed the Committee's conclusion that, although agricultural and veterinary chemicals contribute significantly to the production of quality food and fibre, their use should not be seen as pre-eminent or exclusive but rather as an important tool in an integrated approach to pest management. Accordingly, the Government has established sustainability as a fundamental goal for all of the research and development corporations established under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

The Government endorses the Committee's view that there is a need to foster research on pest management systems that reduce dependence on pesticides by integrating the use of biological, chemical, cultural and physical control methods within sustainable production systems. I also note that over the last two years the Government has responded positively to several Committee recommendations concerning the production and marketing of organic produce.

Fourthly, in response to the Select Committee's recommendation, the Government is developing national standards for the training and licensing of pest control operators. I welcome this response as evidence presented to the Select Committee showed that there was concern about various aspects of the pest control industry, the operators of which treat buildings and domestic residences for termites, cockroaches and other pests.

Fifthly, in response to considerable concerns expressed in evidence, the Committee recommended that the National Health and Medical Research Council conduct a full review of the persistent organochlorin compounds used in Australia in order to reassess whether their continued use is justified on public health grounds. The Government's response indicates that an NHMRC working party has conducted a review of organochlorins and a draft report was released in January 1992 for public comment. I understand that a final report will be considered by the NHMRC later this year.

Although the Government response is welcome, I must record a degree of disappointment regarding the response to the Committee's recommendations on aerial spraying. I remind the Senate that it was the unanimous view of the Select Committee that widespread concerns about aerial applications of chemicals could not be discounted and must be allayed by stricter regulatory action and enforcement procedures. In particular, the Committee expressed the view that there was an urgent need for the development of a uniform, national approach to the regulation of aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals. I am pleased to note that in its response, the Government agrees with this view. Nevertheless, I am disappointed that after two years the matter is still being reviewed by the working parties of relevant agencies. I am sure that aerial spraying continues to be a concern to many people and I urge the Government to address this issue urgently.

In conclusion, I would like to make a gen eral observation about the Select Committee's inquiry. I consider that the inquiry provided a valuable forum for those with informed and considered views on agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their use in Australia. To the credit of those concerned, evidence to the Committee did not reflect intransigent views. On the whole, the evidence attempted to reconcile rather than perpetuate differing points of view, focusing on new approaches and the need for more to be done. This cooperative and constructive approach is reflected not only in the Committee's report but also in the Government's response that we are considering today. I encourage consumer and community groups, the chemical industry, primary producers and Government to maintain a similar positive and constructive approach when considering and acting upon issues that arise in the future.

The Select Committee concluded that agricultural and veterinary chemicals contribute significantly to the production of food and fibre but it is essential that they be used judicially and effectively. In this regard, I quote from a submission which succinctly reflected the views of many people who use agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The submission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers want to use safe products, want to produce clean and safe food and want to leave the environment in better shape.
I consider that the policies and strategies included in the Government's response to the Select committee's report will achieve these goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, I would like to make quite a few remarks about the Government's deliberation on our report; but as the time has come for us to move to another motion, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That regulations 23 and 30 of the Austudy Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No.480 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to debate both of those regulations at the same time. I will then seek, pursuant to standing order 84, that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, divide the question when it is put.

PARA.TAB: I seek to disallow regulations 23 and 30. Voting for this disallowance motion will not interfere with the beneficial aspects of the new regulations. I have it on the highest authority that the adoption of my disallowance motion will not affect the beneficial aspects of the new regulations.

The Government has stated that the regulations mean `simplification and better targeting of assistance for families with children over 16'. However, the fact is that many middle-income families have been unfairly treated and, in fact, targeted by these regulations. I wish to indicate some examples of that. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard examples of the way in which these new regulations, which I am attempting to disallow, will affect middle-income families. Perhaps I should give them to the Minister.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the normal courtesy is to show the Minister such material. Although I have not seen the document, I have no reason to distrust Senator Harradine. I agree to the incorporation. If need be, I will make some comments about the incorporation when I speak in this debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The examples read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: EXAMPLE ONE
A family with two children.
Both children eligible for AUSTUDY.
Parental income $32,000.
Q 1:What would be the effect on this family in 1992 if the "sibling concession" to the parental income had been retained?
A:The threshold parental income for maximum AUSTUDY—$20700—is not adjusted upwards to take into consideration the second eligible child.
However, for every four dollars of parental income earned above this threshold, the two children in receipt of AUSTUDY would lose one dollar in entitlements BETWEEN THEM.
For this family, parental income is $11300 more than the threshold for maximum AUSTUDY [$32000-$20700]. The children lose $2825 in AUSTUDY between them [$11300/4 = $2825].
The family, therefore, would be entitled to maximum AUSTUDY less $2825 in 1992 if the former "sibling concession" to the parental income had not been abolished.
Q 2:What is the actual effect on this family in 1992?
A:Because there are two children eligible to receive AUSTUDY, new regulations adjust the threshold for maximum AUSTUDY ($20700) adjusted upwards by $3700 to $24400.
However, under new regulations, for every four dollars of parental income earned above this new adjusted threshold, BOTH children in receipt of AUSTUDY lose one dollar of their AUSTUDY.
For this family, the adjusted parental income is $7600 more than the adjusted threshold for maximum AUSTUDY. Each child loses $1900 from their annual entitlement. ($7600 / 4)
The family, therefore, is entitled to maximum AUSTUDY less $3800 under the new arrangements.
The family is now $975 worse off—
even without any change in parental income.
EXAMPLE TWO
A family with three children:
one at university, one in year 12, one in year 10—
All three children eligible to apply for AUSTUDY.
Parental income $32000.
Q 1:What would be the effect on this family in 1992 if the "sibling concession" to the parental income had been retained?
A:The family would receive maximum AUSTUDY less $2825, each child receiving maximum AUSTUDY less $941.66.
Q 2:What is the actual effect on this family in 1992?
A:The family would receive maximum AUSTUDY less $2925, each child receiving maximum AUSTUDY less $975.
The family is $100 worse off—
even without any change in parental income.
EXAMPLE THREE
The same family as in example two:
three children—one at university, one in year 12,
one in year 10
All three children eligible to apply for AUSTUDY.
The father earns $32000.
The mother obtains a part-time job earning $10000 p.a.
Total parental income becomes $42000.
Q 1:Everything else being equal, what would be the effect on this family in future assessment for AUSTUDY if the "sibling concession" to the parental income had been retained?

A:The extra $10000 earned by the mother would reduce the children's AUSTUDY by $2,500. The mother would pay $920 tax. The family would lose the Dependent Spouse Rebate of $1379. The mother would pay a $125 Medicare levy.
Of the extra $10,000 in family income, a total of $4924 would go back to the Government.
The family would receive maximum AUSTUDY less [see example 2] $2825 + $2500 = $5325, or less $34.14 per child per week.
Q 2:Everything else being equal, what would be the effect on this family in future assessment for AUSTUDY now that the "sibling concession" to the parental income has been removed?

A:The extra $10000 earned by the mother will reduce EACH CHILD's AUSTUDY by $2500. Therefore, a total of $7500 in AUSTUDY will be lost. The mother will pay $920 in tax. The family would lose the Dependent Spouse Rebate of $1379. The mother would pay a $125 Medicare levy.
Of the extra $10000 in family income, a total of $9924 would go back to the Government—leaving $76!
The family receives maximum AUSTUDY less $2925 + $7500 = $10425, or less $66.83 per child per week.

NOTE:If the father works any overtime, he will be taxed at a marginal rate of 38%. For every $100 in overtime he earns, a total of $114.25 in family income will go to the Government (3x$25 in Austudy, $38 in income tax, $1.25 in Medicare levy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, as an aside I might mention that the shadow Minister and Senator Sowada already have them. In example one the parental income of a family with two children is $32,000. In this day and age, this is not what one would call a high income; it is a middle income. Both children in this family are eligible for Austudy at the dependant rate. Under the regulations which I am seeking to disallow, that family with a parental income of $32,000 will be $975 worse off.

PARA.TAB: The second example relates to a one-income family with three children: one at university, one in year 12 and one in year 10. They are all eligible for Austudy at the dependant rate. With the father earning $32,000, that family will be $100 worse off. I understand that under the provisions of regulation 23, the family will in fact receive nothing. So if my arithmetic is correct, they will be in fact $200 worse off.

Case three illustrates what will happen if the father referred to in example two works any overtime. For every $100 in overtime he earns, a total of $114.25 in family income will go to the Government. I would like the Senate to focus on that point—if the father in example two works any overtime, for every $100 he earns a total of $114.25 in family income will go back to the Government. If the mother of that family gets a part time job and earns $10,000 to pay the bills, the mortgage and so forth, of that $10,000, $9,924 will go back to the Government. This is the sort of bind that these regulations are getting us into.

These examples illustrate some of the negative effects of the new Austudy regulations which the Government says are just simplifying the regulations. These regulations are grossly inequitable. Regulations which entrench this inequity must be removed. Such regulations are a further erosion of the principle of horizontal tax equity for families.

I want the Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats to realise that this question of horizontal tax equity is very important. Clearly, a family with three, four, five or six children, in receipt of whatever level of income, should get better treatment in the tax area than a family without children. In the area of education, families with children should be treated at least as well as businesses. Families on $32,000 or $36,000—they are not vast amounts—have to pay substantial amounts of money if they have a few kids going to university. They cannot even claim these amounts as a tax deduction at the end of the year. Yet, if a company sends its employees to university, that company can claim those expenditures as a tax deduction. To my way of thinking, that is patently unfair.

Regulation 30 omits regulation 89 of the principal Austudy regulations. Regulation 89 contained the formula for application of what was known as the sibling concession. It was not really a concession at all. Its purpose was to ensure that families with more than one child on Austudy were not penalised by losing more for every extra dollar earned by the mother or father.
The sibling concession operated in the following manner. This example, which is taken from a footnote in the regulations, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Michael and his sister, Vanessa, both qualify for AUSTUDY. Normally Michael's AUSTUDY would be reduced by $1 for every $4 by which his parents' income exceeds $19,300. However, because regulation 89(1) applies to Vanessa, Michael's AUSTUDY is reduced by $1 for every $8 of excess parental income.

PARA.TAB: Later, Michael's younger brother Ashley turns 16. Because regulation 89(1) applies to Ashley, Michael's AUSTUDY is now reduced by $1 for every $12 of excess parental income.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the relevance of the brother or the sister, the payment for Michael was reduced only on a 1 : 8 basis, not 1 : 4, as in the instance of a sole recipient. The total reduction for the family remains, however, at 1 : 4; where there are two children, it is a ratio of 1 : 8.

PARA.TAB: With regulation 89 removed—which I am seeking to amend—families with sibling students are entitled, through a revised regulation 87, to apply a general and non-sibling specific dependent student deduction of $3,700 for each additional dependent child in a family aged 16 to 24 engaged in full time study. Previously, through the operation of regulation 87(1)(c)(ii), the children were precluded from the provisions of this regulation. At the same time, regulation 29 has increased the amount of parental income that can be received before the reduction in Austudy entitlements come into play from $19,300 to $20,700. This brings the Austudy threshold into line with the threshold for the maximum FAS payable for one child.

In summary, parents of siblings 16 years and over become entitled to apply a deduction of $3,700 for each sibling in calculating parental income while losing the equitable adjustment formula by which Austudy payments were calculated in the case of siblings. Using the words of the Department, the new arrangements, `extend the income-test-free cushion for each dependent child in a family'.

SPEECH.PARA: This means that some families will benefit and some—mostly larger middle income families—will be disadvantaged. I wish to incorporate a graph that has been provided to me by DEET as a result of questions at the Estimates Committee. I seek leave to have that graph incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The graphs read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: [THE GRAPHS ARE OMITTED FROM THE DATA BASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 2949-51]

TALK.START.PARA: —These graphs indicate, as I have said, that the new regulations will mean that some families will benefit and some, mostly larger, middle income families, will be disadvantaged. If one has a look at the graphs, the situation in the particular cases that I have mentioned will become immediately obvious. I am grateful to the Department for responding to my questions at the Estimates Committee in this fashion and for its work in providing these graphs. It gives a clear indication of the dramatic drop that occurs and the cut-off—which is a very hard taper, not a safe taper—that occurs for quite a large number of families.

PARA.TAB: Not only will families who received Austudy last year be affected in the amounts they receive but also there will be a group of new applicants this year who will be completely ineligible. It should be remembered that the so-called middle income family with more children can mean a lower income per family member than is the case for a lower income family with fewer children. Relative poverty is measured not by income alone but by income in relation to those who are dependent thereon. We should have our tax system geared to ensure that taxes are levied on income consistent with the number of dependants on that income. That would certainly be a far fairer situation than at present.

I now proceed to an explanation of regulation 23. I will explain why I seek the disallowance of that particular regulation. Regulation 23 says in effect that Austudy payments of less than $250 per year are not worth having. That is a value judgment that apparently the Government has come to. Regulation 23 alters regulation 66 of the principal regulations to read:

SPEECH.PARA: Living allowance is not payable if a student would be entitled to living allowance at a rate of less than $250—
previously $50 a year—
(including the spouse allowance under regulation 64).

In 1991 a House of Representatives committee referred to students who receive very small weekly amounts and recommended an increase in the minimum allowance. But the committee appeared to view the payment more in terms of the impact of the monetary amount on decisions to continue education rather than in terms of the justice of the receipt of an amount, however small.

PARA.TAB: The situation of families with more than one dependent student was not taken into account when the Government interfered with the minimum amount of allowance payable. Regulation 66 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Living allowance is not payable if a student would be entitled to. . .

It does not say `if students in a family' or, `the total payment to a family is'. Under the new system we might therefore find that payments to a family with three children total slightly under $750. Under the new regulation—which I am seeking to disallow—the family would receive nothing. The almost $750 would be gone. Yet, $741 to a family with three full time students would come in very handy indeed, particularly when it is understood that Austudy is based on the premise that in most cases either the parents or the students themselves are expected to contribute substantially to their upkeep. I defy anybody to see the logic in the Government's new regulation 23. It is a nonsense. The more children one has the more ludicrous is this regulation.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the concept of a relatively large minimum amount payable has not been introduced in any other area of Government payments. In the social security area, for example, all people who are entitled to a nominal amount—whether it be family allowance or whatever—which is above 5c but below $1 per fortnight, have their entitlement rounded upwards to $1 per fortnight. Honourable senators should focus on the fact that there is no precedent for this. In the case of the payment of the Job Search allowance, the Social Security Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: If, apart from the section, the amount of an instalment would be less than $1.00, the amount is to be increased to $1.00.

Regulation 23 should be disallowed. As I indicated, for a family with three eligible students the minimum would be $750. A minimum of $250 per student this year might become $500 next year, or $1,000 the year after, or $2,000 the year after that. We are setting a precedent here which should not be set. We are allowing the Government to get away with this and it should not be allowed to get away with it.

PARA.TAB: The denial in minimum payments also removes eligibility for fares allowance. That is very important for country people to remember. Country people will be greatly affected by this regulation; quite a large number of people will be affected by it. When the Minister replies, I would like him to tell the Senate how many families have received reductions as a result of regulation 30 and how many families have been cut off altogether as a result of the operation of the new regulation 23. All of this material is computerised so I am sure that it would not be terribly hard to find out. I think it would be very interesting for the Senate to hear from the Government just what has been the effect of the new regulations.

I appeal to the Senate to give proper and due consideration to my remarks and to vote for the disallowance of regulation 23 and regulation 30. I remind the Senate that, pursuant to Standing Orders, I will seek to have the questions put separately when the time comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition readily accepts the procedure that would divide the two matters for determination in the Senate. The Opposition is also very sensitive to questions of equity on the edges of a means test when it applies to any benefit to a family or, as in this case, to students in a family or independent of a family.

PARA.TAB: With regard to a number of dependants within the same family, where siblings are enrolled and there is a greater call upon the resources of the family, the Opposition is also very sensitive to the needs of the family and siblings. But wherever the line is drawn, and whatever the withdrawal rate of a benefit according to the family's increasing income, or the withdrawal rate with regard to a minimum rate of Austudy allowance, we have to face the fact that a line has to be drawn and that we need to consider whether it is reasonable and equitable to draw the line where it falls.

The regulations tabled in the Senate which make adjustments to the Austudy regulations governing the payments of Austudy are new in the two respects to which Senator Harradine has referred. Another new aspect of these regulations that was debated yesterday related to penalty payments now, leading to 20 per cent interest accruing if overpayments are not repaid after a period of three months.The Opposition gave careful consideration to that matter yesterday and I gave a rather too long speech about the question.

It also gave me the chance to state the very positive reforms to Austudy which would benefit all students in Australia that the Liberal and National parties will introduce when elected to government in the coming months. Having made that clear, I also took the opportunity yesterday to refer to what I call the `bleeding heart' context in which the Democrats were prepared to give any amount of allowance to be popular with some students. I do not need to repeat that. Senator Sowada heard me yesterday and I am sure that the Australian public knows that the Democrats will never have to deliver on their luxurious over-promises to students and to many other groups in Australia.

The other matter which I need not refer to is the Chapman report on Austudy—a major inquiry into the Austudy scheme—of which we received copies yesterday. I am happy to note that in most respects the Chapman report parallels the published policies of reform for Austudy for which we have been calling for some years. There are options in the report, some of which are very close to options to which the Liberal and National parties wish to give very careful consideration.
Therefore, I will concentrate the remainder of my remarks directly on the two regulations that concern Senator Harradine and which have led to his motion—regulation 23 and regulation 30.

One other introductory matter to which I want to refer relates to tax deductions for educational expenses. Senator Harradine has made the point in the Senate and to me privately—a point that must gain the attention of all honourable senators—that there is a lack of equity, on the face of it, in a company having a tax deduction in respect of education expenses for one of its employees but a family not being able to claim a tax deduction for the same expense for a student dependant.

A further anomaly relates to self-education expenses. If a person over the age of 25—or any independent person over the age of 18, for that matter—earns an income and is undertaking part time study, that person is able to claim a tax deduction for self-education expenses, up to a limit. There is a question of equity to be determined between those three cases, and I and my colleagues in the Opposition will give consideration to that. Of course, that matter is not directly before us in regard to the two matters that are the subject of Senator Harradine's motion.

I turn now to the Opposition's position in regard to the minimum rate of Austudy. We accept the Government's regulation changing the minimum rate of Austudy living allowance from $50 a year last year to $250 a year this year. The effect of the regulation is to limit Austudy eligibility to those people who are in need. No-one is saying that more needy students are being denied by the change. It is those people in least need—that is, those with the minimum payment—who are being cut off.

For most of the last 19 years about 35 per cent of enrolled full time students received Austudy, and before Austudy the tertiary education assistance allowance. At the moment that percentage is close to 50 per cent. There has been an increase in the proportion of full time students who are gaining Austudy benefits. The drawing back from 50 per cent to perhaps 48 per cent by this new regulation will still leave a much larger proportion of students receiving Austudy than has been the case for most of the last 20 years.

Some $1.2 billion is spent on Austudy each year. The change in the regulation is estimated to save $21m—a very small amount. As I said at the outset, it is a consideration of where the lines ought to be equitably drawn in the cut-off between those students who receive Austudy and those students who do not. Instead of about 50 per cent of students receiving Austudy, this change will mean that about 48 per cent will receive it. Under the previous regulations students were eligible to receive as little as 96c per week in Austudy benefits. Traditionally, it has not been worth the administrative cost to give a student 96c a week, therefore the concept of a minimum payment has been introduced for Austudy. The effect of the change will be to raise the minimum benefit payable to about $4.81 a week.

The minimum threshold set by regulation 23 is, in fact, well below that recommended by the report on student financial assistance issued by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in March last year. The Committee believed that $20 a week ought to be the minimum payment. That view was expressed by both Liberal and Labor members of that Committee, which looked very carefully at Austudy. The Committee actually recommended in March last year that the minimum payment be $20 a week. What we have seen is a shift from 96c a week to $4.81 a week as the minimum.

The coalition in its proposed reforms of Austudy has said that not only does it wish to increase the rate by 6 per cent but also to ensure that Austudy benefits, which have not been well managed by this Government, are targeted to students most in need. Bruce Chapman, in the most recent Austudy review, made the observation that perhaps only 25 per cent of students receiving Austudy would not have continued with their tertiary enrolment for the lack of that allowance. I do not want to argue that we should be quite ruthless in cutting back Austudy, but Bruce Chapman has said on numerous occasions in his report that the present Austudy arrangements are not well targeted. Surely the Australian people want any benefits that are going to students to be targeted to those who are most in need; we need to be convinced that Austudy is going to those students most in need.

That is certainly the principle of the Opposition. The Liberal and National parties believe that Austudy must ensure that not one student eligible to enrol in Australia will be denied enrolment for lack of financial means. We must ensure that all eligible students who win a place in higher education, in TAFE colleges and in schools are able to continue with that educational opportunity and not be denied for lack of finance.

I now turn to regulation 30, which relates to the traditional sibling allowance. It is true that for some 18 years, until last December, there was a quite generous arrangement for Austudy to be paid to families of quite high incomes if more than one dependent student in that family was enrolled in a course of tertiary study. In fact, if a number of siblings were enrolled in tertiary study at the same time, a family could be earning more than $100,000 a year and still qualify. The income figure I have is $102,747 where there are two eligible siblings in a family. Under the special allowance, those siblings would receive some Austudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not under Austudy, let's be honest.

—I wish to make the point that there has been in place for 18 years—it is set out in the graphs; that is what Senator Harradine calls the old sibling scheme—a quite generous scheme in which sibling students in very high income families have been able to gain some Austudy.
—That is not in the graph. That $102,000 is not in the graph.

—I am well informed—the Minister may be able to confirm this one way or the other—what the eventual cut-off point is under one or other allowance. Senator Harradine is referring to the normal rate of Austudy. I am talking about the special rate, which I believe leads to an ultimate income cut off of $102,000.

PARA.TAB: Let me quickly give the Opposition's view about this matter. The effect of the change in regulation 30 is to substantially reduce the amount of Austudy payable to students with siblings over 16 in full time study. But the effect of the disallowance of regulation 30 would be to reinstate the previous sibling concession without removing the new deduction of $3,700 for eligible siblings.

So, if we were to pass Senator Harradine's motion to disallow regulation 30, not only would the old sibling rate be retained—the very generous one that I have described—but there would also be an additional $3,700 deduction in relation to the family income for the purposes of the means test. So there would be an even greater generosity extended were this motion to be passed here today. The Opposition does not agree with that, and that is another reason why we are opposed to the disallowance of regulation 30.

Students applying for standard or away from home rates under Austudy are subject to an income test on their parents' or guardians' income, as we well know, and independent students are not. The measure of adjusted family income, or AFI, is well defined in the regulations. If the AFI exceeds the amount set out in the means test, a reduced allowance is payable. For every $4 by which the AFI exceeds the $19,300 limit, the allowance payable to the Austudy applicant is reduced by $1, and for the normal Austudy allowance this cuts out at an income of $34,561.

I do not need to go over all of the mathematics.
