But I note that the new arrangement, whereby in addition to the deductions for dependent siblings an additional amount of $3,700 is deducted for each eligible sibling, is still a means of calculating the Austudy allowance which gives direct regard to the additional costs of there being more than one student in one family. As a result, we still have in place a cut-off, or a means test, which means that, on the basis of the graphs that Senator Harradine has tabled for the normal Austudy rate of allowance, at many points there is some similarity, and very little difference, in the rates of Austudy that would be received, and the biggest cuts are at the highest incomes.

When we have a blow-out in the mismanaged Budget of this Labor Government of nearly $10 billion—it may turn out by the end of this financial year to be $12 billion, and I see my colleagues in the chamber expressing concern at the mismanagement of the Labor Government with regard to the blow-out of the deficit—when we have massive unemployment of 12 per cent and for young people more than 30 per cent, when we have every kind of loss, suffering and stringency affecting the people of Australia, when difficulties are being compounded day by day under the Labor Government, it is the responsibility of all of us to take into account this kind of reduction in what had been a very generous concession, namely, the sibling allowance under Austudy.

Certainly, when we come into government and when prosperity returns to Australia we will give consideration to seeing what can be done to make a number of improvements to Austudy in addition to those that we have already announced. But, in the present circumstances, and noting that this regulation is estimated to save, as I understand it, only $3m, the Opposition supports the Government regulation and does not support the disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Teague and Senator Harradine for their contribution to this debate. In particular, I thank Senator Harradine for drawing the Senate's attention once again to the inadequacies of the Austudy scheme. The intent of his disallowance motion today is to reinstate the old method of calculating the sibling concession and disallow the regulation relating to the minimum benefit payable under Austudy. The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the disallowance of regulation 30. However, we will be supporting that part of the motion which relates to the disallowance of regulation 23.

PARA.TAB: Austudy benefits abate at a rate of $1 for every $4 above the parental income threshold of $28,700 and cut out above $33,000 and $49,000. Previously, families with more than one dependent child aged 16 or over were entitled to the sibling concession which reduced Austudy by $1 for every $4 multiplied by the number of brothers and sisters. In the case of two dependent siblings, Austudy is reduced by $1 for every $8 in excess parental income.

The Government's new means of calculating the sibling concession reduces the parental income by $3,700 for each dependent child. This dependent student deduction is aimed at better targeting those families in need. The previous method was of particular benefit to larger families. However, it also benefited families with high incomes, as Senator Teague has already pointed out.

The parental income threshold could be as high as $100,000 for a family of three students before benefits cut out. Senator Harradine's motion would also allow, as Senator Teague has pointed out, for the existence of two separate means of calculating the sibling concession, as the old and new methods would coexist. Those who would be greatly assisted would be those families on very high incomes. In addition, this would have a very considerable financial impact. We understand that the net effect could be as high as $20m per annum.
The Government option does offer additional benefits to parents whose combined income is just below the income threshold. Larger low income families will benefit from the dependent student deduction.

As Senator Teague has pointed out, the Chapman report reaffirms the need for better targeting of Austudy. I am very pleased to see that, as was not the case in the debate yesterday, Senator Teague has now had a chance to read the Chapman report and assess many of its recommendations in detail.

The Chapman report offers a broad range of options—not recommendations but options for change which, basically, are all things to all people. I am sure that every student, every education policy maker and every political party in this place could find something in those recommendations which they would like to see implemented in policy. But it is worth remembering that, in respect of the importance of Austudy in ensuring equity and participation in higher education, DEET's own research has indicated that as much as 50 per cent of its client base could not continue in higher education if it was not for Austudy. Further research conducted by DEET has indicated that as many as 33 per cent of those parents who are receiving Austudy in respect of secondary students could likewise not survive if it was not for those payments.So we can see that there is already a significant acceptance of Austudy as a means of ensuring access and equity and of ensuring that those people on low incomes are not disadvantaged in the education system by financial barriers.

Getting back to the disallowance and the regulations that are the subject of this motion, I do not necessarily believe that the options we have before us today are the most effective options for providing for those most in need. However, I recognise that in respect of the sibling concession we must decide between two options, and the regulation proposed by the Government is more appropriate.

I have made many references today to the inequities in the Austudy scheme. I take this opportunity to reiterate my objection to any erosion in the value of grants and to the replacement of grants with loans. We have also come out and opposed the mix and match loans grant scheme as outlined in the Chapman report because we believe that many students, by virtue of financial hardship, would have to turn to a loan in order to continue to finance their studies. It simply highlights, from our point of view, the poor value that students get out of an Austudy grant. It simply does not meet their living costs.

However, I do congratulate the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, on his rejection yesterday of the compulsory loans. I would like him to go one step further in ensuring that loans are not used in the long term as a replacement of Austudy. I think it is vitally important for the student movement to be reassured of that. I cannot help but feel that the Minister responded to the urgency of the day, being the national day of action on Austudy, and that his intention was to placate the student movement and not to commit himself to any real reform of the Austudy scheme.

Contrary to Senator Teague's accusations yesterday, the Australian Democrats have a clear and rational understanding of budgetary constraints. In this case we have recognised that we are faced with a choice between two methods of determining a concession. We have to decide what is most effective in targeting Austudy and what is the most economical.

The other part of Senator Harradine's motion for disallowance relates to regulation 23. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance of this regulation which seeks to increase the minimum amount of Austudy payable from $50 per year to $250 per year. An amount slightly below the level of $250 can represent a considerable amount of money for students and families when considered as a lump sum. As Senator Harradine has already pointed out, the Government considers that amounts less than $250 are just not worth having, but under this new regulation a family with three dependent students on Austudy who may have previously qualified for an amount of $200 per annum each would miss out on an amount of $600 per annum, which is not an inconsiderable amount of money for a struggling middle income family.

Senator Harradine has also rightly indicated that this punitive measure is not contained in any other form of social security legislation and in addition will result in the loss of fares allowances for students, which will be a particular burden on country students and especially on urban students who have to travel great distances to their place of education. In my home town of Sydney that is very much the case with campuses spread wide and far across Sydney and with students often having to travel considerable distances in order to reach their institution.

We recognise, however, the Government's very real attempt to streamline the administration of Austudy by implementing regulation 23. The administration costs of dealing with a minimum payment of $50 per annum which, as Senator Teague has indicated, could amount to as little as 96c per week must be enormous. However, I ask the Government whether it would not perhaps be preferable to adopt in cases like this a method of lump sum payment for small amounts—amounts below $250. In our view, for larger families especially, an amount of just below $250 per annum is a considerable amount of money. While in Austudy terms it may not be a great deal and may not amount to more than $5 per week, a lump sum amount of, say, $200 per annum is sufficient to buy a large number of text books, stationery and material essential to students' education. So I put it to the Government that, rather than instituting this punitive regulation, perhaps it would be preferable to institute a system of lump sum payment of Austudy for amounts that fall below $250.

In our view, this is yet another punitive measure instituted by this Government which will specifically hurt families with a large number of students at university and school. We commend this aspect of the motion for disallowance to the Senate. I have already indicated to Senator Harradine that we will be supporting that aspect of the motion should he seek to call a division. However, we will not be supporting that part of the motion which relates to the sibling concession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating Senator Harradine's motion for disallowance of Austudy regulations 30 and 23, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991, No. 480. It is also the case that if this matter is not resolved by the Senate by 2 June the regulations will be disallowed. We have heard a very articulate debate from honourable senators on all sides of the chamber. I congratulate the honourable senators for the way in which they have debated this matter. The coalition's support for the regulations is welcomed by the Government. This is one of those occasions on which both the coalition and the Government, for their own particular reasons, have a congruent view about these regulations.
—It happens all too frequently.

—I take that interjection so it may be recorded. Senator Sowada alleges that it happens all too frequently. The degree of frequency is in the eye of the beholder. Senator Sowada, as an Australian Democrat, may apprehend that the frequency is greater than that which we on this side of the chamber would apprehend.
—Mostly it is the Labor Party with the Democrats against us.

—Let us not descend into a discussion about how frequently each of us, as different groups, support one another over matters of legislation. The Australian Democrats support regulation 30 but not regulation 23, where they support Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine has raised a serious and important matter. We do not shrink from the issues. That this debate is on is a compliment to the fact that this place has Independent senators who from time to time raise things outside the party system. I make that acknowledgment to Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: Having made those remarks, however, the Government is still of the opinion that these regulations should not be disallowed, that we should proceed. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, has provided me with some fairly copious notes that he would like drawn to the attention of the Senate, and I propose to do that. But much of my thunder has been stolen, peculiarly enough, by Senator Teague who has made an excellent contribution to this debate.

The purpose of Austudy is, of course, to provide financial assistance to students from needy families to enable them to continue further study. Maximum benefits are generally targeted to students from families with a combined taxable income of $20,700 or less. Yearly benefits abate by $1 for every $4 above $20,700, cutting out at parental income levels between $33,000 and $49,000. Of course, that depends on the student's age and the circumstances of the student.

In the past, the abatement rates for families with more than one student child aged 16 or over was more generous than that for families with one such child. This was known as the sibling concession. For a family with three children in full time education, partial Austudy could be payable in certain circumstances on a parental income of over $100,000. Payment of Austudy to families at such income levels was not consistent with the objectives of the scheme, that is, to assist in overcoming financial barriers to post-compulsory education.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Student Financial Assistance, completed in March of last year, was critical of the fact that families on high incomes could benefit from Austudy because of the effect of the sibling concession. It recommended that Austudy benefits not extend beyond a parental income of $55,000. This recommendation was affirmed in the recently released Austudy options paper prepared by Dr Bruce Chapman to which I think all of the speakers in this debate, at one time or another, have referred.

In last year's Budget the Government announced a range of changes to better target Austudy to those in greatest need. Replacement of the former sibling concession with a flat dependent student deduction of $3,700 is, of course, a vital part of all those measures. The new arrangements better assist large, low income families to provide an additional income test free cushion for payment of maximum benefits. For a family with three Austudy students, maximum benefits are now payable up to a parental income of $28,100. In this way, revised arrangements better target Austudy to those people who are in greatest need.

Senator Harradine's motion seeks to reinstate the generous abatement rate provisions which would serve to benefit students from large, relatively high income families. However, he also seeks to retain the dependent child deduction. Senator Harradine is concerned that some families earning additional income will nevertheless suffer a net drop in disposable income through the combined effects of taxation rates and the loss of Austudy through the sibling concession changes. However, it must be borne in mind that these high income families are generally better able to plan towards periods of increased outlays without jeopardy to their children's education. The Government's first priority must be to the neediest sectors of the community.

Senator Harradine's proposal would be very costly and would jeopardise the integrity of the Budget. The Government's proposal announced in the Budget is expected to save $20m in a full year. Under the proposal advanced by Senator Harradine, the net effect would be additional outlays of $15m. The projected savings from the changes to the sibling concession have enabled the introduction of a range of beneficial measures, including some which are supported by Senator Harradine. For example, I understand that Senator Harradine favours the introduction of the student deduction. The measures will also enable the introduction of an increase to the student income test, deductions for students with dependants, the simplification of the Austudy academic rules and the extension of Austudy to students undertaking certain courses offered by private providers.

On the question of the increase to the minimum annual payment level for Austudy from $50 to $250, prior to 1992 Austudy was not payable if a student's annual entitlement was less than $50. In 1992 this was increased to $250 and this is being sought to be overturned. It is evident that the payment of a negligible amount of less than $1 a week is of little consequence to students making the decision whether to continue in post-compulsory education. The arrangement is inefficient and costly to administer, in that the costs to process the application will generally exceed the level of benefit to the student. While the new minimum level of Austudy is set at $250, it should be recognised that both the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and the options paper prepared by Dr Chapman have recommended that the minimum level of assistance be set at $20 per week, or about $1,000 per year.

My understanding is that Senator Harradine is concerned about the cumulative effect on disposable family income that this measure may have on families with two or more Austudy students. For a family with three students, who under the old provisions would have each been entitled to $100, the cumulative loss to the family income is $300. While I appreciate that a very small number of families will be disadvantaged in this way, it must be recognised that such families are likely to be relatively affluent with incomes very close to the cut-off point. Given this, and the sound grounds referred to above for increasing the minimum payment level, the Government believes it is important to pursue this course of action.

I conclude by saying that towards the end of his address to the Senate, Senator Harradine posed a question for the Government to answer. As I recall, the question was: could we provide the Senate with the number of people who are affected by these regulations? I have asked my advisers to see whether it is possible for that to be done so that I can conclude this debate by providing the information that has been sought by Senator Harradine. I am advised that at this stage I am not in a position to provide that information. But I can undertake to make that information available to all the parties in this debate when it comes to hand. I commend the regulations to the Senate and seek the support of the Senate to defeat the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I indicate that, in view of the timetable and program, we will not seek to divide on this matter. However, there is a need to reply to some of the points made and I shall do so very briefly.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I turn to the question raised by the Minister, Senator Cook, and Senator Teague that my disallowance motion in relation to regulation 30, if successful, would reinstate both the sibling concession and the deduction for children. It is acknowledged that if regulation 30 is disallowed, regulation 89 of the principal regulations—the sibling concession—will be retained and that, through the operation of subparagraph 2 of regulation 28, which affects regulation 87, the previous prohibition on claiming both the sibling concession and the deduction for children will be removed.I understood that.

This problem arises from the fact that the Senate is not able to disallow part of a regulation. In fact, I have a Bill which seeks to overcome that particular problem. However, if my motion for the disallowance of regulation 30 is successful, the Government could remedy the problem by the immediate gazettal of an appropriate regulation reinstating the prohibition on utilising both concessions. This was not my intention. I should have mentioned that point earlier—it was in fact in my speech notes.

So far as regulation 30 is concerned—and I am not referring here to the technical question—I fear that the Government and the Opposition have not quite got the point. The Government says that the rationale behind the Austudy provisions is to remove financial barriers to post-secondary education and, therefore, the provisions need to be targeted at those most in need and not to the high income group. I understand that, but that does not address two questions. One is the fact that these regulations will substantially affect middle income groups. I gave certain examples and none of them has been tackled. I spoke about a family with two children on $32,000 a year, which these days puts it in the middle income group. Those are the sorts of people who will be affected by this provision. That is why I incorporated the graphs. Attention has not been given to that point.

Other families in the $40,000 bracket could have quite a number of sons and daughters in education. Clearly, the Austudy provisions, which are to remove financial barriers to post-secondary education, may not be thought to be terribly relevant. A letter from a constituent whose family is in that bracket says quite clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I now have a tertiary student along with a further tertiary student living away from home by necessity but the total allowance has now been decreased by $64 per week as compared to 1991.

A further child was going to undertake his Master's Degree during 1992 which was required to be undertaken in Launceston as the Hobart campus of the University could not offer it to him. He has now declined to do so because of the meagre allowance that he would have received. If he does not obtain employment (he possesses a Bachelor of Commerce Degree in Accounting) he will subsist on Unemployment Benefits.
What annoys me so much is—

and he goes on. It is really a cry from the heart. I appeal to the Government to give this matter consideration. It is a question of horizontal tax equity. Whole groups of families are battling it out on their own, and many of them will get nothing. They cannot even claim a taxation deduction for the expenses incurred for the education of their children. That is unfair. They are taxed as though they have no children; they are taxed as though the children do not depend on the family income, and that is dreadfully unfair. Perhaps that is an argument that should be pursued at another time.

PARA.TAB: I return to the point that regulation 30 will have grossly inequitable effects on some middle income families. I am not standing here for high income families; I am referring to a whole lot of middle income families, particularly those in the bush.

That leads me finally to the points that were made on regulation 23, and I appreciate the comments made by Senator Sowada. The clear point—and the Government has to look at this at some stage—is that the regulation as drawn says `if a student would be entitled to it'. It does not say `if students in a family' or `the total payment to a family is'. I think that is relevant. I repeat my concern that it is $250 as a result of the regulations I am trying to disallow. What about next year? Will it be $1,000, as recommended by Chapman? In those circumstances there will be a situation where a family with three students, each eligible to receive Austudy at the rate of $900 per annum, would lose $2,700. That is a considerable amount.

The other point to remember, and it has not been focused upon by either the Government or the Opposition, is that once that level is raised from $50 to $250, as the Government has now done, the student eligible to receive between $50 and $250 a year is no longer eligible to receive any Austudy and is therefore ineligible to receive any fare allowance. I see Senator Crane coming in. He would agree that that is a very grave situation for people in the bush. If the Opposition wants to vote against the motion, it can vote against it. As far as I am concerned, the Opposition should vote for it. I commend my disallowance motion to the Senate.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—I shall put the disallowance motion in two parts, the first question being that the Senate disallow regulation 23.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now put the question that regulation 30 be disallowed.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made a few remarks after the former Chairman of the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, now the Deputy President, had finished speaking. I had made a couple of introductory remarks before we went on to the debate on Austudy.

PARA.TAB: The Committee of which Senator Colston was Chairman and I was Deputy Chairman was formed on a resolution of the Senate in November 1988. I believe the Committee was very thorough and exhaustive in its deliberations and we tabled our report in July 1990. Despite the Senate convention that the Government table responses within three months, we have waited nearly two years for this report. In the intervening period, I believe that time has been wasted, although the Government has moved forward in a couple of areas, as I will indicate.
I find it somewhat insulting for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to suggest that the Government has moved swiftly, as he does in the first part of the Government response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has moved swiftly to overcome these areas of concern.
To give him credit, he goes on in the report:
Overall the Committee's Report provides a blueprint for the management of farm chemicals in agricultural production for the next decade.

He also makes a point later that some of the Committee's recommendations may be progressed at a pace that is commensurate with the economic restraint we need to exercise in these times. There are three different issues. I believe that, by taking so long to table the reply, we have wasted some time.

PARA.TAB: A close reading of the Government response—and we received it only a couple of hours ago—indicates that, although many of the Committee's recommendations have been taken on board, after two years there is still much work to be done. For example, the Committee made specific recommendations concerning the membership of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and the consultative arrangements for that council. The Government's response merely notes that a range of options for advisory mechanisms are still to be considered. I do not consider that that gives sufficient attention to such an important aspect of the report.

Another issue, and one the Chairman has already taken up, is the Government response to our concerns about aerial spraying. I consider that much of the angst about aerial spraying would disappear if the Committee's recommendations on this matter were implemented fully: that is, there should be a uniform national approach to the regulation of aerial spraying. Unfortunately, the Government response indicates very little progress towards achieving this objective.

One matter that I am particularly pleased the Government recognises is education and training. During the inquiry I took particular interest in this aspect. Evidence to the Committee recognised that it is the key to the responsible and judicious use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. I note that the Government response indicates a government commitment to this area and, in particular, improvements to occupational health and safety. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is pleased to announce that the development of national standards for the training and licensing of pest control operators, recommended by the Senate Select Committee, is currently being undertaken.
That is a step in the right direction. As a former Deputy Chairman of that Committee, I am very pleased that that has proceeded.

PARA.TAB: I also welcome the recognition by the Government that rural women have a significant role to play in the safe and responsible use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. I made the point numerous times during the inquiry that if the housewife asks her husband, or whoever it happens to be, what chemicals he is using, when he has used them, whether he wants his clothes washed with the other clothes around the house or whether they should be washed differently, she would have a better understanding of what is happening and the male out in the field doing the spraying would be more responsible. In some places in Western Australia we saw women driving the spray rigs because they were so well set up. They made sure by using charcoal filters and the like that no contaminants got into the cabins. In some places women were out in the field. I am not saying that women are always the ones who stay home to do the washing. I note that an occupational health and safety grant has been made for the development of educational and training materials on occupational health and safety issues for rural women. I think that is great.

I welcome the establishment of the national registration scheme, in accordance with the recommendations of the Select Committee. When the Committee was investigating this matter the possibility of a national scheme was considered unlikely. Nevertheless, the Committee felt that a national approach would be sensible, practical and cost-effective, not only for government but also for industry. I am pleased that in less than two years the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories have agreed to establish a national registration scheme that will streamline the clearance process of agricultural chemicals in Australia.

The Committee made several other recommendations. I do not have the time to go through them all. A couple of areas are of interest. The Committee recommended that the brochure entitled `Chemical Residues in Food—Questions and Answers' be circulated widely in the community. I notice that that has been widely circulated by the chemical residue section of the Bureau of Rural Resources. That is a step in the right direction. If people understand what they are using, be it a chemical or anything else, or that when driving a motor car they understand that it can be a dangerous weapon if it is used in the wrong way, that is a step in the right direction.

Another area was the priority for labelling of home garden products. As you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would know, a lot of the time people around the garden do not know what is being used to spray roses or whatever. Those articles should be labelled properly. The revised guidelines for the labelling of home garden and domestic products are soon to be published. That is a step in the right direction.

Basically—this is a message I would like to get through to this chamber for the second time today—farmers are very responsible people; they do not want to overuse chemicals. They want to use them only to do the essential job to make sure that they get the cleanest and best food onto the table for people to eat. For example, the Committee looked at a couple of breakthroughs. One of them was the weed activated spray system which was invented by Warwick Felton from Tamworth in my home area. It has sensors that detect individual green weeds. The sensors individually spray only those green weeds in a fallow paddock. The savings in chemicals are absolutely magnificent. There is a saving of about 90 per cent in many instances in the amount of chemicals that are used because all the bare ground is not sprayed while spraying the green weeds. That is a breakthrough. It is a saving to the farmer in the monetary sense. It does not use any more chemicals than are needed to be used to do the job.

Another breakthrough is in the bio-control area. Recently I received a paper from the Minister for Agriculture in New South Wales, Ian Armstrong, relating to the bio-control of Bathurst burr. Bathurst burr is a very annoying weed, especially in New South Wales and in other parts of the east coast, though not so much in Western Australia. Departmental officers have identified and patented a naturally occurring fungus that kills Bathurst burr. That will bring about a saving in the use of chemicals and is a much more responsible way to kill weeds rather than having to use heaps of chemicals.

The weed activated spray that I was just talking about, invented by Warwick Felton, is of immense help in the land degradation area where people are using chemical farming much more readily now that it has been perfected in a way that is beneficial both to the user and the end product. It is also beneficial to the land. If one is not ploughing the land regularly and the land is kept untilled, it is of great benefit to the land.

I welcome the Government's recognition that farm chemicals play a vital role in Australia's agricultural industry, which they do. Used properly, they are a great tool for anyone in the farming community. I believe that the Committee's report recognised this fact and highlighted Australia's hard-earned reputation for clean chemical free food. We have clean chemical free food in Australia. It is of immense importance that we keep our food clean and pure. Yesterday I met with people from Europe and learnt a little about the problem they have with contamination in their river systems and the problems that they have in getting pure food. In the future we will be in a great position to sell pure food to the rest of the world.

I welcome the Government's statement that the Committee's report represents a blueprint for the management of farm chemicals in agricultural production for the next decade. In conclusion, I am relieved that the response has finally been tabled. The Select Committee worked very hard to reach timely, responsible and balanced decisions and it is incumbent on the Government to make sure that the work of the Committee is now fully implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleague Senator Brownhill, I have had the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia for only a short period and have not studied it fully. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Committee on the work it did in this area. It certainly brought back some balance into the debate that was ensuing in the Australian community at the time the Committee started its inquiry. When we look at things such as the use of chemicals it is essential that all aspects and considerations be taken into account. Its presentation should be put in a balanced and proper way, and the Committee did that. As I said, the inquiry brought back some balance into the debate which was at that time getting one-sided. In many instances, there were calls for random banning of the use of some chemicals. The people who were making those calls were doing so purely and simply on emotive grounds and not on grounds based on fact.

PARA.TAB: Like Senator Brownhill, I am pleased that the Government has responded to the Committee's report. It took a significant amount of time, and it might say that it needed that time. However, I think it would have been beneficial to the industry and to the people involved in the use of those chemicals—whether they be manufacturers, aerial sprayers or users—had there been a quicker response.

There is not a lot that I can find fault with in the Government response. I urge the Government to address the issue of aerial spraying in particular. It is an important and integral part of the application of some chemicals. In many instances, aerial spraying is the only method by which the chemicals can be applied because of the terrain over which they are being used or the weather conditions that prevail. The use of a wheeled vehicle or sprayer at such times could create enormous erosion problems.

The other point that needs to be pursued and about which more information needs to be put on the table relates to the beneficial impact in terms of land conservation and the use of chemicals as against traditional methods of agriculture. It has been demonstrated in many instances that the development of minimum tillage—I note that that is included in the report and the response—is one of the best ways of overcoming the severe erosion problems caused by wet conditions or wind erosion.
In conclusion, the Government response to the report is responsible, but much work still needs to be done on this issue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on use immunity provisions in the corporations law and the Australian Securities Commission law. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Beahan
Chairman
Joint Parliamentary Committee on
Corporations and Securities
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Beahan

I am writing to advise you of the Government's response to the Report on the Use Immunity Provisions in the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission Law by the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities which you chair.

As you may be aware, the Government recently introduced the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992 into the Parliament. This Bill (copy attached), which was passed by the House of Representatives on 30 March 1992, substantially implements the recommendations in the Committee's Report. In particular, the Bill removes the derivative use immunity from s.68(3) of the ASC Law and from s.597(12) of the Corporations Law and removes the immunity in respect of the fact that a person has produced a document from s.68(3) of the ASC Law. In addition, the Bill provides that corporations are not entitled to claim against self incrimination.

I note, however, that the Bill does not adopt a further recommendation of the Committee that there be a five year sunset clause on the amendments. The reason for not allowing that recommendation is that serious problems could arise in the prosecution of matters which may have been under investigation for some time. Investigators in complex cases would be hampered by the uncertainty of not knowing which rule of evidence would apply at the time of trial and prosecutions not completed when the immunities revive would be jeopardised by the inadmissibility of crucial evidence. This would involve considerable expense in wasted resources over a long period of time, but could also be expected to bring into disrepute the Government's public commitment to effective law enforcement in the corporations area.
The Government believes a preferable alternative is to ensure that the operation of the amendments is reviewed within twelve months. The Bill provides for this to take place.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Committee for its Report which clearly provided valuable assistance to the Government in its consideration of these very sensitive issues where it is essential that the rights of accused are properly balanced against the rights of shareholders and/creditors of the company.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL DUFFY
