DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the Australian Defence Force Reserves. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: For the information of honourable members, I present a statement containing the Government's response to the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the Australian Defence Force Reserves which was tabled on 28 November 1991. The Government appreciates the valuable work done by the Committee and the contribution made by the Committee through its observations and recommendations.
General Comment on Readiness and Preparedness

The Committees' Report makes a number of comments about the present state of Defence readiness and preparedness. These comments rely heavily on the Committee's judgement that credible contingencies could arise with `little or no warning'. While the Government accepts that such contingencies could arise with little warning, our force structure should take account of our strategic circumstances—including the limited capacity of countries in our neighbourhood to conduct operations against Australia and the lack of any reason for them to do so. Readiness consumes resources so the readiness posture adopted must reflect prudent risk management. The Committee's misunderstanding of this key policy concept, which determines the force structure and preparedness of the ADF, leads the Committee to make recommendations which are based on a false premise. The Government already maintains significant Regular and Reserve forces capable of responding to a low level contingency at short notice.

Intelligence provides early warning and is central to the ADF's level of operational readiness. Within a responsible resource framework, the Government supports continuing substantial investment in intelligence and surveillance capabilities, with particular emphasis on the development of systems to integrate, analyse and disseminate intelligence and surveillance information from military and civilian sources. The Minister for Defence touched on this subject in his Ministerial Statement on the Reorganisation of Defence Intelligence in March 1989.
The findings of the Force Structure Review were tabled on 30 May 1991 and are now being implemented. A further review at this stage would be untimely and inappropriate.
Naval Reserves

The Committee considered the Naval Reserve was generally effective in the performance of its roles and tasks. The Committee was concerned, however, about an apparent lack of progress towards a contribution of the Naval Reserves to the mine countermeasures role. The Government's detailed comment on the Committee's concern is provided in the response to Recommendation 1.
Army Reserves
The Committee claimed the military capability of the Army Reserve was grossly inefficient and suggested a lack of resources has generated an Army Reserve which provides:
a.generally ineffective vital asset protection brigades because of equipment and manpower deficiencies and unsatisfactory training objectives and standards,
b.ineffective manoeuvre and follow on brigades because of poor strength and equipment levels, and
c.ineffective logistics support because of shortfalls in equipment, low manning levels and training deficiencies.

The contrast between the strategic guidance for ground force readiness in relation to that of air and maritime elements has been the source of considerable debate both within Defence and the public arena. Without re-addressing the arguments, the fact remains that Army Reserves readiness must be viewed in the context of the current ground force readiness. Specific comments are:

a.The observation that the Regional Force Surveillance Units are only marginally effective must be questioned, given the Report's own observation that they exhibit `an ability to be operationally ready within their degree of notice'. What is accepted is that the Areas of Operations allocated to the Regional Force Surveillance Units are vast.

b.Criticism of the performance of Logistic and Vital Asset Protection Units on K89 does not recognise the dual influences of budgetary and time restraints. The number of Reservists on K89 would have been higher had the resources been available to support them, and if the community was prepared to accept their absence from their place of work for protracted periods. It is expensive to move units and individuals in and out of isolated exercise areas for limited periods. There are also continuity requirements which make it difficult for Reserve units to be employed for short periods within extended exercises.

c.The lack of training by Vital Asset Protection Brigades in their designed areas is also largely based on resource constraints. It should be noted that all Vital Asset Protection Brigades conduct Officer and Non Commissioned Officer training within their Areas of Operations. All Vital Asset Protection Brigades have also conducted exercises within their Areas of Operations for all elements at least to sub-unit level.

d.Army's observation on the limited capacity of the Reservist to absorb complex capabilities or react to short term contingencies is not, as the Report states, an attempt to suggest the existence of any innate factors within the Reserve. Rather, it is a recognition of the limitations imposed, given the time available for the Reserve to train. Capabilities which require ongoing skill reinforcement, either because they are complex or need to be maintained at high levels, are not generally appropriate for the Reserve. Army does however have Reservists who perform complex tasks, such as surgeons and technicians, who maintain these skills in their civilian occupation. Reserve units are on high degrees of readiness, such as the Regional Force Surveillance Units, where preparation for their likely operational tasks can be achieved in the training time available.

e.Training difficulties mentioned within the Report may be able to be addressed through training being task-related. This is already done to a large degree within the Reserve for individual training. Consideration will be given to applying it at the collective level where training objectives can be focused onto unit tasks rather than roles. There is a fair degree of risk involved in such an approach but in the case of Vital Asset Protection Units it may prove acceptable. Such an approach may allow resources to be applied more economically, enhance training validation, and enable units to meet high performance levels.

f.Manning and equipment deficiencies receive continual attention within Army. Currently Army Office and Land Command are reviewing the methodology of recording Minimum and Operational Levels of Capability (MLOC and OLOC). Clear, quantified requirements for MLOC and OLOC will provide a calculated measure against which effectiveness and readiness can be established. This will ensure rational allocation of equipment and manpower, in accordance with existing strategic guidance and budgetary constraint.

The Report costs its proposed structural changes for Army at around $700 million, in addition to the Ready Reserve costs and ongoing additional annual operating costs rising from $2 million in the short term to $50 million after 10 years. There is little doubt that the deficiencies that do exist could be overcome by such an increase in expenditure. However, without the provision of additional funds, Army could only implement the recommended changes to the detriment of other capabilities.
A detailed response to the Committee's concerns is provided in the responses to Recommendations 2 to 6 and 9 to 12.
Ready Reserve

In framing its comments on the Ready Reserve, the Report asserts that no persuasive argument had been mounted to support its need. The Report's criticism of the Ready Reserve appears at odds with its desire to see greater readiness and service flexibility on the part of Reservists. In Army the Ready Reserve is part of the Active Army Reserve, the only distinction between it and the General Reserve is the degree of training commitment and the conditions of service that reflect this commitment.

The Committee concluded, however, that the Ready Reserve Program may well operate as planned but the 12 month initial training period was excessive, and could have an adverse effect on the General Reserves. The Committee was also concerned that the Ready Reserves might have been introduced at the expense of two Regular battalions and the General Reserve.
Detailed comments on the committee's concern are provided in the responses to various recommendations on the subject but specific comments are:

a.The conversion of 6 Brigade from a Regular to Reserve formation is seen as consistent with strategic guidance. It is quite apparent that the conversion increases the immediacy of the Reserve in reacting to any land threat. The readiness level of 6 Brigade is adequate to allow it to complement the Operational Deployment Force in a low level threat situation if called out.

b.The impact of 49 Royal Queensland Regiment moving to Ready Reserve conditions of service is localised due to the regional nature of the Army Reserve and the discrete funding of the Ready Reserve. There are to be no equipment or manpower reductions in General Reserve units to raise Ready Reserve units and Army Office is to determine the benefits of increasing Regular manning within General Reserve units.

c.There are no apparent ARes strength management and recruiting problems arising from the introduction of the Ready Reserve. Again the regional nature of the Reserve and the specific recruiting targets for the Ready Reserve has reduced any competition for recruits. Likewise, the demand for General Reservists to transfer to the Ready Reserve is not sufficient to generate problems of any consequence.
General Reserve

The Report's criticisms of the Army Reserve are fundamentally based on the Reserve's inability to achieve degrees of readiness that the Committee believes are required by strategic guidance. This criticism is based on a perception of the nature of credible contingencies and time scales necessary for these contingencies to arise which is in fact at odds with strategic guidance (see comments on readiness and preparedness).

The Report does not acknowledge the benefits provided by Reserves on long degrees of notice over `soldiers off the street' and so does not recognise the advantages inherent in a standing Reserve. The Report also fails to address the fundamental nature of Reserve service, that is, that it is made up of part time volunteers who balance their Reserve commitment with a primary career and other personal commitments. The Committee's Report does not address the impact of high degrees of readiness and greater training commitment on Reservists' ability to serve.
Air Force Reserves

The Committee believed the Air Force Reserve was meeting its allocated roles and tasks. However, in the Committee's view, the RAAF needed to make much better use of Reserves in aircrew and airfield defence guard positions.
The Government's comment is provided in the response to Recommendations 7 and 8.
Responses to Recommendations
A list of the recommendations in the Committee's Report is attached, with a Government response to each.
RECOMMENDATION 1
The Committee recommends that Navy should develop an auxiliary minesweeping capability within each of eight Reserve Port Divisions to complement the four coastal minehunters that are to be acquired.
RESPONSE
Agreed in Principle

In highlighting this shortcoming, the Committee was critical of the Force Structure Review's recommendation not to procure the planned permanent core force of ten auxiliary minesweepers. At Paragraph 6.57 of the Report, the Committee strongly recommended the development of a Reserve based auxiliary minesweeping capability within the eight Port Divisions at an estimated cost of $20 million over the TYDP. Prior to the Force Structure Review, the intention had been to adopt a similar approach to that recommended by the Committee; however, there are now a number of difficulties with this recommendation.

The Force Structure Review recommended the core force of ten auxiliary minesweepers should not be procured, based upon the re-orientation of the limited resources within Navy to improve the balance of the Mine Warfare force. Despite this decision, the Force Structure Review indicated that the Craft of Opportunity (COOP) concept would be proven and would provide a basis for timely expansion, drawing on civil resources; ie Reserves.

Accordingly, Navy intends to retain the three vessels of the Interim Minesweeping Force, currently comprised of the Auxiliary Minesweepers BROLGA, KORAAGA and SALVATORE, to complete development trials, prove the COOP concept, and provide continuation training in the minesweeping skills and commence peacetime route surveillance operations.

Additionally, in line with the current initiatives to restructure and fully integrate the Australian Naval Reserve into the Permanent Naval Force, it is intended to continue a program of Reserve involvement in mine countermeasure operations, although it is not envisaged that auxiliary minesweepers will be entirely manned by Reserves. Indeed, the past focus of the Reserves, that is the Port Divisions, has been replaced with an integrated local and national Naval infrastructure where Reserves now work directly as part time members of the Permanent Naval organisation producing a sense of unity and identity with the whole Navy.

It is planned to use Ready Reserve personnel to supplement the crews of coastal and inshore minehunters noting that these personnel should possess a higher level of training, skill and experience than personnel from the General Reserve. The General Reserve personnel will be trained to supplement COOP crews in the minesweeping and route surveillance roles.
RECOMMENDATION 2
The Committee recommends that Army's capability to perform the reactive role be raised significantly by restructuring 6 Brigade.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

The Government does not consider that strategic guidance requires that 6 Brigade be restructured as suggested by the Committee. To restructure 6 Brigade with the varying degrees of notice suggested by the Committee would:
a.require sub-units and possibly units to be composed entirely of ARA to meet the shortest notice, defeating a major benefit of having an integrated formation;
b.likely require the movement of ARA from other parts of the Army to 6 Brigade to meet the increased support required by the higher readiness elements; and
c.the aim of creating a Ready Reserve brigade would not be met by what would in essence simply become ARA and ARes units sharing a common location.
RECOMMENDATION 3

The Committee recommends that if the planned, continual review of the Ready Reserve indicates that 6 Brigade is unable to perform the Land Warfare role at 28 to 90 days notice, it should become a Regular brigade.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

Based on present strategic guidance, the Government does not accept the requirement for 6 Brigade to be able to respond at 28 days notice. The development of the Ready Reserve within Army will be subject to intense scrutiny to determine both budgetary and operational performance. It is anticipated that a recommendation on the viability of the Ready Reserve will be possible at the end of 1994. The Ready Reserve is a new and innovative concept in the ADF which needs to be thoroughly tested.
RECOMMENDATION 4

The Committee recommends that Army's Manoeuvre Forces and Follow On Forces be restructured so as to contribute much more appropriately to the preparedness of the force-in-being for the self-reliant defence of Australia as endorsed by Defence policy.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

The changes to Army's structure recommended by the Committee appear to require a degree of preparedness that is not required by the nature of likely credible contingencies, nor by the time scales necessary for a major ground threat to develop. The Committee's concerns regarding the relatively long degree of notice applying to some elements of the Army Reserve is noted. Army has undertaken to review the application of longer degrees of notice to see if reductions are required within strategic guidance and are sustainable within budgetary guidance.
RECOMMENDATION 5
The Committee recommends that, also through restructuring, the Logistic Support Force should be brought from its current manning of about 2,800 to its authorised level of some 3,300.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

Within its current manning, the Logistic Support Force is structured to provide graduated support to forces deployed on a range of credible contingencies. It is adequately manned to support the more likely contingencies, and can be appropriately augmented in sufficient time to respond to other credible contingencies that may arise. Augmentation could involve reinforcement by ARA and ARes personnel, and drawing upon other elements of the Army structure.
RECOMMENDATION 6
The Committee recommends that, in the light of the Department of Defence's declared policy on independent brigade operations, the retention of Headquarters 2 Division be reviewed.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

The importance of retaining Headquarters 2 Division was confirmed by the Force Structure Review. Headquarters 2nd Division provides Army with a doctrinal base on which to develop and maintain command and control skills for higher level conflict. It is an important element within the Follow on Force providing an ability to command Brigades and other elements being prepared for operations. In the event of a conflict developing to a higher level, Headquarters 2nd Division will be capable of deployment with skilled staff and current and validated procedures.
RECOMMENDATION 7

The Committee recommends that, should the review of the Ready Reserve Program confirm this view, [at paragraph 7.18] these ADG squadrons be manned by part-time Reservists serving, say, 40 days per year.
RESPONSE
Agreed

The Ready Reserve Program is to be reviewed in three years time. The review will consider any changes which might be appropriate. However, the initial view is that the readiness state required for RAAF ADGs could only be achieved with full-time training. Part-time training of about 40 days, would allow for the maintenance of the required capability and readiness achieved through previous full-time training.
RECOMMENDATION 8

The Committee recommends the introduction of an integrated structure in at least five or six selected operational squadrons employing a strong cadre of `career Reservists' (up to 200 training days/year) to support a large component of `part-time Reservists' (say, 40 days/year), with key squadron posts available for the career development of PAF members.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

To crew five or six flying units presupposes that 130 to 156 former RAAF pilots with at least one tour on the squadron aircraft type would be available and willing to serve in the Reserves for up to 200 days per year.
The recommendation is based on the US Air National Guard concept which would not be appropriate to the significantly different scale of operations in Australia for two important reasons:
a.the unavailability of sufficient former PAF-trained aircrew to support a scheme of this magnitude, and

b.the unlikely prospect of attracting sufficient numbers of Reserve personnel opting for 200 days Reserve service a year at substantially reduced conditions of service compared to continuing full-time service.
Thus, the claimed financial saving could prove illusory.

It should be noted, however, that before promulgation of the Force Structure Review, a Reserve aircrew scheme known as the Aircrew Contingency Scheme (ACRS) had been approved for introduction by RAAF in 1991. This program, currently being implemented, is designed to increase the number of aircrew available for contingencies and consists of three elements:
a.Reserve Operations (RESOPS), to provide for the transfer of a number of aircrew positions from the Permanent Air Force (PAF) to the Reserve;
b.Reserve manpower (RESMAN), to formalise the current temporary assistance provided by Reserve aircrew to the PAF; and
c.Staff Operations (STAFFOPS), to shadow post Reservists against selected staff positions to release PAF aircrew for flying duties.

RAAF has continued to review the ACRS and has recently decided to transfer the RESOPS Program from the Active Reserve to the Ready Reserve. This will result in the inclusion of up to 64 Reserve aircrew in the Ready Reserve.

The ACRS, including this most recent initiative, should not be confused with the Aircrew Contingency Supplementation Scheme (ACSS) which provides annual motivational flying for retired, previously qualified F/A-18 and F-111C aircrew, and which forms part of the RAAF General Reserve (as distinct from the RAAF Ready, Active and Special Reserves). Thus, the Committee's suggestion that the ACSS (not the ACRS) be transferred from the Ready Reserve to the RAAF General Reserve is a non sequitur as the Scheme is already a part of the RAAF's General Reserve.
RECOMMENDATION 9
Notwithstanding the complex administrative and legislative tasks involved, the Committee recommends:
.generally the Reserve types of service be streamlined and standardised;
.specifically that:

PARA.TAB: —each Service should have two parts only—Regular and Reserve;
—the Reserve part should have two components—Active and Inactive; and
—reference to emergency forces and emergency Reserves should be deleted.

SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSE
Agreed in Principle

The Assistant Chief of the Defence Force-Reserves (ACRES) is presently coordinating a review of the various components of the Reserves in the ADF with the aim of updating and rationalising the various forms of the Reserves. Amendments to legislation and regulations will be recommended accordingly. The objective of the ACRES review is to achieve as much commonality as is practicable across the ADF.
RECOMMENDATION 10

The Committee recommends that, in conjunction with the rationalisation of the multiple types of service within the Active Reserve component, a range of inducements be introduced to ensure that `part-time Reservists' serve the minimum number of days commensurate with the role and readiness requirements of particular force elements.
RESPONSE
Agreed in Principle

The Services are presently examining whether the Ready Reserve conditions of service are applicable to other elements of the Active Reserve. In general, elements which may have a case for similar conditions of service are those which have a readiness and training commitment similar to that of the Ready Reserve. Application of these benefits would be subject to budgetary provisions. An annual retention bonus already applies to members of the Army Individual Emergency Reserve. Navy is already implementing this recommendation.
RECOMMENDATION 11

On balance, and notwithstanding the considerable pressures on the TYDP, the Committee recommends that the ARes should be equipped fully at an estimated $700 million ($100 million for each of seven brigades) for the vital asset protection role as soon as is practicable.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

The Government acknowledges that deficiencies, where they do exist, could be largely overcome by a large increase in expenditure in appropriate areas. This would involve either an increase in the budgetary allocation to Defence or an adjustment in existing priorities within Defence.

In considering the first option, a realistic and responsible approach is needed and expectations should match the resources Government can provide. Since the White Paper `The Defence of Australia 1987' the real growth in Defence outlays has averaged 0%. In the current strategic and economic circumstances, the option of increasing expenditure is not feasible when overall priorities related to resource allocation are considered.

The second option would have to compete with other projects announced in the Force Structure Review. Alternatively, the $700 million could be funded from planned expenditure over the TYDP by reducing further the number of Permanent Personnel. At an average per capita salary and allowance cost of $36,000, there would need to be a reduction of approximately 1,950 Permanent Service personnel or 3% of the ADF's current strength.

Neither of these options are acceptable to Government. The Force Structure Review determined the way ahead for the ADF. The Review took account of the strategic priorities and the likely resource environment. Within this framework, decisions have been made on the relative priorities for different investment proposals.

Some $50 million has been programmed to provide equipment for the Ready Reserve Brigade, and additional resources will be devoted to improving Army's mobility, including the motorisation of the Ready Reserve Brigade and two General Reserve Brigades. While additional investment may be desirable, it has to take place among other ADF priorities.
RECOMMENDATION 12
The Committee recommends that the on-going Ready Reserve review process should focus on:
.matching the length and content of periods of initial training with the applicable role(s) and capability requirements;
.the question of whether the requirement for a second brigade group in the Ready Deployment Force (but held routinely at longer notice than 3 Brigade) can be met by Ready Reserves;
.the transfer, where the required levels of readiness can be achieved effectively, of Ready Reserve structures and capabilities to the General reserve (eg RAAF Air Defence Guards); and
.the costs and benefits of applying, where appropriate, Ready Reserve conditions of service to General Reserves.
RESPONSE
Agreed
This will be taken up with the review of the Ready Reserve Program.
RECOMMENDATION 13

The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence develop a Defence Corporate Plan for the Development of ADF Reserve Forces which concentrates on establishing the methods necessary to ensure that policy objectives are set and implemented through, among other things:
.formalisation of the steps taken to date;
.development of plans for:

PARA.TAB: -the restructure (of) Army's Manoeuvre Forces and Follow On Forces so that the available Regular and Reserve force structure can be applied to priority capability requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: .the programming of the resources needed.
RESPONSE
Not Agreed

A corporate plan for Reserves would be inappropriate in view of the `Total Force' approach adopted by the ADF. It may be appropriate, however, to focus more intensely on Reserve related matters in Defence's annual Corporate Plan.
RECOMMENDATION 14
The Committee recommends that Defence publish such a Reserves Corporate Plan by the end of 1992 and thereafter report annually to the Parliament on the extent to which key milestones have been met.
RESPONSE
Not agreed for the reason given in the response to Recommendation 13.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is an indication of its interest in this report. It is very strange that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), being a senator, did not table the report in the chamber. That speaks volumes for the Government's interest in the subject of Australia's defence.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth noting that the convention in this place is that the Government responds to a report in 90 days. The Committee's report on reserves was tabled in this Parliament in November 1991. The response we are getting today is not 90 days after the report was presented; it is 90 days after 90 days. It is six months late.

It is interesting that, purely coincidentally, there is a letter in today's Australian by a Mr Ian George. I do not know Mr George; I have never heard of him, but he is a Victorian, so he is no doubt an estimable citizen. His letter states:

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade submitted a report to Parliament in November 1991 on the Australian Defence Force Reserves. This report detailed wide-ranging concerns regarding the preparedness and potential effectiveness of the reserve component of our defence forces and called for urgent government action to remedy some serious shortcomings.

The reserves constitute a substantial proportion of our defence capability (seven out of our 10 army brigades are reserve) and the allegations of inefficiency and lack of purpose by the bipartisan committee warrant prompt official consideration.

However, it is now six months since the report was tabled and Australia still waits for even an indication that the most disturbing state of affairs identified by Mr Lindsay's committee is being addressed. To compound this disquiet, Australia's 26,000 reservists have been given no opportunity to defend their service record or to contribute to a solution. Despite long and loyal service, they have virtually been told to "cop it sweet" and await a bureaucratic decision as to their future.
It is not good enough for the Government to sit on its hands waiting for public interest to dissipate through such transparent distractions as national emblem designs.
Nor is it good enough for the Opposition to allow the Government to delay such a vital matter just because it has yet been unable to detail a comprehensive and credible alternative defence policy.
The Lindsay Committee recommendations need urgent governmental attention, and those that enhance our defence structures and capabilities should be high on the list for early implementation.

SPEECH.PARA: IAN GEORGE
Camberwell, Vic.

Mr George is quite right: the Government did have an obligation to respond to this report with much greater alacrity than it has. While we are on the subject of criticising procedures, I put on the record, as the Deputy Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee which made this report, that neither the Chairman, the Deputy Chairman, the Committee secretariat nor any members of the Committee were advised that this report would be tabled today.

PARA.TAB: The facts of life are that the Government would have known and nominated this date a month, six weeks, two months ago. It would have been a simple matter of courtesy to tell the Chairman or the Deputy Chairman or the members of the Committee that the report would be tabled today. It could have given us some warning so that we could have made a response. But no, not a word of that; there was just an insertion on the Notice Paper and the tabling of the report in the chamber. It is a gross discourtesy, not only to the members of the Committee but also to the witnesses and all the people who worked on that report, that they are treated in such a cavalier way when the Government's response is made as it is now.

What of the response? I will go through that in more detail in a few moments. The response is unimaginative and uninformed; at times it is illogical; it contradicts itself. Overall, it is a quite unprofessional document. It is a document which seeks to preserve the status quo. In a sense, we are seeing in the response of the Department of Defence to the Committee's report a literary example of a modern Singapore garrison mentality: the defence of the status quo.

The Committee's report does not pretend to be infallible. It does not set out to be an immutable blueprint for what the Government ought to do in this field. But it is a closely reasoned and logical approach to what is a very difficult subject; namely, the state of the Australian Defence Force reserves. The report did come up with some innovative, creative and, above all, constructive proposals as to how this problem could be tackled. But nothing the report said has been picked up by the Government.

The report was led by the evidence that was given to the Committee. No-one started out on that Committee with any theoretical model as to what the Australian Defence Force reserves should be. We were led by the evidence given to that Committee. We were an all-party committee. We came down with a unanimous report. Frankly, the report deserves better treatment than it has received in the hands of the faceless bureaucrats who made the response for the Government. I am quite sure that Senator Ray never read the report that we tabled, The Australian Defence Force Reserves. I am quite sure he has never read the response that is being made in his name in this chamber today. I think that says it all about the Government's interest in the vital and basic duty that it has to defend Australia.

The response to the report is composed mainly of assertions, a few misinterpretations of what the report actually says and some misconstructions. I think the most disappointing thing about the Government response is that there is no solid reasoning or even explanation behind the assertions it makes rejecting the recommendations of the defence Committee. All we get are the old cliches—strategic guidance, force structure, warning time and all the rest of it; all the old cliches that those of us who have been around the defence debate have heard ad nauseam.

I suppose I should not be surprised, let alone disappointed, at the response from the Government. The Defence Subcommittee has produced a series of very well researched and very well presented reports over the last six to eight years and on no occasion has the Government or the Department of Defence done anything other than treat those reports with stony silence or, at best, damn them with faint praise.

I am glad that the Government has made as bad a response as it has on this particular occasion because, unlike the earlier reports we did—the one on the resignation rates when service personnel were leaving the Australian Defence Force, voting with their feet against the Government's lack of policy in defence; the management report and the other reports that have preceded this one—what we are involved with in respect of the report on the reserves is a body of about 30,000 Australians who serve in the Australian defence forces. They have a very keen interest in the way the Government is treating them at present. While the Government does not want the matter to be debated in public, those people in the reserves—and it is far more than 30,000 when one takes cognisance of those Australian men and women who have served in the reserves over recent decades—will see that this debate is carried on. You can prophesy with absolute confidence that the Government will come out of this very badly because the response today is very inadequate.

In a nutshell, the Committee showed up the shortcomings of the Australian reserve forces, and it made some suggestions about what could be done to satisfy the Government's own policy directives. The thing that has really infuriated the Department of Defence is the fact that the Committee took the parameters set by the Government and the Department of Defence—the policy directives set in Defence of Australia 1987 and subsequently in Australian Strategic Plans for the 1990s—as policy directives and showed how the Government had not met its own objectives. We would not have minded if we had been able to see that it was making plans to achieve its goals, but on so many occasions we saw that it simply had not made the logical steps which follow from the goals that it laid down.

It was common knowledge all around this town in the early part of this year—I heard in January or early February—that the Department was very upset with our report and that the method of attack would be to say that we had proposed readiness times for reserve units that were quite unreal. That, of course, has come to pass. That is the central argument that the Government is using against our report.

It is rather ironic because we recently had a report by Mr Alan Wrigley into aspects of the Australian Defence Force. The bureaucracy, the interdepartmental committee that had a look at that on behalf of the Government, damned that report on the grounds that lead times for readiness proposed by Mr Wrigley were too long to be workable. Today we have a response from the Government to the defence Committee's report which damns it because it says lead times are too short. It is a very interesting proposition—one which, of course, simply has no substance at all.

The defence Committee did not have any choice in the way it wrote the report. It had to write the report to five terms of reference. Those terms of reference were proposed by the Minister. Essentially, we had to write to published strategic guidance in the form of the Defence of Australia of 1987, updated by ASP `90 which I mentioned before, and certain things followed from that. The Committee wrote meticulously to the terms of reference, even though everyone except the Government knows that those terms of reference are outdated and totally discredited.

The DOA paper of 1987 and ASP `90 both were written, despite what some senior people in the civilian side of Defence have said in my hearing within the last couple of months, before the collapse of the Soviet empire. We are now faced with a totally different strategic world. To argue the way some of the civilians do in defence that, because the geography of Australia never changes and one cannot move Australia to another part of the world, the principles outlined in DOA 1987 therefore have eternal life, is to exercise one's mind in a very childish argument. Of course things change as the politics of the region change, and the politics of the region in which Australia is situated now are quite different from what they were when the strategic guidance papers were written in 1987.

I would like to briefly look at the Government response itself. At a future date I will go through this in much more detail. Probably much to the dismay of my colleagues, I will do it on the adjournment one night. But my response to the Government's response to the report does deserve a more reasoned approach than I am able to give at the moment, having had only a short while with it.
As I said before, the first point the Government makes occurs in its first paragraph in the `General Comment on Readiness and Preparedness' where it attacks the Committee in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: These comments rely heavily on the Committee's judgement that credible contingencies could arise with `little or no warning'. While the Government accepts that such contingencies could arise with little warning, our force structure should take account of our strategic circumstances including the limited capacity of countries in our neighbourhood to conduct operations against Australia and the lack of any reason for them to do so. Readiness consumes resources so the readiness posture adopted must reflect prudent risk management. The Committee's misunderstanding of this key policy concept, which determines the force structure and preparedness of the ADF, leads the Committee to make recommendations which are based on a false premise.

With the greatest of respect to the Government, I believe that it is the Government which is making the false premise. If one is familiar with defence papers, one will know that the phrase `little or no warning time'—in association with the so-called low level contingencies, which is the central point of Australia's defence strategy at present—occurs over and over again. It occurs with good reason.

PARA.TAB: If one can believe in the low level contingencies which the Government talks about in terms of credible contingencies—I do not happen to find them credible, but that is another point that I will develop at another time—it necessarily follows that the lead time and the warning time could be only a matter of hours. It may not be; it may be quite a long period. Obviously, defence planning has to cope with that. That is why one sees in all the defence papers that phrase `little or no warning'. It is quite fallacious and specious to say that the Committee was fixed on this idea of little or no warning time and, therefore, all the recommendations that it made subsequently fall down.

The Committee understands very well that readiness costs money. If forces are going to be held at high degrees of training, ready to go on active service, there is a disproportionate cost in doing so, and there is no point in doing so unless there is a clearly definable reason. There is a world of difference in having a system in place which allows reserve forces the luxury of 180 days or 360 days to get ready. If we are paying $500m a year, as we are for the Army reserves—part of which are on 360 days readiness—we are not getting any benefit. One might as well recruit people off the street, if there is a year to prepare, and not carry the cost of them in the reserves.

The next thing that the Government does to justify its ridicule of little or no warning time is to puff itself up with the brilliance of its intelligence services. The next paragraph of its response states:

SPEECH.PARA: Intelligence provides early warning and is central to the ADF's level of operational readiness. Within a responsible resource framework, the Government supports continuing substantial investment in intelligence and surveillance capabilities. . .

I have no quarrel with that. My quarrel is with the assumption that intelligence services are accurate predictors of what is going to happen. We only have to look at the last decade. The intelligence services did not know that Iraq was going to invade Kuwait in August 1990. They did not know that the Iraq-Iran war was going to start. They did not know that the attack on the Falklands by the Argentinians was going to take place. Close to home, the Australian intelligence services did not know that the Fijian coup was on. They did not know that the first one was on; they did not even know about the second one.

PARA.TAB: By all means we ought to do our best to gather the best intelligence that we can, but we always must be alive to the possibility that it is not infallible and that we are going to be caught out. That is the argument for having some realistic preparedness times.
The Government's response states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government already maintains significant Regular and Reserve forces capable of responding to a low level contingency at short notice.

I ask the Government: where are those forces? Apart from 3 Brigade in Townsville, which is a two-battalion brigade—the Operational Deployment Force—there simply are no forces ready to go on short notice. The Air Force certainly cannot commit, other than in the maritime reconnaissance role and in the transport role, any squadrons on operational service in the strike and in the fighter role—the air superiority role. The lack of any effective ECM capability, the lack of any AWACS capability, prevents them operating effectively. Of course, we all saw in the Gulf deployment with Desert Shield and Desert Storm the huge flurry in getting only two ships ready to go onto a patrolling station in the Persian Gulf.

PARA.TAB: We have the ridiculous situation today that when the RAN wants to send some of its ships on operational service, it has to transfer the fitment of the close-in weapons system from one DDG to another just as years ago, in some families, people had to take it in turns as to who went out because they had only one set of clothes. The Government cannot maintain that it has significant regular and reserve forces capable of responding to a low level contingency at short notice. It is misleading; it is not telling the truth in making that claim.

The rest of the response to the report deals with a number of claims that are not backed up in any way at all by reasoned argument. The Department does not seem to understand the Committee's criticism of the Ready Reserve scheme which was introduced. The Committee made the point that it thought, in the short term, the Ready Reserve scheme would operate very well, but it saw significant problems with it in the longer term. To go on, as the Government does, to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The conversion of 6 Brigade from a Regular to Reserve formation is seen as consistent with strategic guidance—
is to make a claim that does not appear in strategic guidance at all. It goes on to say:

It is quite apparent that the conversion increases the immediacy of the Reserve in reacting to any land threat. The readiness level of 6 Brigade is adequate to allow it to complement the Operational Deployment Force in a low level threat situation if called out.

The Government is fooling around with words there. How can the removal of two professional regular battalions—which is what happened when 6 Brigade was disbanded and reformed as a Ready Reserve brigade—and the replacement of them by a Ready Reserve battalion, admittedly quite well trained initially, compensate for the loss of two full time battalions? Even if one can accept that these guys are as good as the regulars that they have replaced, which is demonstrably false, the readiness period required is still 90 days. There is no faster response from the ready reserves than from the regulars. It is a very misleading and a very specious argument.

PARA.TAB: There is a claim here that the report does not acknowledge the benefits provided by reserves on long degrees of notice—I was talking before about people on 360 days over the `soldiers of the street'—and does not recognise the advantage inherent in a standing reserve. I make the point that, when it is costing us $500m a year for the reserve scheme, we ought to be looking at getting the maximum benefit from it and not have people on 360 days notice before we can use them in an operational setting.

In the part of the response which deals with the recommendations, pretty well every recommendation, except for a couple of motherhood ones, is rejected by the Government. In that we see illogical inconsistencies in the Government position. It is arguing one thing in one place and arguing against the same proposition in another place. Its response to recommendation 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not consider that strategic guidance requires that 6 Brigade be restructured as suggested by the Committee.
It is saying, on one hand, that the Ready Reserve is ready but, on the other hand, it is not ready. It is these sorts of things that expose the Government to ridicule.

PARA.TAB: There is certainly a misrepresentation of what the Committee says in the Government's response to recommendation 3. We do not say that we require 6 Brigade to operate with 28 days notice. We say between 28 and 90 days, according to the circumstance. There is a world of difference, as honourable senators would be aware, between one month and three months. I will come back to the response at a future date and go through it in detail, not that it demands any intellectual effort at all, but for the sake of the record it ought to be corrected.

What we have here is really the defence of the status quo, as I said before. We have a very difficult task in managing the reserves and getting value from them. It is a very complex issue. The propositions that were advanced in the Committee report deserve some consideration.

There was a very good article on Desert Storm recently in the US Armor magazine. I would like to quote an extract by Richard Cheney, the Secretary of Defense for the United States, who was out here last month. In a postscript to this article he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Consider one of my favourite stories about the marines of Company B of the 4th Tank Battalion. They're combat reservists from Yakima, Washington, not active duty personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see the Minister for Defence in the chamber at last, to get some education in a field in which he is sadly lacking. Before the suspension of the sitting, I was quoting from a postscript by Richard Cheney, the United States Secretary of Defense. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: They were activated last December and went into battle with their Abrams tanks when ground operations began in Kuwait on the 24th of February. Before dawn, moving north inside Kuwait, Company B discovered a large formation of Iraqi tanks. They saw some of the top-line T-72 tanks heading straight toward them through a large group of dug-in Iraqi armor. All told, the Marine company with 13 tanks faced 35 oncoming Iraqi tanks, outnumbered nearly three to one. But when the encounter was over, the Marine reservists had destroyed or stopped 34 of the 35 enemy tanks. In fact, in a total of four engagements in four days, Company B stopped 59 Iraqi tanks, 30 of them top-line T-72s. What makes it all the more impressive is that Company B had never used those Abrams tanks before they arrived in the desert. That was their first exposure to the new equipment. And they trained on it, acquired the capability to operate it, and then performed superbly in combat.

Company B was a Reserve company. It was called up on 12 December. On 26 December, in the United States, it converted from M-60 tanks to Abrams—a huge jump in technology. It graduated on 13 January with the Abrams. It was in Saudi Arabia on 17 January. It inherited new Abrams tanks which virtually had no equipment in them. It had to kit the tanks out. In action, it breached the defences in the southern part of Kuwait. One of the most difficult of all land operations is the armoured penetration of a minefield. It completed four battles there with the successes that Mr Cheney indicated, and it returned to America on 25 April.

PARA.TAB: That was a Reserve battalion. It re-equipped with a totally new type of technology in the Abrams tank and it did that in a matter of weeks. It went into action and fought brilliantly. Yet we have these uninformed minds who wrote the report for the Minister saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Capabilities which require ongoing skill reinforcement, either because they are complex or need to be maintained at high levels, are not generally appropriate for the Reserves.

That is utter nonsense. When the report was tabled by the Defence committee I forecast that it would be met with silence and buried by the Department. I made the point today that the reserves of Australia will not allow that to happen. The sad thing is that they are the victims of all this. They will go on sinking further and further because they do not have the resources to support them. The only thing wrong with the Australian reserves is that they are so badly under-resourced; they are very badly off. We made the point that they had to be provided with equipment and training opportunities to reach the level that the Government wants from them, yet we get the fatuous statement in this report that to do so would mean that the Defence Force could not do other things. In other words, the Government is so blind that it cannot see the need for money to meet the minimal objectives that it has set for itself.

PARA.TAB: The reserves will go on, under-resourced, with high wastage rates and poor morale. More regular COs will come in for units which will also destroy the morale of the officer corps. We are in a vicious cycle. The Government had an opportunity to take notice of ways in which that situation could be corrected. Instead, the report was given to somebody who received his military knowledge from a comic book. Some uneducated, junior clerk wrote this report. It is one of the most insulting documents ever to be put in the Parliament and it is something that will haunt the Government because the reserves of the Australian Defence Force will see that this debate is maintained in public. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Statement on Committee Action on the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a statement from the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Honourable senators will recall that the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned at aspects of the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321. Our difficulty was with provisions concerning conclusive exemption certificates which exclude public disclosure of certain material in documents. The regulations provided that such certificates were to remain in force for five years. This was in contrast to the report by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation, which recommended that certificates should only be effective for two years.

PARA.TAB: The Committee devoted some time to this question. We had considerable correspondence with the Minister and asked senior officials from the Department to attend before the Committee. Eventually we decided, with some hesitation, to accept the explanation of the Minister. I reported to the Senate in some detail on this on 24 March 1992 and incorporated our correspondence in Hansard. Subsequently, on the same day, the Senate disallowed the regulations on policy grounds.

At its next meeting the Committee discussed the effect of the disallowance, which was that while the regulations had set five years duration for conclusive certificates, following their disallowance such certificates were in force indefinitely. The Committee then decided to write to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), noting his earlier advice that the Government accepted that this indefinite operation was inappropriate, and asked whether it was intended to make fresh regulations to set a duration shorter than five years. The Attorney-General replied promptly, confirming that the Government believed that there should be a limit on the duration of certificates. Although he still considered that two years was too short, he said that the Department would consult with other agencies to ascertain the best way to resolve the matter. The Committee considers that this helpful advice from the Attorney-General should be made known to the Senate. The Committee will, of course, scrutinise any fresh legislation which appears as a result of this undertaking.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Statement on Scrutiny by the Committee of the Child Care Centre Fee Relief Eligibility Guidelines

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have a statement to make on child-care centre fee relief eligibility guidelines. It is a rather lengthy statement. In deference to the time constraints on the Senate, I will just read the preamble and then seek leave to incorporate the rest of the statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators should be aware from the regular reports and statements of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances that every year, at the instigation of the Committee, Ministers undertake to amend dozens of provisions in instruments of delegated legislation to correct technical deficiencies, to strengthen and safeguard personal rights and liberties, and to provide appropriate review decisions taken by public officials. From time to time, Ministers also undertake to amend the parent Act under which delegated legislation is made.

Tonight I report to the Senate on an initiative by the Committee which resulted in an undertaking by the Minister to provide extensive review rights in a parent Act—in this case, the Child Care Act of 1972. That Act deals with major aspects of the important and sensitive issue of child-care. It defines child-care centres, provides for capital grants for building and equipment, for recurrent grants, including provision for the maximum number of places at a centre, and for fee relief.

There was no provision at all in the Act for external merits review of discretions exercised in the administration of these programs. Normally such matters are picked up by our sister legislative scrutiny committee, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. However, this Act was passed some 10 years before the Committee was established. It gives me considerable personal satisfaction to report that these deficiencies will now be remedied as a result of tenacious action by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the remainder of my statement and to move a motion in relation to the statement.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This matter first came before the Committee when it examined the Child Care Centre Fee Relief Eligibility Guidelines, an instrument of delegated legislation made under the Child Care Act. That Act, as well as providing the usual broad regulation making power, also expressly provides for the Minister to make disallowable guidelines in respect of basic aspects of the administration of the scheme established by the Act. For instance, one set of guidelines, which had to be observed when making decisions under the Act, was to identify children in economic need, and to calculate maximum amounts payable to the operators of child-care centres. Another set of guidelines was to limit and guide a broad discretion granted to the Minister to determine whether a child-care centre was eligible for fee relief.

These guidelines are obviously important even when decisions are made by the Minister. However, this importance is magnified by the Act providing that the Minister may delegate any or all of his or her powers to any officer in the Department.

The particular guidelines in question were made on 19 December 1990, tabled in the Senate on 12 February 1991 and considered by the Committee at its regular meeting on 7 March 1991. The guidelines were not accompanied by the usual explanatory statement. Also, on their face, they provided the Minister or, of course, a delegate, with the discretion to approve a child-care centre as eligible for Commonwealth grants even though at the time the guidelines were not met. Such a discretion always attracts a question from the Committee if, as in this case, there was no obvious right of review of the discretion either in the parent Act or other delegated legislation.

The Committee wrote to the Minister about these aspects of the guidelines on 11 March 1991. The Minister replied on 29 May 1991, providing an explanatory statement. That document assisted the Committee, as it confirmed that there was no external review of an adverse exercise of the discretion. The only protection available for people affected by the guidelines was that they may apply again at any time. Thus, any defects in the original application may be corrected and a refusal is not regarded as final. However, while this is a safeguard of sorts, it may not be an appropriate substitute for external, independent merit review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Therefore, on 7 June 1991, the Committee wrote back to the Minister asking whether advice had been sought from the Administrative Review Council or the Attorney-General's Department on whether AAT review was appropriate in this case.

On 24 July 1991 the Minister replied to the Committee that merit review of discretions in the guidelines was not considered appropriate because the parent Act did not provide for AAT review of what could be termed the head power in the Act. The Committee accepted this point, as we understand that it is the view of the ARC that it may not be appropriate to have subsidiary discretions subject to review when the head power is not so subject. However, this at once raised the question of whether review of that head power should be reviewable by the AAT. This letter from the Minister had also advised that although the guidelines were drafted by the Office of Legislative Drafting, which the Committee has found to produce good quality work, advice was not sought from either the ARC or the Attorney-General's Department on whether AAT review was suitable because of the absence of merit review in the parent Act. Therefore, the Committee wrote to the Minister for the third time on 16 August 1991 asking if he could approach the ARC for its advice on whether the entire general scheme, set out in the parent Act and implemented in detail through delegated legislation, should be subject to AAT review of the merits of any decision. The Minister helpfully agreed to do this.

The ARC reported its findings on 13 December 1991, recommending that the parent Act, an associated Act and delegated legislation be amended to provide for review by both the AAT and, in one case, by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The decisions which the ARC advised should be reviewable included every major discretion in the entire child-care program established by the Act.

For instance, the Act provides that the Minister may determine that an institution is a child-care centre. The ARC advised that this discretion affected the interests of people concerned about receiving assistance. Also, although these decisions are made by a Minister, they do not fall into the class which, because of the level of consequence and highly political nature involved, should be exempt. In addition, these decisions do not involve matters of a polycentric nature, or competing interests of several parties, and are not merely facultative. Therefore, such decisions should be reviewable.

There were numbers of other discretions which the ARC considered suitable for merit review by the AAT. Thus, one section provides that the Minister may approve a body to operate a child care centre. The ARC pointed out that although these decisions are not the final steps in a substantive process, they are essential steps. In addition, the same section provides two separate avenues for the Minister to determine that a child care centre is eligible for assistance under the Act. Both should be subject to AAT review, even though there is express provision in the Act for disallowable guidelines to be made to guide the exercise of the discretion.

The Act provides a number of discretions on recurrent expenditure. In accordance with its longstanding practice the ARC recommended that those which made allotments from a finite pool of money should not be subject to review, but that two discretions which did not involve such allotment should be reviewable. In this context, the power, in certain circumstances, to determine the rate of salary or wages payable at child care centres, should be reviewable.

The power to make a grant for fee relief should be reviewable, even though this is another case where the Act expressly provides for disallowable mandatory guidelines in respect of the exercise of the power.
A discretion to seek repayment of overpayments, which the ARC considered was not substantially different from recovery powers in other Acts, should be subject to review.

With respect to the disallowable guidelines actually made under the Act the ARC recommended that three discretions, relating to children in economic need and the amount of fee relief available, should be subject to review. One of these discretions should be reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, which is thus an example of a case where it is appropriate for an independent tribunal other than the AAT to examine the merits of an individual decision.

Although the ARC sent its recommendations to the Minister on 13 December 1991 the Department did not notify the Committee of this until 16 April 1992, or more than four months later, and only at the prompting of the Committee secretariat. A delay of this length may indicate management problems in the Department.

On the other hand, the Committee has received particularly constructive advice from the Minister, Peter Staples, Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, that necessary changes to the Act would be progressed in the Autumn sittings next year. While the Committee appreciates that this may be the earliest sittings in which the legislative program can accommodate the amendments, the Committee will indicate to the Minister that the importance and sensitivity of child care would justify its introduction early in those sittings.
The Committee is grateful to the Minister for this cooperation, which will improve the technical quality of legislation in the portfolio.

In summary, the Committee's scrutiny of this instrument illustrates the thoroughness and persistence of its operations. More than a year elapsed between the meeting at which the Committee first considered this matter and the final undertaking by the Minister to amend the Act. Moreover, it will be two years from the time the Committee raised the matter with the Minister in early 1991 until the Act is actually amended. Nevertheless, these comprehensive changes to the Child Care Act, and its associated delegated legislation, arising entirely from an initiative by the Committee, will result in the introduction of important safeguards for those affected by Commonwealth child care programs. This is an example of the diligence with which the Committee pursues its mandate from the Senate.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless the Parliament provides otherwise, section 66 of the Constitution prescribes a maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries to Ministers. Amendments to the Ministers of State Act which sets this sum are thus required from time to time to cover changes to ministerial salaries. The sum appropriated is to meet the expected cost of salaries and no more. While the Act covers the total cost of salaries it does not set the amount of individual salaries to Ministers.

The enactment of the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1990, has had, amongst other things, the effect of linking the basic salary levels for parliamentarians to the top of the Senior Executive Service band one in the Public Service.

There is also a similarly proportioned increase in the salaries of Ministers of State. Following the enactment of the Remuneration and Allowances Act the Government set in train arrangements to ensure that the relativities established between the salaries of parliamentarians at that time are maintained. That is, Ministers' salaries are increased at the same rate and at the same time that salaries of senators and members of the Parliament increase. Ministers receive the same percentage increase in additional salaries as members of the Parliament and are phased in the same way.

The amount proposed to be appropriated accords with and includes the national wage case increase of 2.5% effective from 15 August 1991. The inreased amount required in subsequent financial years accommodates the full year effect of the increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill relates to the provision of untied financial assistance to Local Government.
Its objective is to put in place arrangements for the provision of identified local road funding to Local Government for the three years 1992-93 to 1994-95.

In respect of local roads funds, the Special Premiers' Conference of October 1990, decided that funds for local roads would be untied and paid to Local Government, or to State Governments where they are responsible for local roads, via general purpose grants.

The Government decided to introduce interim arrangements for 1991-92 to provide a period of stability while the detailed arrangements were finalised for subsequent years. The interim arrangements were reflected in the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Act 1991.

Since the interim arrangements were agreed to in 1991, there have been extensive consultations with Local Government and with the States. These consultations were marked by a positive attitude and a genuine desire on the part of all parties to develop arrangements acceptable to all concerned.

The Government would like to take this opportunity to place on record its appreciation of the co-operation afforded by the Australian Local Government Association and the various State Associations which comprise its membership. Their contribution is evidence of the value of Commonwealth and State Governments fully involving them in the development of Commonwealth and State policies that will affect directly or indirectly Local Government and its operations.
The arrangements that are now incorporated in this Bill reflect the advice and suggestions that were obtained through the consultation process.
Under the arrangements proposed in the Bill
—the funding involved will continue to be separately identified rather than absorbed into general purpose assistance.
—each State's share of the funding level of some $300m will be maintained at the present proportion.
—the arrangements will operate for a three-year period 1992-93 to 1994-95.
—the funds will be distributed in each State on the basis of principles reflecting road needs.

—the legislation will no longer provide specific allocations for special roads works but the funding of such works may be provided for in the principles that will govern the distribution of grants in each State.
As for 1991-92 the funding will be untied which will mean simply that the manner in which it is spent will be entirely at the discretion of the local governing body.
The commitment, previously given by the Government, to maintain this funding in real terms will be honoured.

The distribution of funds between local governing bodies in each State, as noted above, will be in accordance with principles reflecting road needs. These principles will be worked out between the Commonwealth and each State and Local Government Associations in that State.

The Commonwealth will be insisting that principles that are developed are consistent with the Commonwealth Government's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

An important feature of the new arrangements is to provide funding for councils in the Northern Territory so that all local governing bodies in that Territory which are receiving general purpose assistance from local government will also receive identified road funding.
This change will extend identified local road funding to an additional 52 local governing bodies in the Northern Territory, the great majority of which represent Aboriginal communities.

This change will be achieved by providing for a mechanism to transfer some local roads funds, currently paid to the Territory Government, to Northern Territory Local Governments via the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986.

The level of the funds to be transferred will be decided following consultations between the Minister responsible for Local Government in the Territory and the Commonwealth Minister for Local Government. Up to some $12m could be involved in the transfer.
This change will not disadvantage mainstream councils in the Northern Territory, but will bring arrangements in the Territory into line with those in the rest of Australia.

There will also be some adjustment to funding levels in Tasmania, dependent on negotiations between the Tasmanian Government and the Municipal Association of Tasmania. These negotiations concern the responsibilities of the respective spheres of government concerning certain road works. Funding levels will reflect adjustments to responsibilities. Some $4.5m could be involved.
In both the Northern Territory and Tasmania the adjustments decided will be notified in the Commonwealth Government Gazette according to the requirements of this Bill.

The net financial impact of the changes proposed in the Bill is nil. Increases in funding to the Northern Territory and Tasmanian Local Government will be offset by an equivalent reduction in general purpose assistance provided to those State governments.

Because of the timing of the Government's decision it is not expected that the State Local Government Grants Commissions will be recommending any significant changes to the distribution of grants in their respective States for 1992-93. Certainly the Commonwealth will not be insisting on any such changes. This situation should now assist councils in their planning for the coming year.

Mr President, the changes that are proposed will provide a firm basis for the provision of these grants for the next three years. They will improve the equity of the arrangements. Consistent with our policies for Local Government they will, in addition, strengthen the role of that sphere of government that is so important to all Australians.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
