DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Spindler:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the report entitled The Australian Vocational Certificate Training System by the Employment and Skills Formation Council on behalf of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. The report proposes a new entry level training system designed to meet Australia's training needs into the next century by improving the coverage, quality and equity of vocational certificate training in Australia. The report stresses that it is not a short term response to the recession and high youth unemployment but proposes a long term strategy marked by three time goals: 1995, 1998 and 2001.

PARA.TAB: The Carmichael report adopts, with some modification, the targets outlined in the Finn review, otherwise known as the Young People's Participation in Compulsory Education and Training report. The Australian vocational certificate training system aims to meet by the year 2001 the training participation and attainment targets of 90 per cent of 19-year-olds completing year 12, 90 per cent of 20-year-olds attaining level 2 vocational certificates or higher, and 60 per cent of 22-year-olds attaining level 3 certificates or higher qualifications.

The system would merge apprenticeships and traineeships as part of flexible training pathways. TAFE would be the main provider of advanced vocational training in a network of nationwide senior colleges, skill centres, and private and community providers of on the job and off the job training. These pathways would allow for recognition of prior learning and credit transfer. We have heard much discussion about competencies and the definition of key competencies. The focus of competency-based training is on proficiency in the generic competencies, skills and outcomes.

The Carmichael report does not shy away from the problems of access and equity, specifically for women, non-English-speaking background migrants, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, people with disabilities, the rural poor and marginal workers. The year 2001 is the target date for the equal participation of ethnic groups, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and for women and men in the vocational training system. The report recognises:

SPEECH.PARA: affirmative action is needed not only to entice young women into non-traditional vocational training and to change attitudes in these occupations but to extend equal training, accreditation and recognition arrangements to the service occupations in which women are concentrated.

The report does not overlook the fact that women's participation and success in industry is affected by the concentration of women in traditional areas of study and occupation, a lack of female peers and role models, child-care, retraining opportunities and support services. The report also recognises that a realistic means of financial assistance is essential if young people, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds, are to enter further education and training. It offers insight into the inadequacy of Austudy and questions the worth of a loans scheme—a debate that was raging yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The report acknowledges that Austudy may act as a disincentive for young people to participate in education and training and expresses concern about the potential impact of a loans scheme on deprived income families and on trade and other training. This is particularly revealing in the light of the Chapman report's recommendations.

One aspect of the Carmichael report which has industrial implications is that of trainee wages and training allowances. According to the report, wages in their current form do not bear any relation to the competence or performance of the individual. While concluding that trainee wages are the responsibility of industrial relations parties, it recommends that a trainee wage should be based on time spent on the job, the level of competency attained and the value of the competency demonstrated by the worker on the job. The issue of youth wages is an important one, and it is equally important that wages for young people are not undercut as a result of altered trainee wages.

The report recommends a $1.2 billion real increase in Commonwealth expenditure on vocational certificate training by 1998. This covers funding for TAFE and skill centres, the provision of employer subsidies, the professional development of teachers and trainers, the provision of trainee allowances, and for additional modern plant and equipment. As Carmichael has stated publicly, unless there is a guarantee that the funds earmarked for the expansion of vocational training will not be siphoned off for other projects, the vocational training system will fail.

The implementation of competency-based training has the potential to strengthen the role of industry, to boost our international competitiveness, the skills in our workplace and our strength as a nation. There is much to be commended in the Carmichael report. It is a very weighty and lengthy document which is worthy of far more than the five minutes we are able to give it today in the Senate. I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight on the findings of the report entitled The Australian Vocational Certificate Training System, the Carmichael report, which was put out by the Employment and Skills Formation Council. It is a very important document and has many implications for the future of vocational training in Australia. The report is to be commended for addressing a very important issue facing the area of training. As stated in the report, the global economy has become fiercely competitive, and a better trained work force is indispensable to competition. Therefore, our education and training must be markedly improved.

PARA.TAB: This report follows on from another very important study, the Finn report on young people's participation in post-compulsory education. It even recommends and produces a broad plan for the implementation of some of the key recommendations of the Finn report. Part of this is the recommendation that all students participating in post-compulsory education should undertake on the job training. This report outlines the development of a common vocational education and training framework which uses competency standards, curricula, assessment and certification of skill acquisition to align upper secondary schooling, TAFE, private training provisions and work-based training. Students could be offered subjects with a strong vocational content which have credit into post-school training courses.

This is a revolutionary concept and represents a marked departure from the philosophy that currently underpins secondary schooling in Australia. The concept of a general education will be replaced by one which includes a more vocational emphasis through the learning of generic skills. The recommendations of the report dovetail neatly with the Finn report concept of key competencies.

The report proposes the replacement of apprenticeships and traineeships with a competency-based system encompassing upper secondary schooling, TAFE, private providers and enterprise training on and off the job. The report proposes a new system of entry level training which would effectively merge the current system of apprenticeships and traineeships into a new Australian vocational certificate training system.

Perhaps the most sensible suggestion is that apprentices who master the skills of their trade more quickly than their peers should not be held back by rigid requirements of progression. If they master skills more quickly at one particular level, then they can move on to the next level. One key recommendation of the report is for the establishment of a vocational year of training whereby students who have completed year 12 may undertake a course delivered by TAFE or senior colleges which would include structured work placement, preparing students to attain a standard level recognised and comparable across the broad spectrum of vocational training.

The Government is proud of the fact that the year 12 retention rate has risen but it will not acknowledge that this is the result of the great recession that young Australians have suffered under this ALP Government. Many young people go through to year 12 as they have no alternative other than to join the one million people who are unemployed. The recommendations in this report will make retention at school until year 12 a more worthwhile pursuit for those who do not wish to pursue tertiary education. In the past, many of these went on to apprenticeships and many simply entered the work force as unskilled labour or in growing numbers joined the dole queue.

After year 10 the education system has not served the non-tertiary stream well. The retention rate for year 12 has increased as a result. However, the subjects offered to those students often have very little to do with vocational training. Presently there is not sufficient integration between the school system in years 11 and 12 in preparation for entry into the work force. The recommendations of this report will help achieve that.

The Carmichael report offers a radical alternative to a stale, outdated system. It addresses many important issues that need to be looked at very carefully by all people interested in the Australian education system. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the report entitled Higher Education Council—Sixth Report to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training on the operation of section 14 of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and the higher education contribution scheme. The report views the profiles process and briefly addresses institutional autonomy and reviews the operation and effects of the higher education contribution scheme. The report concludes, on the basis of evidence, including an Ernst and Young survey:

SPEECH.PARA: HECS has not had an impact on the size of the higher education system.

This is supported by the high levels of unmet demand we have been unfortunate enough to witness this year. However, it goes on to state that the higher education contribution scheme is not a severe financial disincentive to enter higher education for year 12 students and rates HECS as a middle ranking factor in the decision not to undertake university studies. One might ask what constitutes a severe financial disincentive? The report also states:
HECS has little effect on the decision of the educationally disadvantaged groups identified in the research.
It is unfortunate that this is not accompanied by any information on particular groups in the community to provide a realistic breakdown about the HECS effects on participation rates.

PARA.TAB: An analysis of the statistics of students who elect to pay HECS up front reveals a steady increase in the number of students 19 years and under choosing to make up-front payments. This number has risen from 12.8 per cent to 17.5 per cent in less than three years. This indicates that there is a large number of students whose HECS is paid for them, presumably by their parents. Evidence supports this, showing that private school students are more likely to pay up front, with their parents footing the bill. This report sadly lacks a socio-economic breakdown of up-front payments. This would enable us to establish the socio-economic backgrounds of the students and might provide alarming evidence for the Government about the nature of students entering tertiary institutions.

I look forward to the upcoming report which determines the appropriateness of using postcodes as a socio-economic indicator, thus providing a means of monitoring the participation of students from lower socio-economic backgrounds in tertiary education. A report released last month by the South Australian Office of Tertiary Education in fact reveals that the State's eastern suburbs are disproportionately represented in universities. These statistics confirm that students enrolled in universities are more likely to come from higher socio-economic backgrounds.

The Government's purported commitment to access and equity principles is meaningless when faced with this reality. This report recommends monitoring HECS every three years or at other times if there are major changes to the scheme. What further changes does the Higher Education Council or this Government have planned for HECS? Is last year's above CPI Budget increase of $144 not a substantial enough change to this scheme—a scheme, I maintain, that is an unfair financial burden to those wishing to undertake education in this country? The very people this Government attempts to encourage through the clever country rhetoric are in fact disadvantaged.

Contrary to the report's recommendation, I stress the need for regular evaluation of the scheme, especially now that the first group of HECS graduates begin to repay their debts. The report alludes to the current public debate over threats to institutional autonomy. We assume this means the heated debate over the John Curtin School of Medical Research and other centres. The Senate Standing Committee into JCSMR agreed that the concept of institutional interference is a difficult one to assess.

I agree that there need be no conflict between academic freedom and institutional obligations, as in the profiles. Distribution of funds by the Government to institutions does entail certain obligations which include financial accountability and careful administration. The report is correct when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The notion of autonomy is debased if it is invoked as a defence against well founded recommendations for change.

The report does cite potential threats to institutional autonomy, such as political pressures, employers and professional bodies in relation to pressure for funds and interference in curriculum formulation. This report is a more substantial one into the profile process and reveals a broad support for institutional profiles. Institutions, given the opportunity to stipulate agenda items, have focused on resource allocation, credit transfer, course articulation, links with TAFE and participation rates.

PARA.TAB: The work of the Higher Education Council provides us with important information through which we can monitor developments in the higher education system. I look forward to future reports and continued assessment of the effects of the higher education contribution scheme. I commend the report to the Senate.

Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Crane:
That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the resignation of Commissioner Turbet from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC),
(ii)with deep concern, the circumstances which led Commissioner Turbet to take the extraordinary step of resigning,
(iii)that the role of the AIRC has been replaced with shady deals between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Secretary of the ACTU (Mr Kelty), and
(iv)that, as the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is not part of these `deals', he is therefore too weak to protect the independence and integrity of the AIRC; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Minister for Industrial Relations to resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were last addressing the motion as moved by Senator Crane setting out very distinctly the reasons why Senator Cook should resign, we were dealing with matters that had come before us—particularly the letter from the former Commissioner, Ken Turbet, who has resigned from the Commission and who set out his reasons for so doing in a very succinct matter, and the letter in reply to Commissioner Turbet by the senator.

PARA.TAB: I was pointing out the distinction regarding what the Government says it is in favour of, that is, the integrity of the Commission. The Government's position is that the Commission is the arbiter on matters of industrial relations and that its decisions should be respected. The Government says that the Commission is central to the functioning of the centralised wage fixing system which the Government says it supports. The points I was making with regard to the two letters as they had been exchanged were that former Commissioner Turbet—who is a man with a long Labor tradition and who believed in the principles of centralised wage fixing—had written his letter in very plain English. The strength of the letter is expressed in a paragraph that I previously quoted where he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, actions by you—
that is, Senator Cook—

and your Government have damaged the public's perception of the independence and integrity of the AIRC. I acknowledge that this is difficult to prove and is denied by Government. However, as a person who lives and works in the industrial community I know it to be a fact. It does not happen overnight and it is not caused by one event or one statement. As a Government and as the responsible Minister you could at least be seen as standing by the Commission, showing support for the principles of conciliation and arbitration.

There are many points in this exchange of letters which highlight the fact that indeed the Government has, by its own actions, undermined the standing and integrity of the AIRC, unlike the Opposition's position. We are opposed to centralised wage fixing systems and want to see a freeing up of the labour market. We are not being hypocritical. We state our case and we state it plainly.

PARA.TAB: The point that my colleague Senator Crane was making that Senator Cook ought to resign as a Minister was borne out not only by this exchange of letters but also by his behaviour in this Parliament. He has simply given an untruthful account of what happened in the Robe River matter and again he gave untruthful information to the Senate concerning APPM. Perhaps the worst offence is that he really did defame Senator Panizza and, at every opportunity he has been given, he has failed to apologise to him. I find that discourtesy from a Minister to a senator in this chamber quite unconscionable.

During Question Time, when the Minister rose to speak in answer to a dorothy dix question, we tried to get him to admit on television that he was in fact a member of the BWIU and had been an official of it. It took him two hours to admit verbally in the Senate that he is in fact a member of the BWIU. That was only after Senator Crane had gone and obtained the documentation which showed that Senator Cook had shown in writing that he was a member of the BWIU and had disclosed it, as he is required to do as a Minister, and that it was a position which could cause a conflict of interest situation. The Minister went on to defend the BWIU. He is clearly in a position where he has a conflict of interest on this matter, but it took him two hours to admit it in this Parliament. In supporting my colleague Senator Crane's motion, there is ample evidence and the motion should be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —That there is a fundamental difference between this Labor Government and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is now beyond doubt. That is why I also, along with Senator Bishop, support the motion moved a couple of weeks ago by my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Crane, which calls on the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) to resign because of the circumstances surrounding the resignation of Commissioner Turbet from the Industrial Relations Commission, in particular, the statements in the form of a letter which Commissioner Turbet made in advising the Government of his resignation.

PARA.TAB: On the one hand, we have this Government reining in the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission while, on the other, we have the senior officers of the Commission, such as Commissioner Turbet, jumping ship. The resignation of Commissioner Ken Turbet from the Industrial Relations Commission on 14 April and the reasons behind it are further evidence—if any evidence was needed—of the subservience of the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Commissioner Turbet is the third longest serving member of the Commission. He has been a dedicated supporter of the trade union movement for 30 years and a member of the Industrial Relations Commission for 14 years. The circumstances leading up to his resignation have been brewing for some time.

Despite claims to the contrary, the Government has been moving to emasculate the Industrial Relations Commission. For example, when the Commission rejected the national wage case decision in April last year, the ACTU and the Government—many would say that they are one and the same—circumvented the Industrial Relations Commission and made their own deal which the Industrial Relations Commission was eventually forced to ratify. It is this sort of shady deal between the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his mate Bill Kelty which has prompted Commissioner Turbet's resignation.

Furthermore, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, has been completely left out in the cold as far as this deal making is concerned. While he mouths platitudes about the impartiality and independence of the Industrial Relations Commission, he is absolutely unable to prevent it being undermined by the accord.

Commissioner Turbet's letter of resignation to the Minister is a damning indictment indeed of this Government's conduct of industrial relations. The letter reveals the depths of the Commissioner's disillusionment with and loss of respect for a government which he has long supported, and I emphasise that he has been a long-time supporter of the Labor Party and of this Government.

The Commissioner cites three reasons for his resignation. Firstly, he says that the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word. In support of this he cites the fact that, despite the Government's declared acceptance of the independence of the Remuneration Tribunal and acceptance that its determination should only be disallowed in exceptional circumstances, it rejected the Tribunal's decision on pay levels for Industrial Relations Commission members.This Government has a history of interfering in the Remuneration Tribunal's decisions where the Industrial Relations Commission is concerned. It started in 1987, when the Government proposed to the Tribunal that commissioners get only 65 per cent of a deputy president's salary instead of the 70 per cent they were already getting.

At other times, the Government has proposed breaking the salary nexus between a Federal Court judge and a deputy president of the Commission, overruling the Tribunal in the process. In May 1990, the Government created a furore when it revoked the Tribunal's recommendations on pay levels for the Industrial Relations Commission. It created the Gleeson Committee of review to review the administrative classifications and salaries within the Industrial Relations Commission. The Government stated that it concurred with the Gleeson Committee's recommendation that the Government should accept Tribunal recommendations. However, it was the Government's recent about-face when it rejected the Tribunal's latest recommendation for pay increases for Commission members that has so disenchanted Commissioner Turbet.

The second reason for Commissioner Turbet's resignation is the damage the Government has caused to the public perception of the Industrial Relations Commission's independence and integrity. The appointment of individuals to the Commission has come under increasing criticism. Commissioner Turbet said that the Commission no longer represents a fair cross-section of the industrial community and is becoming top heavy which ACTU appointees. He accused the Minister of failing to support the Industrial Relations Commission and of being actively critical of it. Finally, the Commissioner accused this Government of a lack of respect for the constitutional obligations of the Commission and its high-handed disregard for the Industrial Relations Commission's authority.

That a man of Commissioner Turbet's standing makes such accusations, and takes such a dramatic stand and extraordinary step as resigning his commission, is a damning indictment of the Government and, in particular, of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. It is quite unacceptable that the Minister should allow himself to be manipulated by the Keating-Kelty accord system. That he should stand by while the body which he claims is central to the industrial relations and wage fixing system in this country is pushed around at the whim of the ACTU is absolutely disgraceful.
The Minister said nothing when Kelty vilified the Commission. He did not demur when the Prime Minister, formerly the Treasurer, declared:

SPEECH.PARA: The accord is the primary national income determining institution.

The accord—the deal between this Government and the ACTU—not the determinations of the Industrial Relations Commission. Yet, at the same time, Minister Cook is making a lot of noise about the need to move to what he calls `enterprise bargaining' although his subverted definition of `enterprise bargaining' and `enterprise agreements' means that they are really nothing of the sort because they remain under the control of the ACTU. If any proof of this was needed, one need look no further than the Government's current proposal to bring independent contractors under the control of the union movement. The result of this piece of disgraceful manipulation will be to saddle the housing industry with all the corruption, rorts and exploitation which is so rife in the commercial building sector.

PARA.TAB: The report of the Gyles Royal Commission into the building industry in New South Wales, released a couple of days ago, paints a graphic picture of what happens when powerful unions—and unscrupulous employers, in this case—are allowed to operate unchecked. Of course, anecdotal evidence indicates that New South Wales is not the only State in which this situation occurs in the commercial building sector. Undoubtedly, it occurs in my own State of South Australia as well.

The Government cannot have it both ways. Either it should have an Industrial Relations Commission that is allowed to do the job it is designed to do without ACTU and government interference, or it should scrap it altogether and move towards total deregulation of the labour market as the Liberal and National parties propose to do.If true and genuine enterprise agreements were in place, the appalling situation that has been evidenced in the building industry in New South Wales and other States would simply not have developed and continued to exist.

The power of big unions like the Building Workers Industrial Union would be broken if compulsory unionism were abolished. There would be no need to deregister the Building Workers Industrial Union, as Commissioner Gyles recommended—or any other union for that matter—because they simply would not have the all-encompassing power which they are now given by the fact that they enjoy effective compulsory unionism.The ACTU is trying to do the impossible; it is trying to retain a centralised system while, at the same time, graft on us a sort of semi-deregulated system. Of course, as far as the ACTU is concerned, deregulation only applies where there are benefits to be gained over and above the award system.

What we have now is the worst of all worlds; we have neither fish nor fowl—an industrial relations commission with no power and no credibility, and an industrial relations system that is supposed to be moving towards deregulation but which, in reality, is coming under tighter control by the Kelty-Keating axis and its shabby deals. The Government has destroyed any shred of credibility which the Industrial Relations Commission may have had. As it is at present, the Industrial Relations Commission is just a useful tool for ACTU manipulations. The Government's plan to restructure the Industrial Relations Commission and curb Commission salary rises will destroy what is left of its independence. It is no wonder that the morale of Commission members is so low that they are now deserting this sinking ship.

The Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry has expressed grave concerns about what is happening to the Industrial Relations Commission. As well he might. Despite the Minister's claims that the Government wants to free up the system of industrial relations, it is in fact moving to tighten up the system.

The amalgamation of unions into mega-unions was a major step down that path and now the Government's aim of bringing independent contractors under the control of unions is just another. The failure of the Minister to protect the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission is a failure to respect the requirements of the Constitution. It is wrong for the Minister to claim that the Government recognises that the Commission has a central role `in ensuring equity and fairness in workplace agreements' when the Government is seeking to curtail that role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair to who?

—Fair only in terms of maintaining the power of the unions. That is the whole purpose of this Government's policy. That the Minister's lack of ability to take any preventive action has resulted in the gradual demoralisation and disintegration of the Industrial Relations Commission is beyond doubt. In reality, the bottom line of this Government's policy with regard to industrial relations is far more sinister than that. Undoubtedly, the stench of death now envelops this Keating Labor Government. It knows that its days are numbered. That is evident every day in this Parliament as the day of the next election draws closer.Therefore, it is now the aim of this Government to entrench union power as deeply as possible before it is thrown from office by the Australian people. Thereby, it will attempt to make life as tough as possible for the incoming Liberal and National Party Government to initiate the much needed reforms in industrial relations which all Australians are so desperately crying out for.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I assure the Senate and the Australian people that, no matter how difficult this present Government seeks to make things for the incoming Hewson Liberal-National Party Government by entrenching union power through the creation of mega-unions and the sort of legislation which it has foreshadowed is coming into this Parliament, a Hewson Liberal-National Party government will not be deterred from making the hard decisions and making the necessary changes to our industrial relations structure which, as I said, Australians are desperately crying out for. It is on that basis that the motion which my colleague has put to the Senate is of prime importance. It is for that reason, among the others that I put to the Senate in this debate, that the Minister for Industrial Relations ought to resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I have not followed the full debate. I am not sure whether Senator Cook is coming in to contribute to it. I can comment only on what I have heard this afternoon. What a nasty little piece of work that was by Senator Bishop on the BWIU and Senator Cook's membership thereof. She said that Senator Cook had concealed for two hours the fact that he is a member of the BWIU. When Senator Cook was asked, not at Question Time but only by way of interjection, he had with him the pecuniary interest form—I know because I sit next to him at this desk—which he was going to produce to show that he was a member of the BWIU.
—Why didn't he?
—Why didn't he do it beforehand?

—I say to the interjectors that it is on the public record. It has consistently been on the public record since he became a Minister. If Senator Crane is trying to tell me that those on his side do not read our forms every year—I know that some of them do—
—I always read yours for sure.
—What is the most notable thing about my forms?
—I'll tell you.
—We will find out on 14 June what is the most noticeable declaration on my form.
—You have got no assets.
—That is true; I do not have many assets. I do not seek to have employment at the same time as I am a member of Parliament. What about Senator Chapman?
—I have.
—Yes. We will not go into that.
—What do you do? Get rid of your business?

—I am not suggesting anything. There is no virtue in poverty. I am not advocating that at all. The point I am making is that in 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991 and also in 1992 although it is not yet published, Senator Cook has put on his pecuniary interest form that he is a member of the BWIU. So much for the accusation from Senator Robespierre—sorry, Senator Bishop—that Senator Cook had at Question Time today tried to conceal his membership of the BWIU. This is taking witch-hunting and paranoia—
—He certainly didn't rush forward to admit it.
—When it is on the public record and it is known to everyone, one does not have to respond to every moronic interjection that comes from those opposite.
—He didn't mind accusing me about the shares in the Moora pulp mill.

—If you want to say, Senator Panizza, that Senator Cook is a member of the BWIU and there is a conflict of interest with his handling of legislation, there is the door. If you are game and if you want to pursue it, take the 20 steps to courage.
—Yes, he wouldn't do it with me though.
—You advocate that he should, Senator.
—He wouldn't do it with me. I asked him a question and he walked out like a cowed dog.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Robust debate is helpful to this chamber but it is not helpful if it is across the chamber. It would be helpful if both sides understood that the debate should go through the Chair. It would give the speaker who has the floor, in this case the Minister, a better chance and, I suggest, everyone else a better chance as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, with regard to those who, in a loudmouth way, have said that there is a conflict of interest and that Senator Cook is not pursuing his duty properly because he is a member of the BWIU and a member of the Cabinet as Industrial Relations Minister, I will know about their sincerity and I will know that they are true believers when they walk outside this chamber and say it.
—Like Senator Cook did.
—Senator Knowles is saying that he should.
—Why didn't he have the courage to do exactly what you're advocating?

—Senator Knowles can ask him that. I am asking those opposite. They are the ones who want to make these comments, but when it comes to facing the barrier that they ask Senator Cook to pass on some comments he has made, they are missing absolutely.
—I have accused him of nothing. He accused me.

—I have said that the implication today is that Senator Cook has a conflict of interest. If those opposite are true believers in that, they will just march the 25 steps out the door, put their statement out and have it resolved in a court. Until they are willing to do that I am saying that that particular section is completely off limits.

PARA.TAB: The royal commission inquiry into the building industry has been introduced into the debate. It must have been with great prescience that speakers brought all this substance in—Senator Crane did not when he first spoke. There are a couple of things the Opposition should remember about that. The Federal Government has taken action to reform the building industry several times. Unlike the Opposition, when we had to we took on the BLF and we beat it. We deregistered it in two States and one Territory where it was most malignant. Those opposite always talked about it through the Fraser years—they had inquiries, they were tough—but when it came to the crunch, down the drain they went. We have requested that the two conservative governments at the State level participate in these Federal reforms. The answer: they do not want to cooperate. Why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it entrenches their power further.

—I see. What is Mr Greiner going to do? He has been in government now for over four years. The worst rorts of all are in the New South Wales building industry. What has he done? He has done absolutely nothing with regard to that. What I have been talking about—my colleague Senator Cook is here; he will probably be interested—is nothing to do with this motion. I am merely responding to the various red herrings that have been dragged across the Senate in this afternoon's debate.
—They are all symptomatic of the same issue.
—The Barry MacKenzie of the Senate bleats on. The only real issue for debate here is the Industrial Relations Commission and Commissioner Turbet. The speakers over here—
—That is not correct.
—What else is up for grabs, Senator Crane?
—I raised the issue of—
—I mean in your motion.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister calls on us to justify our points of order. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to ask the Minister to direct his comments through the Chair—which he is not doing. You have asked him to do so. I ask you to ask him to direct his comments through the Chair.

—Order! There is no point of order. All parties in the chamber have been asked to direct their remarks through the Chair. It is not behoven on the person who has the floor to do that any more than it is the people on my left. If people on my left keep interjecting and inviting response from the speaker on my right, they will get it and they will not be entitled to complain about it.

—I think my colleagues opposite are really trying to assist me. They know that I am having a little yarn while my colleague looks at the motion before the Senate. I thank my colleagues opposite for their great help in enabling me to extend what is a pretty poor speech. I have been speaking for seven minutes already and, given those circumstances, I might cede the floor to my colleague Senator Cook, and then Senator Crane can sum up the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the terms of this motion in front of me, but I understand that—
—Good idea.
—If I am wrong about this, can those opposite please tell me and I will go back and try to have my dinner. I understand that it is a motion which calls upon me to, among other things, resign.
—Got it in one.

—Can I confirm that that is what those opposite are asking me to do? If that is what they are asking me to do, I can tell them that I am not going to and under the circumstances of this issue, I never would.

PARA.TAB: Senator Winston Crane is developing into a little carping critic of this Government's industrial relations policies. He comes out of the stable of the National Farmers Federation and the National Farmers Federation is well known as an organisation which has particular views about industrial relations in this country. It is entitled to those views and I respect it for holding its views but I have to say that just about everyone else in industrial relations does not share them. The National Farmers Federation is one of those groups which is virtually on its own with its extreme right wing, ideologically driven version of how industrial relations should be conducted.

Senator Crane reflects that and espouses that viewpoint—good luck to Senator Crane, he should keep it up. That does not mean that the Government should, in any way, pay any attention to it. After all, it is mostly the ravings of the lunatic fringe in this country and I do not intend to bow to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's the lunatic fringe?

—The views of the H. R. Nicholls Society, the extreme right wing. The ideological view which is propounded out of that quarter, is, in my opinion, the view of the lunatic fringe in the industrial relations debate in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Let us identify one example: APPM, Burnie, Tasmania; date, now. What has happened? This is a company which unilaterally removed the over award payments, which sacked workers because they would not allow the boilers that they were authorised to attend to be made safe. APPM has conducted a campaign of bypassing its representatives in the pretence that it wants to talk to workers, but only in the expectation of telling them and not listening to what those workers have to say.

On the one hand, we have the spectacle of this company being supported by Dr Hewson and John Howard and, on the other hand, being opposed by Premier Ray Groom, the Liberal Premier of Tasmania. Premier Groom supports the role of the ACTU in this dispute; he supports the people of Burnie; he has asked the company to come to the bargaining table and negotiate. Fortunately, it seems that in recent days the company has done that, after holding out and creating an extended dispute. We have a company subject to structural adjustment, because of changes in the broader economy and in protection, pulling on a full scale fight with its work force because it believes in an authoritarian command system of management.

Down the road there is another company in the same line of business—the pulp industry—Australian Newsprint Mills, which is confronted by exactly the same market and commercial problems. It got all of its workers together and said, `Look, we will have some difficulties in the future. How can we join with you and you with us to work out our problems?'. ANM has established a cooperative team approach to resolving, on behalf of the company, the same sorts of problems which confront APPM. ANM is recognised by its commercial peers as an example of international best practice in managing companies, going through restructuring to make its product globally competitive in the market place. APPM is black, ANM is white. Here we have a black and white comparison between the worst practice, APPM, and the best practice, ANM.

I am happy to plead guilty: I support the ANM approach for companies and their employees—and, where those employees want to be represented by unions, without a doubt those unions as well—looking at how that company will survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about if they don't want to be represented by unions?

—If they do not want to be represented by unions, they are usually not members of them and they usually work their issues out anyway. If Senator Chapman had any knowledge of industrial relations, he would know that for a fact.

PARA.TAB: Among the sillier remarks which I have heard about the APPM dispute was a remark by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson. He said, `But the APPM dispute is a reflection of Senator Cook's rigid centralised industrial relations system'. I heard him say that. I have to say, so is SPC. SPC is an example held up by the Opposition as its version of what should be the case. SPC exists under the Government's industrial relations system. The difference is not the system; the difference is the attitudes of the managements of the two companies. The management of APPM wants to make war with and not love to its employees; the management of SPC and ANM want to make love to and not war with their employees and produce a better product.

The system under which these two examples exist is the same system, with all the flexibilities available within it. The outcomes are not a feature of the system; the outcomes are a feature of the managements and their attitudes. I suggest that the Opposition would spend a great deal of valuable time in the interests of this nation, if it were to talk to those extreme right wing managements and suggest that they adopt the Government's policy of a cooperative approach to industrial relations, not a conflict approach.

This motion refers to the resignation of Commissioner Turbet from the Industrial Relations Commission—a resignation which was anticipated for some time—and the circumstances under which Mr Turbet has said that he is resigning. I understand the circumstances about Commissioner Turbet; I have answered questions in this place on previous occasions. I welcome to the floor of the Senate Senator Graham Richardson, who sat in this seat next to me for much of that time. He is an honourable senator, indeed, and a much maligned one by the Opposition in recent times.

I will come back to the issue. The issue is this: this Government supports the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as an independent arbiter to prevent and settle industrial disputes. The Government has this view of the Commission. From time to time, we may disagree with its decisions but, by God, we will fight to the death for its right to exist and make those decisions. That is the Government's position with respect to the Industrial Relations Commission.

Let me contrast it—and the blatant hypocrisy of this motion—with the view of the Opposition. The Opposition wants to abolish the Industrial Relations Commission. It should not come here as a wolf in sheep's clothing pretending that it is a defender of the faith, that it supports the Commission. The Opposition wants to abolish it. That has been said often enough by the Opposition spokesperson for industrial relations. Some members of the Opposition do not have the guts, like Dr Hewson, to say it frankly and openly. He said it when he was in Auckland talking to New Zealand businessmen, but, nonetheless, he was in tune with Australia and the Australian ear was listening to what he said. That is what Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Liberal Party and entitled to be believed, says he wants to do.

Back here, John Howard—a smarter politician, I think, and less ideologically rigid than Dr Hewson—says, `No, you have misunderstood. We do not want to do that; we want to provide a right of employees to choose'. That is what he says. Let us investigate for a minute what Mr Howard is saying because this will be instructive. He reckons he wants a right for employees to choose. He then says that employees will have a right to opt in or opt out of the Commission but that they will all be out to begin with. The only way they can opt in is if their employer agrees to let them. So the only way their grievances can be brought before the umpire for settlement is if the aggrieved party, the worker, has the consent of the employer to bring them there. He says that this supports the system and that this is free choice. Where there is a veto in access to the umpire by one party or the other, there is no free choice. These are just public relations words. When one looks at the content of those words one will see that they are vacuous and empty in the extreme.

Senator Winston Crane should not come in here and pretend, as he often does—he is a devout believer that the Commission is part of the industrial relations club as he calls it and should be dealt with—that he is somehow a defender of it because he is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is part of the club.
—Thank you for the interjection. Let that be noted in Hansard. He has just walked right into it.
—It is part of the club, is it not?

—No, it is not. The club that exists is the anti-industrial relations club. It is made up of dry economic commentators who have not done a hand's tap of work in their lives and who are determined to tell the rest of us how to go about our daily lives. It is made up of ideological quislings like many of those in the Opposition who have this H.R. Nicholls Society version of the world at the front of their brains. By the way, where life does not conform with the theory, life is wrong and the theory remains right.

PARA.TAB: Let us deal with the Turbet resignation. I want to hear from the Opposition if it will retreat from its policy position. We support the continued existence of an independent Industrial Relations Commission in this country as a way of preventing and settling industrial disputes. The Opposition accuses us of supporting a rigid system. That is what Dr Hewson was saying when he said, `Under APPM, that is Cook's rigid version of industrial relations'. He was attacking it. We support it. The Opposition does not, but it is pretending in this motion to defend it. It is a laugh; it is a joke. There is one clear word to describe it in the English language. That word is `hypocrisy'.

Let us go to the next part of this—the so-called shady deals between the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty. Often, people who are representatives of organisations get identified and personified as the organisation. It is a matter of public record that we have an accord with the trade union movement in this country—an accord that has served this country well.

Let me go back to the recession of 1983. I do not think anyone on the Opposition side was here—Senator Reid may have been—when it occurred, but it was a recession under the Fraser Government with double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and negative economic growth. That was the recession of 1983, the Opposition's recession, with a wages blow-out as well. We came to government because of the good sense of the Australian electors in 1983. We came with an accord with the Australian trade union movement. We came with a wages policy. If one does not have a wages policy, one has not got an economic policy.

One cannot run the economy without a wages policy. What is true now was true then. The coalition does not have a wages policy other than some romantic yearnings about nineteenth century mercantilist theory operating in New Zealand. It has no wages policy that befits a modern industrial state. We had one in 1983; we have one now. It is a visionary policy and it has worked for this country. When it was setting records for Australia in comparison with other OECD countries, it was a policy that gave high employment, structural change in the economy and economic growth.

At the same time that there was rapid economic growth, a time in which the bargaining position of unions traditionally strengthens because of scarcity of labour in the labour market, the number of strikes went down. They have continued to go down. They have now gone off the bottom of the graph. The figures put out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics yesterday are the lowest for three decades in this country. That is attributable directly to the accord. There is a recession now, mainly due to international factors and to the locking out—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us hear it from the farmers. Let us hear it from cocky's corner on the other side. It is mainly due to the locking out of Australian agricultural exports from Europe and North America as a result of their export enhancement policies. Why does the Opposition not stand up for the rural sector for once and deal with the international trade implications? Through all the cockies in this place, we hear about trade unions. We never hear about the real problem of international access to markets. We never have that problem brought on as an urgency debate.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is a late forming lobby to try to justify themselves in retrospect. If those opposite are suddenly converted on the road to Damascus, that is fine, welcome to the club, because we are concerned about those access questions.

PARA.TAB: Let us go to wages policy a la 1992. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in February put down the One Nation statement—an investment in public infrastructure development to stimulate economic growth in this country and to create employment. It is a statement which is working. I know that Senator Winston Crane says it is a disaster, because he wants bad news. He wants to luxuriate in unemployment. He wants to luxuriate in all these things because he wants bad news. He thinks bad economic news will mean his Party's election. One Nation provides economic stimulus in public investment and infrastructure to generate growth in this economy, underpin the structural change that we have overseen and lead us into a more competitive international position.

As part of that, we have a wages policy. The first part of that wages policy is that the ACTU agreed to defer its application, due on 1 May this year, for a national wage increase. Why did it agree to defer it? It agreed to defer it in order to lock in the very low level of inflation that we have introduced into this economy and to lock it in as a permanent economic feature of the Australian economic landscape. It agreed to forgo its rights to make a wage application on 1 May in order to achieve that economic result. That is what one calls a wages policy.

The ACTU did this in recognition of the fact that the One Nation statement will lead to job creation. It put jobs ahead of wage increases in terms of that negotiation. We, with them, will negotiate an appropriate time to approach the Commission for a general wage rise round for Australian workers some time later this year; we will agree on the timing and amount we go to the Commission with; and we will ask for a wage increase for everyone. We will be doing that while at the same time encouraging workplace bargaining generating productivity growth in this economy.

There will be wage increases to workers between now and the next national wage case, but they will be wage increases achieved out of productivity bargaining. The national wage case will ensure that workers who do not have access to those sorts of bargains can get a wage increase as well. This Government is concerned about getting an efficient wages policy, a best wages policy, but a policy that is fair to the underdog and people who do not have access to bargaining. So it has to be best and fair. This Government is about a best and fairest industrial relations system, and that is what we are presiding over.

I am told, as I am in this motion, that somehow it is reprehensible that there should be this type of bargaining. It is not reprehensible that leaders of both sides—Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the ACTU, and Paul Keating, the Prime Minister of Australia—should actually talk to each other. It is not reprehensible that they, with their colleagues—Ministers in the case of the Prime Minister and executive members of unions in the case of the ACTU—should engage in bargaining. That is a monumental achievement for good economic management and governance of this country. It is not something that should be treated in a slovenly, shady and despicable way, as this motion does. It is something that should be admired and praised as a significant economic breakthrough.

The motion also refers to me—that I am not part of these deals and I am therefore too weak. Well, can I give Opposition senators a news bulletin. That is rhetoric. What did Mandy Rice-Davies say when she was in the witness box in the Profumo affair? When allegations were made about her character by Dr Profumo, she said, `Well, he would say that, wouldn't he'. And she was probably right. Well, Senator Winston Crane would say that, would he not? He would say this because he wants to try to make a trite little superficial political point. Be my guest. If that entertains the honourable senator, if that makes him happy, if that makes him feel as if he is achieving something in his day, maybe his life, be my guest. It is fine if he is having a go at me. I am happy to accommodate him if that keeps him off the streets and out of trouble; if it makes him happy. But I am not going to be drawn into this type of silly, trite, stupid debate.

One of the reasons that politicians in Australia are held in low esteem by the public is simply that they indulge in this sort of name calling—the sort of name calling that Senator Crane is indulging in. People out there who see the behaviour of members of parliament think, `God, what a hopeless lot!'. I do not want to be part of that. I would rather stand up for something nice in politics—about governing countries and taking responsibility for decisions and for economic outcomes. So I am not going to be drawn into the garbage that is contained in the last part of the motion. I am not going to swap anecdotes about people's characters and play the man and not the ball. I am not going to engage in all of this sort of carry-on.

Let me go to the last part of the motion. I am called upon to resign because of all of the claims that are made. I would be happy to resign if it were a crime to support a free and independent Industrial Relations Commission. I would resign if I lived in a country in which that was a crime. I would be happy to resign if it was thought that having a sensible and responsible wages policy was an economic crime. I would not want to be a Minister in a government of a country that believed that. I would not want to be a Minister in a country where name calling and trite political point scoring, not good government and good management, was thought to be what politics are about. I would be happy to resign if I lived in a country where that was thought to be the ideal. Those sorts of things have been the order of the day in some countries. These countries have mainly been described as communist or fascist. I would not want to be a Minister in any of those governments; I would be happy to resign. But I am not going to resign.

I have a modest role to play in this Government in terms of reform of the great landscape of industrial relations. I also have a role to play in respect of structural economic reform. My role is to help make Australia a world competitive nation. My role is to help change Australia from being an exporter of mineral commodities and agricultural products, from being a mine and a quarry and selling abroad raw materials at the cheapest and lowest price and buying back sophisticated manufactured replacement goods. I want to change Australia from doing that to being a manufacturing and service provider powerhouse in South East Asia and the Pacific rim. That is what I want to do.

I would resign if Senator Crane wanted me to be a manager presiding over the same old regressive economy that we inherited from his Party when it was office. I would not want to be part of that; I would not want to be part of the types of policies followed by the Opposition. I would resign if our industrial relations policy of cooperation, treating people as human beings, respecting the value of their labour, enhancing their skills, encouraging their flexible deployment and their ability to absorb new technology had to change to an authoritarian, `Do as I say' policy—the `Come to work every day because you are afraid that if you don't you will be sacked' approach that we heard from Herb Larratt of APPM the other day. If I had to preside over an economy where that was the ethic—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—That is true. He made the mistake of saying it in a written speech which he published. I can provide the words to the honourable senator. If that became the ruling ethic in industrial relations, the sort of ethic which the H. R. Nicholls Society supports, or that Senator Crane supports, I would resign. But I am part of a proud Government which has a good record in this field. According to the latest opinion poll published over the weekend, most Australians believe that we are streets ahead of the Opposition in managing industrial relations policy.

PARA.TAB: I cannot make my position more emphatic other than to say that I will actually take this motion and put it up on the wall so that when visitors come in I can point to it and we can all have a good laugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President—
—Are you going to speak again on this?

—Yes, I am going to round off my remarks. I hope that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) stays in the chamber while I do so. First of all, I thank the various people who have spoken in this debate, including the Minister, for their contributions.
—Don't get too generous.
—No.
—Oh, come on—give us some point.

—I shall get to the honourable senator in a moment or two. The Minister talked in glowing terms about the economic policy and management of the country by this Government. This was not part of the motion.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at two things that his Government has delivered to this country. It has delivered one million people who are unemployed. It has also delivered a debt blow-out from $23 billion to $150 billion. This country is going to pay for that for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our great grandchildren will be paying for it.

—And our great great grandchildren will be paying and the Minister knows that. This is nothing to boast about. If that is what the accord has delivered to this country, the accord is a failure. This is to say nothing about what the accord has not delivered in respect of workers and employees. We should also take into account the number of bankruptcies that the accord has delivered to this country. That number has doubled each year in the last 10 years.
—How?
—Because of a recession in the economy that is in a state of collapse.

PARA.TAB: The motion before the Senate is about hypocrisy—a word used by the Minister. It is about the hypocrisy of his stance and his position in terms of the Industrial Relations Commission. The motion is not about our position or our policy. Our policy is on the table; it is quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —It isn't on the table.
—It is. It is absolutely and totally on the table. Honourable senators opposite know our position in regard to the IRC.
—What is it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Once before this evening the chamber has been reminded that senators cannot expect the speaker to direct his remarks through the Chair if people on the other side of the chamber continually interject in a way to invite an across chamber debate. It might help the debate if you bear that in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. This motion has resulted from the resignation of Commissioner Turbet. But there is a lot more behind it than just that resignation. Earlier in the debate I quoted what President Maddern of the AIRC had to say. A press report states:

PARA.TAB: In the IRC's 1990-91 annual report, tabled in Parliament yesterday, Justice Maddern said it had been a difficult year, with commission members subject to abuse over the April National Wage Case decision.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on in his report to identify that abuse from employees and the Government. That is what this motion is about. We consistently have Minister Cook, in debate or answering questions, espousing the AIRC as the umpire. Yet when it suits him he goes out with his union mates, particularly the Secretary of the ACTU, Bill Kelty, and denigrates the AIRC.

PARA.TAB: The classic example we have of this is the April 1991 national wage case, and I made a number of points about that. It was not only Senator Cook who abused the AIRC; it was also the then Treasurer, now the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. One of the answers is worth noting—I will not quote them all. When Mr Keating was asked whether he would not have preferred enterprise bargaining under the umbrella of the AIRC, his answer was no. We look at what Minister Willis had to say at the same time. He gave a similar answer to a similar question.

It is hypocritical of people on the Government side to get up here and espouse the virtues of the AIRC but, when it does not jump and bring down the decisions the Government or the Minister want, to go out and fight the AIRC in the public arena. That is the position of the Government. That is what this motion is about. It is not about our policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —When has the Minister done that?
—The Minister has done it consistently in this place, and I quoted him here. If Senator Sherry goes back and reads Hansard he will see it.
—He is entitled to have a view.

—He cannot have it both ways. He cannot say that the AIRC is the umpire, the adjudicator, and then go out in the public arena and adopt a different position—and adopt a different position in this place.

PARA.TAB: I come now to some of the points that were made by Senator Sherry, and I want to relate them to what Senator Cook had to say. Senator Cook referred to my being a spokesman for the NFF and one or two other things, which is absolute nonsense. I want particularly to relate my comments to the New Zealand situation, which was raised consistently by Senator Sherry and by Minister Cook. Let us look at the figures put out just last week by the statistician in New Zealand. It is interesting to note that in the last quarter the number of people employed increased from 1,435,800 to 1,452,800. The participation rate went up to 63.7 per cent from 63.2.

The Government has consistently talked in this chamber about how the workers in New Zealand have been screwed into the ground. Yet we find that real disposable income has increased by 1.2 per cent. If we look a little further, we find that productivity in New Zealand has gone up by between 50 and 90 per cent in a number of operations that have been publicised loud and clear in this country. Provisional work stoppage statistics in New Zealand for October 1991 showed no stoppages recorded. This is the first time that no stoppages had been recorded for a month since the Department of Statistics began publishing monthly work stoppage figures in June 1978.

Senator Sherry will continue to rabbit on because he does not like to hear that the New Zealand situation is working. New Zealand has a current account surplus for the first time in many years. If we look a little further—the Minister introduced this matter into the debate and tried to denigrate the position—we find that for full time wage and salary earners incomes increased by 1.2 per cent between the September and December 1991 quarters. The spending power of the combined total income of households increased by 1.1 per cent. Wage and salary rates paid in all sections of the economy increased on average by 1.5 per cent during 1991.

When one analyses these figures and compares them with the things that have been put before us, we find that not only is the New Zealand work force better off under the changed system but the economy is also better off. New Zealand did not have a current account deficit in the last month. It would be a delightful thing for Australia if we could turn our position around, if we had the courage to take the steps that are required in industrial relations reform and economic reform to bring about similar changes in Australia. It is interesting that Senator Sherry has gone very quiet. The system in New Zealand, which he consistently denigrated in his response to my motion, has proved to be very successful, and it has created a new hope for New Zealanders—a hope that the one million people in this country who are unemployed have not got.

What I have said in this motion is confirmed by what Commissioner Turbet said and by what President Maddern said in his annual report, which was tabled in this place some time ago: the Government adopts one position with the AIRC when it suits it; it adopts another position when it suits it. I have another letter that is worth commenting on, written by Mr Bob Smith, the Secretary of the Federation of Industrial, Manufacturing and Engineering Employees. It begins `Dear Brother Kelty', and he complains about the fact that Commissioner Merriman criticises the Government for the problems it had. I give honourable senators one example of what Commissioner Merriman said. He said that it was most likely the fault of the current Government. What does Bob Smith do? He goes running to Dear Brother Kelty. What does Dear Brother Kelty do? He goes running to Senator Peter Cook and, in essence, says, `Stitch up this commissioner because he dared to criticise you'.

The Government cannot have it both ways. Either it supports the system and is straight and honest about it in the public arena or it does not. Our position is on the table and it is quite clear. On the one hand, the Government is trying in Question Time and in debate to fool us about its position. On the other hand, when it comes to the recommendations by the Remuneration Tribunal or in the national wage case, it adopts another position. It is a quite hypocritical stance. I commend the motion to the chamber.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Crane's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No.2) 1991-92APPROPRIATION BILL (No.3) 1991-92APPROPRIATION BILL (No.4) 1991-92SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1992-93SUPPLY BILL (No.1) 1992-93SUPPLY BILL (No.2) 1992-93

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 and the motion moved by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, for the report of Estimates B to be adopted. The Committee has also passed a resolution, namely:

PARA.TAB: That consideration of the question that the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted in respect of the Department of Finance be postponed until questions asked of Senator McMullan are answered and relevant documents are produced.

INTERJECT.PARA: When the Bill was last considered the Committee was considering program 5 of the Department of Finance. The question before the Chair is that the motion be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There is discussion going on with Senator Hill about some of the documents that people have requested to be tabled relating to commercial in confidence documents. I expect some of that matter to be resolved quickly. The most appropriate thing might be to deal with the Commonwealth task force on asset sales now. The other matter should be resolved fairly soon.
—by leave—I thank Senator McMullan for that. Do I understand Senator McMullan to be saying that we are still waiting for an answer as to whether the documents that we asked for will be provided?

—by leave—That is not actually what is before us. Just to assist the Committee, there is no problem about tabling the lease. There is no problem about tabling almost all the correspondence that relates to it. Within the correspondence there are some matters that are commercial in confidence but which do not relate to the parties to this particular lease. For example, there is a document which has details of the 13 people who have submitted expressions of interest to fulfil the contract. We do not want to release the commercial in confidence details of the other 12—including the Liberal Party. They are entitled to have their confidentiality maintained. That document is being reviewed at the moment. There are no details with regard to this contract which will be—
—Have you tried asking them?
—No. I do not intend to.
—I suggest you do.

—No, I think Senator Panizza will find that there are no relevant documents about which there is any problem. I cannot say for sure because I do not have the documents in front of me. When we get there, we will be able to table a lot of documents which I think will satisfy all of Senator Short's requirements. Let us get on with the business before us and deal with that problem when it arises.

—When we adjourned the debate earlier today, we were dealing with the task force on asset sales. I think that I had asked for the Budget estimate for expected proceeds from asset sales for 1991-92. I do not think that Senator McMullan had that information. I gave him what I thought was the figure for those asset sales. He might wish to confirm that figure.
—Senator Short is correct, as I thought at the time. The figure is $625m.

—I thank Senator McMullan for that confirmation. It was ascertained as well earlier today that there was no change to the situation as of 3 April when the matter was discussed in Estimates Committee B. At that stage there had been no proceeds of assets sales for 1991-92. I asked Senator McMullan earlier today to refresh his memory as to whether there were proposed to be any sales between now and the end of the financial year. I think, again, the answer to that was no. Unless there is any change to that situation—we did have some informal discussion as to whether the Aussat sale may have affected that situation—then would I be right in saying that there will be a shortfall this year in the Budget revenue of $625m so far as the proceeds of the sale of assets are concerned?

—I am advised that, for reasons to do with the sale of Aussat, the shortfall compared with the Budget outcome may be even more than $625m because of some negative consequences from Aussat in regard to a number of people taking over debts and things such as that.
—Do you have any idea of the magnitude of the additional shortfall?

—Apparently, there is not a figure that is publicly available, but it will be substantially more because of the Aussat impact. There is no particular news in the fact that Aussat is a negative impact. But, apparently, I am not at liberty to release the details of that.

—Obviously, it will be released sooner rather than later. If that sale is the only item that will affect the bottom line of the assets sales figure for the outturn for the year, then whatever figure above $625m is published will presumably be the Aussat component. There is no way that even this Government can avoid publishing that. So is there any reason for not giving it to us now?

—It is not as straightforward as that because the factors affecting the variation are more than simply that. Senator Short is correct in saying that the outcomes will be made public. There is no attempt to obfuscate that. I am trying to clarify where Aussat fitted into it. As I understand it, it will go from, as they say in the jargon, a negative outlay of $625m to a positive of $307m.

—I find the whole situation of the assets sales proposals of the Government for this year to be very peculiar indeed. I think that I am right in saying—I will get confirmation of it in due course from Senator McMullan—that the $625m that was estimated for the proceeds this year included expected receipts from Qantas, Australian Airlines, HLIC and, probably, ANL. I will come to that later.

PARA.TAB: The changes that have occurred in the Government's policy, particularly so far as the airlines are concerned, are changes of a nature that have fundamentally affected the situation for prospective bidders for the airlines. Those changes were made not long after much of the work, in terms of the preparation of documentation for expressions of interest by potential buyers, had been done. That smacks, not so much on the part of the task force but more on the part of the Government, of a very considerable mismanagement and bungling of the due process of these things.

There is also the fact that we still have no result, no finality, in relation to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, and I will come back to that later. I appreciate that the problem has not been caused only by this Government, but the whole process adds up to another example of very shoddy management and administration of this area of the Government's activities.

I want to confirm that the method being considered for the sale of assets from the Australian National Line, ANL, is a proposal to actually sell assets without changing the share structure or the capital structure of the National Line. In other words, the proposal is to sell assets from ANL rather than sell ANL itself; is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —Decisions as specific as that have not yet been made. My advice is that the Government announced that it was going to sell a substantial part of ANL. What is called a scoping study is being undertaken and has virtually concluded. When that report is presented, the Government will make decisions, on the basis of the consultant's report and the task force's consideration of it, about precisely when, how, how much and which part of ANL might proceed to sale. That level of detail has not yet been resolved.

—Yes, I understand that, but I also understand from the discussion we had on 3 April in Estimates Committee B that that scoping study is a study relating to the scope that exists for the sale of the assets of ANL rather than for the sale of the Line itself. Is that not correct?
—My advice is that it covers all possibilities with regard to the sale of ANL.
—Does that include the sale of the whole shareholding of ANL?
—At this stage there would have to be a change of Government policy to sell all of it. What I was trying to clarify is that we have not constrained the various range of options—
—The scope?
—Yes, the scope of the scoping study, if you like. We have not constrained the various options they might pursue to sell what the Government has described as a substantial part of ANL.

—I think we are talking about the same thing which means that there is not at this stage a proposal to sell ANL as an entity, but rather to sell parts of ANL in the form of various of its assets, which assets are still to be determined.

—No, that does not logically follow. There are various options for selling a substantial part of an organisation such as ANL and they are all being pursued. It is not limited to merely the sale of perhaps some of its assets. That may be the outcome but it is not the only option under consideration. There has been no decision to so constrain the examination at this stage.

—What is the view of the board of ANL towards the prospect of having assets—still to be determined—of ANL sold, without the board having a say in which assets are to be sold and an assessment of the value of them? How does that relate to the fiduciary responsibility and legal responsibility, under the corporations Acts, of the directors of ANL?

—It is a bit early to say that but I am assured, as Senator Short would expect, that when the Government gets to make a decision about the mechanism of any proposed sale—whether it is of assets or whether it proceeds otherwise—it will be consulting with and seeking the cooperation of the board of ANL, not least because there are some legal requirements that we do so; but Senator Short would expect us to do so even if there were not. My understanding is that it is a bit early to get into that degree of detail, because we have not decided that we are going to sell any of the assets. That is not the only option, as I have said. So that is a bit premature. We will be seeking the cooperation and agreement of the board if we can receive it.

—One would expect that there would automatically be consultation and cooperation, but that is a different point from the point that I raised which is a legal point. My point is the legal responsibility and liability of directors of any corporation, under the relevant corporations Acts and related legislation and rules, so far as their responsibility to their shareholders is concerned over the purchase and disposal of assets.

PARA.TAB: If Senator McMullan is saying that the Government will have consultation and cooperation but that in the end the directors of ANL do not have the final responsibility for the decisions that are taken, it seems to me that it puts the directors and the board of ANL in a very difficult legal position in relation to their fiduciary responsibilities and their legal responsibilities.
