If Senator McMullan does not agree with that, then where am I wrong? If Senator McMullan does agree with that, then does that not seem to be a very extraordinary way for the Government to proceed and an extraordinary situation in which the Government will be putting corporation directors?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very conscious of questions of fiduciary responsibility and responsibilities of directors. It is an issue to which we have given some emphasis and priority during the term of the Government. We are certainly conscious of it and we will be conscious of it in the manner in which we proceed with this sale. Senator Short is correct in saying that it is an important issue, and it will be treated as such.

—I will not pursue it further at this stage, given that we have the rest of the night ahead of us. I hope that the situation will be much clearer by the time of the Budget Estimates, because it is potentially a very serious matter. Without further explanation, it does seem that there is a real risk that, through the method of handling this ANL asset sale, unless the Government is disposing of the shares in the line, it is usurping from the directors of a corporation their legal and fiduciary responsibility for the control of both the purchase and disposal of the assets of that corporation. I will not pursue it further at this stage, but I put the Parliamentary Secretary on notice that it is a subject I want to pursue at considerably greater length during the Budget Estimates.

PARA.TAB: Coming back to the financial side of things, I ask whether the shortfall of $625m-plus has been included in the Treasurer's latest Budget deficit forecasts released on 11 May and showing the forecast $9.3 billion deficit for this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost all of it. I understand that there is one late adjustment item that may not have been included—I am not absolutely sure. But overwhelmingly, yes, there certainly was a consciousness of that. I do not want to say that every dot and comma was covered, because that may prove to be somewhat inaccurate, but overall, the answer is yes.
—Have there been any developments in the unfortunate saga involving the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation since we met almost two months ago?

—As Senator Short would be aware, the delay has been occasioned by a delay in the approval process by one of the State governments. One of the factors that apparently has been influencing that is that they are awaiting the outcome of the Gyles royal commission and any reference it might make to CIC, which is the successful purchaser, as the honourable senator would be aware.

PARA.TAB: I am advised from the press reports, and this has been confirmed by the officers, that the Gyles royal commission was critical of CIC's role in some matters which it examined. I am not aware of the full range or significance of those criticisms as yet, but they are being examined by the Government. The task force is looking at it and consulting with other relevant authorities to see whether that has any implications for what course of action we want to pursue from here. The royal commission is very recent, but that factor is a new factor in the equation we are examining.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I correct in recalling that, at the end of the day, CIC turned out to be the only likely purchaser of HLIC?
—No, I am advised that that is not the case.
—Is there any information available to the Parliamentary Secretary or the task force as to whether those who may have been potential buyers beforehand have any continuing interest?

—We have no reason to think they would not be interested; but, of course, we executed a contract with CIC subject to the relevant approvals. Therefore, we have not been engaged in conversation with any other potential purchasers. It would be a bit extraordinary if we had. So I cannot confirm any concrete response, but there is no reason to think people who were interested previously would not be interested now. There has been no consultation because we have concluded the process, subject to approvals.

—Again, the situation might be clearer at the time of the next Estimates. I again express some concern at the total lack of any proceeds for asset sales, despite the work that has been done by the task force and others in the past 12 months. It is quite extraordinary that a government that has been trumpeting its ability to handle its financial management can go through a whole year with a great deal of effort with not one cent to show for it at the end of the year on behalf of taxpayers on such an important item.

PARA.TAB: I shall ask a couple of questions in relation to the Government's objectives in asset sales. So far as the question of employee share ownership is concerned, the Parliamentary Secretary may recall that we had some discussion about that during the Estimates hearings in relation to Australian Airlines and Qantas. It was established that, whilst employee share schemes are an objective in the case of sales for both Australian Airlines and Qantas, it is not a requirement as such. The question I want to ask is of a more general nature than just the airline sales situation. Precisely what is the Government's policy requirement so far as employee share ownership schemes are concerned in its ongoing asset sale or privatisation or corporatisation program?

It is certainly a top priority so far as the Liberal and National parties are concerned that a privatisation program should have an appropriate and generous employee share scheme as one of its key requirements. I would have thought that a government of this Government's political persuasion would have had at least a similar policy requirement. There appears to be no such requirement. I would appreciate the Parliamentary Secretary's comments on that. If I am wrong, I would like to be directed to evidence to indicate that the Government does in fact have employee share ownership as a very important part of its overall policy objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of employee share ownership remains an important objective for the Government in all the asset sales where that is appropriate. Some of them are more literally asset sales in the conventional sense—of course, it does not arise there—but in the privatisations and related processes it remains a high priority of the Government to have such employee share ownership schemes established.

PARA.TAB: If someone wants to use stronger words and say, `We are tougher than you; we have an objective, not a priority' or whatever, we can have that debate on another occasion. It is an objective which we will pursue and on which I hope we will be successful. That is what I said last time, and there is not much more to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is going over the ground we went over in Estimates, but I think that Senator McMullan has added a different dimension. There is a considerable difference between employee share ownership schemes being an objective, as the Parliamentary Secretary said it was in Estimates Committee B, and it being a requirement. As I understand it from the Estimates discussions on 3 April, there is no guarantee that an employee share ownership scheme will be part of the sale of the shareholdings in Qantas and Australian Airlines. Indeed, it was made quite clear by Mr Heinrich at that time that that may or may not be the case. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Employee share ownership schemes are best and most easily handled in the context of a public float. That is simple. Whether we have a public float is not yet determined. We will certainly be discussing with prospective purchasers, in the context of what we are doing, the objective of the Government that employees should have shares in both airlines in due course.

Whilst an admirable objective, that answer contains nothing at all of a mandatory nature as far as employee share ownership schemes are concerned. Whilst I note what Senator McMullan said in response to me a moment ago, it does not seem to me that he has addressed the point I made and the question I asked, which is why—if I am correct—the Government does not have as a sine qua non of a privatisation process the incorporation of appropriate and, indeed, generous employee share ownership schemes, given the considerable benefits that I think he and I and most people would agree they incorporate. Is it because there has been a traditional dislike or distrust of such schemes by the trade union movement or are other reasons involved?

TALK.START.PARA: —The outcome of our respective approaches is unlikely to be very different. It is really a policy debate for another forum; it is not really an Estimates matter. I do not have anything to add.

—I thank the Minister. I do not have any more questions on that item. Indeed, I do not have any more questions on the Department of Finance as a whole. I am not sure whether my colleague has either. That leaves us with the issue that we have deferred. Have there been any further advances on that?

—I do not have all the information on that. Let us go on to the next Estimates. We will return to that when we all know what the situation is absolutely. I need to consult a little more. Let us go to Treasury and deal with that. We will come back to that area, with apologies to the officers who have been kept waiting for it. I am sure that we will be as quick as we can. The worst thing we could have is a bit of confusion about a document or something. Let us get it all clear.

—It is not only the document itself and the documents that pertain to it that I want; I also require answers to the six questions that I asked the Minister earlier. Is he working on those as well as annexures A and B to the document that he tabled earlier in the day? Is that right?

—That is a matter we can deal with when we get to that item. I do not have all that immediately at the front of my mind. I am trying to put together a comprehensive lot of documents. I think they cover everything that everybody was seeking. I do not know whether they answer every dot and comma—I may have missed something—but it is a pretty big and comprehensive list. But let us not get into a debate about that. Let us get some things passed. We can deal with that when we actually get to it and when I have all the bits of paper and I can reassure people or find out what the situation is.

—If that was meant to be a sort of reassurance that everything was in hand, I will take it with a grain of salt. As long as the matter is deferred, we can deal with the debate subsequently and see whether Senator McMullan satisfies the requirements.

—Is it the wish of the Committee that we move to the Department of the Treasury? There being no objection, it is so ordered. We will again go by the running sheet. It seems to me that we can do as we have done previously and take the questions on notice section in relation to the various program headings. I move to program 1, which is `Economic Policy'. Is there any matter there? I notice that there is something in the report on page 7 and a reservation from Senator Bishop and Senator Short on page 13.

—I am sure that my colleague Senator Short will have something to say on this as well. When we were dealing with the Department of Finance, we talked about the model that was specially built by Treasury to test the Fightback package and the use that Finance made of that model. I asked very specific questions about whether the model that was used by Finance was in fact exactly the same for Fightback and for the One Nation statement. The answer we got was very simply that Senator McMullan did not know and neither did the officers from Finance, and that, provided we had the officers from Treasury here who actually wrote the software for the model, we would be able to ask them whether it was exactly the same for the Fightback package and for the One Nation statement. We could then go on to explore how Treasury treated the two policies and the model.

—In every such process there is always a continual revision of parameter changes as new data becomes available. I am assured that, if there were any very minor changes, they would have been of no significance in the outcome. All such matters are constantly under revision because new information becomes available about various factors that are fed into the equation. But, as I understand it, there are no significant or major changes. It was essentially the same.

—The answer to my question is that the model for testing was not exactly the same for both packages. The question as to whether the modification was great, minor, significant or insignificant is a value judgment. The only people who can make that value judgment are the people who are in possession of all the facts and are knowledgeable about it. Is the adviser or advisers in the box the person or people who wrote the software for the model that was used? Yes or no.
—I imagine that no one person did it. The answer is no. I do not see any reason why there should be. I have nothing to add.

—I am very pleased to hear what the Parliamentary Secretary imagines. All I want to know is whether the two people sitting in the advisers box are the people who wrote the software. The Parliamentary Secretary has told me that he imagines they are not. Did he actually ask them?
—I did not say I imagined they are not, I said no.

—That is quite refreshing; we got a simple answer to a simple question. How did Treasury use the model in treating, first, the Fightback package and, secondly, the One Nation statement? When we were in the Estimates hearings I recall correctly that the Parliamentary Secretary refused to let the officers answer as to whether or not they had run the One Nation statement through the Treasury model. Could the Parliamentary Secretary now confirm whether or not Treasury ran the One Nation statement through the model?

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the Department of the Treasury, program 1, Economic Policy.

—On 5 May this year at 11.44 p.m. I drew attention to the abnormal sitting of the chamber until 3.40 a.m. that day and the very serious physical and psychological effects that can result from such behaviour. Tonight I understand the likelihood is that we will sit once again until the early hours of tomorrow morning.

PARA.TAB: The response to my speech on 5 May was quite extraordinary. A large number of people working within the environment of Parliament House contacted me. I speak now not on behalf of honourable senators, because I think they are almost beyond redemption, but on behalf of the Public Service—the clerks of the Senate and the House of Representatives, the attendants, the Library, the Sound and Vision Office, the transport officers, the security people, the press gallery, the honourable senators and honourable members themselves and last but not least, and even more importantly, the spouses and families of all those detained in this enormous sheltered workshop which we call Parliament House.

It must be fairly obvious that the management of business in this chamber is in a shambles, otherwise we would not be in this extraordinary predicament. There is no excuse for the behaviour of the last few days of the sitting of this week.

Has anyone considered the other issues apart from health? For instance, I am told that the Comcar drivers are sitting outside in the cold. I am told that it costs $2,000 an hour for us to have those drivers out there. It is time for action. A precedent has been set in the last couple of days; that is, the passive smoking precedent and the effect that that has on people in a working environment. I am willing to give testimony in a court of law for any public servant working within this building. I would support any stress effect that working in this environment might have on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about senators? Should we get compensation as well?

—Yes, and senators and members. I am sure that I would be supported by Dr Tony Adams, the Chief Medical Adviser to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I think the time has come. It will be tested only in a court of law. I am saying publicly tonight that I am prepared, with my background in medicine, to give support to anybody who wishes to take a case in that regard if they can prove their involvement in this bizarre behaviour. Even Senator Patterson may need my help. Those who have been here longer than I have obviously have been affected by this environment and do not consider it to be abnormal. I am still in the happy state where I can perceive that it is abnormal.

—Order! I am not quite sure what that had to do with the Estimates of the Department of the Treasury. We are on program 1—`Economic policy'. Senator Bishop was cut off in her prime a little while ago.

—I will restore the prime. We have established that the officers who are advising Senator McMullan tonight are not the officers who wrote the software for the Treasury model which was built specifically, at some quarter of a million dollars, I think the figure was, to test the Fightback package. Was the One Nation package put through the model which Treasury built especially to test the Fightback package?

—I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has indicated on a previous occasion that there was not a distributional analysis done of the One Nation statement. It was not the same sort of package. The analysis was done on the areas for which it was relevant; that is, the price effect of the changes of the wholesale sales tax. I understand that the Prime Minister has stated that. Who am I to add to what he had to say?

—So the answer to my question again is no, it was not run through the same model. When Senator McMullan talks about distributional analysis, I suppose he is talking about the impact it has on ordinary Australian taxpayers. Of course, the One Nation statement does have an effect on ordinary Australian taxpayers. The fact that the Budget has blown out and the figures do not add up means that the things which were promised in that package will not be possible. Is Senator McMullan asserting that the One Nation package somehow did not affect the disposable income of ordinary Australian taxpayers?
—I do not have anything to add.

—I noticed that Senator McMullan did not even attempt to consult his advisers. Obviously, the Government treats the Fightback package in one way and the One Nation package in another way. The other thing which was important was the assumptions used with regard to inflation rates. This point was very strenuously canvassed by my colleague Senator Short. I believe that he wishes to intervene at this point.

—Senator Bishop and I, in a reservation to the report of Estimates Committee B, pointed out, as we did strongly in the Estimates Committee hearing, the absurdity and lack of impartiality and objectivity in the modelling. A quite different inflation rate was used to run through the modelling of the coalition's Fightback figures to that which was evident in the Fightback documents. As a result, the Government reached an absurd result on the impact on revenue and real wages. The modelling which was done and the inflation rate which was assumed led to the absurd result that the Fightback proposals were aiming for a fall in real wages of 3 per cent to 4 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator McMullan—as I did during the Estimates Committee B hearings, but I did not receive a satisfactory answer at that stage; perhaps the Department has had a chance to look at it since then—why that absurdity was used with respect to the assumptions. Why was it that such a blatantly unprofessional result was obtained? Why was it that only one side of the ledger was looked at with respect to the implications of the inflation rates which were used? Why did the Government not take account of the impact on the revenue as well as the impact on the expenditure and, therefore, the impact on the ability and size on the tax cuts which the coalition's proposals automatically envisaged? Why was it that such a lack of professional approach could have occurred?

TALK.START.PARA: —We had a very lengthy debate on this during the hearing of Estimates Committee B. I do not have anything to add to what I said then. I reiterate what was said at that time. The Treasury, in analysing the Fightback package, used the scenario C assumption which was in the supplementary paper No. 1. At that time, scenario C was being trumpeted around the place as the likely jobs outcome of the Fightback package. I assume that the Department was entitled to conclude that that was the basis on which it should draw. I understand that that was the only figure it could find in Fightback.
—That is not true.
—I am quoting what the officer said; I am only repeating it.
—The officer got it wrong; so don't repeat a falsehood.

—It is all right for Senator Kemp to get excited, but he cannot claim that one scenario will have a wonderful jobs option and then get upset when somebody takes him at his word. I do not have anything to add beyond that. It is too late at night—Senator Herron's argument was sufficiently persuasive on that point—to merely repeat a lengthy discussion which we had on 3 April. I have nothing to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Kemp has pointed out, the statement Senator McMullan has just made is absolutely wrong, as was the statement which was made by the Treasury officers during the hearing of Estimates Committee B. It is quite clear and it is stated categorically in the Fightback document that there was a longer term price level increase of zero to 2 per cent in the coalition's proposals. Despite that, the Treasury chose to ignore it and assumed an inflation rate of 6 per cent to 7 per cent in its modelling. Of course, that led to a very distorted result and one which was absolutely unfair and discriminatory in the presentation that resulted by the Treasury of the Fightback package's proposal.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, we will not be able to pursue that any further than we have tonight and during the Estimates Committee hearing. As Senator McMullan said, time is getting on. I repeat that it is a matter of grave concern that all the evidence in relation to this exercise pointed to, as we said in our reservation to the Estimates Committee B report:

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned that the Treasury analysis is not even-handed and impartial, and is seen as favouring the Government. We—
that is the coalition members of that Committee—
express our strong concern at the evidence of political interference displayed by the Minister and his staff in the production of Treasury's published response to the Opposition's policies.

Let me ask another question in relation to the Treasury's distributional analysis of the Fightback package. Is Senator McMullan aware of the submission by the Minister for Social Security dealing with the Treasury distributional analysis of the Fightback package? It was a submission prepared in February 1992 and it commented on the Treasury's methodological approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Chairman.
—Perhaps I should inform Senator McMullan that that document, which has been released by the Opposition, had in its recommendations, referring to the Minister for Social Security:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Minister note that:
The Treasury papers—

that is, those papers showing the main results of the Treasury distributional analysis of the Fightback package. Of course it was the Treasury distributional analysis that was the main basis for the Treasury's attack on the Fightback package. The recommendation from the ministerial submission by the Department of Social Security's modellers and policy officers of the Department of Social Security states:
That the Minister note:
The Treasury papers show pensioners and allowees to gain from the Fightback Package for all combinations of measures modelled.

The proportions of wage and salary earner losing households range from none to ninety one per cent depending on the measures modelled. The most comprehensive analysis shows 61% of all households in losing groups.

The Treasury papers are strongly critical of the expenditure data in the ABS Household Expenditure Survey because it does not match Consumer Price Index weighting patterns and because far too many households surveyed appear to spend more than their income.
It goes on:
DSS does not agree that the HES data cannot be made useful for the comparison of expenditure and incomes and Treasury have not pursued DSS oral suggestions on ways of adjusting the expenditure data.
I will not quote the document in full, but I seek leave to table that document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a public document?
—It is now a public document. It has been for some time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows that the Treasury papers indicated that pensioners and allowees gain from the Fightback package for all combinations of measures modelled. It also says that the reason for this gain by pensioners and allowees is in large part the 8 per cent increase in payments to pensioners and the 6 per cent increase in payments to other Department of Social Security clients, as well as the well-designed GST tax credits proposed by the Opposition. The Department of Social Security also went on to say in its criticism of the Treasury analysis that it was done in such a way as to allow the Department to portray Fightback in the worst possible light. As the Department of Social Security said:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of groups estimated to lose in the most inclusive analysis is unreasonably high.
The Department of Social Security also said that the Treasury had not pursued DSS oral suggestions on how it could improve its methodology, despite DSS's specialised knowledge in this area.

PARA.TAB: In short, the ministerial submission of the DSS demonstrated the very high political nature of the Treasury analysis. At the same time, it re-emphasised that no Social Security client groups would be worse off under Fightback and, in fact, that all would be net winners. That information was supplied several months ago. It was brought to the attention of the electorate by my colleague Senator Alston some time ago. I have heard no response at all on that from the Treasury or from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope they put that in their pamphlets. Do you think that will go in their pamphlets, Senator Short?

—As my friend and colleague Senator Patterson says, we wait with great interest to see that put into the Government's pamphlets, instead of the straight lies that the Labor Party's pamphlets now show. Accusing the Opposition of increasing prices by 15 per cent because of a GST of 15 per cent without taking any account of the offsets from the other tax reductions is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: I hope that Senator McMullan, who is a reasonable man and who, I think, is one of the more honourable members on his side of politics, may have the good grace—I am not holding my breath on it—to get up and apologise on behalf of the Government for the absolute distortion that the Government deliberately has portrayed in relation to the Fightback package and at least acknowledge that the methodology used by the Treasury was very faulty. It was criticised very strongly by the expert department, namely, the Department of Social Security, in terms of the distributional analysis. Not one part of that, not one whit of it, has the Government seen fit to get up and acknowledge publicly. I ask Senator McMullan to take this opportunity to set the record at least partly straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know anything about the document to which Senator Short refers. It is not going to do anybody any good for me to start speculating about it. I do want to counsel a bit of caution in this seeming contagion about assuming the unprofessional response of officers. Dr Preston made, I thought, an eloquent response to that. I do not want to reiterate it at all but, for anybody who might have the misfortune to have to read all this, at page 271 of Estimates Committee B Hansard Dr Preston responded to the attack on the professionalism of the Treasury in an effective way which it would only waste the time of the Senate for me to reiterate. I want to say only one more thing about the accuracy of analyses. I put on the record that one part of the reservation is wrong, as I am advised. The reservation at page 13 says:

SPEECH.PARA: For example, it—
that is the Treasury—
did not model the impact of major reductions in business taxes which are central elements of the Fightback! package.

I am advised that the business tax cuts are reflected in the distributional analysis model. The only ones that are not are the tariff cuts because apparently there was a modelling difficulty. All the others, I am advised, are in the distributional analysis model and the reservation is wrong in that respect. With regard to the other comments, I will let the facts speak for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not engage in debate on all of this. My colleague Senator Kemp will say a few words on the matters we have just been talking about. I want again to say for the record that the Treasury analysis of the overall price impact of the Fightback package—this is a different point from the one Senator McMullan was mentioning, which was a distributional analysis point—was of the order of 3.6 per cent compared with the coalition's own modelling of an impact of 4.4 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Again, I would hope that the Parliamentary Secretary has the decency to acknowledge that publicly. I also hope that he might—and I repeat the invitation—publicly refute the lies that have been contained in pamphlets distributed by the Labor Party purporting to claim that the coalition's goods and services tax proposal will lead to an increase in the price level of 15 per cent when his own advisers have told him that the price impact is going to be less than 4 per cent. As I say, I invite the Parliamentary Secretary to acknowledge that the Treasury's analysis shows a figure of less than 4 per cent. I ask him to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is all a bit childish. I have not seen a Labor Party pamphlet which claims that prices are going to increase by 15 per cent. I have seen some Labor Party pamphlets that say the Opposition is going to put a 15 per cent tax on things, which is correct.
—No, they say that prices will increase by 15 per cent.
—Quite frankly, you know it. You have seen it. It was used in the Wills by-election.
—It has been all over Australia.
—Well, I am not aware of that. The pamphlets that I have seen were—
—You are not only not in the factions; you don't seem to be in the Party sometimes.

—I would have responded if that interjection had come from anyone else. But as it comes from Senator Bishop, I will treat it with the contempt it deserves. The situation is that I do not claim that taxes will go up by 15 per cent under Fightback. I never have. I think they will go up unfairly. I have seen some extraordinary claims from the Opposition side about the impact it will have on the price of food and other things. Senator Short now tries to pretend that because overall it is going to be in the range of 3 1/2 to 4 1/2—we all can argue about what it will be—it is therefore going to be 4 1/2 on everything. The honourable senator knows that that is not true. Some prices will go down and some will go up. Some will go up a lot and some will go up by a small amount.
—This is the first time that I have heard a member of the Government acknowledge that some prices will go down.
—I have said it plenty of times. The honourable senator should read my articles more often. As I have often said, Ferraris will be cheaper and Holdens will be more expensive.

—Not only will those items change in price but a very wide range of household goods that are now taxed at 30 per cent and 20 per cent will also fall. Let me phrase the point that I was making in a different way. Is it a fact that the one-off price impact of the Fightback proposals, as modelled by the Treasury, shows an increase of less than 4 per cent?

—I am fairly sure that is right. It is a matter of public record. It is nothing to do with the estimates. What the Treasury has said is a matter of pubic record and I do not think it has been challenged. Let us get on with the business.
—Is the Parliamentary Secretary, in his last comment, accepting on behalf of the Government that figure of less than 4 per cent?

—Do not be absurd. Senator Short asked me a question about what the Treasury analysis said and I said that I thought he had it correct. I do not have it in front of me but it is a matter of public record. It is silly to have a debate about it at 11 o'clock at night.
—I do not want to have a debate about it. I would like confirmation from the Parliamentary Secretary that the Government has not refuted that figure contained in the Treasury analysis.

—I think this is an absolutely outrageous abuse of the Estimates process. It has nothing to do with it. I have stated my position publicly on innumerable occasions about the price impacts of the GST. I have done so in debates with many of the honourable senator's colleagues. Maybe he should talk to some of them. I have been at meetings with several of the honourable senator's front bench colleagues at which we have debated the GST. We have been all through this.

PARA.TAB: I do not think anyone can pretend—and I do not think the honourable senator should—to have such a degree of precision that one can say it is going to be 3.6, 3.9 or 4.4. It all depends on modelling and assumptions and whatever. But I have not, and do not, pretend that it is going to be 15 per cent or anything like it. I do not want to pluck a figure out of my memory as to what the exact Treasury figure was. But that is a matter for public record. Everybody can get access to it. The Government neither seeks to refute it nor confirm it. It is the independent analysis of Treasury, which it published.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in prolonging this. But I take it from what the Parliamentary Secretary has just said that the Government has not refuted the Treasury's figure.
—Of course, they have not. They just told lies about it.

—Well, if the Government has not refuted it, in my book that is a pretty clear indication that it accepts the figure. If it did not accept the figure, of course it would refute it. So I take it that it is an acceptance of that figure.

—I wish to raise a few points which are associated with the points put forward by my colleague, Senator Short. The matters he touched on raise a wider issue, and that is the use of the Treasury by the Government to conduct what is essentially a political exercise in respect of its political opponent. I think that is a very important issue. As I have noted in this chamber before, the Treasury is a great Department. The standing and authority of the Treasury are important in terms of the functioning of the government of this country. It is an extremely important institution.

PARA.TAB: There is the greatest concern that, for the first time, the Treasury has allowed itself to be used for what is clearly a blatant political exercise. It is important to note that Dr Preston, when appearing before the inquiry into superannuation, conceded that a certain amount of work had not been done in this area because, as he said, the Treasury did not have the resources with which to conduct the exercise. Of course, the Treasury had the resources to conduct a major exercise and to do work on the Fightback program. But in the case of the Government's superannuation policies, it did not appear to have the time, the resources and presumably the people with which to conduct a proper analysis.

The point that I would particularly like to raise with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) in the context of these estimates, and in relation to what Senator Short has said, is that one of the issues that came up during the hearings of Estimates Committee B—and I think this was confirmed on a number of occasions by Dr Preston—is that the office of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) gave many instructions to the Department in the conduct of its analysis of the Fightback document.

I understand that the normal practice of the Public Service is to ensure that notes are kept of conversations with a Minister's office. In the last week we have noticed that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade kept careful notes of conversations that it had with Senator Evans's office on another matter of major political controversy.

In relation to this, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary: following the hearings of Estimates Committee B, were further checks made of the individuals to see whether notes were kept of the instructions which were issued from the Treasurer's office to the Treasury about the modelling of the Fightback program? In particular, in the astonishingly controversial choice of the 7 per cent inflation figure and the fall in real wages figure, did the instructions to use those figures come from the Treasurer's office? I would like that question to be answered so that it can be put on the record for all to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is that there is nothing to add to Dr Preston's answer given at the Estimates Committee. The answer to the second question is that the choice of the figure with regard to the inflation assumption was a departmental decision, not a decision made on the instruction of the Treasurer.

—Do I take it from the answer to my first question, that notes were not kept of the instructions which were issued from the Treasurer's office? Could Senator McMullan make that clear, because in the context of this debate it is fairly important.

—I do not have the words that Dr Preston used in front of me. My understanding was that he indicated that there were some notes kept of some conversations, and the pressure of time prevented it being a comprehensive record. He gave the answer to that and I have nothing to add.

—I am not sure that that is sufficient. My memory of what Dr Preston said—I do not have all the material before me—was that he felt that no notes were kept. I am pleased to hear that some notes were kept. Further inquiries at a later date may elicit just what was contained in those notes.

PARA.TAB: In his statements before Estimates Committee B, Dr Preston said that the document which Four Corners had held out to be a Treasury document—Senator McMullan will recall the controversial Four Corners program—was, in fact, prepared in the Minister's office. I would like Senator McMullan to check with the officers and make it clear for the record why, when that was discovered by the Treasury—which I would imagine was within a fairly brief period of the Four Corners program appearing—did the Treasury not issue a statement saying that the document, which was a matter of public controversy at that time, was not a Treasury document?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see why they would, in the normal course, be expected to do that. I do not know why they did not do it. It does not seem to me to be very surprising. If we spent our lives running around trying to deny every remote reference to ourselves, we would not get time to do the things for which we get paid. That is probably what motivated them, as it often motivates me, to ignore occasional inaccuracies which appear about me in the media. It is part of the price one pays for public life and participation in the public sector. I do not have anything further to add on that.

—The problem with that particular answer is that, as I mentioned in the first part of my remarks, the Treasury allowed itself to be used for what was clearly, as Senator Short has said, a naked political exercise, a naked job on its political opponents. At least some senior officers of the Treasury were prepared to allow their great Department to be used for those purposes. In the weeks and months to come, they may well reflect on their particular role.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury could have maintained its old tradition of keeping at arms length from governments and providing advice fearlessly to governments, whether governments like it or not. Not just any old person, but the Four Corners program and the Government—and remember, the Government was involved in this right up to its neck—tried to piggyback on the authority and independence of the Treasury by pretending that this was a Treasury document. One way that Mr Cole and Dr Preston could have strongly asserted the independence of the Treasury was to make it clear that that particular document, which was such a matter of public debate at that time, was not a Treasury document.

I wish to record my own great concern about the behaviour of officers of the Treasury in this matter. A former secretary of the Treasury, in an article in the Financial Review, has pointed out some astonishing features of the behaviour of some senior officers of the Treasury in this particular matter. They will have to wear that particular opprobrium for all time. I think that when a great department such as Treasury allows itself to be used for such a cheap political trick, it is going to become a subject of public debate. The tragedy of this is that the public, perhaps quite rightly, will assume—and the events in the days and weeks to come will sustain or deny the proposition—that the Treasury is not the independent body that keeps itself at arms length from government and is prepared to offer advice and, above all, prepared not to be used by governments for shabby political purposes.

I have a couple more questions in relation to this unit that was allowed to be established by the Treasury to do this political hatchet job on its political opponents. Am I correct in assuming that the unit that was established to model the Fightback program has now been disbanded?

TALK.START.PARA: —The unit was not created to operate the model; it was created to develop the model. Once the model had been developed, the officers were sent to do other duties. The model still exists and is still in regular use, as one would expect.

PARA.TAB: I use this opportunity, with respect to the time, to very briefly say that I refute the allegations that Senator Kemp has made about several hundred very hardworking officers of the Australian Public Service and the slur he has cast against them. I have done it so often. I feel like apologising to the Committee for doing it at 11.18 p.m., but on behalf of those officers I must say that I do not accept that series of assertions. I do not want to start a debate about it, but I felt that I should put it on the record, otherwise it may appear that I had allowed it to go unchecked and unchallenged, and I do not wish that to happen.

As I said, according to the Hansard record, the officers did some things in the analysis of Fightback which were favourable to the Opposition—I might have wished that they had done something else—but they did it all in a professional manner. Let us not go around slurring people just because we do not like the answers they come up with. I have nothing further to add. The body was set up to develop the model. The model has been developed. The officers have been dispersed. Obviously, the development unit no longer exists, but the model still exists and is still in use.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to that, what I have not done is slur 400 or so officers of the Department of Treasury, as the Parliamentary Secretary has said. What I have said, which I maintain, is that a number of senior officers of the Treasury—it may be one, it may be two, it may be three or four—failed to maintain the great tradition of that Treasury, and allowed themselves to be used for this shabby political stunt which Senator McMullan has stood up in this chamber and sought to defend. Senator McMullan should not go around saying that I am slurring 400 officers of the Treasury; I am not. He has used that great Department for shabby Labor Party political activities.

PARA.TAB: It is not the 400 or so officers that need to hang their heads in shame, in my view. It is probably one, two, three or four very senior officers, whose responsibility above all is to protect the independence and integrity of that particular body, who failed to do this when they allowed the Treasury to be used for such a shabby political purpose. So he should not go around making those accusations about me. I have not slurred the Treasury. I stand here and say that those senior officers had a duty to protect the independence of that institution and, by their behaviour over this Fightback package, they manifestly failed to do so.
The Minister mentioned that that model is still being used. Can the Minister detail for the Committee precisely what that model is being used for at the present time?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a micro-economic model. It is used to assess the distributional impacts of the various proposals that are under consideration from time to time. I do not have its current program but it exists; it continues to be used.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Kemp is seeking only to cast such a serious reflection on a small number of officers, I want to come to their defence. There are within the Treasury senior officers—I do not know which ones Senator Kemp is referring to because from what he says it could be any of the SES—and I have met a large number of them. I think that they are Australians of whom the nation can be proud. They do much valuable service for the nation, far beyond the salary we pay them. They are public servants in the best tradition. It is very unfortunate that we should have this sort of attack upon them. This is a democracy and people are entitled to attack and criticise anybody. Parliament is an institution in which people are entitled to say what they believe, and I accept that Senator Kemp believes what he says to be true. But I very strongly disagree with him. Hopefully, we can leave it there because I am not seeking to attack him; I am seeking to defend the people that he is criticising. I accept that he believes it; I just do not agree with him. I do not have a work program for the model but I am assured that it is in current use and will continue to be for some time into the future as a very useful distributional analytical tool for the Treasury.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan will recall that, during the questioning by Estimates Committee B of the Australian Taxation Office on 21 April, it was learnt for the first time that the Government had experienced a shortfall in revenue to the end of February of $600m compared with its Budget estimates to that date. That further shortfall was not quantified but the quite clear expectation was that it would not be of great magnitude.

PARA.TAB: Some of us, including myself, expressed surprise at that and asked why the rate of the shortfall would ease back in the way that was implicit in the figures. Senator McMullan might recall that he queried some of my arithmetic on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I was right, too.

—I am afraid that he was not right because three weeks later we found that, far from there being a shortfall of a little more than $600m, there was a shortfall in excess of $2 billion—I think the figure was in the order of $2.3 billion. What was the reason for that mistake?

—I understand that the new elements in the equation were, essentially, the revised national accounts figures indicating that the rate of wage increase was less than previously indicated, and a shortfall in the income from small business and provisional taxpayers in general. I do not have a lot to add to that, but that is my understanding of the areas in which the problem arose.

—I thank the Minister for that answer but I do not understand it because at the time that this information was given to Estimates B, on 21 April, the officer who provided the information said that the Government or the Taxation Office—in conjunction with the Treasury, I think—was in the process of a review of its estimates, in particular its revenue estimates, and that it was expected that they would be available to the Treasurer by the end of April—only a week or 10 days from then. Is the Minister saying in the answer that he just gave me that such a wealth of new data arrived in the ensuing seven or eight days as to provide the massive change in the expectation that was given to the Senate Committee on 21 April? It sounds too extraordinary to be true.

—I do not think that it is possible to be so precise as to nominate the days on which these events took place, but my advice and understanding is that there were some early signs that there had been a slippage in revenue but that the indications were that that may have been merely temporary.

PARA.TAB: As data came in and it became apparent that perhaps the problem was more substantial, the review that was referred to in the Estimates Committee was undertaken to see whether that was accurate. That is a technical matter and I am not familiar with the detail of how that is actually done. The figures would have been made available to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) early this month. That led to the public indication of it by him. There is not really much more to add. As the information came in, it was assessed and reassessed. Of course, as Senator Short would know, the flow of data is such that one has to be mindful of the fact that what may be the first indication of a change may also just be a statistical blip or a one-off event. So one needs to be careful about leaping to conclusions of major parameter shifts because of one change on one occasion. There is appropriate need for caution in revision of revenue forecasts. —I do not have the exact date, but I understand that when the Treasurer returned from his overseas trip he was advised of that.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Answers to Questions asked of Australian Taxation office by Senator Watson

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B358) asked:
What will the new ATO computer systems, to be implemented in July 1993, do in terms of identifying when a debt is due and payable, the aggregate amount and the ageing process?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO's new integrated computer system, to be implemented in July 1993, will initially take on board the PAYE Group Employer and Sales Tax revenue lines.

Both of these revenue lines operate on the basis of the group employer or registered sales taxpayer self-assessing their liability to pay to the Commissioner amounts of tax instalment deductions (TIDs) deducted from their employees' salary or wages, or, in the case of a registered sales taxpayer, the amount of sales tax charged to a customer in respect of the sales of taxable goods.

In most cases, for both PAYE and Sales Tax, the period of time for which a liability can arise is a calendar month. Thus, for group employers, a liability to pay to the Commissioner amounts of TIDs deducted from employees' salary or wages in a given calendar month normally arises seven (7) days after at the close of that month, that is, TIDs deducted in the month of April become due and payable on the following 7 May.

Similarly, with Sales Tax, a liability to pay amounts of sales tax charged to customers in a calendar month normally arises 21 days after the close of that month, that is, sales tax charged during the month of April becomes due and payable on the following 21 May.

In the ATO's new computer system the due date by which a liability is expected to be received from a group employer or sales tax client will be recorded on their computer record for the relevant liability period—normally a calendar month. This due date can be extended by the Commissioner in accordance with powers provided under the relevant taxing Acts.

As part of a number of important review processes undertaken by the new computer system the records of all clients will be periodically subject to examination to identify instances where clients have failed to carry out their obligations as required by law. These periodic reviews will normally be carried out on a weekly basis. However, some review processes are invoked on a daily basis.

One of these periodic review processes will be to identify clients who have failed to acknowledge a monthly liability for either PAYE or Sales Tax. Because the laws relating to both PAYE and Sales Tax do not require a group employer or sales taxpayer to acknowledge a liability unless and until that person has actually made deductions of TIDs or charged sales tax, as the case may be, a calendar month may elapse in which that person is correct in not sending an advice of liability to the Tax Office. In order to identify those clients who have failed to acknowledge a liability that has actually occurred and those who have not sent an advice of liability because no liability actually exists, the new computer system provides for the recording of an estimated liability (based on historical, industry and seasonal patterns) for each client, for each liability period. This estimated liability value is recorded on the client's record.

As part of the periodic reviews, client records are examined after the standard due date has elapsed, that is 7th of month for PAYE and 21st of month for Sales Tax. Where a client has an expected liability for that particular month recorded but no actual liability has been acknowledged the system will identify that client as a potential non-lodger and will issue a notice ( under s.14I of the Taxation Administration Act) requiring that client to provide information to establish the extent of their liability. This expected liability information may also be used to select certain categories of clients for field audit/inspection activities in an effort to quantify liability.
On the basis of the client's reply to the notice or the results of the field inspection a quantified liability will be recorded on the client's account.

Once a quantified actual liability is recorded on the client's account another function carried out by the periodic review process will be to identify those liabilities which are due and payable but which have payment (either full or partial) outstanding. This outstanding payments review function operates on two fronts—for clients who are already the subject of Debt Collection follow-up, and secondly, for those clients who by virtue of their failing to pay a liability are Debt Collection cases for the first time.

Clients who are already the subject of Debt Collection actions will have the latest accounting information recorded on the record downloaded to the ATO's Debt Collection case management system—COMPACT. All Debt Collection cases recorded in COMPACT are prioritised on the basis of the quantum of debt outstanding so that appropriate actions can be taken by staff in the Debt Collection areas to recover these debts. The COMPACT system provides a range of functions to Debt Collection staff so that they can monitor cases, resubmit them for re-examination at specified intervals as well as providing a range of facilities to generate notices, and other legal documents. Cases recorded in COMPACT are normally allocated to a particular Debt Collection officer (case officer) so that a one-to-one relationship can be established between the Tax Office and the client.

New Debt Collection cases which are referred to the COMPACT system for actioning are also given a priority—a debt level indicator. This priority is established by reference to the value of actual liabilities that a client has outstanding at the time of the running of the periodic review. Where a client has actual liabilities outstanding and has also failed to acknowledge a liability for a liability period where the system is expecting a liability, the value of the estimated/expected liability is also included in the calculation of outstanding liabilities for debt level assignment purposes. As with existing Debt Collection cases, new cases are assigned to a specific Debt Collection officer for appropriate follow-up actions with the client.

It should be noted that under the ATO's new integrated system a picture of a client's indebtedness, across all revenue lines for which that client has dealings with the Tax Office, will ultimately be available. The first release of the new system which caters for the PAYE and Sales Tax revenue lines will, however, initially limit the across revenue line picture to only those revenue lines. As other ATO revenue lines are redeveloped to come on board the new system they will also be incorporated into the aggregate picture.

As to the question of the ageing of debts, the new system is being designed to provide an analysis of all debts by not only their age, but also by value, by revenue line, by debt type ie. primary tax debts and other tax debts and by branch office responsible for the debts.

The design will specifically enable the Commissioner to satisfy the Financial Statements reporting requirements as set out in the guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance for the preparation of the annual financial statements. Under the guidelines, receivables as at 30 June, must be disclosed in accordance with an age analysis showing amounts overdue for less than 30 days, 30-60 days and more than 60 days.
The facility to provide an ageing analysis is planned to be available to ensure that ageing analysis is in place to satisfy the first full year of activity, i.e., 1993-94.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B322) asked:
1. What is the proportion of taxpayers who are found to lack adequate record keeping?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. The ATO has become aware of the lack of proper record keeping in the small business market segment through feedback from tax auditors involved in the audits of this segment. As such figures detailing exact numbers are not available. Business Audit Managers from all offices meet regularly to discuss, amongst other things, audit results. These meetings and tax auditor feedback are valuable sources of information for the taxpayer education area of the ATO and for additional case selection information.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B310) asked:

In the United States action has been taken by taxpayers directly against tax auditors personal assets in circumstances of behaviour of a non-professional character of excessive zeal when carrying out audits on the taxpayers' premises.
1. Has the ATO considered the cases that have been brought in the United States and compared the similarities?

2. Is the ATO aware of or has it looked at the discussions concerning the possibility of Australian Customs officers being liable personally for their own assets and are taxation officers in a similar position to that of Australian Customs officers?
3. Provide a copy of the documentation.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: All ATO staff, including tax auditors, are required to perform their duties in accordance with the duties of their position and within the bounds of the Public Service Act and Regulations. Where an officer is found not to have acted in accordance with the aforementioned then appropriate disciplinary action is taken.

In the normal course of events if a taxpayer was to take action against an auditor for possible over-zealousness then the officer involved would usually refer the matter to the ATO for appropriate consideration.
If the actions of the officer were found to be reasonable then the ATO would assume responsibility and defend the officer involved.

1. The ATO is not aware of any such cases in the United States and is unlikely to follow them up based on the fact that the legal system and social attitudes in the United States are quite different to those in Australia.
2. The ATO is not aware of Customs officers being personally liable but will make contact with Customs to initiate discussions to obtain further details.
3. The ATO has not sought legal advice on the matter and to date has seen no reason to do so.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B311) asked:
Can you bring us up to date on what was referred to as "mafia-type" operations within the Melbourne ATO?
The inference was that of the three people from the Tax Office, one has passed on, one is now operating in private practice and the third is still with the Tax Office. Is that correct?
What charges have been levelled?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: As a result of suspicion about the possible association between Taxation Officers and persons alleged to have involvement in criminal activity in Victoria a comprehensive investigation was undertaken. This involved co-operation with other law enforcement agencies.

The investigation did not identify evidence sufficient to prosecute any officer with any offences associated with connections to "mafia type" operations. As a result of this investigation it was found that two officers (both of whom have resigned) had possibly been involved in activity not directly related to the investigation. Investigations were conducted into these activities. As a result there is currently a matter involving one ex-officer with the DPP. This involves alleged offences arising from the conduct of a business by the officer (companies and associated offences) and the possession of ATO documents containing taxpayer information which we allege is a breach of S.16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. A second matter, involving possible offences under the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Taxation Administration Act, in which another officer is involved is awaiting the provision of additional information before a decision can be made as to further action.
There is no deceased officer who was a suspect in this case.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B315) asked:

An Australian Taxation Office fax machine was used for the dissemination of a letter on ATO letterhead, signed by Mr Talevski for the organisation of a public demonstration in Melbourne in February 1992. It is understood that Mr Talevski was not a member of the Taxation Office, but that the letter was sent by an employee of the Taxation Office.
How many messages were actually sent by the member of staff?
It is understood that the officer of the ATO involved in sending the letters has been charged, but what has he actually been charged with?
Has the case been heard? If so, what have been the findings of the inquiry? If guilty, what is the maximum and minimum disciplinary action that will be taken?
What controls are in place within the ATO to ensure that resources of the ATO are used only for Australian Taxation Office purposes?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Eight facsimiles were sent by a member of Sales Tax, Melbourne Office, on behalf of Mr Talevski.
The officer concerned was charged under sub-section 61(2) of the Public Service Act with misconduct within the meaning of sections 55 and 56 of the Act.

An inquiry was conducted and the charge was proven. The officer was reprimanded and was fined $50.00. The least severe form of disciplinary action available where a charge of misconduct is proven is admonition. The most severe action available is dismissal.
The ATO in common with other employers, cannot expect to detect breaches of this kind at the time of occurrence. Once detected, they are dealt with expeditiously.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B343) asked:

PARA.TAB: Could the ATO provide details as to the progress the AFP has made regarding the investigation into the leaked details of the Smiles case?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The AFP is to conduct interviews with Officers of the DPP in the near future. We understand that further inquiries are dependent on the outcomes of those interviews. We will continue to monitor progress.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B361) asked:

Whether he had been misled in an answer to a question asked at an earlier Senate Estimates hearing, and in particular whether Deputy Commissioners had correctly certified that their assets register information was accurate, and whether any of them had expressed any reservation.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The previous answer has been reviewed, and it is considered to be an accurate statement of policy and intent at the time that it was written. It can however stand elaboration.
The certification sought from Deputy Commissioners in relation to the 1990/91 Financial Statements was of the following form, as recommended by the Department of Finance:

SPEECH.PARA: `I certify that the financial statements for the year ended 30 June 1991 are in agreement with the . . . Office accounts and records and, in my opinion, the statements have been prepared in accordance with the Financial Statements Guidelines for Departmental Secretaries.'

PARA.TAB: Deputy Commissioners were each asked a series of questions in late April 1991 relating to the status of their asset registers, and the likelihood of being able to meet the assets reporting requirements at 30 June 1991. While the responses confirmed our previous knowledge that there were some system deficiencies, all but one of the offices anticipated being able to meet the requirements by 30 June.

In the event, one Deputy Commissioner subsequently expressed reservations in respect of the accuracy of the assets information in his Office. It was however concluded, in the light of the definition of materiality in the Guidelines, that this reservation did not materially affect the accuracy of the aggregate figures included in the Statement of Supplementary Financial Information.

As the answer to the earlier question noted, all Offices were to have undertaken a stocktake prior to 30 June 1991. It is likely, in view of the system deficiencies that we were experiencing, that some certifications were based upon stocktake results, rather than formal asset registers, which were still being compiled.

As reported at the hearing on 21 April 1992, work is in hand to implement a standardised recording and reporting system in all Offices, and to ensure that assets are correctly recorded as at 30 June 1992.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B365) asked:

Apart from the sanctions already contained in the Act itself and apart from the answer given to Senator Bishop about the Parramatta exercise in relation to the loading of paper, what arrangements have been made to ensure that the privacy of sensitive tax information, including tax file numbers, will not be leaked or issued from the Tax Office?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Staff training courses on security and privacy are conducted frequently. The information given to staff at these sessions is constantly reinforced by on-the-job training and good supervisory practice. Staff training videos on privacy and secrecy are shown, both at the training sessions and at other times. Further reinforcement is given by the Commissioner in addresses to staff.
All ATO officers sign a declaration of secrecy upon commencement with the Office.

In respect of mailing practices, substantial and well-documented quality control procedures are in operation and additionally, in respect of the ATO's major automated mailing facility in Canberra, state of the art equipment is in use to help minimise the possibility of machinery malfunction.
A number of specialised areas exist in the ATO with a national focus on privacy and secrecy:
—Security Directorate
—Computer Security
—Privacy
—ADP Audit
—Internal Audit.
A Security Co-ordination Committee has been established to co-ordinate the work of the above areas.
Representatives of each of the above areas conduct an on-going series of presentations to senior staff on security and privacy matters.
Manuals, policies and procedures on privacy and security practices are widely distributed to staff and compliance with them is monitored and evaluated by the Program Evaluation Branch.
A series of posters and brochures has received wide distribution among staff to serve as a visible reminder to preserve taxpayer confidentiality. Articles also appear in the national staff magazine.
We make public our own standards of secrecy by printing appropriate messages in Tax Pack, in brochures and on forms.
Proof of Identity standards have been established for dealing with taxpayer inquiries to ensure that we are dealing with no-one but the taxpayer or their authorised representative.

Publicity is given to others in the "taxation community" eg, tax agents, accountants, Prescribed Payment System payers, financial institutions and employers, about the need to maintain the confidentiality of taxation information that they handle, including tax file numbers.
Penalties for breaches of the secrecy provisions in tax law were doubled in 1989 to their present maximum of a $10,000 fine, imprisonment for 2 years, or both.
Positions of Security Administrator and Privacy Contact Officer have been established in all Branch Offices to monitor and advise on security and privacy matters.
An information security program is in progress to implement guidelines in the ATO-developed Security Manual.
ATO policy restricts staff access to taxpayer information on the basis of "need to know".
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B373) asked:

Does the Taxation Office intend to process taxpayers through the South Australian courts of so-called no written record? If so, will there not be a degree of injustice in that some will have their determinations concealed, whereas others going through courts of written record will have their issues exposed to the public?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Office contacted the South Australian Attorney-General's Department which advised that it was not aware of any proposal by the South Australian Government to create courts of "no written record". The Taxation Office has no intention whatsoever to process taxpayers through any South Australian courts of "no written record". All disputes as to tax liability will continue to be dealt with under the existing High Court, Federal Courts and Administrative Appeals Tribunal Structures.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B373) asked:
In relation to interest payments due under the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Act 1983, why are more than 90 per cent of interest payments not paid within the required 30 days?
Do taxpayers still receive the interest payment up to the date of sending out the cheque?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: It is not the case that more than 90 per cent of interest payments made under the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Act 1983 (IOP) are not paid within the required 30 days. The Ombudsman's Report to which Senator Watson referred, stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: `. . . in 30 per cent of all interest on overpayments cases it received in 1989-90, the ATO failed to meet its own standard of finalising payments of interest on overpaid tax within 30 days.'

PARA.TAB: It also stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: `. . . six branch offices were able to finalise more than 90 per cent of their 1989-90 cases within 30 days of issuing amended assessments and refunds of the tax overpaid. . . '
(refer page 35 of the Ombudsman's Report 1990/91).

PARA.TAB: In regard to the 1989-90 period to which the Ombudsman is referring, of the total of 15 ATO Branch Offices, 12 processed more than 50 per cent of their IOP cases within 30 days. The Ombudsman viewed as unreasonable the performance of 3 Branch Offices which processed less than 50 per cent of IOP cases within 30 days.

Since this 1989-90 period, the ATO has significantly improved its performance in processing interest on overpayments. The Ombudsman was informed in September 1991 that the ATO is working to meet the 30 day target it has set itself for as many cases as possible and the ATO is currently investigating ways of streamlining the process.

It is not possible to meet the 30 day performance target in all cases because of the complexity of the calculation involved for some taxpayers and the need to obtain information from a variety of sources in order to carry out that calculation.

In relation to the second question, it has never been the case that all taxpayers receive their interest payment up to the date of sending out the cheque. Under the IOP Act, the taxpayer has been and is legally entitled to interest up to the day on which the overpaid tax is refunded to the taxpayer (or applied against another liability) ie: to the day the amended assessment issues.

Current figures available for the period 1 July 1991 to 27 March 1992 indicate that approximately 42,000 taxpayers (out of approximately 66,500 interest payments made) received their interest cheque at the same time as the amended assessment issued and hence did receive the interest payment up to the date of sending the cheque. This outcome was possible because the interest calculation was able to be done automatically on the computer system. However, in the remaining cases that require the manual determination of interest, the ATO aims to finalise and issue the interest cheque as soon as possible after the amended assessment issues.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B375) asked:
Can a building be classified as a trust building and be eligible for the 4 per cent straight-line reduction as outlined in the economic statement?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The One Nation Statement of 26 February 1992 announced an increase in the write-off from 2.5%pa to 4%pa for buildings either used for the provision of short-term traveller accommodation or used for industrial purposes.

The higher rate will apply to buildings, or extensions, alterations or improvements to buildings, commenced to be constructed on or after 27 February 1992 that are used in the relevant manner. It will not apply in respect of expenditure on buildings, improvements, etc. commenced to be constructed before that date.
The fact that a building is classified as a trust building will not be relevant. What is relevant is the time of commencement of construction and the particular use of the building.

A taxpayer who commences to restore or convert a trust building after 26 February 1992 will be entitled to deduct capital expenditure on the restoration or conversion at the higher rate if the building is used in the relevant manner.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B376) asked:
In relation to EDR No 61, if someone gives a church worker, for example, $500 to take a needed holiday, is that related to the worker's personal needs or to their occupation and service?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Ruling in respect of which EDR 61 was a draft has been issued in final form as Taxation Ruling IT 2674.
It is impossible to answer the question without knowing the full circumstances in which the amount of money was given.
In considering the particular facts the following matters, taken from IT 2674, would be relevant in determining whether the $500 would be assessable or not.
Whether an amount is assessable income depends on the quality or character of the gift in the hands of the recipient.
As a general rule, an amount is assessable income even if it is a receipt of a one-off nature if it is possible to:

SPEECH.PARA: relate the payment to the church worker to any income producing activity on his or her part; or
point to any employment, personal exertion or other income producing activity by the church worker of which the receipt of the payment is in a relevant sense a product or incident.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, a payment made to a church worker on personal grounds would not be assessable income. That would be where there is no connection between the receipt of the amount and any income producing activity by the church worker. Examples of this are:

SPEECH.PARA: where the amount is given because the church worker is in dire physical or financial circumstances; or
where the church worker's personal qualities or attributes occasion the payment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B377) asked:

According to the Tax Office, what constitutes a liquidators declaration in terms of section 160W(a)? Does the Tax Office require any particular form or details? For example, what would be the status of a report in a newspaper or, for example, a written statement to shareholders? Are any time specifications involved?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The liquidator's statement required under section 160WA must be contained in a written declaration. For example, the minutes of a shareholders and/or creditors meeting may contain a statement by a liquidator that the liquidator has reasonable grounds to believe that shareholders will not receive any distribution in the course of winding up the company. If later signed by the liquidator, the minutes would constitute a written declaration as required by the legislation. A written statement by the liquidator to the shareholders would also be acceptable. However a verbal statement by a liquidator which had not been reduced to writing and authenticated by the liquidator would not be acceptable. Shareholders need to know that the liquidator has made a written declaration and a newspaper report may indicate that such a document was in existence.

There is no time limit in which the liquidator must make the declaration after winding up procedures have commenced, as long as, at the time of making the declaration, the liquidator believes on reasonable grounds that there is no likelihood of shareholders receiving any distribution.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B380) asked:
Why are drafting services exempt from having to present PPS forms to clients? Is not their work regarded as part of the construction industry?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The PPS provisions provide that payment for drafting services will be subject to the PPS provisions when carried out as part of architectural, building and certain other services, in connection with construction projects.

However, payments made for drafting and other building-type services will not be subject to the PPS provisions when they are carried out in isolation and do not form part of an activity covered by the PPS arrangements.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B380) asked:

In relation to tax deducibility of moneys invested into the Film Finance Corporation, what criteria are set for films under division 10BA which will determine whether or not an investment in a film is suitable for a tax deduction?
One of the criteria is that the program should be of broadcast quality or suitable for public exhibition in the cinema. Who, for example, sets the criteria for this?
Who acts as the appropriate watchdog to govern the individual funding decisions of the Film Finance Corporation?

It is understood that taxpayers' funds from the Film Finance Corporation were used to finance the film referred to as Sacred Sex. Given the criteria that are set down, does the ATO consider that such a film should have qualified, and how much money was invested?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: As indicated in the course of the hearings, these questions can best be answered by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Accordingly, these questions have been referred to that Department for response.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B407) asked:
