1. What is the cost to revenue of the decision to impose an indefinite moratorium on the sales tax of veterinary products and vaccines used in the treatment of companion animals?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. Industry sources have estimated approximately $4 million per year of potential sales tax was involved.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B418) asked:
Does the Tax Office pay fringe benefits on taxi fares for employees who regularly work overtime in Australian Taxation Offices around Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Yes. Fringe Benefits Tax is payable where regular transport is provided to shift workers and others who regularly work late hours in the normal course of their employment.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990/91, the taxable value of the ATO on transport provided in these circumstances was $169,786.00. The FBT liability on this amount was $79,799.42.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B414) asked:
Could the ATO please answer questions previously placed on notice in relation to reports by John Howard about tax rorts out of control.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The Tax Office is unable to find any record of those questions. The Office will, of course, respond to specific questions should Senator Watson wish to raise them in response to this answer.

SPEECH.PARA: Overseas Pensions

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:
1. Does the Tax Office accept that taxpayers with some overseas pensions being treated as provisional income are being disadvantaged by having to pay their tax in advance?

2. Is it reasonable that this penalty should be imposed on them when there is absolutely no requirement to have PAYE deducted from the overseas pension (they are unable to comply with PAYE even if they wanted to)?
3. What action is proposed by the ATO to correct this unreasonable situation?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. and 2. No. These taxpayers are being treated in precisely the same manner as the majority of other taxpayers whose income is not subject to deductions at source; that is, they are subject to provisional tax on assessment.

The law was changed primarily to ensure that taxpayers with tax debts over $3,000 did not gain an unfair advantage over the general body of taxpayers through an ability to escape both deductions at source and provisional tax.
3. Taxpayers who face genuine payment difficulties because of their specific circumstances should approach their Deputy Commissioner regarding a payment arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: Prescribed Payments System

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:
1. Are you aware that it is very difficult to extract a legible copy by the third copy of the from?
2. What is the annual cost of producing these forms?
3. Are you aware that the paperwork for the PPS system often takes longer than the paperwork for the actual creditor?
4. Are there any plans to instigate a review of the whole PPS that the system is reasonable and practicable?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. Yes.
3. Yes.
4. A major review of the key elements of the PPS is presently under way, with special focus on the paperwork aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: Fringe Benefits Tax Booklet

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:

I am aware that the Australian Taxation Office has recently issued a booklet to assist tax agents and taxpayers in the preparation of FBT returns. However, it would appear that this publication is being severely rationed in that tax agents are only being sent a single copy and are being told that if additional copies are required they must be purchased through the Australian Government Bookshop.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The information booklet `Fringe Benefits, Tax—a guide for employers', was recently revised and copies have since been distributed according to where we believe the greatest need exists. Feedback suggests that some parties believe that the method of distribution adopted was not appropriate.

To respond to this criticism, it is important to note, again, the title of the booklet—`Fringe Benefits Tax—a guide for employers'. This publication has been produced with the intent of assisting the taxpayers themselves to meet the requirements set down by the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act. We in the ATO have always considered that tax agents have access to more extensive material dealing with FBT such as CCH, Butterworths etc. For this reason we have not seen a need to produce extensive information of the type contained in the booklet specifically for tax agents. Notwithstanding this fact, we have recognised that the quality of the information contained in the booklet has led to its extensive usage by tax agents.

In previous editions of the booklet, sufficient quantities have been printed to allow distribution on the basis of one booklet for every registered FBT taxpayer ie: approximately 120,000 copies made up of 34,000 non-agent taxpayers and 86,000 for agent registered taxpayers which were intended for distribution via the tax agent. In practice we found that many agents did not forward the copies provided for their clients, instead using them within their own practices.
In the instance of the 1992 re-print of the booklet, the decision was taken to distribute 50,000 copies according to the following formula:
37,000 copies to non-agent taxpayers (employers themselves).
7,000 copies to agents ie: a single copy for every agent with an FBT responsibility.
6,000 copies for distribution by the ATO to new registrations etc.
Senator Watson asked:
1. Has the issue of Tax Pack resulted in more and more individual taxpayers having their tax returns completed by tax agents?

2. What is the reason for the change (it has been suggested that the issue of Tax Pack was deliberately undertaken to coerce taxpayers into the Tax Agent net as it would be easier to control lodgments etc)?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. There is no established connection between the introduction of Tax Pack and increasing use of tax agents.
2. The ATO rejects entirely any suggestion that Tax Pack was part of a deliberate strategy to encourage taxpayers to use tax agents.
Tax Pack was designed to

SPEECH.PARA: provide a step by step guide to taxpayers in the completion of their returns—helping them to `get it right the first time'
to provide a more efficient means of distributing return forms and instructions to taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: There has been wide acknowledgment that Tax Pack was a very valuable service initiative, indeed members of this Senate Estimates committee have expressed such comment at previous meetings.
Senator Watson asked:
1. Why is it that tax agents' lodgment program continue to show partnership and trust returns outstanding when these have already been lodged?
2. Why is it that these lodgments are not picked up by the computer until after March?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. and 2. Most branch offices defer the processing of these returns till later in the financial year. Processing of these returns as they are received is not essential to the raising of assessments, since they are largely of a statistical nature and more relevant to our Audit program.

As lodgments are not recorded till later in the financial year, tax agents lodgment program reports early in the year will show these returns as outstanding. The extension of ELS to these returns in 1992/93 should largely eliminate this deficiency.
Senator Watson asked:
Given the severe impact of the recession what impact has this had on budget collection of corporate and other taxpayers taxes in the year to date?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This question was answered in the course of the hearings, in response to specific questions by Senator Short.
Senator Watson asked:

It is not uncommon for the issue of company refund cheques to be unduly delayed. What systems have now been put in place to prevent this situation occurring in the future and so to ensure the timely refund of any surplus company tax?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: We are aware that delays occurred in 1991/92, due to the late completion of the computer system designed to support the processing of company returns.
There have been no reported delays in the general processing of 1991 company returns, in particular those involving a refund.
Senator Watson asked:
Last year professionals including dentists, solicitors and barristers came under the scrutiny of the tax office and were required to pay back more than $2 million.
1. What was the amount expected before the audit? Did this $2 million correspond to what was expected?
2. What did it cost to run the audit?
3. I understand that panelbeaters, fishermen, furniture removalists etc are to be targeted this year. What amount of revenue is expected from this group?
4. What costs have been budgeted for this audit?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. and 3. Project based audits (PBAs) are designed to implement risk management strategies through regular scrutiny by industry group.
Projects are usually selected based on consideration of one or more of the following criteria:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) compliance research and industry information indicates that compliance levels for that industry are relatively low;
(ii) recent audit activity detected large amounts of omitted income or overclaiming of deductions;
(iii) there is a perceived significant risk to the revenue;
(iv) the industry has not recently been audited and generates significant amounts of income.

Unless current evidence of non-compliance is available from other sources, the initial stage of the project is designed to determine whether a compliance problem exists. On the basis of initial findings a project may proceed or may be discontinued.

PARA.TAB: For this reason the ATO does not place expected revenue outcomes on PBAs. Their primary purposes are:

SPEECH.PARA: to measure the extent of compliance as a basis for monitoring future trends in voluntary compliance
to identify major sources and causes of taxpayer error so that these can be overcome appropriately (through meetings, publicity, education etc) for that group
to ensure that taxpayers audited pay the correct amount of tax.

PARA.TAB: 2. and 4.While a project program is developed for each PBA, they are not costed separately. Costs of the projects may vary widely depending on whether they involve full investigation of taxpayers' affairs or review of a single area of human error.
We are monitoring costs of the program as a whole and early signs are that PBA is a cost effective tool for monitoring and improving compliance.
Senator Watson asked:

Is not the Commissioner ignoring section 3(4) of the Training Guarantee Administration Act which states that the intention of the Parliament is that this Act should be implemented in a manner consistent with the achievements of its objectives minimising the burden on employers.
Can the committee have an assurance that this provision is being adhered to?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO is mindful of the intent of section 3(4) of the Training Guarantee Administration Act (TGAA). A concerted effort is made in our public education activities to explain and help eligible employers address the record keeping requirements of the Act. Assistance and advice is given over the free Hotline service and at presentations and conferences attended by ATO staff. Examples of documentation employers can use to demonstrate that their training programs and related activities meet the eligibility requirements of the TGAA are also provided in readily available literature produced by the ATO.

With regards to financial records, it is generally the case that the records employers maintain for other business purposes contain sufficient detail to verify their expenditure for the TGAA. Employers are only obliged to verify that they have met their minimum training requirement of 1% of annual national payroll.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearance for Software used in ELS

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:

When is the Tax Office going to accept its responsibility and provide clearances for the software available so that Agents can be certain of the accuracy of information provided to both the Tax Office and also their clients?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO follows the following steps in registering software packages to be used by Tax Agents and produced by software producers.
The ATO produces software specifications relating to:
—data format
—edits
—communication specifications
These specifications represent compulsory and minimum requirements. The specifications are distributed free of charge to any parties interested in producing software.
ATO provides, free of charge, a test facility whereby the communications component can be tested by software producers prior to approaching the ATO for registration.
ATO provides, free of charge, test cases to assist producers in testing the accuracy of their package with ATO requirements.
ATO goes through a process, free of charge, to ensure that the package meets our published specifications.

The registration process ensures that the software package produces data which can be transmitted to, and received electronically by, the ATO and that data can subsequently be processed by the ATO's computers.

SPEECH.PARA: NOTE: In most cases tax agents purchase software packages which comprise integrated components of the range of responsibilities they undertake on behalf of their clients. The ATO registration process relates only to the compliance of the package with ATO published specifications. The process is limited to that and does not extend to verifying functionality beyond those specifications.

PARA.TAB: We consider that this set of actions represents an acceptable level of service to our tax agent clients.

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign Superannuation Funds

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:

There is a problem in relation to foreign superannuation funds with members who are employed in Australia. Technically, such funds will not qualify as "non resident superannuation funds" for Australian tax purposes because of the existence of Australian members and technically may be subject to Australian tax on their world-wide income. This issue has been raised previously with the Australian Taxation Office who have indicated that each fund will be considered on a case by case basis. However, this is now an issue which should be given higher priority.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Section 272 of the Income Tax Assessment Act (the Act), in effect, deems non-resident superannuation funds, apart from `foreign superannuation funds' as defined in subsection 6(1) of the Act, to be residents of Australia. Therefore, if a non-resident superannuation fund has Australian resident members and/or receives deductible or rebatable contributions, it may be taxable on its world-wide income. However, the extent to which the assessable income of a non-resident superannuation fund will be taxed in Australia will be subject to any relevant Double Tax Agreement. Broadly, the Double Tax Agreements restrict Australia's taxing rights to certain Australian source income.
The issues are under examination. However, it is not appropriate for the Australian Taxation Office to comment on whether the law should be amended in relation to this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign Investment Funds

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:

1. What steps will the Australian Taxation Office be taking to educate the public as to the effect of the proposed new regime involving foreign superannuation funds, particularly in view of the fact that the legislation, which is not yet available, is to take effect on the 1st of July 1992?
2. Is it the intention of the ATO to issue an information paper or the Government draft legislation prior to that date? If so, when?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. The ATO has already been actively involved in the process of consultation that formed part of the development of the foreign investment fund measures. Officers of the ATO have participated in seminars dealing with these measures. The ATO will mount an appropriate public education program, having due regard to other competing programs. The program will be modelled on that provided when the controlled foreign company measures were introduced in 1990-91.
2. On Thursday 2 April 1992, the Treasurer released an information paper on the measures. It was also announced that the legislation will be introduced in the autumn sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: Retirement Homes

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:

I understand that the ATO is investigating the possibility of taxing resident funded retirement villages. I refer in particular to a case in South Australia, the SA Retirement Villages Association, in which the ATO is of the view that `interest free loans' associated with `resident funded villages' were really `a premium to obtain a guaranteed lease' and therefore, in the Department's view, subject to taxation consideration.
1. What is the state of the ATO's concerns in this area?

2. Does the ATO/Government realise that any current/retrospective legislation in this area could have disastrous consequences for future building programs of community based groups, and equally financially embarrassing results for the incumbents of many villages?
3. I understand the ATO were due to have discussions with officers of the different state and Australian Retirement Villages Association last 29 January. What was the outcome of these discussions?

4. I understand that the Taxation Commissioner has produced a draft Discussion Paper setting out the Commissioner's preliminary view on the taxation of receipts by owners of retirement villages from incoming residents. Will this paper be made available?
5. I understand that a working party who have pursued this draft paper have made extensive submissions to the ATO on this paper. What is the ATO's response to these submissions?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. The ATO is concerned that retirement village proprietors have entered into arrangements which attempt to shelter profits from any income tax liability. The ATO does not accept the argument that the initial payments made by incoming residents never constitute assessable income.

2. The ATO is not proposing that there be legislation to deal with the situation on a retrospective basis. The ATO considers that the profits being made by retirement village owners should be brought to account under the existing provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, in view of the fact that in the past several Branch offices of the ATO have approved some individual arrangements, it is not intended that our view of the taxation treatment of income derived by village owners will apply retrospectively.

3. The ATO met with industry representatives on 26 August 1991. As a result of those discussions, the ATO agreed to delay the release of a proposed Exposure Draft Ruling (EDR) until further written submissions were made by the industry.

4. A discussion paper outlining the ATO's views was provided on a confidential basis to industry representatives prior to the meeting in August 1991. It is not proposed to release that document publicly. After the ATO has had an opportunity of considering the submissions of industry in response to that paper, an Exposure Draft Ruling will be released publicly for further comment before a Taxation Ruling issues.

5. The industry has had some difficulty in co-ordinating its written submissions to the ATO. However, we now have been assured that those submissions will be completed by no later than 30 April 1992. It will be necessary then to consider those submissions in detail prior to the public release of the EDR.

SPEECH.PARA: Revenue Collection

PARA.TAB: I refer to an internal memorandum by senior audit managers within the ATO which was leaked to the papers last October. The paper was prepared by a group calling themselves `The Northern Primary Audit Managers for the Business Management Committee' and was dated March 22, 1991.
Senator Watson asked the following questions and the answers are provided below:
1. Would you agree that the administrative savings from the existing self-assessment system may well have been outweighed by the administrative cost? What is the administrative cost?
2. What is the ATO's answer to the suggestion in the Memo that `any form of cost benefit analysis would support an expansion of self-assessment'?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. and 2. An evaluation of self assessment as introduced in 1986 was completed by the ATO in 1989. The results of that evaluation and a detailed exposition of the efficiency and effectiveness of self assessment are contained in the ATO's submission to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It is understood that the submission is to be released by the Committee on 29 April 1992. A copy of the relevant chapter can be supplied to members of the Estimates Committee should they request it.
3. How many tax debts have not been pursued?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 3. We cannot give a precise answer but can advise the following:
(i) At the end of March 1992, there were around 331,000 debts within the debt collection program.
(ii) The vast bulk of these debts—around 65%—were less than $2,500.
(iii) The vast bulk of tax outstanding, however, is tied up in a relatively small number of large debt cases, all of which are either
(a) being pursued;
(b) deferred, held pending resolution of a dispute/litigation/bankruptcy proceeding etc.
4. What is being done to ensure that only one TFN is issued to each taxpayer?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 4. Measures to maintain/improve TFN integrity include:
—proof of identity checks, subject to regular revision, for all new TFN applications;
—national individuals database to aid taxpayer identification;
—systematic validation of tax file numbers quoted by taxpayers to employers and financial institutions followed by corrective action where errors are found; and
—computer-based checking facilities to identify potential dual registrants for examination and corrective action.
5. How many taxpayers have been discovered having more than one TF number?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 5. To date, our computer checks have revealed around 30,000 instances of potential dual registration. (These would have occurred over a number of years commencing before the introduction of the formal TFN scheme). To appreciate the significance of this volume of `errors', it needs to be recognised that—
(i) TFN's are now widely used—over 12 million registrants: they are used in administration of HECS, DSS pensions etc, as well as for tax administration. 30,000 represents 0.25%.
(ii) Citizens can move in and out of the tax system irregularly for a variety of reasons. Tracing or identifying some taxpayers becomes difficult because:
—they change their names or the way they express them;
—of the incidence of common names, particularly among ethnic groups; and
—often citizens provide insufficient information to effect positive/correct identification.

(iii) Because of (ii) some citizens end up receiving a second/dual registration. From our examination, the great majority of these can be put down to clerical/human error—they do not represent attempts to defraud revenue.
6. Under the present audit system is there still a series of checks and balances that in effect act as a net to prevent the patently unacceptable processing error from occurring?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: A range of checks and balances are in operation, not only within the audit system, but also within the ATO returns processing systems to detect obvious errors.
For example, checks are carried out to:
—validate claims for rebates, credits and deductions against income disclosed (eg, ensuring the disclosure of dividend income where there are claims for imputation credits);
—identify excessive claims (eg, tolerance checks on tax instalment deductions, rebates and credits to ensure maximum limits are not exceeded);
—ensure the arithmetic accuracy of data input (eg, arithmetic checksums for income, deductions and rebates);
—ensure assessments are not erroneously issued, by identifying cases requiring scrutiny (eg, large refunds);
—detect incompatible claims (eg, claims for foreign tax credits and no foreign income disclosed);
—ensure limits and thresholds are not exceeded (eg, maximum claims exist for most rebates, such as dependant rebates where the maximum claim is currently $1,296);
—ensure compliance with security arrangements for VIP taxpayers (eg, manual intervention or scrutiny is required);
—ensure the accurate matching of taxpayer information (eg, identity checks to validate tax file numbers to prevent duplicate assessments);
—validate tax agent software used in the electronic processing of returns (eg, scrutiny of tax agent software to ensure acceptable operation of checks and balances);
—ensure accurate application of averaging provisions (eg, storage and accessing of prior year(s) taxable income(s)).
All checks and balances are under constant scrutiny and are subject to ongoing review and modification.
7. Why were Prescribed Payments System error reports stopped?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 7. When the PPS was first established, error reports were generated as returns were being processed. These reports contributed to significant delays in processing returns/providing refunds, and there was significant level of taxpayer complaint. The errors reported related largely to potential under and over-allowances of PPS credit, the latter often associated with PPS income disclosed in partnership returns. In the case of under-allowances, many of these were found to involve potential omissions of income that required lengthy follow up with agents and clients.
It was concluded that rather than delay 100% of cases, such checking would be conducted on a post issue basis. Accordingly, the majority of pre-issue checking was abolished in 1989/90.

PPS income reports are now input to the Income Matching System, and along with other categories of income reports, are matched by computer with taxpayer records. This process produces a large number of potential income omissions which are systematically reported for follow up action, according to revenue priority.
8. Why are duplicate group certificates no longer keyed?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 8. Around 40% of group certificates are reported on computer magnetic media, and this does not require keying. The balance are received on paper.

For the 1990 Income Matching System run last year, details of 8.1 million group certificates were captured and processed: 5.6 million on magnetic tape, the balance keyed. We do not have the resources to key all, and if we did, we are not convinced that the effort involved would be justified.
The processing of group certificates in this way led to the identification of many thousands of taxpayers who had not declared all of their income or who had failed to lodge returns.
Our strategy for the short term period is to:
—increase the level of automation of employers—get more employment data on magnetic tape.
—selectively key paper group certificates for specific/targeted employment groups and process this data as part of the Income Matching System.
9. What is the basis of the ATO's decision to audit a specific group?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 9. A group of taxpayers are selected for audit based on consideration of one or more of the following:
(i) compliance research indicates that the particular group has a relatively low level of compliance;
(ii) recent audit activity of members of that group detected large amounts of omitted income or overclaiming of deductions;
(iii) there is a perceived significant risk to the revenue;
(iv) the group has not recently been audited and generates significant amounts of income.
10. How would the ATO rate the compliance rate of the taxpaying community?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 10. The ATO does not rate the taxpaying community as a whole in terms of complying with taxation law. Rather the ATO looks separately at the compliance levels of various industries and professions within each market segment.
11. The memo mentioned that there had been an excess of `work related claims'. What is the estimated loss in taxation revenue from this area?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO is not in a position to estimate the loss in taxation revenue from overclaiming of work related expenses. However, modifications to tax return forms will require taxpayers to separately identify work related expenses into components. This modification is being made to encourage taxpayers to make correct claims and to assist the ATO in detecting those taxpayers who overclaim. Other measures will be pursued.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B379) asked:
Is there a notification in Tax Pack that Exposure Draft Rulings and final Rulings are available at prices ranging from a certain amount? Is there an upper limit to which the cost is applicable?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This question was answered in the course of the hearings (refer Hansard page number B379), in response to specific questions by Senator Watson.
Page 5 of the 1991 Tax Pack refers to the ability of taxpayers to gain an individual ruling under section 169A, when they lodge their returns.
Tax Pack does not indicate that EDRs and final rulings can be purchased.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B431) asked:
1. Why did the ATO not accept the comments of the Federal Court in what is known as the Westfield case and consequently produce EDR 72?
2. Would you agree that if the Taxation Commissioner is not going to accept the comments of the Full Federal Court as correct, then the entire self-assessment system is fraught with danger?
3. If taxpayers cannot rely on the Tax Office to accept the determination of the second highest court in the country, what can they rely on?
4. If the ruling system is to make a positive contribution to tax administration, it must be balanced. Do you agree? This Ruling EDR 72 is not?
5. Do you agree that there is a definite bias against business displayed by this Ruling?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: First, it is important to recognise that Exposure Draft Taxation Rulings (EDRs) are not statements of the Australian Taxation Office's interpretive policy. They represent the preliminary, though considered, views of the ATO. EDRs may not be relied upon by taxation officers, taxpayers and practitioners. It is only final Taxation Rulings which represent authoritative statements by the Australian Taxation Office of its stance on the particular matters covered in the Ruling.

EDR 72 was produced to set out the ATO views as to the application of the decision of the High Court of Australia in FC of T v. The Myer Emporium (1987) 163 CLR 199; 87 ATC 4363; 18 ATR 693 and the development of the law in later cases.

The ATO accepts that the Westfield case was correctly decided on the basis of the conclusions of fact found by the Full Federal Court. However, EDR 72 states clearly that we do not accept certain comments of Hill J on one issue, viz. whether a profit must be made by the very means contemplated at the time of entering into an isolated transaction to be income.

The reasons why the ATO does not accept those comments were stated clearly in EDR 72 at paragraphs 44-45. We consider that the comments of Hill J quoted are obiter dicta and, therefore, not of binding authority. Furthermore, we do not accept that those comments are correct. We do not agree that the proposition made by Hill J is implicit in the High Court's decision in the Myer Emporium case, which is the leading case as to when a profit on an isolated transaction is income.

The ATO is not required to apply obiter dicta of the courts because such statements are not of binding authority. Although we consider dicta of the Full Federal Court to be of great weight in interpreting the law, we do not automatically apply them in every case e.g. if they are inconsistent with a decision of the High Court of Australia.

The approach taken by the ATO in EDR 72 does not mean that the self assessment system is fraught with danger. In this instance, the ATO has used the Ruling system (as it was meant to be used) to state the ATO view of the law and our reasons for that view. Consequently, taxpayers will know our view when they self-assess. If a taxpayer does not agree with the ATO's view that a profit on a particular isolated transaction is income, the taxpayer can dispute that issue under the objection and appeals provision of the law.

We strongly reject any suggestion that EDR 72 is biased against business or is not balanced. The EDR presents an even-handed analysis of the principles that have emerged from decided cases. The ATO has demonstrated that our views on isolated transactions are even-handed in issuing EDR 76 which sets out a treatment of losses on isolated transactions which is the `mirror image' of the approach in EDR 72. That is, a loss from an isolated transaction is deductible, generally speaking, if the taxpayer expected the transaction to produce a profit which would have been assessable income.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B439) asked:
Does the ATO keep statistics in situations where a department is issued with excess refund cheques and assessments for businesses in excess of what their clients should have received?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Action to correct cases where refund cheques are issued for incorrect amounts is taken by individual branch offices. Details of these cases are kept by branch offices.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B433) asked:

1. Taxpayer service has become the catchcry of the Tax Office over the past several years and the ATO has spent large sums of money in attempting to provide service. We have witnessed the issue of the Tax Pack, the General Inquiries area of the branch offices are closed on Wednesdays for staff training, pamphlets covering many topics are available in various languages, videos are available to schools etc.

What studies have been undertaken to quantify the benefit being obtained from the various taxpayer service activities being undertaken by the Tax Office? How are these activities justified if the outcome of the program is not accurately assessed?
2. How accurate and timely is the advice being given by inquiry officers? How is its efficiency

SPEECH.PARA: and accuracy measured (complaints are still being received from members and non-members about long delays in having phone calls answered and also the quality of answers received)?
Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO undertakes extensive needs analysis and customer satisfaction measurements regarding its publications, video products and advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax Pack

PARA.TAB: AGB Research Pty Ltd carried out an evaluation of Tax Pack 90. In brief, 80% of those who had used Tax Pack found it useful or very useful, 76% found the instructions easy or very easy to understand, 74% of those who used Tax Pack wanted to see it again next year.
Tax Pack 91 was evaluated by Reark Research. Results indicate that changes made as a result of the evaluation of Tax Pack 90 were well received.

SPEECH.PARA: Schools Kit

PARA.TAB: In June 1989 the Tax Office launched a taxation schools kit. Frank Small and Associates evaluated the kit. The research concluded that the kit had widespread support and was highly successful in educating students on basic tax issues.

SPEECH.PARA: CGT

PARA.TAB: Market testing was conducted to determine clients' knowledge of CGT and to pre-test the series of seven information booklets. Returned evaluation forms distributed with the publications indicate: 90% of tax agents found the two basic booklets useful or very useful, 88% of tax agents rated the overall kit as useful or very useful.

SPEECH.PARA: TFN

PARA.TAB: The TFN stage 2 campaign was evaluated by Quantum Market Research. The campaign included a number of information booklets, one of which was sent to all households in Australia and translated into 14 languages. Key results were: awareness of TFN rules raised from 77 per cent to 95 per cent, increase in quotation rate of TFNs to investment bodies from 32 per cent to 87 per cent, understanding of the main areas of TFN rules very good, with up to 93 per cent of respondents able to correctly answer questions on the rules.

SPEECH.PARA: Training Guarantee

PARA.TAB: The Tax Office commissioned Woolcott Research Pty Ltd to undertake evaluations on a sample of affected employers, before and after receiving Tax Office information on the scheme in 1991. Brochures were translated into five languages. The survey indicated: 97 per cent said they would comply with the scheme, 65 per cent felt the scheme was an excellent or reasonable idea, 56 per cent were undertaking more training than ever before.

SPEECH.PARA: Company and Superannuation Self Assessment Scheme

PARA.TAB: An information package was distributed to all affected businesses. Components of the package were market tested before printing. An ATO survey of 2000 tax agents and non-agent companies was undertaken in December 1990 to measure the effectiveness of the materials: 60 per cent said the package was their principal source of information, 80 per cent found the components useful or very useful, 87 per cent said the package was quite or very easy to read.
2. The efficiency of advice of inquiry officers is measured by:
In 8 offices, the PABX has measuring equipment to record the time taken to answer telephone inquiries. Depending on the office, 71-95% of calls were answered within two minutes.

The remaining offices do not have measuring telephone equipment. They rely on feedback from callers and from their switchboard. Measuring equipment will be installed in other Branch Offices when opportunities arise under our decentralisation and modernisation plans.

The accuracy of advice of inquiry officers is gauged by a range of mechanisms such as oral or written tests, supervisor monitoring and feedback from taxpayers and tax agents. A recent report from Branch Offices indicate that BOs have a rate ranging from 80 to 95%, for complete and accurate responses. Strategies are under development to improve these rates.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B425) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: The Everett amnesty

PARA.TAB: The guidelines announced recently by the Commissioner of Taxation for the settlement of capital gains tax liabilities arising out of post 19 September 1985 Everett assignments raise important questions of principle.

Alternatively, instead of asking the following questions, you could ask if the ATO officers have read T M Dwyer's comments in Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin, No. 4 for 1992 and the officials please comment?
1. What authority does the Commissioner have to waive tax liabilities on a mass basis?

2. Do you not agree that duty under s 8 to administer generally the ITAA does not confer a general dispensing power upon the Commissioner? Claims by the Crown to have such a power vanished with the notions of the divine rights of Kings. The Act binds both taxpayer and the Commissioner and "no conduct on the part of the Commissioner can act as an estoppel against the Act. (Kitto J in FCT v Wade (1951))

3. Do you not agree that if CGT liabilities are owing, the Commissioner must ascertain them under the ITAA and collect them on a case by case basis, as capital gains will vary enormously with each case?
4. If the Commissioner complains that to apply it correctly is administratively too difficult, then he should ask the Parliament for legislative repeal. Agree?
5. The case brings up another major question of principle. The settlement requirement offer is that "no further amounts of income are to be assigned".

Do you not agree that it is not for the Commissioner to tell taxpayers how to arrange their affairs? The general law allows for the Commissioner not to take away. As Williams J observed in Tweddles's case (1943) 7 ATD 186 at 190:
`The act must operate on the result of a taxpayer's activities as it finds them.'

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1-5. The ATO considers that the guidelines issued for the settlement of the capital gains tax issues arising from certain Everett assignments are within the powers conferred upon the Commissioner under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The guidelines were issued to resolve an outstanding problem with a number of taxpayers in a way the Commissioner considers to be a cost effective manner; they facilitate the collection of tax which might not otherwise be paid.
By issuing the guidelines, the Commissioner is not telling taxpayers how to arrange their affairs. It is open to taxpayers who wish to maintain the assignment, to do so.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B426) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Capital gains tax and land deals

PARA.TAB: It has come to my attention that ATO is showing an interest in land deals that result from compulsory acquisition. Presently the actual land deal is not taxable, but the ATO is considering the compensation component as a possible source of revenue.
1. Is this so?
2. Have any amended assessments been forwarded to taxpayers?
3. I understand that the ATO reasoning is based on the section 160M(7) of the ITAA. Is this part of the Act under consideration for revision?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1-3. The compulsory acquisition of land constitutes a disposal of that land for the purposes of Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Any compensation received as a result of the compulsory acquisition is regarded as consideration received as a result of or in respect of the disposal of the land. That is, if the land was acquired before 20 September 1985, no capital gain will accrue as a result of the compulsory acquisition. If the land was acquired after 19 September 1985, a capital gain may accrue or a capital loss may be incurred depending on the amount of the disposal proceeds and the cost of the land.
Rollover relief may be available where the land owner acquires a replacement asset in place of the asset which was compulsorily acquired.
Where consideration is received in respect of the disposal of an asset, subsection 160M(7) does not apply to assess any part of that consideration.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B426) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Capital Loss Transfers—Section 160ZP

PARA.TAB: Section 160ZP deals with the transfer of capital losses within corporate groups.

(a) The section places a limit on the CGT losses that can be transferred to group companies. This limit equates to the cost base of post 19 September 1985 shares and loans in the CGT loss company held by other group entities, determined at the time when the loss transfer notice under subsection 160ZP(7) is lodged with the Commissioner.

As part of the self assessment system the Commissioner has indicated that the ATO no longer requires notices and elections specified in the Act to be lodged until requested. This may create significant tax exposures for corporate groups.

Section 160ZP(7A) quite specifically applies the loss transfer limitation tests to the time the transfer notice is lodged with the Commissioner. Therefore if this notice is not lodged until some years after the relevant capital loss transfer has been utilised, the transfer may be limited by reference to the cost base of the group's investment in the loss company at that later time. In the intervening period, group loans may have been repaid or shares in the loss company redeemed, which may have significantly reduced the CGT cost base of the group's investment in the subsidiary that generated the capital loss.
This may retrospectively result in an earlier CGT loss transfer becoming ineffective.

Does the Minister not agree that for purposes of clarity and certainty subsection 160ZP(7A) should be amended as companies complying with the Commissioner's directive not to lodge notices and elections could inadvertently jeopardise earlier CGT loss transfers and the subsection provide no discretion to the Commissioner nor to the Courts in this regard.

(b) Section 160ZP also operates to reduce the CGT cost base of a corporate group's investment in a subsidiary, where a CGT loss is transferred from that subsidiary for utilisation by other group entities.

No indication has been given in the legislation of what CGT cost base reduction will be made when there are both pre and post 19 September 1985 investments in the CGT loss entity. It is understood that the Commissioner's approach is that the CGT cost base reduction is set totally against the post 19 September 1985 shares. However, this approach would appear inequitable as any reduction in the market value of a subsidiary resulting from the CGT loss which it has incurred would clearly impact on the value both pre and post September 1985 shareholdings in the subsidiary.
How can this problem be overcome? By a ruling or legislative amendment?

Given the total lack of legislative direction as to how to calculate this reduction to the CGT cost base of a group's direct and indirect investment in the CGT loss subsidiary and as to which specific asset this reduction should apply, it will be virtually impossible for members of complex corporate groups to effectively self assess their tax liabilities where there has been a CGT loss transfer within the group.

(c) In determining the quantum of the CGT loss transfer limitation in subsection 160ZP(7A), pre 19 September 1985 shares and debts owned by group entities in the CGT loss subsidiary are ignored. Therefore, where an investment in a subsidiary is exclusively by way of pre 19 September 1985 shares, then CGT losses generated by that subsidiary are unable to be transferred to other group entities and will effectively be quarantined within the subsidiary.

Given that section 160ZP was introduced to stop multiple capital loss transfers in respect of the same underlying CGT loss and capital losses in respect of pre 19 September 1985 assets are not allowed, this restriction is clearly inappropriate and requires legislative amendment.
Does the Minister agree?
Can the ATO address the undermentioned issues?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: (a) This question raises an issue which is being considered by the ATO. Appropriate recommendations will be made to the Government if it is considered the law needs to be amended.

(b) To develop a legislative formula for cost base reductions to deal with all the different circumstances that may arise in a corporate group would be extremely difficult and complicated and could even be impossible. It was for this reason that the relevant provision states—`. . . is reduced by such amount as is appropriate having regard to the direct or indirect interest of . . . ' the particular company in the subsidiary.

This approach allows the adjustment to be made in an equitable manner depending upon the particular circumstances of each case, including where pre and post September 1985 shares are involved. Accordingly, it is not considered that a ruling or amendment is needed.

(c) This issue was raised at the meeting of the Capital Gains Tax Subcommittee of the Taxation Liaison Group held on 4 December 1991 where the ATO undertook to review the issue. As the operation of the existing law in this respect is not unclear, the review has not been given a high priority and has not yet been completed.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B427) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 160ZZN and Section 160ZZNA

PARA.TAB: These sections deal with the transfer of an asset to a wholly owned company by an individual or trust and a partnership respectively, and require that the market value of the shares which are issued in respect of the assets transferred is substantially the same as the market value of the rolled over asset. However if there is an unrealised taxable capital gain in respect of the assets being rolled over into a newly incorporated company, the shares will invariably be worth less than the gross market value of the assets.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This requirement prevents taxpayers from claiming roll-over relief in respect of an asset transferred to a company in such a way that share values are altered with the effect that capital gains or capital losses can be manipulated. Where a company acquires an asset and issues shares as consideration for the acquisition, the requirement means that the company must issue shares that have a value substantially the same as the value of the asset.

Share values reflect many factors, including the extent of any franked and unfranked dividends which the company may or will have available for distribution. The ATO believes that, generally speaking, this requirement can be satisfied.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B427) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 160ZZNA—Election

PARA.TAB: Section 160ZZNA deals with the transfer of partnership assets to a wholly-owned company.

One of the conditions for rollover relief is that all of the ex-partners elect for the rollover relief to apply. It is not seen why this is necessary and that each partner should be free to choose whether or not to elect for a rollover to apply. Furthermore, in the case of large partnerships, it may be impossible to obtain the agreement of all partners for a rollover to apply.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This is a policy matter which is not under consideration by the ATO.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B428) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 160ZZO—Deemed Disposed Trigger

PARA.TAB: Section 160ZZO deals with the transfer of assets between group companies.

(a) Paragraph 160ZZO(2B) was repealed with the result that shares in group companies which were issued in consideration of assets acquired would no longer be able to have pre CGT status even though the assets that were transferred may have had that status.
(b) Paragraph 160ZZO(1)(h) deems there to be a breach of group relationship where, after the transferor is liquidated:
(i) a company that was a group company at the time of the rollover, disposes of a share in the transferee; or
(ii) the transferee issues shares to a person who was not a group company.
The trigger requirement in subparagraph (i) and (ii) are clearly too broad and require legislative amendment.

Even where the disposal of the share in the transferee is to another group company, subparagraph (i) will operate. In this case a disposal of the rolled-over asset is deemed even though it remains in the company group, i.e., there is no change in the ultimate underlying ownership of the asset.

Where the transferee is the ultimate holding company, e.g., a publicly listed company, and it issues shares, subparagraph (ii) would deem a disposal of the rolled-over asset albeit that there may not have been any significant change in the ownership of the company. This result is apparently unintended given the comments in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: (a) This issue was raised at the meeting of the Capital Gains Tax Subcommittee of the Taxation Liaison Group held on 4 December 1991 where the ATO undertook to review the issue. As the operation of the existing law in this respect is not unclear, the review has not been given a high priority and has not yet been completed.
(b) This question raises an issue which is being considered by the ATO. Appropriate recommendations will be made to the Government if it is considered the law needs to be altered.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B428) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Value Shifting—Division 19A

PARA.TAB: Division 19A deals with the transfer of assets between companies under common ownership and focuses on the manipulation of asset values within the corporate group that can lead to the artificial generation of a capital loss.

(a) If the division is to operate effectively, the reference to `consideration in respect of the disposal' in paragraphs 160ZZRD(2)(a) and (b) must mean actual consideration paid or given and the section should be amended accordingly. If this is not the case, then subsection 160ZD(2) would apply and hence a market value consideration would be deemed to have been paid. In that event, the pre-condition for section 160ZZRD will not have been satisfied and the division can never operate.

(b) An appropriately modified version of subsection 160ZZRD(2) should apply in respect of the operations of sections 160ZZRF and 160ZZRFA to ensure that on transfer of assets, market value is a shelter (`safe harbour' transfer value) under those sections. The explanatory memorandum indicates that this was the intent however this is not reflected in the legislation.

(c) Division 19A does recognise that there are two sides to any `value shifting' transaction. The value of the transferor is diminished and, correspondingly, the value of the transferee is increased. Section 160ZZRH therefore provides for a compensating cost base increase to direct and indirect equity investments in the transferee.
However, subsection 160ZZRD(2) limits the operation of section 160ZZRH to circumstances where:
a post 19 September 1985 asset is transferred below the lessor of its indexed cost base or market value; or
a pre 20 September 1985 asset is transferred below its market value.

Therefore there may be circumstances where an asset is transferred, such that the requirements of subsection 160ZZRD(2) are not satisfied and, hence, compensating cost base increases cannot be implemented under section 160ZZRH. However, sections 160ZZRF and 160ZZRFA may still operate to reduce the CGT cost base of direct equity and debt investments in the transferor. This runs contrary to the general outline of the provisions contained in the Explanatory Memorandum, which suggests that any cost base reductions should be tax neutral to a group.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: (a) This matter is addressed by amendments proposed by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 2) 1992, introduced into the House of Representatives on 2 April 1992 (see clause 47).

(b) and (c) The cost base reductions effected by sections 160ZZRF and 160ZZRFA are of `such amount (if any) as is reasonable' having regard to, inter alia, the amount of consideration in respect of the disposal of the first asset to the transferee [in the case of subsection 160ZZRF(2)] and the extent (if any) to which the market value of the share or loan is reduced as a result of the disposal of the first asset at the first asset disposal time [in the case of subsection 160ZZRF(3) and section 160ZZRFA]. Where the consideration received by the transferor in respect of the disposal of the first asset is equal to the market value of that asset, it will not be reasonable to make any cost base adjustment under those sections.
This `reasonableness' approach allows both cost base reductions and increases to be made in an equitable manner, depending upon the particular circumstances of each case.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B429) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 160ZZS

PARA.TAB: Section 160ZZS deals with the situation of where there has been a change of the underlying ownership of a pre 19 September 1985 asset.

(a) Since the section was introduced it has been widely recognised that it is badly drafted and it is unclear as to how it will apply. The problems caused by the drafting of section 160ZZS were recognised in a recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision (ref. Y59 91 ATC 502) when the member, Mr McMahon, stated:

`It will be noted that s.160ZZS is silent as to the date on which the property is deemed to be acquired and is silent as to the value at which it is to be taken in . . . . In Income Tax Ruling 2340, the Commissioner has purported to fill the gap in the legislation . . . .'

Income Tax Ruling IT 2340 states that the assets to which the section applies will be deemed to have been acquired for their market value at the time the majority of the beneficial interests changed. However, as mentioned above, this is not specified in the legislation and as such, the legislation should be appropriately amended.

(b) The section requires the Commissioner to be satisfied that the majority underlying interests in an asset be held by natural persons who, immediately before 20 September 1985, held majority underlying interests in an asset. If therefore there were no natural persons who held an interest before 20 September 1985, it would not be possible to satisfy the section. This would appear to be the case with government owned business enterprises as the government is not a natural person.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: These matters are addressed by amendments proposed by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 2) 1992, introduced into the House of Representatives on 2 April 1992 (see clause 50).
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B429) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Litigation Settlement/Damages

PARA.TAB: Given the breadth of the definition of asset in section 160A of the Act, and the fact that the draftsperson saw it necessary to specifically exclude certain forms of settlements and awards of damages in section 160ZB of the Act, it is strongly arguable that a plaintiff's claim against a defendant constitutes an asset, and accordingly, any settlement or award of damages may constitute consideration received by the taxpayer on disposal of that asset.

Notwithstanding that the settlement or award is intended to compensate the taxpayer for the loss that he has suffered, this loss will not, however, be recognised for the purposes of establishing the cost base of the asset, as the provisions of section 160ZH(9) are limited to situations where the taxpayer pays money or transfers property in respect of the acquisition of the asset. The settlement or award, less any incidental expenses, will therefore constitute a capital gain which (in the absence of any offsetting capital losses) will be included in the assessable income of the taxpayer.

Legislative amendment is therefore required to both recognise that the loss to which the settlement relates should reduce the taxable capital gain accordingly, and litigation settlements/damages payments in respect of assets, the disposal of which would otherwise be exempt from capital gains tax (e.g., pre 20 September 1985 assets, motor vehicles etc.), should correspondingly be exempt from capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO considers that where a litigation settlement or damages are received in respect of the disposal of an asset, the amount of the settlement or damages received constitutes consideration received as a result of or in respect of the disposal of that asset. Therefore, if the asset was acquired before 20 September 1985 or is a motor vehicle of the type mentioned in section 160A, no capital gain would accrue as a result of the receipt of the settlement or damages payment. If the asset was acquired after 19 September 1985, the amount of any capital gain or capital loss will depend on the amount of the disposal proceeds and the cost of the asset.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B429) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Threshold Amounts

PARA.TAB: The threshold amounts for listed personal use assets which cost $100 or less and any personal use assets sold for $5,000 or less, have not been increased since the CGT legislation was introduced albeit if they had been indexed they would have been approximately $150 and $7,500 respectively.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This is a policy matter which is not under consideration by the ATO.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B430) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Cost Base

PARA.TAB: It was announced in the 1991 Budget that current expenses such as interest will be included in the cost base for certain assets. However indexation does not apply to current expenses; nor are current expenses taken into account when calculating capital losses. Furthermore the cost base of personal use assets as well as non-personal use assets acquired prior to 21 August 1991 do not include current expenses. These anomalies should be corrected by legislative amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This is a policy matter which is not under consideration by the ATO.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B430) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Liquidations

PARA.TAB: (a) Section 160ZL concerns the return of capital on shares.

There is a view that section can apply to interim distributions made in the course of a liquidation. This is based on the view that an interim distribution cannot be taken as consideration for disposal of shares in a company in liquidation. This view seems to be inconsistent with the whole concept of a liquidation; surely once a liquidation has commenced any payment made by a liquidator is "in respect of" the pending disposal of the shares.

It is suggested that to overcome this problem section 160ZL be amended to state that an interim distribution by a liquidator is not a return of capital for the purposes of that section, but rather is the consideration related to the disposal of the share.

(b) Double taxation may result on a liquidation where property is distributed to the shareholder by the liquidator. If the property which is distributed was acquired post 19 September 1985 the company being liquidated would be assessed on any capital gain on disposal (if the disposal qualifies for rollover relief under section 160ZZO it would be the shareholder company which would be taxed on that gain upon the eventual disposal by that company).

However, the liquidation will also result in the shareholder company disposing of the shares it holds in the company being liquidated. The value of the property being distributed would be consideration from the disposal of the shares and hence may give rise to a capital gain. Although the amount of the gain would be reduced by the section 47 deemed dividend this may not completely eliminate the capital gain.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: (a) It is the ATO's view that section 160ZL does apply to an interim distribution made in the course of a liquidation because the shares have not been disposed of.
(b) This question raises a policy matter which is not under consideration by the ATO.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B430) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Capital Gains Legislative Challenge

PARA.TAB: Has the Minister or the ATO an answer to question on notice 1818?

With reference to the recent report in the Sun Herald of 22 March 1992, headed `Capital Gains Tax : would not stand up to legal test' in which the Technical Director of the Taxation Institute of Australia (Mr Geoff Petersson), is quoted as saying that recent High Court judgments would indicate that a successful challenge to the capital gains tax would be `an odds on certainty', and recognising that in order to over come this problem it would be necessary to re-enact these provisions as a separate tax in order to satisfy s.55 of the Constitution, will the Government take this opportunity to simplify both the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Capital Gains Tax legislation by introducing new legislation dealing with income tax and capital gains tax as separate, and simplified, measures.
Has the ATO sought Attorney-General's advice?
What would be the implications on revenue should such a challenge be successful?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This issue was addressed at the Committee's Hearing on Tuesday 21 April 1992.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B430) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Capital gains tax—record keeping and partnerships

PARA.TAB: Under the present CGT system, a number of tax implications arise at the time a partner enters or leaves a partnership which are far from simple. In a partnership when there is a sale of an asset from the group, it is not the partnership which recognises the gain or loss, but the individuals.
This makes it an onerous task of record keeping for partnerships.
Are there any plans on the part of the ATO to allow a simplification of the procedures necessary?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The ATO does not have any plans to change the procedures for partnerships.
Senator Watson asked:
1. How many senior officers of the Deputy Commissioner at second Commissioner level have received golden handshakes from the ATO in the last three years?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. One.
Senator Watson asked:
I refer to the ATO audit of superannuation fund returns in which it uncovered a general lack of understanding of the complex legislation and procedures in the industry.
1. What has the ATO done in the area of re-education of this area?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. The ATO is about to commence a market survey to determine what problems the industry has with the superannuation legislation. Using the market research results to identify the problems, an awareness strategy will be developed to inform and educate those associated with the industry. A closer working relationship with the ISC has been developed in order to quickly identify problems when they first surface in the industry.
In addition to this the ATO is writing a book for practitioners which will be published by 30 June 1992. Also, the ATO has held seminars and training for the industry and will continue to do so.
Senator Watson asked:
1. In December, 1990, 12,000 S169A requests were outstanding. Could we have a comparable figure for December, 1991? It is usual for requests to reach a peak in December.
2. What is the latest figure outstanding?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. Data is not available for the number of section 169A requests on hand in December 1991.
2. The latest figures available indicate there were 3,373 Section 169A requests on hand as at 13 March 1992.
Senator Watson asked:

Last August the ATO announced that it was reversing it's interpretation of laws relating to the sale of privately grown timber so that it would now be assessed as the sale of a capital asset. It told foresters the interpretation would be retrospective and that growers would be reassessed going back five years.
1. Will private forestry owners be given any special consideration in order to pay the back taxes owed?
2. Many of the private forestry owners have been urged to lodge appeals.
How many have done so?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. The ATO has not considered that non-compliance was deliberate and accordingly no penalty is to be imposed by way of culpability and every effort will be made to assist those affected with their taxation responsibilities.
2. No appeals have been lodged as yet.
Senator Watson asked:

SPEECH.PARA: EDR 45

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of a meeting attended by representatives of the Australian Taxation Office and the various tax accounting and legal bodies, this proposed Ruling is currently under review. Some indication should be given as to the progress of this review.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Following the meeting of 27 February 1992 with representatives of the banking and corporate sectors, the Tax Office agreed not to publish a final ruling on interest rate swaps until the banking industry had been given the opportunity to make a further, detailed submission. That submission, of about 70 pages, was lodged with the Tax Office on 14 April 1992. In the circumstances, it is expected the final ruling will be published very early in May 1992.
Senator Watson asked:
The penalty regime appears somewhat confusing and therefore I would like to use this forum to clarify the following example.
A husband and wife are in partnership. The husband does the books, lodges the returns. However, he chooses to omit some of the partnership income—deliberately and wilfully.
Given that the wife is an innocent beneficiary what would be the level of penalty against:
1. the wife; and
2. the husband.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Section 223 of the Income Tax Assessment Act (ITAA) provides for penalty tax to be imposed where a partner makes a false or misleading statement or omission relating to the affairs of the partnership (defaulting partner).
The defaulting partner is liable for penalty tax of up to double the tax that he or she and each of the `other partner' has escaped (Sec. 223(2)).

SPEECH.PARA: In the hypothetical situation given:

PARA.TAB: 1. the level of penalty in respect of the tax avoided applicable to the wife (`other partner') will of course depend on the circumstances. If she (the `other partner') did not know and could not be expected to know of the misstatement, additional tax in respect of primary tax avoided by her would be fully remitted, (i.e. no per annum or culpability component)

2. the husband (`defaulting partner') would be heavily penalised for the deliberate and wilful understatement of his share of partnership income. A typical penalty outcome (in the absence of further aggravating factors (e.g. second offence/delaying tactics) would be to require him to pay additional tax calculated on the basis of a `culpability' component in the order of 45 per cent flat of the tax avoided plus a `per annum' or interest component of 14.026 per cent p.a.
Senator Watson asked:
(a) What is the average time delay in getting evasion cases into court.

(b) Is not the Commissioner concerned that in some cases in the giving of evidence because of the time factor the memory of the investigating officers and others have been dimmed with the passage of time?
(c) To what extent does the ATO employ Queens Counsel's in public prosecutions involving the Crimes Act?
(d) Has the tax office encountered problems with the public prosecutors office not accurately doing their homework resulting in loss of revenue by failure to succeed?
(e) What is the success rate in terms of the Commissioner vis—vis taxpayer in prosecutions involving tax matters before the High Court, Federal Court, State Supreme Courts, Magistrate's courts?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: (a) Depending on the complexities of the case the time period will vary from investigation through to prosecution.
Generally:
(i) less complex cases being prosecuted under the Taxation Administration Act will usually be prosecuted in 3 to 12 months.
(ii) cases involving the Crimes Act which are relatively straightforward will be prosecuted in 6 to 12 months.
(iii) cases involving the Crimes Act which are more complex (e.g. which involve complex transactions or overseas evidence) can take anywhere from 2 to 4 years to prosecute.
(b) In the majority of Taxation cases the evidence is self explanatory and the documents themselves will prove the case.

With reference to the memory of Taxation Officers, all investigatory officers keep notes, records of interview and documentation to support the case. This may be used at any time to refresh their memory.

(c) The ATO has not directly employed Queens Counsel to prosecute. Any cases which require Queens Counsel are handled by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). The DPP is responsible for the hiring and payment of fees to Queens Counsel for criminal prosecutions.
(d) In the 9 months ended 31 March 1992 76 cases have been prosecuted by the DPP of which no cases have been dismissed. This is an indication that the cases are being handled properly by the DPP.

(e) In the 9 months ended 31 March 1992 the Taxation Office (in house prosecutions) and the DPP have prosecuted 363 taxpayers. Of these cases prosecuted 99% of taxpayers have been convicted (further details of these statistics are attached).
The majority of the cases handled by the Taxation Office are dealt with by the Magistrates Court. Few cases proceed to the Supreme or County Courts.
Senator Watson asked:

1. What progress has been made to clarify the "grey areas" of the law which has caused so much of the extra revenue to be collected from the top 100 companies in the recent audit of the top 100 companies?

2. I understand that the ATO has accepted the review findings on its large case audit program by the Pappas Carter Group. Could you please tell me what the ATO is doing with each of the following recommendations.
a. Segment the large corporate population and expand the sample size to the top 600 corporations.
b. Change its audit approach to be less revenue focused and more preventive orientated.
c. Improve the timeliness of rulings to clarify its position.
d. Improve organisational effectiveness
3. On audits, the report recommends the following. Will these be implemented?
a. Ongoing presence for corporations perceived to have a low level of compliance.
b. Periodic audits every two to five years to cover five to 10 key issues over two tax years.
c. Single year audits for small to medium sized clients with a perceived low level of compliance.
d. Issue based audits to help clarify important tax issues.
e. Tax strategy review to determine a corporations relative risk and the appropriate audit program.
4. What organisations restructuring will be necessary to meet the above objectives?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. Pappas, Carter, Evans and Koop (PCEK) in their review of the Large Case Program (LCP) suggested that the way to increase voluntary compliance was to narrow the gap between the ATO's interpretation and corporate taxpayers' interpretations of the law. They believed there were three ways in which the gap could be narrowed.

SPEECH.PARA: RULINGS

PARA.TAB: In a concentrated effort to expand the rulings process, the Commissioner has established a high level, ATO wide working party charged with the brief of recommending ways the Commissioner's perspective of the law in "grey areas" can be quickly communicated.

That working party has developed a number of proposals for further consideration. These proposals include better issue identification, possibilities for the earlier airing of issues, shorter timespans between identification and ruling publication, forms of rulings and appropriate levels of resourcing for the rulings program.
Final considerations will be completed within the next few weeks, after which implementation will proceed as quickly as possible.
2. At the outset it is important to note that, as stated in the PCEK report, many of the recommendations made correspond with the future direction for the Complex Audit Branch of the ATO.

2a. We note PCEK's comment that the large corporate group client base could be expanded to 600 groups with turnovers of $100 million or more. In fact to some extent the other areas of complex audit already include some of these.

The basic thrust—that to manage complex audit activity it is necessary to be better informed about the client base—is in accordance with ATO aims of using information systematically to determine the extent of non-compliance. The Complex Audit Business Management Committee has commissioned working parties for this purpose. One has as its principal objective the development of a profile of the complex audit population according to risk—using a macro approach to its analysis.
Another working party has developed a proposal for a national case selection policy based on ratio analyses to assist in the ranking of risk.

SPEECH.PARA: NB: It should be noted that the Complex auditable population reaches beyond the 600 corporate groups with turnovers of $100m plus. We need to ensure that corporate groups with smaller turnovers are also subject to risk analysis. Further, the above Committee has identified others to be included in complex audit's population. These extend beyond corporate groups to stand alone corporations and trusts (including joint ventures and superannuation funds), the tax planning industry, key individuals associated with major businesses, international transactions, and complex issues and industries (some of which may be project based).

PARA.TAB: 2b. We are establishing systems and processes to ensure that issues for clarification via the rulings process etc. are identified on a timely basis and are communicated as widely as possible. Auditors themselves will become more involved in the preparation of rulings and/or determinations.

Further, while the detection role of the audit process itself is readily apparent, its prevention role is often overlooked. In providing a taxpayer with the Commissioner's view of the law as it applies to a taxpayer's specific facts, a further result of an audit is that it often sets a precedent for future years.

2c. As stated in answer to the first question, there is a high level, ATO wide working party charged with recommending options to ensure the Commissioner's perspective of the law is quickly communicated.
As noted, it is expected that the relevant working party's final recommendations will be made in the very near future.
2d. PCEK proposed 4 organisational initiatives:
i.developing pools of technical expertise;
ii.a different approach to team management and composition;
iii.regular evaluation of teams; and
iv.reassessment of existing plans for decentralisation, modernisation and training.

Pools of expertise or teams of specialists have long been a feature of the Audit program. We strongly support the development of pools of technical expertise and have moved to build on, refine and co-ordinate the specialisation that already exists in the Audit area.

One of PCEK's recommendations is for a case co-ordinator to participate in the settlement process, to ensure objectivity in that process. We are confident that , as stated in the guidelines for the conduct of taxpayers and taxation auditors, the view case managers put to taxpayers is the view of the ATO and not merely their own. However, we note there is concern amongst taxpayers and their advisers which appears to translate into often drawn out settlement processes.

We have decided, therefore, upon an independent review process to speed up the settlement process. Taxpayers and/or their representatives will be able to make their own submissions to a review group made up of 3 senior officers, including an SES officer. The review process will not occur as a matter of course and will focus mainly on technical issues.

Further, a number of upgraded positions (Senior Officers Grade A) to take on some of the tasks identified for a case co-ordinator by PCEK are soon to be advertised. The use of these positions plus the implementation of quality assurance measures and proposals for independent review bodies, nationally, will combine to ensure Pappas Carter's recommendations on performance evaluation are incorporated into normal practice.

It is important to note the PCEK caveat about its findings and conclusions, i.e. its brief was to examine the LCP only. Its recommendations on other areas were necessarily made without full knowledge of the context of the issues they may face.

Our decentralisation program is aimed at breaking up over-large CBD branch offices into more dispersed offices of a manageable, human kind. Such offices have proved to be more efficient and provide a better platform for improving client focus. It is recognised that short term dislocations will occur and these are being addressed. For example, in evidence before the Committee, Mr Mitchell addressed our approach to concerns raised by Senator Watson about the impact of decentralisation on-going audits under the large case program. Evidence before the Committee also referred to the approaches being taken through, for example, the introduction of specialist cells to harness ATO experience and expertise in dealing with complex advising matters.

Turning to audit modernisation, the Modernisation process is indeed long term—10 years, and as explained during the hearings hard choices about scheduling and priorities needed to be made. Decisions on the scheduling of audit modernisation and the use of interim arrangements are being addressed in that context.

A training officer was recently dedicated to Complex Audit and is undertaking the process of identifying the on-going training needs of audit staff. As established, further training requirements will be addressed.
