3a.-3e. The report adopted a number of methodologies that were being developed within the ATO. Many of the recommended audit products are tools that have been used by complex auditors for many years.
One of the relatively new products is the tax strategy review.

We believe that proper risk assessment shows that a significant audit presence must continue in large corporate groups, but new strategies and new approaches need to be implemented to promote a balance of audit activities that maintain a Complex Audit coverage in high risk areas. In short, we need to use new approaches to maintain or expand coverage in this area, while at the same time making resources available to other risk areas. A proper mix of these products should enable that to happen.

Beside the benefit of being up to date with corporate risk profiles via the strategy reviews, an added benefit will be the timely identification of "grey" issues for clarification via the rulings process etc.

It is intended that the proposals for the various audit methodologies go through the internal and external consultative processes before implementation. All of the products referred to in the question will be part of the total audit products package and will be implemented.

4. Unless the Senator's question is not fully understood, this question and that in 2(d) are considered to be on the same matter, and hence the answer provided to question 2(d) above is applicable here.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxation Administration

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:
1. If an officer makes a mistake during an audit and the taxpayer picks this up and has it corrected what action is taken against the officer involved?

2. Under the present system of self-assessment the onus of proof is all on the taxpayer. If the ATO and the taxpayer are working together to build a better Australia, should not the ATO accept part of the burden of proof?

3. Putting the onus of proof on the Commissioner would not be helpful for the taxpayer would sit back and do nothing, but do you not agree that a better system would be one whereby at the very least a greater emphasis should be placed on the care needed to be exercised when preparing and issuing amended assessment, in particular asset betterment statements?
The preparer of the statement should discuss the statement with the taxpayer before issuing the amended assessment. Do you not agree?
4. Do you not think a fairer system would be that the taxpayer should be able to recover all or part of his costs where:

SPEECH.PARA: their objection is allowed in full;
the assessment contains mistakes made by the Commissioner or his officers;
the amended assessable income is decreased?
Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. The action taken would depend on the circumstances of the incident. For example, action taken could range from guidance and training to improve the officer's skills at one end of the scale, to formal counselling at the other end.
2. The income tax law provides that the burden of proving an assessment is excessive lies with the taxpayer.
This provision reflects the principle that the facts in relation to income and expenses are facts which are, or should be, peculiarly within the knowledge of the taxpayer.

3. In the Audit process, it is the policy of the ATO to raise progressively with a taxpayer the issues being addressed in the audit and to give the taxpayer every opportunity to disclose or clarify the factual situation.

Before raising any assessments as part of the audit process, it is also ATO policy to discuss the findings of the audit with the taxpayer and his/her advisers and to consider any representations from them on the relevant issues and findings of the audit.

As part of the current ATO audit procedure tax auditors discuss the statement of source and application of funds with the taxpayer during the collection of information to prepare the asset betterment statement and also when the statement is finalised, if the taxpayer is willing to do so.
4. This question raises policy issues which are essentially for the Government.

The income tax laws presently provide for the payment of interest to a taxpayer where an objection is allowed or partly allowed. Interest is paid where there is found to be an overpayment of tax which is to be refunded to the taxpayer or applied against any liability of the taxpayer to the Commonwealth.

In many cases where amendments are made in consequence of an objection, they are made because the taxpayer provides more information/ documentation or explains the facts more fully after an objection is lodged. Frequently this information is not available to the Commissioner when the assessment is made.

The question whether costs should be awarded to taxpayers where assessments made by the Commissioner are allowed in full by the Commissioner or amended by the Commissioner to correct errors made by the Commissioner has to be considered in this context.

SPEECH.PARA: Publicity of the Audit of the TOP 100 Companies

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson asked:

I would like to express some concern about the Commissioner's implication in his publicity via media releases that `tax avoidance was widespread among large companies' (AFR, 1 July 1991). Similar comments were made during the Martin Committee Inquiry into the Australian Banking Industry.

In 1989, the ATO alleged international profit shifting by banks. After further inquiry, a public ATO report to that committee on 13 May 1991 (Mr Vince Mitchell) stated "the major trading banks had not used tax havens to shift profits derived from the lending activities in Australia".
1. Does the ATO have a statement of ethics that they abide by?
2. If so, what are they?
3. If not, do you not think that it would be a good idea to have a statement implemented and then abided by?
4. Do you not agree that to portray companies as cheats is unethical?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: This question appears to be based on the comments by Mr Bob Bryant of the Corporate Tax Association in his letter to the editor of the Financial Review, published on 26 February 1992.

The statement that `tax avoidance was widespread among large companies' (AFR 1 July 1991) is not a statement of the Commissioner's—rather one by the journalist based, it would seem, on the large dollar results generated by audits into the large corporate groups.

That article dealt with the results of the program to then and how they exceeded expectations, some background on the Large Case Program and the observation that while there was some friction between the ATO and the large corporates when the Large Case audit inquiry commenced, things had subsequently settled down.

Although the ATO submitted to the banking inquiry details of bank involvement in shifting their own profits offshore and the promotion of tax effective financing and investment, a perusal of Hansard (of 22.8.91) and the ATO submission provides no evidence that the ATO has made any comments to the inquiry similar to `tax avoidance was widespread among large corporates'.

While that part of the submission quoted here (and by Mr Bryant) of course deals with only the major trading banks and only their use of tax havens (by no means all the Top 100 companies nor all forms of tax avoidance), it was our belief then—and is still today—that tax avoidance practices are not widespread amongst large corporations.
To answer the specific questions—

1.-4. In accordance with the co-operative environment we in the ATO have continued to foster with our clients, we took the initiative to develop (after extensive consultation with external parties), a set of guidelines for the conduct of taxpayers and taxation auditors. These were first published in late 1989 and revised with effect from 1 July 1991. A copy of the guidelines is freely available from tax offices.

The guidelines recognise that dealings between the ATO, taxpayers and their representatives should be open between all parties and conducted according to publicly articulated principles so that the obligations of each party can be understood and fulfilled in a reasonable and sensible way.
We believe that these guidelines act as a code of ethics or an agreed code of conduct for tax officers, taxpayers and their representatives.

More broadly, a draft Code of Ethics for ATO staff was circulated at the March 1992 ATO Corporate Planning Conference. Following that, more work has been commissioned to, in particular, include practical examples as a guide for staff prior to the Code being finalised.
Finally, as explained above, the Commissioner has not stated that cheating is widespread amongst companies.
Senator Watson (Hansard page no. B438) asked:

1. Can the Senate Committee be assured that in circumstances where a taxpayer is subject to audit, and the ATO debits a taxpayer, that same taxpayer automatically receives all consequential credits. Has this always been the practise? If not, from what date was the change made?

SPEECH.PARA: Voluntary Disclosures

PARA.TAB: 2. Where a taxpayer makes a voluntary disclosure in relation to the understatement of income or the overstatement of expenses, what is the last date acceptable to the Tax Office in terms of the disclosure qualifying as a voluntary disclosure? e.g., at the date of notification of an audit; once the audit has actually commenced with the officers on the taxpayer's premises etc.

3. The taxpayer in relation to self assessment, particularly corporations and superannuation funds, find themselves in an intermediate situationin relation to self assessment. I refer to the need for a change in legislation to cover the case law precedent where, in assessing the number of years a taxpayer's review, a year in which there was a nil assessment is not deemed to be a year of assessment. While it may be the intention that the ATO goes back 4 years in addition to the year under review, the precedent as enshrined in case law does not support this practice.

4. The rules for self assessment need to be handled in a particularly sensitive manner, since there could well be a ground-swell of resentment particularly by people who are tax illiterate and who lack clerical and arithmetical skills. Can the Committee receive an assurance that the proposals relating to the changes in self assessment will not only be tabled for Parliament but be subject to a review of a committee of Parliament?

5. I refer to a recent prosecution of a taxpayer who was given an undertaking at the time of audit that if he assisted investigative officers by voluntary disclosure, such prosecution would not take place.
Is this not only a breach of trust, and what are the rules relating to disclosure and prosecution?

This action was brought by the Director of Public Prosecutions. In view of the fact that a verbal promise was made by ATO staff not to commence prosecution action against the taxpayer, why was the taxpayer's file subsequently referred to the DPP? It is felt that such a practice by the ATO is regressive in view of the fact that it is attempting to encourage voluntary disclosure by taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. During the course of an audit if a taxpayer is found to have omitted income then credits relating to that income will be taken into account in calculating the taxpayers liability. This has always been standard ATO practice.

2. In broad terms, voluntary disclosure concessions will be available to a taxpayer until such time as the ATO makes contact with the taxpayer or his or her representative, e.g. direct inquiries of the taxpayer, an initial interview prior to audit, a request for a statement of assets and liabilities, or an audit of his or her liability to other taxes.

3. As noted in the question, it is the practice of the ATO to treat taxpayers with nil assessments on an equivalent basis to other taxpayers. In these circumstances an amendment to the law is not seen as a priority issue.

4. The reasonable care test to be introduced as part of the self assessment system will not ask taxpayers to exercise any more skill than their particular circumstances will allow. A person who is tax illiterate or lacks clerical and arithmetical skills will not be penalised under self assessment if they make an honest attempt to get their assessments right.

The proposed self assessment system has been the subject of two public discussion papers (December 1990 and August 1991) which invited submissions from interested parties. It has also been developed in full consultation with legal and accounting representatives as well as other interested groups.
It is a matter for the Government to decide whether a Committee of Parliament should consider the self assessment system in addition to the consultation which has already taken place.

5. The secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act preclude the Commissioner from disclosing the taxation affairs of particular taxpayers. However in relation to voluntary disclosures and prosecution Income Tax Ruling 2246 in paragraph 6.1e(ii) states, inter alia,:

SPEECH.PARA: ". . . where a person has made a voluntary disclosure prosecution action should not be taken. . .

PARA.TAB: Income Tax Ruling 2246 has been reviewed with the assistance of The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). DPP has advised that paragraph 6.1e(ii) overstates the position. The fact that a person has made a voluntary disclosure does not necessarily preclude a prosecution. However, it is a factor to be taken into account in deciding whether the public interest requires criminal proceedings. The DPP has advised that, as a general rule, it is unlikely that a person who has genuinely made a voluntary disclosure will be prosecuted, unless the offence exhibits a significant degree of criminality. The decision whether to prosecute in such cases will be made on the advice of the DPP.
Senator Watson asked:

1. I refer to the abuse of the withholding tax provisions by migrants. In its final report, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled "Efficiency Audit of the Australian Taxation Office International Profit Shifting" certain recommendations were made directed to migrant tax avoidance.
Following that report the ATO initiated a National Project to accurately determine the level of taxpayer compliance with all areas of the withholding tax legislation including overseas beneficiaries.
Can the Minister or the ATO officials detail to the Committee the level of compliance in the ATO's evaluation to date together with other observations derived from the national project audit?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The Government response to the Standing Committee Report is expected to be tabled soon.

Withholding tax audits have commenced and the results of audits conducted so far, confirm our advice to the Standing Committee that the risk to revenue from overseas beneficiaries' schemes is nowhere near the level that was being suggested. The audit project is still in progress and more detailed evaluation is not available.
Senator Watson asked:
1. How does the Tax Office intend to ensure that Tax Agents who are targeted for special auditing treatment do not have their personal or business reputations permanently damaged?

2. What compensation is to be made available to Tax Agents who lose clients as a result of the Tax Office's audit strategy (especially where there is found to be no audit adjustments that are out of the ordinary)?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. Each year a range of projects are selected in industries that have taxpayers with potentially high risks to revenue. The audits of the selected industries are Project Based Audits.

Tax agents have been selected as part of the ATO's project based audit activity. Accordingly, Tax Agents will receive the same treatment as all other industries. Taxation Officers are trained and committed to conducting audits in an efficient and professional manner.
The tax office carries out quality assurance checks of audits conducted and takes necessary action to improve the quality of audits where it is found necessary to do so.

2. The tax agent's clients would not be aware that a tax agent is or has been audited unless the tax agent was prosecuted and details of the prosecution were published or unless the tax agent advised them. In the event that a tax agent was prosecuted then depending on the seriousness of the offence(s) the tax agent would usually be deregistered. In the circumstances it is not considered that the question of compensation is at issue.
Senator Watson asked:

1. In a recent speech by the Commissioner of Taxation to the Australian Institute of Criminology, the comment was made that the Australian Taxation Office is unsure of the number of taxpayers who are opting out of the system and that there are a large number of so-called "illegals" who are not disclosing their income. The Australian Taxation Office should indicate what steps are currently being taken to bring these people within the tax net.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1. In relation to taxpayers opting out of the system, the Commissioner was referring specifically to individual taxpayers. In the Commissioner's speech he did go on to say that we already have substantial mechanisms in place to monitor and to achieve compliance in this segment. These include:
—the Pay As You Earn System under which tax is deducted at source and matching information supplied to the Tax Office;
—the general Income Matching System, which compares income information with details supplied in tax returns and reports those who have not lodged a tax return but probably should;

—Employment Declaration processing which enables the ATO to verify the validity of employee information provided to employers and ensures that details supplied on group certificates at a later date (including tax file number) are accurate; and
—the general Tax File Number system.
Through these mechanisms the ATO is able to detect those who do not lodge a tax return and probably should.
2. The "illegals" referred to in the Commissioner's speech includes:
—those persons engaged in criminal business pursuits which generate assessable income;
—high profile persons who for various reasons attract the interest of law enforcement agencies; and
—those who because of their status and possible criminal business connections merit particular attention.
Strategies developed for 1991/92 to deal with this market segment include:
—examine alternative methodologies for dealing with various criminal business sectors within the market segment;
—increase input and participation in joint task forces (with other law enforcement agencies) particularly for cases with significant revenue implications.
—actively seek increased cooperation with law enforcement agencies and access to criminal intelligence databases; and
—continue to foster and improve liaison with law enforcement agencies through increased attendance at and participation in seminars, conferences, debriefings and meetings.
Senator Watson asked:
With reference to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) issuing letters requesting information for the purpose of conducting training guarantee audits:
(1) How many letters are to be dispatched?
(2) How many training guarantee audits does the ATO intend to undertake?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ATO intends to dispatch 3,000 training guarantee letters.

(2) The 3,000 Information Requests are audits in their own right. In some cases it will be necessary to request further documentation to substantiate claims made and could result in field audit activity.
Senator Watson (Hansard page No. B433) asked:

I have in my possession a copy of a letter sent by the Commissioner to the Chairman of the Australian Finance Conference late last year asking the Chairman to direct his members that officers of the ATO would vigorously attack any arrangements involved the possibility that some companies were not paying their full amounts of tax assessable for vehicles that had been let on lease.
1. What other forms of communication did the ATO send to members of the Australian Finance Corporation?
2. What about those leasers of vehicles who are not members of the Australian Finance Corporation? Were any of these informed of the Commissioner's attitude in this matter?
3. What are the normal information disseminating procedures followed by the ATO when it wishes to target a certain practice which it wishes taxpayers to voluntarily correct?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: 1.-2. In addition to the letter to the Australian Finance Corporation, the issue was also dealt with at the Tax Liaison Group (TLG) meeting on 27 November 1991. The Commissioner told members of the TLG that by raising this issue in the TLG forum that it should broadcast the matter to a wider audience.

3. The communication strategy adopted to publicise a particular issue would depend on the nature of the issue and the target audience. The issues can range from an unacceptable tax practice in a particular industry to publicising achievements and successes of the ATO. The general approach would be to incorporate a combination of media releases, seminars, speeches and appropriate documentation which may include letters to industry representatives.
Senator Watson asked:

The ATO has embarked on a program of rationalisation which will see the number of branches increase from 16 to 25 over the next 2 years. For every extra office established there are greater costs of administration.
What is the additional cost in setting up additional offices compared with operating out of central office?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: There are no additional staff associated with the establishment of additional branch offices; in fact, the total number of staff in the ATO is declining. In addition, decentralised offices are less costly to operate than large centralised offices.
At the present time, the ATO in most central locations is badly fragmented—currently about 120 buildings. This fragmentation is extremely costly and inefficient.
In establishing a new branch office there is an initial once-only administrative cost of $900,000 to $1,000,000 for:
. equipment;
. training;
. library and stores material;
. general running costs; and
. staffing costs associated with the set-up of the office.
However, following the establishment of a new decentralised office, ongoing operating costs have been found to be less because of:
. increased efficiencies;
. reduced rent;
. reduced overheads; and
. reduced staffing needs for comparable workloads.
These ongoing savings have been traditionally achieved in past decentralisation exercises.
Senator Watson asked:
1. I refer to the Tasmanian pilot scheme offering a one stop shop for help with business tax.
What are the significant issues to emerge from this pilot project?

2. I refer to the pilot program centred on Tasmania, whereby the Business Tax Services Group have organised a one-stop shopping concept for tax agents who have Fringe Benefits, PAYE, Sales Tax and Prescribed Payments Tax.
Could the committee be advised of the success of this program to date and whether this concept will be extended to other states?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:
1. The pilot has been operating since mid February in the Hobart office and an extensive process has been put in place to evaluate the outcomes from both the client and the ATO point of view.

PARA.TAB: The first phase of the project included research among ATO staff and clients and looked at the requirements for technical support to allow a "one stop shop" concept to operate.

Research among clients indicated a need to know who to contact in the ATO and the prevention of being passed from one point to another for advice. Those involved in small business also wanted better access to information, and it is an aim of the pilot to address this perception.

Research to date indicates that the ATO is able to re-organise the way we provide service by having staff work in teams which look after the needs of a particular group of clients. The level of service will be greatly enhanced when modernisation of the ATO computer systems is complete.

2. While Tax Agents are now able to deal with the one area for a clients business affairs, the Business Tax Services pilot is also aimed at those businesses wishing to contact the ATO direct for advice. The pilot program is particularly aimed at the small business operator.

The Tasmanian pilot has been operating since mid February and to date all responses from both tax agents and business clients have been of a positive nature. The first report in an extensive evaluation process will be delivered in July and will address key questions from both the Client and the ATO perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: RELEASE OF NAMES IN AAT CASES

PARA.TAB: I would like to bring to your attention a problem that has been for tax workers, advisers and researchers and tax publishers for some 40 years.
Because taxation hearings with the AAT are held in private, the publishing of these reports occur under two different names by the two major publishing firms, CCH and Butterworths.

The solution to the problem lies in allowing the AAT taxation hearings to be held in public, unless the applicant opts for a private hearing, instead of the other way around. Therefore the hearing of taxation matters and publication of taxation decisions would be in conformity with virtually all other matters in which the AAT has jurisdiction.
Senator Watson asked:
Is the ATO investigating this issue?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: When taxation hearings were heard at the Taxation Boards of Review, such hearings were conducted in private unless the person requesting the review sought a public hearing.

When the jurisdiction of the Taxation Boards of Review was transferred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in 1986, the privacy of taxation affairs afforded to a person under the then existing review procedures was preserved by the enactment of section 14ZF of the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

The ATO is aware of the difficulties which lie in the identification for publishing and reference purposes of decisions of the Tribunal published by Butterworths and CCH. However, it maintains a long held view that existing review procedures in taxation matters before the Tribunal ensure that proceedings before the Tribunal in relation to the review of objection decisions or extension of time applications will be heard in private unless the person requesting the review or making the application wishes otherwise. The ATO holds the view that in taxation matters before the Tribunal the principle of confidentiality should be maintained and that the anonymity of the taxpayer and other persons concerned (other than the Commissioner) should be maintained and that the identity of parties (other than the Commissioner) should not be disclosed. It is considered that many taxpayers prefer an administrative review by the Tribunal where privacy is assured rather than a judicial review in public.

SPEECH.PARA: NON-ASSESSABLE/NON-DEDUCTIBLE BONDS—"ONE NATION PACKAGE

PARA.TAB: In the Prime Minister's "One Nation" statement on page 189, the Prime Minister outlined concessions in relation to the issuing of non-assessable/ non-deductible bonds. As a result of this statement there have been concerns in the market place in relation to various components of the concession.

The Prime Minister in his "One Nation" statement of the 27 February, 1992 outlined a proposed amendment to the taxation laws to provide the facility for non-assessable/non-deductible bonds to be issued to finance certain new transport and electricity projects. The interest on the bonds would be neither deductible to the issuer nor assessable to the lender.
Senator Watson asked:

1. A project would be required to produce assessable income for a period of not less than 30 years to qualify as an eligible project and, therefore, able to issue eligible bonds, yet the maximum term of such bonds is 10 years.
(a) What is the purpose of this differential? and,
(b) If the Government only wishes to allow this concession for 10 years, why not allow bonds, which could run up to the life of the project, with concessions only for the first 10 years?
2. The concession requires that the project be owned, operated and used by the issuing company for the purpose of producing assessable income for 30 years.
(a) Does the concession lapse if the project is subsequently sold? and,
(b) What of projects that are operated by a sub-contractor (which is not uncommon in some large scale projects)?

3. An investor in an eligible bond may incur expenses, either directly or indirectly (at least, as viewed by a tax auditor), in earning this non-assessable income. Ordinarily, for a taxpayer to claim a tax deduction for an expense, that expense must not be incurred in earning a tax exempt income.
(a) Could you confirm that expenses which may, conceivably, be viewed as attributable to earning this income will be tax deductible? and,
(b) If such expenses are non-deductible, where is the concession since the issuer is deprived of a tax deduction for the interest?
4. Finally, will any gains made on the disposal of such bonds, which reflect their tax exempt status, be tax exempt? If not, why not?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: These questions will be answered by the Department of the Treasury.
Senator Watson asked:
The amendment to Section 122J to remove the "on tenement" condition was made effective from 1 July, 1991.

Is not this date unfair, as the industry is working under a system of self-assessment and audits. The mining industry has been under the impression that off-tenement exploration was deductible before 1 July, 1991, now it is not.

It has always been believed by industry (and the Tax Office despite the denials of the current generation) that preliminary exploration expenditure was deductible and investment in exploration in this country was based on that understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Until the changes made by Taxation Laws Amendment (No 3) Act 1991, general mining exploration or prospecting expenditure was only immediately deductible if it was on a mining tenement. This contrasted with the treatment of exploration or prospecting for quarrying materials, or for petroleum or gas. There, an outright deduction was available under provisions which never required that the exploration or prospecting be on a mining tenement.

Before the legislative change took effect from 1 July 1991, the ATO had never agreed that preliminary expenditure incurred by a mining or exploration company before the acquisition of a mining tenement was deductible. The ATO's view of the deductibility of general mining exploration and prospecting expenditure is set out in Taxation Ruling IT2642.
Senator Watson asked:

How many people are in the internal audit division? Is it headed by persons with adequate tertiary qualifications and/or internal audit training experience? Can you outline some of the internal audit commitments covering internal audit?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: There are 36 people in the Internal Audit Section.
Yes; the Director, Internal Audit and the 4 Chief Internal Auditors in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth are suitably qualified through tertiary studies and/or substantial relevant experience.
The Internal Audit Training Program involves a basic course run in house for all Internal Audit staff, plus advanced courses run externally, including by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO).
Senator Watson asked:
I would like to raise an issue which I initially raised during the debate on TLAB No. 3 1991 late last year. Satisfactory answers were not received at the time.
I draw your attention to the situation where apparently Local Authorities are liable for payment of Fringe Benefit Tax on Camp Allowances paid to employees.

As you are aware, in a large rural Local Authority, it is essential for employees to camp on job sites, for which they are paid $10.00 per day in accordance with the award. The council provides necessary camp equipment/accommodation, but does not provide food. Employees would generally spend 3 or 4 nights per week in camp and return to their home for the remaining nights.
1. Do you consider that there needs to be clarification of when the local authorities will need to pay FBT or when it is to be treated as a travelling allowance?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: Where a camp allowance or other similar allowance is paid for the purpose of compensating an employee for additional expenses incurred, and for any other disadvantages suffered, by reason that the employee is required to live away from home in order to perform his/her duties of employment, it will be a living-away-from-home allowance fringe benefit as defined under the fringe benefits tax law. Whether a camp allowance is a living-away-from-home allowance fringe benefit and subject to the fringe benefits tax laws, or a travelling allowance and subject to the income tax laws, is a matter to be determined on the facts of each case.

In relative terms, there have not been a significant number of inquiries on the treatment of camp allowances. Nevertheless, it is intended to include guidelines, as part of the current review and redrafting of Taxation Ruling IT 2030, that will assist taxpayers in determining whether an allowance such as a camp allowance is a living-away-from-home allowance fringe benefit or a travelling allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: VETERANS' AFFAIRS—Rulings (Legislative Services)

PARA.TAB: In November 1987, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in South Australia ruled that compensation payments made for incapacity to work through a service cause under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees') Act 1971 were of a like nature to disability payments made under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and were tax exempt under paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (3) of section 23AD (3) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (ITAA).

In February 1992, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) reversed the decision and now states these payments are not of a like nature and payments made to ex-service personnel under the Commonwealth Employees' (Rehabilitation and Compensation) Act 1988 are taxable.
Senator Watson asked:
1. What was the basis for this decision reversal?
2. How can the ATO rule that injuries are not of a like nature?
3. Will the ATO consider reverting to its former ruling and admit that these payments are of a like nature and therefore not taxable?

SPEECH.PARA: Answer:

PARA.TAB: The secrecy provisions of the income tax law preclude answers being given in respect of a particular case. The following general comments can, however, be made.

The income tax law specifically exempts from tax, payments of pension made under section 70 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. There is no exemption for regular compensation payments for incapacity to work made under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees') Act 1971 or the Commonwealth Employees' (Rehabilitation and Compensation) Act 1986; those payments are subject to income tax. In this situation, the assessability of the payments turns on the legislation under which the payments are made and not on the type of injury.
A decision to reverse an earlier decision may be made when the earlier decision is incorrect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for the table. As no-one can tell me where this table is in my loose leaf unindexed document, I think that we will have to find some better way of dealing with some of these responses. I will refer to the document that I have been handed. It lists offences involving manipulation of the tax system—Crimes Act, forgery, imposition, and computer offences. It lists Taxation officers as beneficiaries and other non-officer beneficiaries. I assume that all the offences were perpetrated by Taxation officers?
—Yes.

—There were nine cases in which officers were beneficiaries and which were referred as criminal cases to the DPP. Two cases are described as awaiting DPP action. Charges laid by the DPP—six. In regard to court cases in progress, there is none where the officer is the beneficiary and one where the others are the beneficiary. Convictions obtained, four; cases dismissed, two; dismissals or resignation from the Australian Taxation Office, five; and other disciplinary taken or pending. I think we had the amazing admission that, even where there had been a conviction, an officer could still remain as a member of the Public Service. Can we have that confirmed?

—I am advised that the law does not require that an officer convicted of a criminal offence be dismissed from the Australian Public Service, but in fact only three officers convicted since July 1990 remain in the ATO. One of them is a very recent case in which disciplinary action is in train. I am not pre-judging that the person involved will leave the Tax Office; the matter is not resolved, so we cannot conclude one way or the other. The second case involves a junior officer convicted of theft of some stores. The third case involves an officer found to be in private possession of cannabis during investigation of another matter.
—Let me get that right. Out of those officers convicted in that period, three had criminal convictions and are still employed by the Australian Tax Office. Is that right?
—Let us put it in perspective. One officer was found to be in private possession of cannabis. I have to say that I do not know—
—I did not ask for moral judgment. Was he convicted?

—Can I answer? I know Senator Bishop would love to be over here answering questions, but she is currently over there asking them. Let us continue on that basis. It is clearly a nice headline-chasing question to ask, `Are there three people found guilty of a criminal offence still employed by the Tax Office?'. I know Senator Bishop would love a quick answer so that maybe she can get a headline tomorrow.
—Just a truthful one will do.

—Senator Bishop throws a lot of allegations around. I have given her truthful information, and I am about to repeat it. Because I do not want to give it in the terms that suit her little mind, she will have to take it in the way I give it, but it will still be accurate. An officer found to be in private possession of cannabis remains in the Public Service. If Senator Bishop thinks that is a scandal, that is a matter for her moral judgment. There is one person against whom disciplinary action is in process. People cannot be dismissed without that. Whether that person will remain in the Public Service is not yet a matter for judgment. I do not know any details about the third matter, but I am advised that a junior officer convicted of theft of some stores remains in the Australian Tax Office.

—This is why these things take so long. Firstly, was the person found in possession of cannabis convicted of such possession? Under the law, that is still a criminal offence. If Senator McMullan wishes to change the law, then he can go about doing it. At the moment, it is a criminal offence. Secondly, is the officer subject to disciplinary action? Was he or she convicted of a criminal offence? Yes or no? If so, for what? Thirdly, does the person who was convicted of theft and who is still employed constitute the third of three people convicted of criminal offences who are still employed in the Australian Tax Office? Yes or no?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Burns)—Senator Bishop, you can ask the question; you cannot require the answer you want.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very extraordinary question. I have said, and I will read it very slowly: only three officers convicted since July 1990 remain in the ATO. That is the third time I have said that.
—Convicted. Good.

—I am glad if it has got through. That remains the case and that remains the circumstance under which it has taken place. Those remain the cases in question. As I said, it is the third time I have said it.
—Of what was the second person who is still under disciplinary action convicted?
—I understand it is a question of theft.

—So we have two thieves and one smoker of cannabis who are still employed by the Australian Tax Office. Does Senator McMullan think that will make the Australian public feel satisfied? Why is it that the Government continues to have people convicted of theft employed by the Australian Tax Office, dealing with Australian taxpayers' confidential files, including the sorts of matters that we are going to deal with in the rest of this report where we have leaks, reports given, and Senator McMullan does not even read them?
—I have nothing to say.

—After criminal convictions, we have at category No. 2 illegal information disclosure. We have three people with criminal cases referred; one case awaiting DPP action; two with charges laid by the DPP; two convictions obtained; and two dismissals or resignations. Does that mean that all people who are convicted of illegal information disclosure have been dismissed?
—As a matter of logic, it must, yes, and it does.

—That is good. We get the situation where people who are convicted of theft do not get sacked but those who are convicted of illegal information disclosure do. The next category is administrative offences, Crimes Act, imposition, et cetera: category A, incorrect expenses claimed; category B, false declarations to gain employment. Thirteen criminal offences in category A and five in category B have been referred to the DPP. Three charges have been laid by the DPP; one court case is in progress; and three convictions have been obtained. That apparently means that out of 13 cases referred, only three proceeded. There were three convictions obtained and two dismissals. With regard to incorrect expenses claims, which is given as an example of an administrative offence, where there were three convictions, only two have been dismissed. Where is the other person?
—The officer is checking the exact details.

—While we are finding out where the other person is, the fourth category is theft of Australian Tax Office property, where there were two cases referred, two charges laid, two convictions obtained and no dismissals. Presumably they are the two who are still employed. Going back to category one, where there were nine cases referred, six charges laid, four convictions obtained and five dismissals or resignations, were the four people against whom convictions were obtained, which were cases involving manipulation of the tax system, dismissed?
—Yes. They were either dismissed or they resigned. I do not know the status, but they are all out of the Tax Office.
—Quite frankly, I think it makes quite a distinction. I would like to know which ones resigned and which ones were dismissed.

—I will check on that. Sometimes people resign. It is very hard to dismiss people after they have resigned. If they know a dismissal is coming they may well resign. I will try to get that information.
—We still have not found the missing person, have we?
—No. I will give Senator Bishop that information as soon as I receive it.

—While we are talking about dismissals and resignations, do I understand that Senator McMullan is telling me that the legal position is that the Government is not obliged to dismiss anyone? I understand that. Does the Department have the power to dismiss people for theft and manipulation of the tax system and so on?
—Yes.
—Therefore the two people who were convicted of theft who are still in the employ of the Tax Office must be there because the Tax Office has chosen not to dismiss them? Is that correct?

—Action is still pending on one of them, as I have said on a couple of occasions, so we cannot conclude whether that person will be dismissed as a consequence of the theft or not. The person against whom a conviction has been obtained but who is still in the Public Service was transferred after a review by the Tax Office, as I understand it.

—I am sorry, but I do not and cannot accept the fact that, once the court has made a determination and there is a conviction, that is the end of the matter. It is not a question of disciplinary action being part of the process. If the Australian Taxation Office makes a decision not to dismiss a thief and thinks it is proper to have him within the Tax Office, the Australian people might disagree. However, we will pursue that in another arena.

PARA.TAB: I wish to move on to the question of the prosecution of Mr Smiles and the way in which the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the then Treasurer, has been treated by the Tax Office. When we are making an analysis of the way in which the Tax Office has treated Mr Smiles, we have only one instance on the record of how the Labor Party is treated to compare it with, and that is in relation to Mr Keating. I will get the letter in a little while so that it can be included in Hansard. I reread the letter because it was not just one tax return which was outstanding; it was two tax returns. When I asked how many ordinary Australians were prosecuted for failure to lodge their tax returns in the last year, I got an answer that the number was in the vicinity of 10,800 people. In other words, 10,800 people who had no clout were prosecuted, but one person, who happened to be the Minister in charge of the Australian Taxation Office, got special treatment; there was no prosecution. In a moment I will ask about the nature of the penalty that most of those 10,800 people would have attracted.

Then I have to compare this treatment with the treatment of Mr Smiles. The dispute involves the question of apportionment; that is, an expense was incurred by way of employee wages and the taxpayer made a decision about what part of the wages was paid as assessable income and what part of the wages was designed for personal use. That is the sort of dispute that hundreds of Australians have with the Tax Office every year. I asked, in cases where the Tax Office chose to prosecute, how many prosecutions had in fact been brought under the Crimes Act as distinct from the Taxation Administration Act. I received an answer from the Minister. The answer is none.

Then I took a look at the decision handed down in the Federal Court the other day concerning Mr Smiles's application regarding this prosecution. I read the headlines in the newspaper. When I read the judgment itself—and I might go upstairs and get that as well in a moment—I see that the judge said that the policy that the Tax Office has adopted of prosecuting so-called high profile people is not a fair or reasonable policy in the way it has been constructed.

I then received a phone call about another question I asked concerning the report in the Sydney Morning Herald which said that 12 members of parliament in the Legislative Assembly of New South Wales had been investigated by the Tax Office. Two adjustments were made, from memory. I received an answer back from the Minister as to whether or not that was true. If it was true, I wanted to know how the Sydney Morning Herald knew about it. This is again the leaking Tax Office. The answer that the Minister gave me—and which is in this pile of papers somewhere—was that it was not 12 members of parliament; I was not quite accurate. It could have been 10, 11 or 15. Of course, when I ask for the figures, the Minister pleads section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and cannot give us any information.

Clearly, this phone call told me the other day that I was on the right track and that in fact I should ask the Minister to tell me the highest and lowest adjustments that were made following the investigations concerning members of the Legislative Assembly, and what the average was. I think the Minister can give me that information without breaching section 16 of the Tax Act. I ask the Minister to ask the officers to supply me with the highest adjustment made to somebody investigated, the lowest adjustment made and what the average was.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know anything about the matter which the honourable senator raises and the officers do not have any information. I will take the question on notice and see what we can do.

—I thank the Minister. I have a further question relating to Mr Smiles. Can the Minister advise me as to whether or not further investigation has taken place on the report that was never read, and whether or not the Department has gone back to the Federal Police to ascertain what action has been taken to find the leaker in the Australian Taxation Office concerning the affairs of Mr Smiles.

—There has been a lot of interchange between the Tax Office and the Australian Federal Police with regard to this matter. In particular, on 21 May the ATO internal investigation section staff met with the AFP with regard to this matter. Although this is not directly an ATO matter, I am advised that the AFP has visited the DPP office a couple of times with regard to this matter.

—I do not accept that it is not a matter for the ATO. It is. It is still responsible for the leak. It is responsible for finding that leak because the information emanated from the Tax Office. The ATO cannot say, `It is not our problem. We did not do it.'. It is obliged to continue the investigation.

PARA.TAB: The operations of the Perth office are, quite frankly, a scandal, and I will have the opportunity to deal with that in another place. I will further pursue the matter of how this report that was initially never read is being dealt with by the Tax Office and just how far negotiations have gone with the Federal Police and what advices may be available. I will ask those questions when I have another opportunity in a different inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, in view of the fact that the Opposition did not want this to proceed past midnight, and indeed it is within 30 seconds of that at this stage, I do not know whether the Parliamentary Secretary intends to move that the Senate do now adjourn.
—No, I do not.
—If not, I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
Question put.

ROW.ENTRY: Short, J. R. Devereux, J. R.
(Senator Beahan did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen.)

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the running sheet we are now down to program 7—Industry Commission. Are there any further matters in relation to the Department of the Treasury?

—I note that the Industry Commission is the vehicle to which inquiries are referred where there is to be a change in tariffs. Although we note that the nature of the work has changed from time to time since it was the Industries Assistance Commission, nonetheless it is still the convention if there is to be a change in tariff that there can be an inquiry by the Industry Commission. I wonder whether Senator McMullan could inquire of his officers—who seem to have deserted us—whether there has been any inquiry of, or any consultation with, the Industry Commission concerning the proposed imposition of a $12,000 tariff on the importation of second-hand vehicles into Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bishop correctly notes, there is no officer present to advise me on that, but my understanding is that there has not been.
—Would the Parliamentary Secretary advise the Senate why there has been no inquiry?

—That has nothing to do with the reservation that is before us. It is a policy matter. I will refer it to the responsible Minister to see whether he will provide an answer. I do not think it is an Estimates

SPEECH.PARA: matter and I do not think it has anything to do with the reservation before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be pleased if the Parliamentary Secretary would refer it to the Minister concerned. It is not a reservation I am referring to; it is part of the report.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to program 7? If not, we will not put the motion in relation to Estimates Committee B because there is one matter outstanding.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That consideration of the report of Estimates Committee C be postponed until after consideration of the reports of Estimates Committees D, E and F.

INTERJECT.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of Administrative Services. We will proceed according to the running sheet, which mentions non-portfolio specific issues on page 2 of the report.

—I refer to item 8 on page 2 of the report wherein the Committee noted with concern the differences of approach adopted by Ministers in attendance at Estimates committee hearings. On this occasion one Minister refused to accept any questions not directly and obviously relevant to the Additional Estimates. I am referring to the Minister on duty, Senator Bolkus, who would not even permit questions to be asked in respect to an audit report on the Department.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that the Estimates Committee D hearing is best forgotten. The Minister decided to take a very narrow interpretation of the scope of the hearing and limited discussion to actual Additional Estimates. He allowed no peripheral discussion whatsoever, notwithstanding the fact that officers of the relevant departments were ready and willing to provide the information. He even refused to take questions on notice and instead suggested that they be put on notice in the Senate. The practical effect was that issues that had arisen between Budget Estimates and Additional Estimates and which would have been of interest to the Committee and the Australian public were gagged.

Earlier in the Estimates hearing the Committee adjourned to seek advice from the Clerk. Fortunately, the Deputy Clerk was at the hearing. From recollection, the advice given was that the guidelines did allow some latitude. It was pointed out, and agreed by the Chairman of Estimates Committee D, that this particular Committee had an excellent record and did not engage in frivolous time-wasting questions. The Minister, however, had made up his mind: there would be no questioning of any consequence whatsoever. As I mentioned earlier, he would not even permit questions on the Auditor-General's report on the Department.

I will give another example. A perfectly legitimate line of questioning of the Australian Property Group, which was of an information seeking nature, was effectively stopped. In fact, a question on the terms of the leasing arrangements used by the Australian Property Group was again gagged, this time because the Minister did not wish the Committee to pursue arrangements concerning the leasing of ALP property to a major government department.

My colleague Senator Bishop pursued this issue in regard to the Auditor-General in the recent Estimates Committee hearings. However, I say quite properly that it really fits within Estimates Committee D, because the Australian Property Group negotiated that transaction. I intend to attempt to pursue that matter further. I have to say, out of a sense of propriety, that this exercise should never have been pursued in the first place. I will return to that point later. The hypocrisy of this whole approach to Estimates was breathtaking. I think the issue I referred to in regard to property will be clarified before the Appropriations debate is concluded this evening.

In the past seven years I have served on Estimates committees with a range of Ministers, from Senator Walsh to Senator Ray, and I have never complained before. What Senator Bolkus did at the recent Committee hearings was not only a disgrace to himself; it also did untold damage to the functions and purposes of the Estimates committee system. It must have been a source of great embarrassment to other members of the Committee, who showed the lack of intestinal fortitude which has been a characteristic of this failed Government. It was the sort of display one would have expected to see in a failed totalitarian state and it was totally out of character with what is normally expected of a Minister of the Australian Government.

I was reported in Hansard as saying words to this effect and they are certainly true. Not only does this Minister wish to ban freedom of speech in the form of political advertising; he is also apparently determined to ban freedom in this Parliament. It was a very black day for the Estimates committee process and a black day for democracy in Australia.

As I have mentioned, it is not as though this particular Committee engages in frivolous or time-wasting questioning. A stopper was put on everything that was not directly related to the actual additional dollar estimates. While I appreciate the fact that the supplementary Estimates are certainly different and not as extensive—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Additional Estimates; that's what they are.

—Yes, the Additional Estimates. I understand that they are not the same as the Budget ones, but matters certainly do arise in the interim between one lot of Estimates hearings and another. It seems to me that this Parliament has every right to raise those questions on such occasions. As I have said, it was a black day for the Estimates and a black day for the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: In fact, this has been noted in the Committee report. I know that the Chairman has tried to get some clarification as to how far we can go in Additional Estimates and also in the Appropriations debate. But there is no doubt that we cannot have these extremes, with some Ministers allowing wide ranging debate and others having a complete blackout. It is the sort of thing that cannot be tolerated within the Senate Estimates committee process; if it is, we might as well forget it altogether. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling any further senators, I would like to make a comment from the Chair in relation to the matter raised by Senator Parer. I do not wish to make any comment in relation to the Minister to whom he referred. I indicate to the Committee that I feel some responsibility in respect of this matter. It would be desirable if there were consistency of approach between various Ministers.

PARA.TAB: I have, in fact, written to the President in relation to this and asked that the matter be considered by the Standing Committee on Procedure. I made a comment in relation to that a week or so ago, but not all honourable senators would have been in the chamber at the time. I indicate quite clearly to honourable senators that I concede that it is a problem. Because it is a problem, it should be addressed by the Procedure Committee. I expect that that will happen now that I have written to the President asking him to list the matter for the next Procedure Committee meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief comment on what you have said, Mr Chairman, and also to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Parer. In my experience in this Parliament, which is almost two years, from time to time we have had trouble on Estimates Committee D, largely because of what I would regard as strange interpretations by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) of the guidelines which cover the sorts of questions allowed in Additional Estimates.

PARA.TAB: It is not only a matter of consistency; I think we need a degree of common sense. All of us appreciate that in the context of the Additional Estimates, it is appropriate to apply some guidelines and rules. My experience, as I took part in a number of other Estimates committees, is that the Ministers showed, by and large, a degree of commonsense—they allowed a period in which some general matters could be raised and after a reasonable period the Committee returned to the particular matters which were listed for Additional Estimates.

I would just like to record that, in the context of Estimates Committee D, Senator Bolkus, I think for the second year in a row, chose to adopt what I regard as an unduly restrictive approach. I say `unduly' because I do not believe that any other Estimates Committee has a Minister that takes the approach that Senator Bolkus takes in this matter. I suppose that, in the context of the procedures available to us in this chamber, Senator Bolkus can act in that manner. I dare say that at some later stage—maybe not in the course of this evening but at some later stage in the progress of that Committee—Senator Bolkus's life can be made less comfortable than it may otherwise have been, if he wishes to proceed in this manner.

I wish to give notice that I think that that Committee, from my experience—and I have been on it now for two years—has worked well. It is not a committee which takes a long time to get through the business. I think the issues are well canvassed, but they are not canvassed at any tedious length. It is very poor for Senator Bolkus to repay the courtesy and cooperative spirit of that particular Committee with his behaviour. It brings no credit on the commonsense of Senator Bolkus. I wish to record that, if he wishes to act in that manner, I would find it hard to see that that Committee could act in such a cooperative manner in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Bishop, I would just like to mention that I think the point has been made, not only by this Committee but by another committee as well, that there is not a consistency of approach. I can assure Senator Kemp that there is a great deal of commonsense on the Procedure Committee, so it would be looking at the commonsense approach.

PARA.TAB: It is not my role to stifle debate, but I do not think much more would be achieved by canvassing this issue at great length. Quite honestly, I can see the Committee's problem, but I can also see Ministers' problems. Definite guidelines have never been laid down for Ministers to follow; they have more or less grown up a bit like topsy. But the matter certainly will be addressed, because not only this Committee but also another committee has referred to the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on that point, Mr Chairman. I am pleased to see it is being addressed in this way. I think it is worth making the observation that those Ministers who are good Ministers, who are not frightened of information being received by senators or of being shown up as being inadequate, have a very sensible approach to the committees in that they find that a lot of the information that can be elicited by senators' questionings is in fact very useful for them. I do not think they are unaware of the fact that they can be snowed by their own departments. I have seen Ministers, such as Senator Ray, use the Estimates process very much to their own advantage. But I do find that where we have a poor Minister—and I mean a really poor Minister—we get obfuscation and a denial of committee members' opportunity for questioning, and I can only say that this is the sort of behaviour we have seen from Senator Bolkus.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Reid) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Estimates for the Department of Administrative Services. The Committee was discussing an item under the non-portfolio specific issues, item 8.

—I draw attention to the fact that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) is sitting in the chamber. Three honourable senators on this side have complained about the arrogant approach he took in Estimates, with the total gagging of any discussion on any peripheral issue relating to his Department. Still he does not respond as to why he took an attitude that has been foreign to any Estimates committee I have been on in the seven years I have been here.

PARA.TAB: The comment made by the Committee did not apply across the board to Estimates D, because the other Ministers involved—notably, I think, Senator Collins—allowed wide-ranging debate. It may be argued that some went too far; I am not in the position of saying that. If there is any criticism, it should not be for that, it should be when total debate is gagged. Yet the Minister sits there and makes no attempt to explain himself. I think it shows the contempt he had for that Committee and, therefore, the contempt he has for this Senate and this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further matters in relation to that item, we will move to program 1, Property Services, subprogram 1.1. There is an item `Negotiations with canteen operator' on page 4 of the report.

—I refer to item 1.1, which is the Australian Property Group—part of property services. In the general part of this discussion, I pointed out my attempt to raise a perfectly legitimate matter, which was the negotiation by the Australian Property Group to lease ALP property to a major government department. The officer, Ms Argall, did partly respond to my questions, but was chopped off by the Minister. In fact, some of my colleagues said, `Surely there was something you could have done.' There was nothing we could do because we simply did not have the numbers to do it.

PARA.TAB: Earlier in the debate on one of the other Appropriation Bills, my colleague Senator Bishop pursued this matter. This was in respect of the Audit Office which is the occupant. However, it was not the Audit Office that negotiated the contract; it was the Australian Property Group. I understand that the documents themselves, part of which are supposedly commercial in confidence, were shown to the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill. I do not know whether the documents themselves were produced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet.
—Not yet.
—Do you mean have they been tabled in the Senate?
—Yes.
—No, not yet.
—But they are going to be, are they? Perhaps I should ask Senator Bolkus whether he intends to table those documents.
—What documents are we talking about, Senator Parer?

—This was a document that was referred to in an earlier Estimates committee. The document is the lease agreement that was negotiated by the Australian Property Group between the Audit Office and the ALP.
—There is more than that. There are a whole series of documents, and we are expecting them to be tabled, as decided by the Committee earlier.

—I am not quite sure who is tabling them. That matter was raised in the debate on the Department of Finance. I would have expected them to be tabled under that particular Department when we went back to it.

—The reason for this dilemma is that, whereas the Australian National Audit Office is the client, the Department of Administrative Services services that client; therefore, physical possession of many of the documents required may be the subject of negotiation by Senator McMullan to have them found and have them released from Senator Bolkus's Department. The point that Senator Parer is making that those documents could possibly be forthcoming right now is a relevant one. Perhaps we could be advised as to how that negotiation is proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Documents were requested from Senator McMullan and, through him, from the Australian National Audit Office. Steps were taken earlier this evening to present documents to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in an attempt to show to him that some parts of documents that Senator McMullan was going to present, it was felt, had to have parts excised from them because some information was commercial in confidence. That is a normal practice of this chamber and this Parliament. Senator McMullan is currently endeavouring to locate the final set of documents. I anticipate that, as he has been requested to table some documents, he will come back to the chamber with documents and also with information as to the availability for tabling of the lease and the pre-lease agreement.

PARA.TAB: Earlier today, Senator Bishop gave me some notice about questions that she would ask me in respect of my responsibility in this area and asked whether I could answer those questions. I did not respond to the discussion at the outset of this Estimates Committee's hearings because my view on the role of Additional Estimates committees is on the record and, as Senator Kemp rightly said, it has been on the record for the second year in a row. It is a view that is sustainable. It is a view that has had support from the other side of the chamber from time to time.

When we are dealing with additional estimates, then we are dealing with additional estimates; when we are dealing with appropriations, we have a full frontal approach to investigate a department's expenditure. However, when we are dealing with additional estimates, we are limited to those additional estimates. That is a sustainable position. In arguing for that, I made it clear that my position was that the terms of reference of the Committee are such that we are limited to additional estimates.
I will turn to the questions that were raised earlier today by Senator Bishop. I do so, as I say, without wanting to traverse Senator McMullan's area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus, before you do, I am certain that you would be cognisant of the fact that the information was asked of the Department of Finance under program 7, the Australian National Audit Office. I would expect that the information that was requested would be provided again under that program when we are discussing the Department of Finance. We will be able to go back to the Department of Finance by way of a motion when it is necessary. I do outline here that the matters for further consideration under the Department of Administrative Services relate to subprogram 1.1 and subprogram 3.7. I consider that it is not really appropriate for the matter that was discussed under the Department of Finance to be discussed at this stage. If you wish to proceed in some way which you think may be helpful, let us try it.

—I take your point. I agree with you that information that was sought earlier of Senator McMullan is very much the province of Estimates Committee B and Senator McMullan has that under control. However, in the earlier proceedings in this chamber some questions were essentially put on notice to be directed to me in respect of Estimates Committee D. To be consistent, I would argue that they were not before the chamber, nor were they before the Committee. However, in order to expedite proceedings and ensure that people leave this chamber satisfied that they have had information given to them on this matter, I seek your indulgence to give information which otherwise would not be required to be given to this Committee.

PARA.TAB: In doing so, I advise that I was put on notice that I would be asked whether the Commonwealth has committed itself to a lease. I am informed that on 8 April 1992 the Australian Government Solicitor contractually committed the Commonwealth to the pre-lease and lease agreements of this property. I was also notified that I would be asked what is the average term for leases in the ACT. My advice is that the lease terms vary according to the individual requirements of client departments. Most major leases provide for a minimum base term of 10 years, with two options for an additional five years each. I am further advised that in the current property market where there is a scarcity of investors, developers are now requesting lease terms of 15 years before commencing new construction programs.

I am further advised that financing demands this. In recent months a project in South Australia—the building of the Australian Taxation Office—was deferred for some time because of the insistence by financiers on a longer than 10-year term. The market is now demanding that terms of more than 10 years are entered into, and this agreement is consistent with that.

A further question was asked as to why the Barton-Parkes area was chosen for expressions of interest. I am informed that a number of agencies and departments have expressed the desire either to relocate or to find additional space in that area. APG was responding to that interest. I am informed that the total possible demand for Commonwealth leases in the Barton-Parkes area was some 30,000 square metres. That included requirements from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, the Australian National Audit Office, the Industry Commission, the Attorney-General's Department, the Public Service Commission, the Fisheries Service and the National Food Authority. The request for expressions of interest was first published on 27 October 1990. It solicited propositions ranging between 3,000 and 8,000 square metres. I will seek leave to table the relevant advertisement of the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had that.
—Has it been tabled, Senator?
—Yes.

—In that case I will not seek to table it. It could be asked why the Australian National Audit Office would choose this particular location. It is fair to say that it was its preferred location. There were a couple of reasons for that, not the least of which was the recommendation in the Public Accounts Committee report No. 296—
—We have dealt with that.

—Senator Bishop is now dealing with me and I am now dealing with her. I am giving the honourable senator a comprehensive answer. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts report number 296, entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament and dated 9 March 1989, states in the paragraph preceding the Committee's conclusion on this matter:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of the Audit Office's location is timely since the Audit Office has been compelled to move from its central office in Canberra because of structural problems in the rented building. A new location must be found. Consistent with the report's concern with strengthening the links between Parliament and the Audit Office, there is a final recommendation.
It goes on to recommend:
The Australian Audit Office plan for a new building either within the Parliamentary Triangle or on State Circle adjacent to the new Parliament House, and that the building be called Audit House.
The Parkes-Barton area was chosen as the preferred choice by the Audit Office, and that reflected the recommendation of the Public Accounts Committee.

PARA.TAB: The next question that was signalled was: what are the rental levels for the various major areas of the ACT? We have received Australian Valuation Office advice which suggests that the rentals for the various areas are as follows: for Civic, $340 per square metre per annum; for Barton—the area that was preferred—$330 per square metre per annum; for Woden, $318; for Belconnen, $270; and for Tuggeranong, $220. Rentals in Barton, of course, are forecast to show the highest long term growth rates because the supply of land in that area is limited. There is high private sector and Commonwealth demand for the location, and it is a prestigious area as well.

The next question that would have been put to me was: how does the rental for the subject building, the Lend Lease proposition on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, compare with the rest of the market? I am advised that the prime net rental is based on $280 per square metre as at 1 January 1991, escalated at a fixed percentage of 10.5 per cent till occupancy. I am further advised that outgoings have been estimated at $42 per square metre, and that this all up compares favourably with similar standard buildings in similar locations. In short, the comparable gross rental as at 1 January 1991 was $322 per square metre. I note, Mr Chairman, that the going rate for Barton was $330 per square metre per annum. So this is below the going rate.

I am also advised that, in comparing this rental with the average Barton rents, it should be noted that the Commonwealth negotiated a considerable contribution to fit-out and rent-free period due to integration of fit-out in the base building. The fit-out contribution is $400,000, and there is no rent to be paid during the construction of the fit-out. In essence, there was in fact a major saving to the Commonwealth from the fact that fit-out and no-rental levy during the construction of the fit-out are also covered by the owner of the building.I must stress this point: all agreed rentals have been based on advice from the Australian Valuation Office.

In another question placed on notice I was asked: does this lease have dispute resolution provisions? I am informed that it does. The lease agreements have specific provisions for disputes to be referred to an arbiter or ultimately to a court. I was asked: does the lease provide for increases in annual rent? Yes, it does. The rent review provisions include annual rent escalations at 9 per cent per annum, calculated from the commencement of the lease, which is occupation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine per cent?

—I am advised that 9 per cent is very much the going rate—is it not? The long term growth rate valuation forecast is 11.61 per cent. So it is well below that. I was asked: are there lease terms and conditions yet to be fulfilled? I am advised that the lease terms and conditions have been fully agreed. As a requirement of the pre-lease agreement, the building must be delivered to specifications. I was finally asked: is there a penalty for not proceeding? The advice is that if the Commonwealth does not proceed with these agreements, it would be in breach of contract and liable for damages in accordance with contract law.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of other matters that should be adduced at this particular time. Outside the chamber I was asked at what stage the Australian National Audit Office first learnt that the ALP was the backer or was behind the Lend Lease proposal. I am informed by my Department, and through it by National Audit officers, that they recall discussing the proposal at a meeting on 29 November 1990, which is some two weeks after the close of expressions of interest. The Audit Office people cannot say whether the ALP involvement was discussed or not. However, they indicated that they also do not recall learning anything about it later, although clearly they did know about it by March 1991 and did not consider it a concern.I am advised that they probably did know at the November 1990 meeting about the ALP involvement in the proposal. At all material times they were aware of it. As I say, they did not consider it a concern.

There are a couple of other things that need to be placed on the record. In terms of expressions of interest, the Liberal Party was so keen to get into this one that it beat the Labor Party by two days. There was an expression of interest on 13 November 1990 from Mr Tony Eggleton to provide the property and, as I say, on 15 November from Lend Lease on behalf of the Labor Party. I table both of those letters of expression of interest. One letter is from the Labor Party dated 15 November and the other is from the Liberal Party dated 13 November.

Some of these documents have excisions because they are commercial-in-confidence, but they have been discussed with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. As to further documents, I do have copies of letters dated 7 December from Mr Robert Ireland, project manager, to the 14 proponents of properties, in response to the calling for expressions of interest. I table those documents. On 11 January 1991, minimum standards documents were forwarded to the 14 proponents, and I table those documents. On 21 January 1991, revised minimum standards were forwarded to the 14 proponents. I table the letter together with the list of those to whom it was distributed.
