The closing date for minimum standards was 1 February 1991.

Invitations were sent out to meet with proponents on 25 March 1991. I table a copy of the invitation sent to Mr Tony Eggleton of the Liberal Party. Unfortunately, he did not front for the meeting. I have a timetable here of the times organised to meet with developers, and I table that. I also table the list of those to whom the timetable was sent. I table the Australian Property Group brief to ANAO dated 21 November 1990, with excisions for reasons of commercial confidentiality.

I table a letter of 29 November 1990 from the Australian National Audit Office making it very clear that in a meeting of 29 November the proposal for the site opposite the National Press Club had been discussed, and that it was the preference. I also table a letter of 4 March from the Deputy Auditor-General confirming that it was very much the preference of the Audit Office to be located at that particular site.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is happening is highly out of order because we are looking at the Department of Administrative Services and the reservations do not cover anything like what we are doing at the moment. But I will allow it to proceed within reason because I think it may save us time when we go back to program 7 in the Department of Finance. I hope honourable senators realise that we are highly out of order and it pains me to have to say that.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Brownhill) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian public should be aware that at least 24 senior public servants are hanging around in the foyer of this establishment waiting for Godot. They are not getting the call at any stage. They are waiting to come into this chamber. It may be that honourable senators want to behave in this way with the collusion of the Democrats, who I thought would have had more sense. It is now nearly 1.15 a.m. I do not know how long this charade will continue, but it is not conducive to good decision making or to the stability of this chamber. We owe it to the public servants outside, who are expected to continue their work today, whereas we are not sitting when this chamber rises.
—The question before the Chair is that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

—Mr Chairman, I want to support what Senator Herron said as he walked out of the chamber. The confusion you found yourself in supported the point he made. TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday night this week, in the adjournment debate, I raised some concerns I had about Australia Post's new charges. I made the point that country people are used to not having a full range and speed of services that their city counterparts enjoy. They are used to paying more for food, petrol and telephone. They are used to not having convenience stores and, in many cases, daily newspapers. I made the point then that most newspapers and magazines were bought and received on a mail subscription basis.

PARA.TAB: The cause for complaint was that magazines were now to cost more money. Magazines that cost 46c in 1990 would now cost 87c to metropolitan areas, 99c to country areas and $1.52 to interstate country areas. In other words, over an 18-month period the cost of mailing a magazine to country people had risen by 223.5 per cent. At a time when Australia Post is making annual profits of around $144m, I regard that as appalling, given that it is a monopoly service.

Since that speech, I have been contacted by proprietors of country newspapers who have told me a quite alarming story. They, too, have been caught by these new charges but they have had even further restrictions placed on them by Australia Post. It may be the end for some country papers. Declining sales and reduced advertising, caused by fewer rural businesses being able to afford to advertise, mean that their viability is very marginal. Now they have been told they are all to be a part of Print Post. Australia Post bills it as the new service for registered publications which will have significant advantages and revenue opportunities for publishers. Frankly, I cannot see any advantages at all.

Australia Post claims that the new system has been introduced because the former registered post arrangements were losing millions every year. What it means for newspapers is, firstly, that the outrageous hike in prices that I outlined for magazines will also apply to newspapers that are mailed to subscribers. A paper that was selling at a price of 60c and a postage of 45c has been costing $1.05 an issue. With the new charges, the same paper will now cost a minimum of $1.69.

That is just the start of the additional cost because, under this Print Post system, newspapers can no longer be rolled for mailing as is the usual practice. The new arrangements will require newspapers to be flat folded and wrapped in plastic to a larger letter size of 360mm x 260mm x 20mm. This raises a number of difficulties. Firstly, the cost of plastic wraps will be far higher than the present paper strip band, the cost of machinery will be outside the budget of many country newspapers and even if machinery is not used, it will be a far slower and, therefore, more labour-intensive arrangement than the present system.

Secondly, there are obvious environmental problems with plastic wrappers. At a time when each person in Australia produces an average of one tonne of rubbish every year, we ought to be encouraging less disposable rubbish, not more. Thirdly, the flat package restrictions will mean that some newspapers like The Land newspaper will not always be able to meet the 20mm thickness criteria. Depending on supplements or bulky additions, they will simply be too thick to fold and too fat to post flat. I am also advised that postal workers hate these plastic wrappings because the packages tend to stick together, unlike the rolled newspapers which are easy to handle and to sort into bundles.

Probably the most insidious part of all of this, however, is that Australia Post has already issued a brochure telling newspaper owners about the new arrangements. It is only from the fine print, however, that one realises that these new rules will not come into effect until 1 July 1993. That means there is still time for newspaper owners to object and protest. I urge every country newspaper from Tweed Heads to Tumbarumba in my State to get on the phone to Australia Post, write to Senator Collins and complain to their local member of Parliament. The other way they can protest is to make a submission to the Industry Commission's Mail Inquiry at PO Box 80, Belconnen, 2616.

I believe it is important that all newspaper owners object, and object strongly to this. It is an outrage, at a time when inflation is almost at zero and country people have been pushed to the brink of bankruptcy, that Australia Post tries to impose this. It has been done in a most underhand way and ought not to be tolerated. It may well be that the present category system for registered post is ineffective and uneconomic, but it is not the genuine regular newspaper that is causing the inefficiencies. The answer must surely be not to hit the country papers but, rather, review the method by which publications get special postage concessions. If that were tightened up, the present system, which is frankly expensive enough, could be retained. As I have said, country newspapers ought to seriously look at these new charges. If it is going to adversely affect them, they must speak up before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to note that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia was tabled on 23 August 1990. Nearly two years later, the Government has announced a response. Without commenting on that response, I draw the Senate's attention to recommendation 39 on aerial spraying. The Committee recommended the development of a uniform national approach to the regulation of aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals. The Government said in its response that it agrees.

PARA.TAB: I have already alluded to an increasing number of complaints with regard to aerial spraying. The Committee heard some of those complaints. These complaints come from a number of sources. The obvious ones are neighbouring farms, houses, schools, businesses and people using affected common waterways. Tonight I draw attention to a group of people who are less obvious complainants and who currently face considerable difficulties having their cases dealt with. These people are simply road users.

No doubt honourable senators will be aware that farmers plant their crops right up to the boundaries along roads. At first that seems practical, but it makes the aerial spraying a very tricky business indeed. If we add to this the placement of electricity lines, commonly in the same direction as roads, we see straightaway that it takes some considerable aerial manoeuvring, even when using helicopters, to achieve a maximum cover of the crop. It could be said that it becomes impossible not to over spray the road.

I have a video in my office, taken on 6 March this year, which shows this problem very clearly. In that video we see that time and time again a pilot over sprays a road which has passing traffic. Cars and trucks are one thing, but three hours after the pilot has passed the road and the spraying is finished, a school bus comes along. It stops on the edge of the road, which is the usual place for a bus to stop, and lets out the children. They walk along the grass and then cross the road. Some days they leave their bikes there, pick them up and ride home—the bikes having been sprayed, apparently.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy was called to this case and samples were taken from the roadside. These have proven positive for chemicals, but no-one will divulge which chemicals are involved. As it was potatoes that were being sprayed at the time, it seems most likely that they were being sprayed with Dithane, a member of the Mancozeb family, commonly used in this area for these purposes. On such crops, spraying usually takes place every seven to 10 days. The children who picked up these chemical residues in this case could be doing so quite frequently.

As a result of this complaint to the Department, the only possible action that could be taken was to fine the pilot for over spraying the road. That could only be initiated by the owner of the road—another government department—and we are told it is being considered by the Public Prosecutor. The people affected, because they were on a road and not on private property, appear to have no avenue for action themselves. Even if they had been in the right place, officialdom moves painfully slowly, leaving people to suffer repeated incidences of chemical exposure.

This was by no means an isolated incident. I have more reports of over sprays of roads used by school buses. There are other incidents in which cars stopped on the side of the road were directly over sprayed, as were some people having picnics in the area. All of these events occurred in the north of Tasmania this year. I have no doubt it is only the tip of the iceberg, as many incidents go unreported due to the public's lack of faith in being able to actually get something done about this problem with our attitude and our usage of chemicals.
It will take more than the Government's friendly words to overcome this disenchantment that people have with the lack of getting

SPEECH.PARA: something done. What the people are really waiting for is action rather than words contained in a response almost two years after the date of the agricultural and veterinary chemicals report, which was tabled on 23 August 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 21 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a question without notice (Senate Hansard, 6 April 1989, p.1070), regarding the mercury contamination risk from a Japanese submarine which was sunk during World War II in Darwin waters, what has happened about this most serious matter particularly, in relation to the undertaking given in the answer that whatever was necessary to protect the environment, including the removal of any mercury, would be done quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: There is no indication that there is any risk of mercury contamination of the environment from the Japanese submarine I-124 which was sunk off Darwin in 1942.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade obtained historical evidence from the appropriate authorities in Japan, the Federal Republic of Germany and the United States of America in 1989 and 1990. An exhaustive examination of this and other evidence by a professional maritime archaeologist led to the following conclusions in January 1991:
(a) The I-124 was not equipped with a mercury trim or ballast system, nor was it carrying a cargo of mercury.
(b) No submarine in the Imperial Japanese navy was equipped with a mercury trim or ballast system.
(c) The German design on which the I-124 was closely based did not provide for a mercury trim or ballast system.
(d) The only possible source of mercury contamination from the I-124 is from mercury contained in navigational instruments and this would be negligible.
Copies of the report, The Flamingo Bay Voyage by Mr Mike McCarthy, are held in a number of public libraries.

In addition, the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries analysed fish caught at the wreck site in 1989 and found there was no evidence of mercury contamination from the wreck. Mercury levels were within the normal range.

Finally, as the Australian Government respects the submarine as a Japanese war grave, no internal examination of the wreck has been undertaken. However an external examination of the hull in March and April 1989 indicated that it was then in sound condition.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department monitor the consequences of the Chernobyl disaster, which occurred six years ago on 29 April, specifically reports such as those which advise that in some areas near Orel and Bryansk near the border of Russia and Byelorussia, ground contamination is close to 50-100Bq/Km(2).
(2) Are these reports correct.
(3) In what way does the department interact with the Chernobyl cleanup and relief effort.

(4) Is the Minister aware of a statement by the Movement Against Uranium Mining and Friends of the Earth that because of the growing radio-ecological catastrophe unfolding in the CIS, and the diminishing market prospects for uranium because of worldwide opposition to nuclear power, Australia should withdraw from all aspects of the nuclear fuel cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1 & 2) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy and other relevant Commonwealth departments and agencies, principally the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, receive reports on the consequences of the Chernobyl nuclear accident. The most comprehensive report received to date has been "The International Chernobyl Project" report in 1991 on the radiological consequences of the Chernobyl accident outside the immediate vicinity (the 30 Km "exclusion zone") of the reactor site.

This report noted that in areas such as Orel and Bryansk, ground contamination was recorded at levels which prompted the then Soviet authorities to relocate some of the people living there. These levels were in the vicinity of 40 Curies per square kilometre (approximately 1500 kilobecquerels per square metre). The International Chernobyl Project team concluded that some protective measures taken at the time, including the relocations in those areas, generally exceeded what would have been strictly necessary from a radiological protection viewpoint.

Although the Chernobyl accident has had significant human and economic consequences, particularly inside the exclusion zone, the extent of its effects has often been clouded by lack of sound evidence or misinformation. The particular report referred to above, however, has been acknowledged as one of the most reliable. It was prepared by an international advisory committee responsible for the work of the Project team comprising some two hundred scientists from twenty five countries and various international bodies, including the World Health Organisation. It concluded that, at the time of the project study, there were significant health disorders in the communities surveyed that were unrelated to radiation, but no health disorders that could be attributed directly to radiation exposure. It further assessed that it would be difficult to discern any future increase over the natural incidence of cancers or hereditary effects, even with large and well designed long term epidemiological studies. The report also stated that reported absorbed thyroid dose estimates in children were such that there may be a statistically detectable increase in the incidence of thyroid tumours in the future.
Departments will continue to monitor reports and assessments on the consequences of Chernobyl.

(3) Australia has participated constructively in various post-Chernobyl activities, principally through its contributions to and participation in the work of international agencies such as the World Health Organisation, as well as the International Atomic Energy Agency and the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency. Australia's contributions have been most notable in the fields of nuclear safety, in the negotiation of conventions that have been concluded on early notification of a nuclear accident and on assistance in the case of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency, and in current discussions on issues of nuclear liability.

(4) I am aware of statements of this nature. The present level of demand for uranium is being affected to some extent by concerns about nuclear power but also by other factors affecting the supply/demand dynamics of the industry. Nuclear generating capacity worldwide is expected to show modest growth over the coming decade. Nuclear power remains an important source of energy, in the form of electricity, for several of our major trading partners. Australia will continue to be a reliable, competitive supplier of uranium to those countries, under our stringent nuclear safeguards and non-proliferation conditions.
In relation to other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle, Australia is making a valuable contribution towards the safe disposal of nuclear waste through the development of the SYNROC process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 6 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent kit regarding the newly introduced travel health telephone service for doctors, how much did it cost to prepare the information kit and container, and why was it necessary to present the three pages, a brochure and one sticker in a glossy box.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The cost of preparing 500 media and information kits was $5,330.80. The Department used surplus stock of boxes to contain the information kit. These boxes had previously been prepared for the AIDS Travel Safe Campaign.
